fields.headline: Dutch police braced for Chelsea
fields.standfirst: Security operation tonight is test run for Euro 2000
fields.trailText: Dutch police have said that the security operation for tonight's Champions League match between Feyenoord and Chelsea will be treated as a practice run for the European championship.
fields.body:
Dutch police have said that the security operation for tonight's Champions League match between Feyenoord and Chelsea will be treated as a practice run for their plans to prevent hooliganism during this summer's European championship.

With the Euro 2000 final taking place in Rotterdam, along with group matches, the police are keen to show the tournament organisers their ability to deal with potentially volatile matches.

Tonight's Group D tie is seen as such a match. Both teams have notorious hooligan followings and Feyenoord, who have one of the most organised gangs in the Netherlands, have a long history of clashing with English clubs. Chelsea fans were involved in incidents a fortnight ago in Marseille's stadium, where police used tear gas and batons.

In recent years Feyenoord hooligans have caused serious trouble at Dutch league games and clashed with police. The club have urged their fans not to travel to away matches during this Champions League campaign, fearing that some might cause trouble. Feyenoord also refuse to take tickets for away games.

Officially about 1,600 Chelsea fans have bought tickets for tonight's match but Dutch police fear hundreds more may travel without tickets, given the proximity of Rotterdam. Most supporters are expected to travel to the Hook of Holland by ferry.

Chelsea fans have been warned that anyone coming off the ferry drunk will be turned away immediately, as will any fans drunk before the game.

About 500 police officers will be on duty at ferry terminals, Rotterdam city centre and in and around the ground. This is double the number usually used for Feyenoord games but may be the number employed during Euro 2000.

Hans Stoop, a Rotterdam police spokesman, said: "We are very concerned and aware that the two sides might use this occasion to create trouble. But we are very anxious about mounting an effective police operation. The Euro 2000 final is in Rotterdam and the eyes of the world will be upon us. We will be able to use tonight's match as good practice for the championships."

Dutch police have also received information from the hooligan unit of the National Criminal Intelligence Service about known troublemakers who may be intending to travel to Rotterdam.

Privately the police are confident of being able to control the Chelsea fans, given that there will not be many and the majority will arrive by ferry, making it easier to track them.

What they fear is an organised attack from the Feyenoord hooligans, who have arranged recent clashes using the internet. Feyenoord hooligans are divided into two groups: one aged 25 and above, and one for youngsters. Some estimates put their total number at 800-1,000.

With the Euro 2000 finals three months away and thousands of foreign fans expected, particularly English and German, police fear Feyenoord hooligans may use the tournament to create trouble.

Stoop added: "We have become very organised in tracking our hooligans and know who most of them are. We are asking our politicians to do something about our law to give us more powers to make arrests before problems arise."

Chelsea will submit a 52-page report to Uefa on Thursday when they answer a disciplinary charge over the trouble involving their fans at the game in Marseille. The report will point out that missiles were thrown into the away section by home fans, and will claim that stewards were confrontational and that riot police overreacted.

 About 800 German hooligans plan to march through Berlin on March 25 in protest at their exclusion from the Euro 2000 finals in the Netherlands and Belgium. Their government is restricting the travel of known troublemakers.

fields.headline: Vialli turns down £22m Dutch auction
fields.trailText: Gianluca Vialli used Chelsea's arrival in the Netherlands yesterday to play down persistent reports that the club are on the verge of agreeing a deal for PSV Eindhoven's £22m-rated striker Ruud van Nistelrooy.
fields.body:
Gianluca Vialli used Chelsea's arrival in the Netherlands yesterday to play down persistent reports that the club are on the verge of agreeing a deal for PSV Eindhoven's £22m-rated striker Ruud van Nistelrooy.

"The asking price at the moment is out of our league," said the manager. Which begs the question: what league do Chelsea want to be in?

Recent struggles against Marseille have only underlined the view of Feyenoord's well-versed coach Leo Beenhakker. "For me, Chelsea are missing something," he said. "There is a gap between Chelsea and teams like Lazio, Barcelona and Bayern Munich."

And one area of deficiency is up front. Chris Sutton, Tore Andre Flo and Gianfranco Zola have not scored in the Premiership since January 4. And a sharper attack in the Champions League would have eased Chelsea's path to the quarter-finals.

Instead they are sweating on winning here tonight or, failing that, beating Lazio at home in a fortnight to qualify. Two draws might also be enough.

With a predator such as Van Nistelrooy in the side all that nail-biting might have been prevented and Chelsea's chances of winning this tournament improved. But Vialli remains unconvinced. "Prices are going crazy. We are looking for good players but they have to be affordable."

Presumably players such as Sutton, who cost a mere £10m but cannot score. Surely for Chelsea to reach a higher plane they must pay the going rate for players who can deliver the goods.

What Chelsea need tonight is the tactical discipline and concentration that earned draws at Milan and Lazio, otherwise Ed de Goey will be in for a busy return to his former club.

For this is not the same Feyenoord crushed 3-1 at Stamford Bridge in November. Then the Dutch were undone by player disagreements and Beenhakker's romantic notion of fielding four strikers.

A 4-4-2 pragmatism has since tightened up Feyenoord's play, securing them four points out of six against Lazio. The Dutch also need victory tonight to go through. It should make for an exciting game.

Chelsea (probable, 4-4-2): De Goey; Ferrer, Desailly, Leboeuf, Babayaro; Petrescu, Wise, Deschamps, Poyet; Zola, Flo.

Feyenoord (probable, 4-4-2): Dudek; Van Gobbel, Konterman, Van Wonderen, Rzasa; Bosvelt, Van Gastel, Paauwe, De Visser or Thomasson; Kalou, Cruz.

webTitle: Rioch flies away from struggling Norwich

fields.headline: Rioch flies away from struggling Norwich
fields.trailText: Bruce Rioch has resigned as manager of Norwich City, citing frustration at the lack of resources. Fittingly, at a club where Delia Smith is the majority shareholder, things have been cooking a while.
fields.body:
Bruce Rioch has resigned as manager of Norwich City, citing frustration at the lack of resources. Fittingly, at a club where Delia Smith is the majority shareholder, things have been cooking a while.

"I am ambitious as a manager but right now the club don't have the resources to match those ambitions," he said. "That is the only reason I took the decision to leave.

"There was not one final thing, just an accumulation of issues. Things finally came to a head and in the end it was an easy decision to make, although it is certainly not one I have taken lightly."

Rioch, who arrived at Carrow Road in June 1998, had 16 months left on his contract. Ninth place last year fuelled expectations of a return to the Premiership but this season Norwich are 15th in the First Division, with one win from 11 matches.

Rioch said he was under no pressure from the board to leave and first approached the directors with a view to quitting last Wednesday. Further talks were held after Saturday's home defeat by Crystal Palace and the board agreed to terminate his contract.

The director of football Bryan Hamilton has been appointed caretaker until the end of the season. The former Northern Ireland manager begins at the deep end with a derby at Ipswich on Sunday.

"I'm extremely disappointed and very surprised," Smith said of Rioch's departure. "It's very hard for us because we'd hoped we'd got it right but discovered that we hadn't."

Rioch has had little money to spend despite selling Darren Eadie to Leicester for £3m. Long-term injuries to Craig Bellamy and Phil Mulryne have also hampered his attempt to restore the top-flight status Norwich lost in 1995.

The former Arsenal and Bolton manager said he was keen to get back into football as quickly as possible, though he stressed: "There's nothing lined up."

Nicolas Anelka will be heavily fined by Real Madrid for missing three days' training. The former Arsenal striker ended his boycott yesterday but trained on his own in the afternoon.

"He will be fined," said Real's vice-president Juan Onieva. "It will be a tough sentence. The only thing now to decide is how much." Speculation in Spain suggested the fine would be about £412,000, a quarter of Anelka's salary.

He was due at an emergency meeting of the club's directors last night. The £23m summer signing had skipped training since Friday, saying the tactics adopted by the coach Vicente del Bosque did not suit him and that he was being treated with a lack of respect.

Real's president Lorenzo Sanz warned he would not put up with further indiscipline from Anelka but insisted the Frenchman would not be sold.

Anelka's magnanimous decision to put himself once again "at the disposition of the players and the coach" is believed to have come after talks with his team-mate and compatriot Christian Karembeu.

Anelka's former team-mate Nwankwo Kanu will sign a new contract at Arsenal this week, believed to worth about £25,000 a week.

Third Division Swansea City have announced plans to float on the stock market. "We have been struggling financially and hope that by floating the club we will make it financially viable," said the general manager Mike Lewis. Swansea will invest most of the money in long-term development, including their new stadium. Some will be made available for players.

 The Scottish Cup semi- finals will be played at Hampden Park on the same weekend next month. Ayr meet Rangers on April 8 and Hibernian take on Aberdeen the following day.

fields.headline: Feyenoord 1 - 3 Chelsea
fields.trailText: Feyenoord: Dudek, Rzasa, Van Wonderen, Konterman, Van Gobbel, De Visser, Paauwe, Van Gastel, Bosvelt, Tomasson, Cruz. Subs: Graafland, Gyan, Kalou, Samardzic, Van Vossen, Korneev, De Haan.
fields.body:
Feyenoord: Dudek, Rzasa, Van Wonderen, Konterman, Van Gobbel, De Visser, Paauwe, Van Gastel, Bosvelt, Tomasson, Cruz. Subs: Graafland, Gyan, Kalou, Samardzic, Van Vossen, Korneev, De Haan.

Chelsea: De Goey, Babayaro, Desailly, Leboeuf, Petrescu, Poyet, Wise, Deschamps, Di Matteo, Zola, Flo. Subs: Cudicini, Hogh, Sutton, Ambrosetti, Morris, Thome, Harley.

Referee: Knut-Erik Fisker (Denmark)

Heavy rain has made for less than ideal conditions as Chelsea seek the win that would give them a quarter-final place. Chelsea manager Gianluca Vialli has recalled Didier Deschamps and Marcel Desailly after resting them at the weekend. Albert Ferrer is ruled out with a bad back.

1 Chelsea kick off and immediately hoof upfield for a goal-kick. Gentle stuff to start as the teams size each other up.
3 Feyenoord get the ball up on the back of a long kick by 'keeper Dudek; Thomasson holds up well in midfield before spraying it wide for Bosvelt on the right. He cuts inside but Chelsea stifle the move on the edge of the area.
6 Chelsea come close as Zola and Poyet combine in a one-two; Zola feeds Poyet on the corner of the penalty area then picks up the return to shoots and force a save from Dudek.
7 Chelsea follow up with a long-range strike from Flo - easy for Dudek.
9 Penalty to Chelsea Uproar as Van Wonderen brings down Flo when the Norwegian cuts in from the right. Leboeuf takes the spot kick but Dudek makes the save - uproar again but for the opposite reason.
13 Leboeuf, perhaps frustrated at his miss from 12 yards, has a pop from all of 45 yards. He doesn't sky it but he doesn't score either. The crowd seem muted as the game hits a momentary lull.
16 Wise gains possession just outside the Feyenoord area and passes for the advancing Flo to win a corner. Wise takes with Flo as the target but Dudek, after such an inpressive start, makes a complete hash of the save. He punches the ball straight up in the area and after a bout of head tennis is relieved to see Desailly head behind for a goal-kick
21 Chelsea exposed at the back as Babayaro makes a mess of clearing a hopeful long ball by Feyenoord but Leboeuf saves the day from the advancing Van Gobbel.
22 Feyenoord beginning to move the ball around well and create space.
23 Feyenoord work the ball up to Thomasson who again holds up well for Bosvelt to deliver a deep cross that Van Gastel is just unable to reach.
28 A mistake by Cruz in the Feyenoord half opens things up for Chelsea. Flo picks up the ball and feeds Petrescu on the right. He then cuts inside and passes to Zola on the edge of the area but the Italian cannot make his shot count. Wise takes the resulting corner, Dudek stays put this time as Poyet gets in a lame header from six-yards out. Rzasa, on the line, heads clear.
30 Wise has crack from 30 yards out and forces Dudek to tip it over for a corner. Comes to nothing. Chelsea now looking equal to the task and willing to have a go at every opportunity. This has stunned the crowd into near silence.
33 After a brief spell of smart moves and a desire to get the ball out of their own half, Feyenoord now look happy to sit back and see what Chelsea are going to do next. Continue to play high up the field probably.
39 Goal Feyenoord 0 - 1 Chelsea A deep ball from Wise on the half-way line is headed on for Zola to turn and shoot from just outside the penalty area. Top strike to give Chelsea a deserved lead.
43 Zola now has his tail up as Chelsea seek to capitalise on their lead. Leboeuf feeds Zola who swiftly finds Poyet advancing on the six-yard box but Van Gobbel runs him out before he can get in a clean shot.
45 Brief worry for Chelsea as the half comes to a close. Feyenoord win a free kick to the right of the Chelsea area; comes to nothing as Feyonoord continue to display the chronic lack of ideas that has characterised their first half. Half-time with Chelsea in control.

46 Substitution Kalou on for Paauwe. Here we again. Feyenoord resume with a lot of running and look more capable of getting a result than when they went off.
48 A fine angled cross from Bosvelt finds Cruz on the edge of the Chelsea area and his sweet strike clears the bar by only a foot.
48 Chelsea win a corner, Wise takes but Konterman puts it behind for another corner. Wise takes again and plays it short to Zola before picking up the return and crossing towards Desailly on the edge of the six-yard box. Dudek gets up but drops the catch before smothering the chance.
54 Chelsea appear to have lost some of their momentum as Feyenoordturn their tactics to building from the back.
55 Feyenoord win a free-kick 45 yards out after Desailly fouls Kalou. Van Gastel has a pop and sends the ball into the crowd.
58 A little passion has made all the difference to Feyenoord's game and Chelsea's lead is now looking fragile.
59 Goal Feyenoord 1 - 1 Chelsea Chelsea stretched at the back as a whipped-in cross is palmed fractionally clear by De Goey and into the path of Kalou who manages to back-heel the ball into the net.
60 Deschamp unleashes a shot from 30 yards out and forces Dudek to make a flying save.
64 Goal Feyenoord 1 - 2 Chelsea
Terrific move by Chelsea. Zola releases Babayaro down the left who races on towards the line to deliver a great cross for little big man Wise to get up and restore Chelsea's lead.
68 All to play for now as Chelsea step up a gear.
69 Goal Feyenoord 1 - 3 Chelsea Chelsea book themselves a spot in the quarter-finals and await confirmation. Flo gets clear on the right and cuts inside before unleashing a left-shot that beats Dudek at the far post.
74 Chelsea show no signs of letting this tie die down despite the fact that Feyenoord now look finished. Vialli's men happy to take their chances on the break from midfield, however, rather than push up.
75 Substitution Samardzic on for Visser
77 Substitution Morris on for Poyet.
80 Not too much to shout about as Chelsea play out their time in Rotterdam. Morris, Wise and Petrescu continue to spray balls out to Zola on the left and Flo on the right. Feyenoord seem more concerned about giving away another goal than reducing their deficit.
84 Zola begins to indulge himself with some smart, yet fruitless, moves around the Feyenoord defence.
85 Chelsea corner. Wise takes and aims for Flo again but Van Gobbel makes the clearance.
86 Feyenoord free-kick. Van Gastel takes from 45 yards out and rams it straight into the wall. Wise picks up possession and finds Di Matteo who then plays it deep to Zola on the edge of the area. He then lays it off for Flo to shoot high.
90 Substitution Ambrosetti on for Zola. Four minutes of extra time as the game descends into nothing more than kick-around. Fresh-feet Ambrosetti happy to run his socks off. Feyenoord nearly benefit from the somnambulant Chelsea defence when Cruz latches on to a vicious cross and shoots from just inside the area. He forces what could well be the Save Of The Match from De Goey. Full-time. Feyenoord 1 - 3 Chelsea.

Flo gets clear on the right and cuts inside before unleashing a left-shot that beats Dudek at the far post. 74 Chelsea show no signs of letting this tie die down despite the fact that Feyenoord now look finished. Vialli's men happy to take their chances on the break from midfield, however, rather than push up. 75 Substitution Samardzic on for Visser 77 Substitution Morris on for Poyet. 80 Not too much to shout about as Chelsea play out their time in Rotterdam. Morris, Wise and Petrescu continue to spray balls out to Zola on the left and Flo on the right. Feyenoord seem more concerned about giving away another goal than reducing their deficit. 84 Zola begins to indulge himself with some smart, yet fruitless, moves around the Feyenoord defence. 85 Chelsea corner. Wise takes and aims for Flo again but Van Gobbel makes the clearance. 86 Feyenoord free-kick. Van Gastel takes from 45 yards out and rams it straight into the wall. Wise picks up possession and finds Di Matteo who then plays it deep to Zola on the edge of the area. He then lays it off for Flo to shoot high. 90 Substitution Ambrosetti on for Zola. Four minutes of extra time as the game descends into nothing more than kick-around. Fresh-feet Ambrosetti happy to run his socks off. Feyenoord nearly benefit from the somnambulant Chelsea defence when Cruz latches on to a vicious cross and shoots from just inside the area. He forces what could well be the Save Of The Match from De Goey. Full-time. Feyenoord 1 - 3 Chelsea.

fields.headline: Paradise postponed
fields.standfirst:
The much-needed change and progress that devolution
                                                  brought to colleges in Northern Ireland is being
                                                  smothered by the reimposition of direct rule
fields.trailText:
Further education in Northern Ireland is entering a "revolutionary"
                                                  phase and holds one of the keys to lasting peace. So says
                                                  David Hunter, who is director of the Association of Northern
                                                  Ireland Colleges.
fields.body:
Further education in Northern Ireland is entering a "revolutionary" phase and holds one of the keys to lasting peace. So says David Hunter, who is director of the Association of Northern Ireland Colleges.

"The really strange thing was that that border was like the Berlin wall. Everything stopped at it."

Northern Ireland's 17 further education colleges were working within a very small geographic and population area, dominated by the violence. Since 1972, decisions had been made by Westminster direct rule ministers, whose interests were primarily English. There were no links with colleges in Ireland, no sharing of expertise and no access to the much more vibrant Irish economy. Protestants hesitated to seek contacts.

"Change now is down to agencies like ourselves," Hunter says.

Sadly the politicians in London and Belfast seem determined to block that revolution. The reimposition in February of direct rule from Westminster after the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, threatened to resign as First Minister, was, Dr Hunter believes, little short of tragic.

When devolution came last November the education departments were reorganised, giving responsibility for training, further education and higher education to one minister and all pre-16 education to another. Dr Sean Farren, the Social Democratic and Labour Party member to whom the higher and further portfolio fell, lectured for 25 years at the University of Ulster in Coleraine. Many decisions had been put on hold during the talks which took place between the Good Friday agreement and devolution, and were now hurried through.

Dr Farren spent his first fortnight as a minister doing the rounds of further education and training personnel, admitting his lack of knowledge.

"I recognise that people will assume that my real interest is higher education," he said, "but I recognise that further education has been the Cinderella and I want to see equality in provision and in funding."

He instituted an immediate enquiry into student funding, including fees, looking at Scottish developments and was considering giving further education students parity with higher education. That enquiry is continuing, but with no local minister to report to. He promised to encourage links between further education colleges and the Northern Ireland universities, and to promote franchising of degrees. Almost his last decision was to approve a new university campus with further education links at Springvale on the peaceline in Belfast.

The imposition of fees by the British government has raised a barrier in Ireland that Dr Hunter believes is culturally damaging. A social scientist, he taught at the Belfast Institute until he became the Association's second director a year ago.

"We taught an HND Social Care course. It was useful having people in the class who came from the other jurisdiction. It is useful to see that there is another point of view if you teach community relations. A lot of people ignore the differences, but you don't solve anything that way." Now far fewer southerners can afford to come north.

David Hunter was impressed by devolution. "I think we had a minister who wasn't from England, who had a real interest. We were seeing a greater focus. We were trying to solve our own problems. It became our responsibility not the responsibility of somebody who did not have to report back to a democratic body in Northern Ireland. What we appreciated was that he had a real commitment to social inclusion."

Dr Hunter is an adult learner himself, having worked in England, then returned to college to take A levels. His first job back in Northern Ireland was with the Shankill Initiative, a development programme to regenerate a poverty-stricken and fiercely loyalist area of Belfast. His wife, a nurse, is finishing an Open University degree. His ambition is a secure future in Northern Ireland for his children.

His son has just passed his 11-plus and his daughter is 17 and considering university.

Like so many other parents, particularly Protestants - who are witnessing a disproportionate brain drain of student children because they fear unionism has no future - he hates the thought of them going to Britain to study and never returning. The arrival of devolved government meant, he had hoped, "that my children could have normal lives here."

The further education revolution was encouraged by the IRA ceasefires, and given momentum by the 1998 Good Friday Agreement. Two years ago Northern Ireland's further education colleges were removed from the control of the Education and Libraries Board and followed the English colleges into incorporation. They combined to form the Association and instituted cross border partnerships to pool knowledge. Colleges north and south were asked to consider shared teaching and moderation and swapping of expertise in specialist areas.

Last October the Association took 150 people involved in further education to Innis, County Clare, Ireland's e-town.

"What we saw there was the town of the future. Schools, colleges and businesses were all linked through the internet."

A meeting in Athlone of principals from north and south followed, and partnerships have been made with employers and local authorities. The Association began nurturing initiatives in eight curriculum areas, designed to increase technical skills within Northern Ireland and to give people wanting leisure learning access to everything from Tiffaney glass to computing.

Northern Ireland retains the 11-plus and has an education system that, at its best, produces much higher results than Britain, but, at its worst, nurtures significantly higher levels of adult illiteracy. A recent report by a team from Queen's and the University of Ulster shows the 11-plus has increased social and academic disadvantage.

There is also a skills shortage in vital modern technical and information technology areas, where the north lags behind the south. Information technology and call centres are gold mines for remote areas.

The skill gaps - together with currency disparities because Britain is outside the European currency union - make it more difficult for the north to attract IT industries. North-south disparities mean skilled workers head south, where the economy is booming.

"It is impossible to get a plumber or an electrician in the north," Dr Hunter said. "There is a major skills drain. You have only got to look at what Xerox is doing in Dundalk to see what is happening." Xerox is building a huge plant in Dundalk, five miles south of the border. It has turned one of the wildest of the bandit-country safe havens for terrorists into a boom town.

Direct rule threatens progress, Dr Hunter said. "The difference with devolution is the ability of our ministers to get involved and understand detail. The big problem is that that momentum is lost."

webTitle: ITN Bosnia reporters win libel damages

fields.headline: ITN Bosnia reporters win libel damages
fields.standfirst: LM magazine pays out £300,000 for 'faked war camp footage' slur
fields.trailText: Two ITN reporters accused of faking footage of a Serb-run camp in the Bosnian war were today awarded £300,000 in a libel action against LM magazine.
fields.body:
Two ITN reporters accused of faking footage of a Serb-run camp in the Bosnian war were today awarded £300,000 in a libel action against LM magazine.

The magazine, formerly Living Marxism, claimed that Penny Marshall and Ian Williams misrepresented a headline-grabbing image of an emaciated Muslim, Fikret Alic, at the Serb-run Trnopolje camp in August 1992. Ms Marshall and Mr Williams said that LM's article, headed "The picture that fooled the world", amounted to a highly damaging attack upon their reputations and professional integrity.

The two journalists, who were described by their counsel during the two-week trial as "decent, honest and courageous", were each awarded £150,000 - the maximum suggested by Mr Justice Morland - and ITN received £75,000.

In a joint statement after the verdict Ms Marshall and Mr Williams said: "There was never any doubt whatsoever that the allegations made against us were both untrue and unfounded. The reports in question were filmed and presented with the professionalism and integrity that would be expected of us.

"LM was given every opportunity to retract the article and its allegations. Its decision not to do so resulted in our taking legal action in order to clear our names.

"Today's verdict and award clearly vindicates that course of action and, perhaps more importantly, gives dignity to all those who were detained in the camps."

LM's editor, Michael Hume, and publishers Informinc (LM) Ltd and Helene Guldberg, had said during the trial that the criticism of the reporters was justified because they had deliberately selected shots of Mr Alic "caged behind barbed wire" at Serb-run Trnopolje camp in August 1992.

ITN's editor-in-chief Richard Tait said today: "I believe this verdict makes it a good day for British television journalism.

"It is important for many reasons: it clears the names and reputations of Penny and Ian and wholly vindicates our decision to take action against LM over the lies they told about them.

"Penny and Ian's reports of conditions at Trnopolje and Omarska were one of British television journalism's finest achievements in the last 10 years."

LM (Living Marxism)

fields.headline: Hague's tax offensive
fields.standfirst: The Tory leader is out to disprove claims that he is a one-issue politician, obsessed with Europe
fields.trailText: It is a sign of how far the Tories have sunk that the party's spinners have been forced to expend enormous amounts of energy over the past 24 hours promoting William Hague's speech in favour of tax cuts.
fields.body:
It is a sign of how far the Tories have sunk that the party's spinners have been forced to expend enormous amounts of energy over the past 24 hours promoting William Hague's speech in favour of tax cuts.

Such a speech by a Tory leader a decade ago would barely have attracted attention from voters who regarded the Tories as the party of low taxes. Margaret Thatcher's three election victories - and John Major's surprise victory in 1992 - were all won on the back of pledges to cut the tax rises of the 1970s, which saw the top rate of tax spiral to 83%.

Mr Hague is painfully aware, however, that the Tories lost their tax-cutting reputation during the dying days of the Major government, when Labour proved that the Conservatives had increased the tax burden. Hence his speech tonight in which he pledges to "set our country free again" and reverse Gordon Brown's "stealth taxes".

It is not just Mr Major's record which has forced Mr Hague to try to convince voters that the Tories will cut taxes. Wise heads at central office have advised him that his obsession with Europe is in danger of casting him as a single-issue politician.

Although he chose the rightwing think tank Politeia for the speech, Mr Hague knows that his tax-cutting message cannot be crafted in Thatcherite materialist terms. His speech is therefore forward-looking - there is a mere passing mention of Lady Thatcher - with a gesture to the centre ground as he argues that there is a "moral case for taxation".

"If citizens come to see themselves not as willing co-operators with the state but as the down-trodden victims of authoritarian tax-gatherers, the propensity of the citizen to act properly, and on the basis of goodwill rather than fear, is reduced," Mr Hague says.

His hopes of reaching out to all wings of his party appear to have failed. One veteran of the Tory centre right, said last night: "What a pity to see William claiming there is a moral case for lowering taxes. Everyone knows that lower taxes always favour the rich."

webTitle: It's too soon to buy into Lastminute.com

fields.headline: It's too soon to buy into Lastminute.com
fields.standfirst: Beware the absurdly overvalued internet stocks - for a bubble is bound to burst, argues Will Hutton, the respected economic commentator and chief executive of the industrial society
fields.trailText: Tuesday, 5pm: Beware the absurdly overvalued internet stocks - for a bubble is bound to burst, argues Will Hutton, the respected economic commentator and chief executive of the industrial society.
fields.body:
Lastminute.com is a remarkable company, remarkable website and a remarkable business concept. It has grown fantastically in 18 months and is a British first. Its brand name is already one of the best-known on the web, made better-known by the events of the floatation. It is reaping all the benefits of first entry. And its founders are inspirational and entrepreneurial. The question is not any of that; it is whether it is worth over £5 a share, valuing it at some £750 million.

My view is that it is not. The valuation is absurd, part of a worldwide fashion for anything to do with the new economy and the internet - and dangerous. I suspect that Martha Lane Fox is right: Lastminute will be one of the internet companies with long run prospects that may succeed. But granted that, I cannot believe it is right to value at such a price a company with so few assets and such a long prospect of not paying profits and dividends.

What is happening is the doctrine of the greater fool. We know the price of internet companies is absurd, but buyers expect the price to become more absurd tomorrow. Hence the bubble, in its essence like any other of the great manias in history, and which is affecting internet shares in every western stockmarket. It will be pricked, and in the United States the price correction will affect the whole stock exchange and potentially - interacting with the trebling in the oil price - trigger an economic downturn. So beware.

Even if Lastminute is a worldbeater there will be opportunities to buy it cheaper than today.

fields.headline: 'tache, Clash and Smash
fields.trailText: SO SOU ME!
fields.body:
SO SOU ME!

As widely predicted in every corner of the press, Graeme Souness is the new manager of Blackburn Rovers (even Lawnmowing Monthly ran an editorial favourably comparing Souness's managerial skills with those of the new Qualcast XV2000). With his hair still seemingly made up of a collection of moustaches, the hard man took up his post this morning and will be in charge of Rovers' next match away at Fulham.

After being unceremoniously hounded out of his last job at Benfica, Souness was plainly chuffed to be back in sheepskin. "This is a wonderful opportunity and just the sort of challenge I relish," said the man who made Yosser Hughes look cuddly. "I am delighted to be back in day-to-day management". Rumours that there was also a party at Michael Thomas's house have yet to be confirmed.

Equally excited at the appointment of a man with a decidedly chequered managerial history, Uncle Jack Walker had his say. "There is a big job to be done here and I believe we have found the right man to do it," he said, having carefully tippexed out the words Woy, Hodgson, Brian and Kidd. "Graeme Souness is precisely the man we need," Walker went on, "and he can count on our full and unswerving support." Tony Parkes, who takes up the role of assistant manager, might be allowed a small chuckle at this point.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

IT'S THAT GOB AGAIN

In an ideal world, Lonely Nicolas Anelka would be at the forefront of the alternative-rock movement. With a ring in his nose and a spring in his Vans, the French international striker would be a multi-platinum recording artist with hits such as "Leave me Alone" and "Everyone I work with is an idiot." However, despite an interview today in which he displayed more attitude than Primal Scream in a youth club, Nic remains a footballer. Albeit one who's been fined £275,000 for having an attitude problem.

After the kerfuffle which has seen Nic suspended without pay for 45 days, he used an interview with France Football to air his feelings towards current employer Real Madrid. "They treat me like a dog," was one (mmmm, treats!), "I am alone against everyone" was another. A third suggested that "It's difficult to succeed [at Real Madrid], even if you were the best player in the world." So God knows how Steve McManaman managed it.

It really is marvellous how little Nic has learned to restrain his tongue over the past two years. In fact, if anything, his disregard has matured like a fine cheese. So here he is lecturing Real on how to play the game properly: "Speed is modern football," he revealed, adding helpfully "My game is based on speed." With that sort of comment you wouldn't expect Nic to be at the Bernabeu beyond the summer, although where he will end up remains to be seen. As Nic himself puts it: "Are there any other clubs interested in me? I don't know."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"If you want to talk football, fine. If you want to talk about transfers, then find yourself another club." Gerard Houllier lays down the law. So that's Robbie Fowler off to Charlton for £79m then.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

SLINKY AFRO

Dedicated Fifa watchers (ensconced in Geneva with a copy of I Spy Bureaucrats) are astonished. Football's governing body recently sent a team of inspectors to South Africa to appraise their bid to host the 2006 World Cup. But instead of writing off the hot favourite as a disorganised rabble stuffed to the gills with violent criminals (as Bobby Charlton could have told them), Fifa's elite squad have decided that, actually, it's rather a nice place.

"We were most favourably impressed - the whole thing really was excellent," said Alan Rothenberg today, the man behind the USA's successful bid in 1994 (and the MLS too, but we'll let that one pass). "Clearly the infrastructure is in place," he went on. "There would be a few modifications but the country has six years to make them."

Mr Rothenberg made frequent reference to 'smiling faces' and 'history' as he discussed the possibility of the first World Cup on African soil. Mr Rothenberg also revealed that some FIFA members "will take into account whether a continent has had a World Cup before and how long ago they had it" before making their decision.

So to summarise, South Africa has a great infrastructure, a friendly people, historical legitimacy and the support of Sepp Blatter. We've got Tony Banks and a Wembley that doesn't work. The final decision on the venue won't be made until 6 June, but if the Fiver were a betting email publication...

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Newcastle manager Bobby Robson has flown to Spain, reportedly with the aim of watching former charge, Barcelona captain Pep Guardiola.

Rivaldo's wife is taking English lessons. Whether this means that the world's best player is set for a move to Manchester United, or just that Mrs Rivaldo has got into Richard and Judy remains to be seen.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Everton have agreed a £6m deal with kit manufacturers Puma. Puma will become the club's official sportswear provider as of next season. Everton today also completed the signing of Mark Hughes from Southampton.

Henrik Larsson has returned to action for Celtic scoring twice in a 5-1 victory for the under-21 side against St Johnstone.

Southampton captain Jason Dodd has been rewarded for 11 years' service at The Dell with a testimonial at the start of next season.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match (10pm) Big Cup, Big Bob, and Big Awkward Pauses.

Feyenoord v Chelsea (2am) You've seen the best bits, now watch the whole thing!

Football extra (3.40am) The only Nationwide football on terrestrial tv and it's on after reheated Big Cup.

Channel 4: Football Italia (2.10am) Serie A action from Sunday night on Wednesday morning. We blame the Italian postal service.

Channel 5: Argentinian football (4.25am) Whereas the Argentinian mail looks quite impressive by comparison.

fields.bodyText: SO SOU ME! As widely predicted in every corner of the press, Graeme Souness is the new manager of Blackburn Rovers (even Lawnmowing Monthly ran an editorial favourably comparing Souness's managerial skills with those of the new Qualcast XV2000). With his hair still seemingly made up of a collection of moustaches, the hard man took up his post this morning and will be in charge of Rovers' next match away at Fulham. After being unceremoniously hounded out of his last job at Benfica, Souness was plainly chuffed to be back in sheepskin. "This is a wonderful opportunity and just the sort of challenge I relish," said the man who made Yosser Hughes look cuddly. "I am delighted to be back in day-to-day management". Rumours that there was also a party at Michael Thomas's house have yet to be confirmed. Equally excited at the appointment of a man with a decidedly chequered managerial history, Uncle Jack Walker had his say. "There is a big job to be done here and I believe we have found the right man to do it," he said, having carefully tippexed out the words Woy, Hodgson, Brian and Kidd. "Graeme Souness is precisely the man we need," Walker went on, "and he can count on our full and unswerving support." Tony Parkes, who takes up the role of assistant manager, might be allowed a small chuckle at this point. * * * * * * * * * * * * * IT'S THAT GOB AGAIN In an ideal world, Lonely Nicolas Anelka would be at the forefront of the alternative-rock movement. With a ring in his nose and a spring in his Vans, the French international striker would be a multi-platinum recording artist with hits such as "Leave me Alone" and "Everyone I work with is an idiot." However, despite an interview today in which he displayed more attitude than Primal Scream in a youth club, Nic remains a footballer. Albeit one who's been fined £275,000 for having an attitude problem. After the kerfuffle which has seen Nic suspended without pay for 45 days, he used an interview with France Football to air his feelings towards current employer Real Madrid. "They treat me like a dog," was one (mmmm, treats!), "I am alone against everyone" was another. A third suggested that "It's difficult to succeed [at Real Madrid], even if you were the best player in the world." So God knows how Steve McManaman managed it. It really is marvellous how little Nic has learned to restrain his tongue over the past two years. In fact, if anything, his disregard has matured like a fine cheese. So here he is lecturing Real on how to play the game properly: "Speed is modern football," he revealed, adding helpfully "My game is based on speed." With that sort of comment you wouldn't expect Nic to be at the Bernabeu beyond the summer, although where he will end up remains to be seen. As Nic himself puts it: "Are there any other clubs interested in me? I don't know." * * * * * * * * * * * * * QUOTE OF THE DAY "If you want to talk football, fine. If you want to talk about transfers, then find yourself another club." Gerard Houllier lays down the law. So that's Robbie Fowler off to Charlton for £79m then. * * * * * * * * * * * * * SLINKY AFRO Dedicated Fifa watchers (ensconced in Geneva with a copy of I Spy Bureaucrats) are astonished. Football's governing body recently sent a team of inspectors to South Africa to appraise their bid to host the 2006 World Cup. But instead of writing off the hot favourite as a disorganised rabble stuffed to the gills with violent criminals (as Bobby Charlton could have told them), Fifa's elite squad have decided that, actually, it's rather a nice place. "We were most favourably impressed - the whole thing really was excellent," said Alan Rothenberg today, the man behind the USA's successful bid in 1994 (and the MLS too, but we'll let that one pass). "Clearly the infrastructure is in place," he went on. "There would be a few modifications but the country has six years to make them." Mr Rothenberg made frequent reference to 'smiling faces' and 'history' as he discussed the possibility of the first World Cup on African soil. Mr Rothenberg also revealed that some FIFA members "will take into account whether a continent has had a World Cup before and how long ago they had it" before making their decision. So to summarise, South Africa has a great infrastructure, a friendly people, historical legitimacy and the support of Sepp Blatter. We've got Tony Banks and a Wembley that doesn't work. The final decision on the venue won't be made until 6 June, but if the Fiver were a betting email publication... * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL Newcastle manager Bobby Robson has flown to Spain, reportedly with the aim of watching former charge, Barcelona captain Pep Guardiola. Rivaldo's wife is taking English lessons. Whether this means that the world's best player is set for a move to Manchester United, or just that Mrs Rivaldo has got into Richard and Judy remains to be seen. * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF Everton have agreed a £6m deal with kit manufacturers Puma. Puma will become the club's official sportswear provider as of next season. Everton today also completed the signing of Mark Hughes from Southampton. Henrik Larsson has returned to action for Celtic scoring twice in a 5-1 victory for the under-21 side against St Johnstone. Southampton captain Jason Dodd has been rewarded for 11 years' service at The Dell with a testimonial at the start of next season. * * * * * * * * * * * * * TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO ITV: The Big Match (10pm) Big Cup, Big Bob, and Big Awkward Pauses. Feyenoord v Chelsea (2am) You've seen the best bits, now watch the whole thing! Football extra (3.40am) The only Nationwide football on terrestrial tv and it's on after reheated Big Cup. fields.headline: Times in merger frenzy
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The Los Angeles Times yesterday became a victim of the merger frenzy gripping America's media industry when it was taken over by the publisher of the Chicago Tribune in a deal worth $8bn (£5bn).
fields.body:
The Los Angeles Times yesterday became a victim of the merger frenzy gripping America's media industry when it was taken over by the publisher of the Chicago Tribune in a deal worth $8bn (£5bn).

The proposed merger of Times Mirror, the owner of the LA Times and Chicago's Tribune group is set to create the country's third largest selling newspaper group.

Analysts had also expected the venerable Chicago-based Tribune to expand further into television - where it already owns 22 stations - or other interactive services.

The Chandler family, which controls 64% of the voting rights for the Times Mirror, has agreed to the deal, which includes the assumption of about $1.5bn in debt.

The LA Times has hit the headlines in recent months after a plan to intensify the integration of the editorial and advertising departments horrified employees and readers and led to a public apology.

Mark Willes, the company chairman at the centre of the controversy, was understood to be unlikely to join the newly merged group, which will be headquartered in Chicago under Tribune leadership. In announcing the cash-and-share deal yesterday, the Tribune focused on the expected multi-media opportunities.

Dennis FitzSimons, executive vice-president, said: "In a world that is increasingly fragmented, local, branded mass media providers will remain the most valuable resource for advertisers looking to reach a mass audience with impact and frequency."

The new company will create an internet company with about $55m in projected revenues this year. Following the acquisition, the Tribune will own 11 daily newspapers, which have together won some 80 Pulitzer Prizes, four radio stations and the Chicago Cubs baseball team.

Shares in rival newspaper firms Gannett and Knight Ridder rose on the merger news.

fields.headline: Microsoft and Andersen join forces
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Microsoft
fields.trailText: Microsoft joined forces with Andersen Consulting yesterday in an alliance designed to prevent internet rivals from undermining the dominance of its desktop operating system Windows.
fields.body:
Microsoft joined forces with Andersen Consulting yesterday in an alliance designed to prevent internet rivals from undermining the dominance of its desktop operating system Windows.

The two firms are to form a new company, Avanade, to sell software and services to Andersen's existing client list of Fortune 500 companies as well as internet start-ups.

Microsoft, the company founded by Bill Gates, expects the new venture to head off increased competition from operating systems such as Linux, which many programmers prefer for internet-based services.

Steve Ballmer, Microsoft's chief executive, called the agreement with Andersen "the most significant partnership we've announced for a long, long time".

The deal was heavily promoted by Mr Ballmer and his counterpart at Andersen, Joe Forehand. Avanade, which is to employ more than 3,000 technicians, will be valued at about $1bn under the terms of the deal. Microsoft is to contribute some $385m while Andersen will provide training and other services.

Mitch Hill, a 20-year Andersen veteran who will become Avanade's chief executive, expects the new company to become profitable within 18-24 months.

"We have a huge investment to get started and we plan on being profitable very quickly," he said.

Avanade, based in Seattle, expects to announce its first client within the next few weeks, following regulatory approval.

The new venture is also planning on a fairly rapid initial public offering at around the same time as it expects to make its first profit.

"We are going to be pedalling fast to scale up," Mr Hill said. The company will be focused on large-scale enterprises, a market that Microsoft has so far failed to dominate.

"The benefits that Avanade is going to bring is to really speed to market internet and e-commerce solutions," Mr Hill said. Given the speed with which internet companies are growing, Mr Hill said he expected the client list soon to include start-ups and other web concerns.

Avanade is largely designed to improve the market for Windows 2000, Microsoft's latest corporate software. Mr Ballmer described the new agreement as an "opportunity for Microsoft to drive Windows 2000 in the biggest economic enterprises".

Before the arrival of Windows 2000, Microsoft had little to offer companies wanting reliable heavy-duty internet services.

Under the terms of yesterday's deal, Andersen has agreed to provide specialised Windows-based training to about 25,000 of its employees, amounting to a third of its workforce. It will also create a separate consulting practice to develop specific business solutions based on Microsoft technology.

The company did not reveal who had come up with the name, but Mr Hill said it was an amalgam of avenue and promenade.

"One is about the journey and the other is about the place you're trying to get to," he explained.

Avanade will be trying to get to several places at once with offices across the US as well as bases in London, Paris, Sydney and Singapore due to be set up within 18 months.

Shares in Microsoft fell yesterday along with the rest of the technology-dominated Nasdaq composite index.

fields.headline: Low blows to the belly
fields.standfirst: In the latest round of his fight for fitness,  Stephen Moss climbs into the boxing ring with a world-class practitioner and learns five good moves that will limit the damage
fields.trailText: In the latest round of his fight for fitness, Stephen Moss climbs into the boxing ring with a world-class practitioner and learns five good moves that will limit the damage
fields.body:
First, the sensational news. I have lost half a stone; well, OK, about 6lb if you want to be picky. Now, admittedly, 6lb is less than 3% of my original weight (guesstimates on a postcard please), but it's a start. Only another 35lb to go. The news would have been even more heartening but for a weekend spent in Vienna, where gyms have barely penetrated - Jörg Haider's jogging obsession is not shared by his fellow countrymen - and every menu is a death trap. How the Viennese manage to waltz eludes me; it is a miracle they can walk.

Everything comes soaked in butter or garlic sauce; meat - grilled, griddled, cuttled and occasionally raw - appears to be obligatory; and strudels and tortes (there should be a law against them) are a way of life. All the hard work of the past six weeks swam before my eyes - and promptly drowned. My food charts make X-certificate reading.

But Vienna was an aberration and the fightback has begun, with boxing the latest weapon in the fitness war: more punch, less paunch. Now, there may be some who think it ridiculous that I should be trying out boxing on the health pages; shouldn't it, they might aver, be on the anti-health pages? All I can say is that this is a form of boxing (sometimes called "boxercise") that minimises the danger of injury: you get all the "fun" of boxing with none of the fury (not to mention brain damage).

My personal trainer, Sam, and I have been sparring more or less since the beginning. He stands there with large pads on his hands, which I pummel wearing boxing gloves. He showed me how to jab with the left (if that's your weaker hand) and save your right for the bigger punches. Boxing is good exercise - with lots of leg and body movement - and an excellent way of releasing aggression. It's tiring - because you have to move and punch at the same time, so everything is being used simultaneously - but also rewarding in a way that conventional exercise isn't.

The treadmill can, as everyone who has used a gym knows, get pretty dull, no matter how diverting the boy bands cavorting round on MTV are. Boxing provides a way of varying the exercise, interacting with someone else, and setting goals - not just increasing stamina, but becoming a better technical boxer (punching is more about body positioning than hand or arm power, and it is easy to assess how well you are doing it).

When Sam left me for his girlfriend a couple of weeks ago, I cooked up a little scheme - to take him to a boxing gym where he could pit his skills against a proper boxer. Which is how last week we came to be standing in the ring at Jimmy McDonnell's boxing gym (slogan: "Get fit and don't get hit") in London's Camden Town.

Jimmy was a world-class fighter in the late 80s, won a European championship at featherweight and fought for two world titles. He now trains some of the UK's best professional boxers, some gifted amateurs and a varied bunch who are training to get fit or to explore some mythic notion of masculinity. Women are welcome here too, by the way, and plenty show up: they enjoy the release of aggression, can learn self-defence, and are particularly attracted by kick-boxing.

M y hope was that Jimmy would show Sam the ropes, and lots of the canvas too. But it didn't work out that way. Instead, Sam and I did all the fitness stuff, danced around the ring punching Jimmy's mitts (he would occasionally give you a friendly cuff around the head and tell you to keep your guard up) and then sparred with each other (gentle body punches only).

We did four three-minute rounds (a workout for regulars would last 10 rounds or more; a workout for the pros could be three or four hours) and it was utterly draining. This is anaerobic (as well as aerobic) exercise: the action is so fast and unrelenting that there isn't enough oxygen for the body (at least this body) to recover. After 12 minutes I was out on my feet: I spent the last couple of minutes limply punching (nudging, actually) a punchbag. The judges made the bag the winner on points. Sam, needless to say, survived the ordeal much better. So much for revenge.

Without necessarily donning the gloves and entering the ring, there are several things everyone can learn from boxers and apply in their own fitness regimes:

 Discipline. Boxers may damage themselves in the ring, but on the whole they don't damage themselves outside it. "Don't put bad oil in a good engine" is Jimmy's dictum. Avoid drink, drugs and cigarettes, and watch your diet. (Jimmy says he has never sworn, smoked, tasted alcohol, taken drugs, or consorted with any woman other than his wife; his only vice, he says, is telling lies.)

 Jog to build up your stamina (but check with your doctor first if you have any history of heart trouble).

 Skipping is a good form of cardio-vascular exercise and a way of building up leg strength.

 Try circuit training: a series of short, intensive exercises designed to get your heart rate up. These might include press-ups, lunges (taking a stride forward and letting your trailing knee almost touch the floor), squat thrusts (jumping up from a squatting position), sit-ups, skipping, and running on the spot. Spend five minutes or so warming up and stretching; then do each for 30 seconds, with 30-second rests between them; go through all the routines twice, so that your heart rate is raised for around 20 minutes in all. This combination of exercises combines aerobics with resistance work, needs no equipment, and can be done in the privacy of your bedroom.

 Put the theme from Rocky on your CD player, and shadow box in front of your bedroom mirror. It will raise your heart rate and teach you to be light on your feet. You will look ridiculous, but who cares? After all, nobody ever laughs at Lennox Lewis.

 Stephen Moss is spending three months working out at Matt Roberts at One, 1 Aldwych, London WC2 (0171-300 0600). Jimmy Macs boxing gym is at 111 Camden High Street, London NW1 (0171-387 8050). It offers boxing and kickboxing, and runs individual and group sessions.

fields.headline: To sleep, perchance...
fields.standfirst:
Do you dream of a sleeping pill that doesn't leave you
wiped out the next day? Oliver Burke maninvestigates a
new drug that claims to do just that
fields.trailText: Do you dream of a sleeping pill that doesn't leave you wiped out the next day? Oliver Burke maninvestigates a new drug that claims to do just that
fields.body:
Insomniacs know all there is to know about broken promises. Gadget catalogues slide from between the pages of Sunday supplements offering miracle pillows, orthopedic beds, life-changing humidifiers and CD compilations of soporific seashore noises - all lucrative for their manufacturers but not noticeably relieving the agonies of the estimated 10m British adults who suffer from sleeplessness. Just trying to plough through the proliferating and near-identical volumes of self-help literature on the subject ought to induce slumber, but even that's not foolproof. This, after all, is the paradox of sleep: the more energy you focus on eliminating the problem, the harder it becomes to reach a goal you can only reach by forgetting that you want it.

Which is why we should offer a decidedly cautious welcome to the latest "revolution" in sleep treatment. But a welcome nonetheless, because Sonata - the appropriately restful tradename for a new drug launched in the UK later this week by Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories - really does appear to bring us significantly closer to the "sleep on demand" craved by the nation's tossing and turning hordes.

Traditional sleeping pills - benzodiazepines like Valium - launch an all-out assault on the insomniac's nervous system, guaranteeing a night's sleep but causing collateral damage in the form of next-day grogginess, a nasty reaction with alcohol and, above all, the prospect of dangerous dependency. Sonata, according to its makers and promising pre-launch clinical trials, behaves more like the fabled smart missile, targeting the relevant part of the brain, then breaking down and leaving the body swiftly - doing away with next-day side-effects and, as far as researchers are currently aware, with dependency. Crucially, in consequence, it can be taken in the middle of the night, when sleeplessness strikes, anytime up to four hours before you plan to rise. In the arcane jargon of sleep research, the drug "preserves the natural sleep architecture".

To its credit, Wyeth has resisted the temptation to slap a heartstopping price tag on Sonata: GPs' budgets will only pay £3.60 for every two weeks of treatment prescribed. This is not a display of selfless generosity on the part of a pharmaceuticals firm - that really would be revolutionary - but instead reflects the manufacturer's certainty of reaching an enormous, and enormously profitable, mass market: 50% of Britons suffer disrupted sleep, 24% of them frequently; the company further claims that "around a third of patients consulting their GPs are dissatisfied with their sleep".

It's a surprisingly youthful market, too, given that sleep problems are traditionally associated with older people. GPs are reporting anecdotal evidence of a significant increase in the proportion of insomniac patients under 40. A key prob able reason is the growth of the 24-hour society and the flexible working it demands. Studies have shown that 65% of people who frequently alternate between day and nightshifts suffer from disrupted sleep patterns.

Sonata may well live up to its promise, but it will be breaking the mould if it does. "Just about every other sleep drug introduced onto the market in the last 20 years has claimed to be better than anything else, and to have no side-effects, so one has to be cautious," says Professor Jim Horne of the sleep research centre at Loughborough University, and a maverick in the field. Our troubled relationship with sleeping pills, Horne argues, stems less from a lack of innovations in the lab than from some fundamental misunderstandings about who should use them and how they really work.

"Most insomniacs don't complain of sleepiness during the day, so though they find wakefulness at night upsetting, they don't actually need more sleep than they're getting," he says. "There's a category of insomnia that is associated with feeling worn out all day, but those people don't respond to sleeping tablets anyway." Even when they do work, the medications function not so much by bringing on sleep as by reducing anxiety - in other contexts, benzodiazepines are used as tranquilisers - making the failure to fall asleep seem less distressing.

This is small comfort for the sleepless millions who want rest without addiction, and it's to them that Sonata's aspirin-like convenience and lack of stigma is likely to appeal the most. Ultimately, if they want it to work, it probably will: "Pills don't necessarily mean you get to sleep sooner," says Horne. "Time just feels like it's passing less slowly, so you worry about it less. And then you sleep."
fields.bodyText: Insomniacs know all there is to know about broken promises. Gadget catalogues slide from between the pages of Sunday supplements offering miracle pillows, orthopedic beds, life-changing humidifiers and CD compilations of soporific seashore noises - all lucrative for their manufacturers but not noticeably relieving the agonies of the estimated 10m British adults who suffer from sleeplessness. Just trying to plough through the proliferating and near-identical volumes of self-help literature on the subject ought to induce slumber, but even that's not foolproof. This, after all, is the paradox of sleep: the more energy you focus on eliminating the problem, the harder it becomes to reach a goal you can only reach by forgetting that you want it. Which is why we should offer a decidedly cautious welcome to the latest "revolution" in sleep treatment. But a welcome nonetheless, because Sonata - the appropriately restful tradename for a new drug launched in the UK later this week by Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories - really does appear to bring us significantly closer to the "sleep on demand" craved by the nation's tossing and turning hordes. fields.headline: Keep taking the tablets
fields.standfirst: Latest research suggest that periods are bad for women's health. So can anything be done to limit the damage?  Sarah Boseley reports on one solution, the Pill
fields.trailText: Latest research suggest that periods are bad for women's health. So can anything be done to limit the damage? Sarah Boseley reports on one solution, the Pill
fields.body:
Some things in life are immutable. There is a rhythm to the seasons, night follows day, tides ebb and flood and a woman's body goes through a menstrual cycle every 28 days or so until the menopause sets in. That is the way it has always been and we assume it will forever stay.

But does it have to be so? Or are we needlessly imprisoned by our and our doctors' assumptions about what is natural? Modern woman has nearly three times as many periods as her forebears endured, and evidence is accumulating that the toll of all this menstruation may not only be nuisance and distressing mood swings, but also an increased propensity to some diseases.

The first myth is that modern menstruation patterns are natural. In an article in the latest Lancet medical journal, Charlotte Ellertson and Sarah Thomas, based in the Mexico office of the population council, write that times have changed: "Women in pre-historic times, as estimated by research among contemporary hunter-gatherer populations, probably had far fewer periods (about 160 ovulations over their lifetime) than modern women."

Women living in industrialised countries today begin menstruating at an earlier age and go through the menopause later. They limit their families to two or three children and scarcely breastfeed, Ellertson and Thomas say, "three months per birth, with half of American infants never breastfed at all". So their bodies get very little break from menstruation, with its hormonal surges and the physical stress on the ovary each time a ripe egg bursts through the wall. Modern woman can expect to go through about 450 periods in her life.

So it can be argued that women are living an unnatural life - a sophisticated life of our own choosing, thanks to modern contraception, but one which leads to an unnatural number of periods. Some women are relatively undisturbed by their monthly bleed. Some welcome it as a sign of their fertility or as proof that they are not pregnant. But for some, periods are painful and debilitating - the "curse" of generations of women.

The Lancet article argues that "there is plenty of modern evidence that amenhorrhoea (absence of periods) is often healthier than the alternative". A woman who is not ovulating escapes the sharp changes in hormone levels that can lead to mood swings. Arthritis, epilepsy and other conditions that worsen with the cycle would remain stable. Menstruation can cause endometriosis and anaemia.

But most alarming is probably the link with ovarian cancer, explored in the current New Yorker magazine which, coincidentally with the Lancet, has taken a radical look at menstruation and the pill. Ovulation, it points out, encourages cell division as the breach in the ovary wall caused by the release of the egg is healed. Studies have shown that a woman's lifetime risk of ovarian cancer drops by 10% every time she has a child.

"Why? Possibly because, between nine months of pregnancy and the suppression of ovulation associated with breastfeeding, she stops ovulating for 12 months and saves her ovarian walls from 12 bouts of cell division," says the article.

The same argument applies to the changes in the lining of the womb, potentially increasing the chances of endometrial cancer, which, together with ovarian cancer, is a characteristically modern disease, the consequence, in part, "of a century in which women have come to menstruate 400 times a lifetime," it continues.

Dr Sheldon Segal, a distinguished endocrinologist, well-known contraceptive researcher, and co-author of Is Menstruation Obsolete?, agrees with this scenario. "The evidence is very clear", he says, for the impact of menstruation on ovarian and endometrial cancer, although the jury is still out on the possibility that it might be implicated in breast cancer. "Among women who take oral contraceptives, they reduce their risk of ovarian cancer by one seventh," he said.

But they still have periods, don't they? Well no, they don't. Not a menstrual period in the proper sense of the words. What they have is a superficial bleed, which is not the same thing. There is no ovulation. This is the irony that the New Yorker hooks into. That for women on the pill, that bleed is not necessary.

It was devised by a pioneer of the pill, John Rock, who thought that if women took 21 pills and then seven placebos, enabling them to have this non-functional bleed which seemed like a period, then the Catholic church might approve the pill as a "natural" form of contraception which did not interfere with the normal rhythms of life. All it did, he argued, was extend the natural, infertile, "safe" period.

Of course, the argument was kicked into touch by John Rock's church. But the pill continued to be made and marketed in the pseudo-natural way he had devised. It may be that many women feel better about taking the pill knowing that their body has a week's break, but in fact, argue today's scientists, it makes very little difference. "We have never had any reason why there is a need for a rest," said Dr Segal. "It was more of a means of selling the idea to women rather than there being a medicinal basis for three weeks on and one week off."

For all that he, and the Lancet writers, are challenging the orthodoxy, Dr Segal says he is not urging all women to take the pill continuously and give up periods for good. "I do see it as a possibility that women will want to have fewer periods as a lifestyle choice, but I'm not really urging women to do this if they have no problem with their menstruation. But when it stands in the way of their normal functioning, women should be given the opportunity to decide for themselves."

Ellertson agrees. Speaking from the labour ward of a hospital in Mexico where she was about to give birth she said: "I don't think women would want to use the pill for decades on end - probably just for a few months and then have a break. But there is no evidence that the placebos do anything good."

Some women have been aware that they can take two packets of pills in a row to avoid a period interrupting a special event, such as a holiday. But they have a sense that they are doing something irregular and possibly damaging. It is also, says Dr Segal, only a certain group of women who generally are that well informed. "In the United States, that wisdom is mainly available to middle-class women with their own private physician," he said. And not all doctors or family planning clinics would give that advice.

Ellertson and Thomas, who say women who think they are maintaining a natural cycle on the pill "are being duped", think women should be given the information so they can decide what sort of menstrual pattern suits them. "Women could use pills to adjust their cycles as convenient," they suggest. In the future, they say, "women most harmed by their cycles might choose to suppress their periods for years at a time. Others might simply reduce their annual number of bleeds."

For all the regular scare stories about the pill in the UK, it is one of the best-studied drugs in medicine, she points out. Women whose periods distress or damage them should be told there is that option.

"Health professionals and women ought to view menstruation as they would any other naturally occurring but frequently undesirable condition," she writes in the Lancet. "This means providing those women who want it with safe and effective means to eliminate their menstrual cycles, contributing to happier, less encumbered lives and helping women individually and society as a whole."

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.trailText: Heartburn | Toenails
fields.body:
The acid test
Q: I've stared getting the most awful heartburn - often in the middle of the night. During the day I burp frequently. The other day, I let out a huge burp in a crowded lift at work, and wanted to die of embarrassment. I feel so bloated that none of my trousers or skirts do up. I've tried a glass of milk at night, and hot water after my meals, but it hasn't helped at all. Any advice?

A: You are not alone. Around 40% of the British population get heartburn and acid regurgitation (known in medi-speak as gastro-oesophageal reflux disease or GORD). The problem occurs because the sphincter that lies at the bottom of the oesophagus relaxes temporarily and lets acid from the stomach flow back up the oesophagus. This causes burning behind the breastbone as it washes up the oesophagus, an acid taste in the mouth and excess gas, which accounts for the burping and bloating.

The first step is to cut down excessive alcohol, fatty foods and smoking, all of which can exacerbate the reflux. A lot of people find out the hard way which foods to avoid; tomatoes, citrus fruit, pickles and hot curries are common culprits. Stress triggers heartburn in some people and stress management techniques such as yoga may be very effective. You can buy drugs that neutralise acid, such as Gaviscon, and others that block acid, such as Tagamet or Zantac over the counter. But the drugs that switch off acid production in the stomach, such as Losec, are only available on prescription, so a visit to the GP may be worthwhile. If you don't get better with treatment, or have additional symptoms such as weight loss, difficulty swallowing, or passing blood in your stool, you'll be referred for a test to look inside your oesophagus and stomach (endoscopy).

Embarrassing nails
Q: My toenails are disgusting; discoloured, crumbly, yellow and thick. I'm embarrassed to take my socks and shoes off even in the height of summer and have stopped going swimming - which I used to enjoy. My GP gave me some stuff to paint on the nails which didn't do anything at all. Is there any hope?

A: The first step is to head back to the GP and ask for nail clippings to be taken and sent to a good lab to see which fungal strains you're harbouring in those nails. The drugs terbinafine (Lamisil) or itraconazole (Sporanox) daily for three months can work wonders. Your GP can also refer you to a podiatrist for nail care, and a dermatologist to confirm the diagnosis and advice about treatment.

Diet misery
Q: I've been on a strict but well-balanced diet since January. I have lost 10lbs and everyone tells me I've never looked better. But I feel totally fed up. Could I be missing out on some vital vitamin?

A: Researchers in Oxford have recently published a controlled experiment showing that dieting makes everyone unhappy even if they've never been depressed before. Women who have been depressed in the past get particularly low if they diet. In answer to your question, it seems to be the dip in blood levels of the chemical trytophan that makes you miserable when you diet. Tryptophan is processed in the body to make serotonin, the chemical in the brain that transmits "happy" messages. Many antidepressants, such as Prozac, work by increasing levels of serotonin in the brain. There doesn't seem to be any evidence as to whether you get used to the tryptophan dip if you maintain your diet over a long period, or whether taking trytophan supplements would counteract the depressing effects of dieting. Perhaps just knowing about the tryptophan effect will make you feel less miserable.

 These answers are intended to be as accurate and full as possible, but should never be used as a substitute for visiting a doctor and seeking medical help. If you have a question for Dr Robinson, email drann@dircon.co.uk or write to her c/o The Health Editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. She regrets that she cannot enter into personal correspondence.

webTitle: US airport security demands anger UK

fields.headline: US airport security demands anger UK
fields.standfirst:
Transport in Britain: special report
Read the letter
fields.trailText: John Prescott is involved in a row over US anti-terrorism plans to bring in security agents to check passengers at Heathrow and Gatwick on all transatlantic services run by British Airways and Virgin Airlines.
fields.body:
John Prescott is involved in a row over US anti-terrorism plans to bring in security agents to check passengers at Heathrow and Gatwick on all transatlantic services run by British Airways and Virgin Airlines.

The US government wants to force all foreign airlines to have identical security programmes to US companies from autumn. The plans would allow the federal aviation administration (FAA) to impose "additional security on any airline at any time" running services to the US.

The scheme has led to vitriolic correspondence between the deputy prime minister and his US transport counterpart Rodney Slater. Mr Prescott has told him that the plans are "an infringement of UK sovereignty" and "fundamentally flawed and ultimately unworkable".

Mr Prescott's tough stance is revealed in a letter and minutes of a meeting with Mr Slater which have been released to the Guardian under the US freedom of information act. Under Jack Straw's current freedom of information bill Mr Prescott's letter would stay secret until 2030.

The changes would allow the FAA to amend every airlines' security programme to make it identical to US carriers. At a number of airports - including Heathrow and Gatwick - the US wants additional security. The plans also envisage airlines having to adopt US security procedures, accept US security personnel working in foreign airports, hire specialists and develop identical passenger automated screening programmes and explosive detection technology.

In a letter last May to Mr Slater, Mr Prescott demands the repeal of the proposals. "The es sential point, put plainly, is that the law is unacceptable to the UK government: it is an infringement of UK sovereignty and would cause severe economic consequences for the UK aviation industry.

"Perhaps these negative points could be in some way tenable if the law was to improve aviation security. In fact it is likely to have the opposite effect by leading to the imposition of inappropriate and inefficient techniques.

"This runs counter to the spirit of multilateralism which is the basis for international cooperation on aviation security. A separate concern is the damage this will do to future international cooperation against terrorism.You will know, as well as I, that in these volatile times this is not something we can afford."

He adds: "In our submission we urge the FAA to revert to congress to explain that this legislation is fundamentally flawed and ultimately unworkable.

"Whilst we are directing our concerns to Capitol Hill, the administration has an important role to play in preventing this ill-advised legislation from proceeding. I believe the only right course is for this to be repealed."

Britain is one of 87 countries and organisations objecting to the proposed changes mainly because an internal US paper shows that it is regarded as "an impermissible extraterritorial application of US law and it will cost far more than an original $826m (about £516m) to implement".

The US government is considering Mr Prescott's complaints and will make an announcement this autumn on whether it is to go ahead.
