fields.headline: Capital gains
fields.standfirst: Public and private partnerships are now part of the treasury landscape. Isn't it time for the chancellor to explain the usefulness of this system?
fields.trailText: The government should be more explicit about exactly why we have the PFI, says Peter Robinson, chief economist at the influential Institute for Public Policy Research think tank.
fields.body:
Few issues can match the marriage of public and private interests in "partnerships" for generating more heat than light. Since the Institute for Public Policy Research established its commission on the future of these arrangements we have been accused at one and the same time of wanting to privatise the NHS and to scrap the private finance initiative (PFI).

Confusion abounds; it is hard to have an open and honest debate over this most important question facing our public services.

Take PFI. Two principal arguments have been put forward. It was said that under the right circumstances letting contracts to the private sector to build or do up hospitals and schools could yield efficiency savings and so better value for public money allocated to delivering health, education and other public services. Secondly, PFI was hailed as a way of allowing the government to reconcile its wish to spend more on capital investment with its commitment to keep a tight fiscal stance - by moving capital spending "off-balance sheet".

The first of these arguments remains strong. It is the second that has never quite held up. For the period covered by the Labour government's first comprehensive spending review (from April 1999 to March 2002) the PFI will account for about £11bn of investment or 14% of total publicly-sponsored capital spending. Is it really the case that this investment could not have taken place without the existence of the PFI (which Labour inherited from the Major government)?

In fact the treasury's fiscal rules could be easily satisfied without the PFI. By definition the golden rule adopted by Gordon Brown allows the government to borrow for investment and so automatically allows, for example, a hospital to be built using funds raised through conventional public borrowing rather than through the PFI.

Mr Brown's sustainable investment rule requires that the net ratio of public debt to national income should be below 40% of GDP over the economic cycle. What would have been the implications for this rule of abolishing PFI as part of the spending review in 1999, so that the £11bn of PFI capital spending over 1999-2002 had been replaced by normal public sector capital spending?

The answer is that the net debt-GDP ratio would still have fallen below 40% in 1999-2000. By the likely end of this parliament it would indeed have dropped to 36.4%. In other words, if PFI had been abolished and the same capital spending had been undertaken through normal public spending channels, the sustainable investment rule would have been satisfied along with the chancellor's golden rule. The treasury's new fiscal framework is entirely compatible with not having the PFI. Here is an initiative that turns out not to be necessary to secure prudent public finances.

An important point to emphasise is that under PFI the public sector is still left to pay for the assets being built and the services being provided. (Things are different if there is a dedicated stream of charges from the users of a new facility, such as a toll bridge, for example). A sequence of public payments has thus had to be set aside to meet the commitments resulting from PFI contracts. In 2004-5 the government will be spending £3.6bn a year servicing such contracts.

The national audit office has audited a number of PFI projects, asking whether they do offer the public value for its money. These seem to show that there are savings from PFI; future savings may total as much as 20% on aver age when compared with the public sector option. However, the NAO's audits include two PFI schemes involving big information technology investments.

If they are excluded, estimated savings fall to about 10%. This sort of level of savings was also arrived at by consultants Arthur Andersen in their report for the treasury's own PFI taskforce. When Arthur Andersen investigated a larger sample of PFI schemes, they found that an average saving of 17% might be achieved.

We thus have estimates for possible future savings from PFI ranging from 10 to 20%. From this we can calculate the "true" contribution of PFI to the public finances. On the basis that the government will be spending £3.6bn in 2004-5 to service PFI contracts, this much-vaunted initiative will turn out to yield savings to the taxpayer of between £360m and £720m a year (although this does not include gains achieved by avoiding cost overruns).

That is not as much as was hoped. That fact does not of course mean PFI is a bad idea, only that we need to be clear why we have it rather than alternatives. The rationale is not "off balance sheet" spending (it is not) but better value for public money spent - justified as part of a wider agenda for modernising and improving the quality of public services. Increasingly - in its defence - this is what the treasury itself has been emphasising.

Labour made changes to PFI, including guaranteeing that the pay and conditions of staff will not be harmed if they are transferred to private companies under PFI contracts. These are welcome. But the government should be more explicit about exactly why we have the PFI.

Since it is clear that the treasury now accepts much of the above why does chancellor Brown not make an explicit statement saying PFI is really about securing significant if not spectacular increments in the value of public spending on services? fields.headline: Lastminute flotation soars ahead
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com shares jumped ahead on their first day of trading on the stock market today, boosting the paper fortunes of the company's founders. The shares, placed at 380p, each leapt to 511p in the first hour of trading, boosting the value of the company from a starting point of £571m to £768m.
fields.body:
Lastminute.com shares jumped ahead on their first day of trading on the stock market today, boosting the paper fortunes of the company's founders. The shares, placed at 380p, each leapt to 511p in the first hour of trading, boosting the value of the company from a starting point of £571m to £768m.

The rise eased back to 492.5p by 1.40pm, but with 11m shares traded by 10.30am, lastminute.com was the stock market's second most popular share, behind perennial leader Vodafone.

The frenzy was compounded by a reduced share allocation which saw private investors make only modest profits. The 189,000 registered users of lastminute.com who applied for a stake in the fledgling company were each allowed only 35 shares. Each private investor's stake began the day worth £133 and rose to £178 in the first hour.

The jump added millions in value to the stakes in the company - which specialises in selling late-breaking deals in holidays, hotels and flights through its website - owned by its founders Martha Lane Fox, 27, and Brent Hoberman, 31. The rise raised the value of Ms Lane Fox's stake to just over £60m and Mr Hoberman's to £91m.

The jump in the share price was widely expected by City analysts, although many have raised doubts over the high valuation put on the business. It has been in existence for less than two years and has yet to make a penny profit.

Freeserve, which was the darling of the stock market when it floated at the beginning of last year, has subsequently seen its market value plummet. However it is still valued higher than its parent company, Dixons.

Ms Lane Fox said the response to the share offer was "overwhelming". She declined to comment directly on the valuation of the company, but said that the business would not be easy for a newcomer to copy. "We have 1,100 supplier relationships. These are individually negotiated deals, we are not just going into existing databases - that is what makes this very hard for anyone to replicate."

The company will raise £113.5m from the share issue, which would be used to expand the business, she said. "There will be more products and services, we'll be in more countries and we'll grow in digital TV and mobile phones." Lastminute.com is already available through Cable & Wireless Communications' digital TV service, and is soon to go live through cable company NTL. It also has deals with BT Cellnet and Orange. The latest technology in mobile phones, known as wireless application protocol (WAP), gives internet access available to mobile handsets.

As well as the UK, lastminute.com has websites for the French, German and Swedish market. Under the terms of the share issue Ms Lane Fox and Mr Hoberman are locked into the company for six months.

"Six months is the initial lock-up period, but obviously we are both here for the long term. It's far too early to comment on what we might do in the future," Ms Lane Fox said.

fields.headline: So much hot air
fields.standfirst: As heart operations fall for the first time in 25 years, Observer health editor Anthony Browne says Labour is failing the NHS
fields.trailText: You can almost feel the red faces in the department of health. Last week, after two years of preparation, the government launched a "crusade against heart disease". More money! More surgeons! More operations! More lives saved!
fields.body:
You can almost feel the red faces in the department of health. Last week, after two years of preparation, the government launched a "crusade against heart disease". More money! More surgeons! More operations! More lives saved!

A week later, no less a body than the Society of Cardiothoracic Surgeons reveals that in the real world, rather than the virtual world of spin, the government's biggest achievement in the treatment of heart disease has been to cut the number of heart operations for the first time since records began. For the last 25 years, the number of heart operations - such as life-saving bypass surgery - has been rising by around 1,000 a year. It took just two years of New Labour - self-proclaimed saviour of the NHS - to reverse that trend. Last year, the number of operations fell by around 500.

Confusingly, the department of health's own figures show a rise in the number of operations, but their statistics refer just to England, not the UK as a whole. When caught as red-handed as this, the only response has to be hands-up "mea culpa", will try harder.

These bland statistics matter more in a way than other data such as the length of waiting lists. Every heart operation gives hope to someone who goes to bed each night wondering whether they will wake up. Often they don't: thousands of people in Britain are waiting for heart surgery, and each year a large number of them die before they get to the operating table.

It is difficult to imagine anything more distressing than being told by your doctor that you have a life-threatening heart condition which requires immediate surgery - but that you must wait a year for an appointment. And even then, your operation may be cancelled on the day you turn up to hospital. Some heart patients wait more than 18 months for treatment.

Britain does far too few heart operations - around half the European average. Partly it is because we have far too few heart surgeons - far fewer than any other European country, when adjusted for population. The government is hoping to recruit more, and has given a little money for it.

But the report by the Society of Cardiothoracic Surgeons shows the problem is a lot deeper than that. The reason that the number of operations fell is not because the number of heart surgeons fell, but because each heart surgeon did less. In the words of the report's authors, they were left "twiddling their thumbs".

This enforced inactivity is because of the shortage of high-cost, high-maintenance intensive care beds. You can't do a heart operation and then just leave the patient on a trolley in the corridor.

The number of intensive care beds has fallen under Labour, as it did under the Tories. It's all in the name of "efficiency savings" which see empty beds as a waste of resources. At one point this winter, there was only one empty intensive care bed in the whole of the UK. That meant that all non-emergency operations had to be cancelled. Poor Maevis Skeet hit the headlines when the lack of beds meant her operation was cancelled so many times that her cancer became inoperable. Patients with life-threatening conditions were being driven hundreds of miles across the country in search of a bed - and sometimes they arrived dead.

So that is New Labour's modern NHS. The party elected on a promise to save the NHS is patently failing to do so. What it has delivered is endless spin. Like almost all health scare stories, what this boils down to is lack of money. In Britain we spend around half the amount on health care we need to. Until the shortfall is rectified - and whatever the wafflings of Gordon Brown and Tony Blair there is virtually no chance they will do so - this government's promises on the NHS - like last week's on heart disease - will be so much hot air.

fields.headline: Floating Lastminute.com
fields.standfirst: Mark Tran looks at Lastminute.com's extraordinary popularity
fields.trailText: Mark Tran explains Lastminute.com's extraordinary popularity
fields.body:
Unofficial trading today began in Lastminute.com, the UK's hottest internet company. The shares were floated at 380p, valuing the loss-making company at £571.3m - but had risen to 525p by mid-morning, making Lastminute.com worth £788m.

What is Lastminute.com?
The company is the brainchild of Brent Hoberman, who runs it with Martha Lane Fox. He came up with the idea in 1996 while working at a small internet consultancy in London. The concept is that people are too busy to plan ahead and so always arranged something at the last minute. He put the idea to Lane Fox, who pooh-poohed the idea at first. The pair eventually raised £600,000 from backers and launched in 1998.

How does Lastminute.com work?
The site gets "excess inventory", otherwise known as unsold aeroplane seats, hotel rooms or theatre tickets, and offers them at bargain prices over the web. It has about 800,000 registered users - a figure which is rising by about 30% per month - and has offices in London, Paris, Munich and Stockholm. Lane Fox has also said that efforts are being made to try and break into the US market.

How much money does it make?
Its revenues in the last quarter, which included the peak Christmas shopping season, totalled £409,000, but like many internet companies it is losing lots of money. Yet its share price makes it worth almost £1bn so there is something wildly out of kilter.

Why is Lastminute.com so popular?
Lastminute.com is Britain's version of Amazon.com in the US. Just as Amazon was the first internet company to hit public consciousness in the US so Lastminute has been the first to do so in the UK. This underlines the advantage of being first in the field, getting well-known, and building up the brand name to grab market share. Lastminute also happens to be at the right time in the right place. Its appearance coincided with the onset of internet fever in the UK in the last year and the arrival of US money looking for internet opportunities in Europe. Lastminute and other fledgling internet companies have benefited from this influx of cash. It also helps to have two young photogenic chief executives.

Isn't it risky to buy shares in a company that does not make money?
Investors have piled into companies like Amazon and Lastminute in the expectation that they will make money one day. The reasoning is that because they were first, they could dominate their markets. The problem is that a good internet idea is easy to copy. Cheap plane tickets can now be had from sites such as Easyjet, Ryanair and Go, so the bargains at Lastminute are no longer that terrific.

So is Lastminute heading for trouble?
Possibly. Another problem with Lastminute's present value, is that it will be hard for the company to make profits on a sufficient scale to warrant its current share price. Once investors realise this, Lastminute can expect to see its share price to drop. Thousands of car companies competed with each other, when cars first appeared on the market. Now only a handful exist, General Motors, Ford and DamilerChrysler, among them. Internet companies could go down the same road.

What happens when the bubble bursts?
The current frenzy for internet stocks has all the hallmarks of previous bubbles, rocketing share prices, all greed and no fear. All overheated markets eventually cool off in a hurry - the South Sea bubble in 1720, tulip mania in 17th century Holland and the Japanese stock market in the 1980s. Inevitably, there will be a shakeout of internet companies. The first companies to appear in a new market are not necessarily the most durable ones. Once shares tumble, internet companies are likely to be bought up by traditional companies like banks and similar "brick and mortar" entities.

webTitle: Souness takes the reins at Blackburn

fields.headline: Souness takes the reins at Blackburn
fields.trailText: Graeme Souness took over as manager of Blackburn Rovers today. The former Liverpool, Rangers and Southampton manager has signed a three-and-a-half-year deal at Ewood Park and starts with immediate effect.
fields.byline: By Football Unlimited staff and agencies
fields.body:
Graeme Souness took over as manager of Blackburn Rovers today. The former Liverpool, Rangers and Southampton manager has signed a three-and-a-half-year deal at Ewood Park and starts with immediate effect.

The 46-year-old, who will have previous Ewood boss Tony Parkes as his assistant, said: "This is a wonderful opportunity and just the sort of challenge I relish. I am delighted to be back in day-to-day management."

Rovers, who won the Premiership title in 1995, are currently languishing in eleventh place in the First Division. But Souness is confident he can return the Lancashire club to the big stage. "This club is geared for top-level football and has a proven record," he said. "My job is to help bring back the good times to Ewood Park and I can't wait to get started."

Confirming the appointment, Rovers owner Jack Walker said: "Graeme Souness is precisely the man we need and he can count on our full and unswerving support. There is a big job to be done here and I believe we have found the right man to do it."

Walker also praised the efforts of Parkes, adding: "I'm absolutely delighted that Tony is to stay on with us. Twice in recent seasons he has helped to guide us from the possible threat of relegation and done really well."

Souness was one of the finest all-round midfield players in world football. He won 54 caps for Scotland and enjoyed a glittering career with Middlesbrough, Liverpool and Sampdoria.

He became the first ever player-manager at Glasgow Rangers in 1986 and brought significant success to Ibrox - four successive League titles and four League Cup triumphs - before resigning in order to succeed Kenny Dalglish at Liverpool.

Souness never lived up to Anfield's expectations, however, and after a solitary FA Cup success, left the club to join Galatasaray of Turkey. In 1996-97 he returned to England to manage Southampton, but went abroad again with Italian clubs Torino and, most recently, Benfica.

But Souness is confident he can return the Lancashire club to the big stage. "This club is geared for top-level football and has a proven record," he said. "My job is to help bring back the good times to Ewood Park and I can't wait to get started." Confirming the appointment, Rovers owner Jack Walker said: "Graeme Souness is precisely the man we need and he can count on our full and unswerving support. There is a big job to be done here and I believe we have found the right man to do it." Walker also praised the efforts of Parkes, adding: "I'm absolutely delighted that Tony is to stay on with us. Twice in recent seasons he has helped to guide us from the possible threat of relegation and done really well." Souness was one of the finest all-round midfield players in world football. He won 54 caps for Scotland and enjoyed a glittering career with Middlesbrough, Liverpool and Sampdoria. He became the first ever player-manager at Glasgow Rangers in 1986 and brought significant success to Ibrox - four successive League titles and four League Cup triumphs - before resigning in order to succeed Kenny Dalglish at Liverpool. Souness never lived up to Anfield's expectations, however, and after a solitary FA Cup success, left the club to join Galatasaray of Turkey. In 1996-97 he returned to England to manage Southampton, but went abroad again with Italian clubs Torino and, most recently, Benfica.

fields.headline: Reward for willingness to listen, learn and act
fields.trailText: Are you happy with the service you receive from your bank, building society, insurance company, or investment company?
fields.body:
Are you happy with the service you receive from your bank, building society, insurance company, or investment company?

Do they listen to your complaints and respond to feedback or are you constantly complaining about small, but frustrating matters?

This year readers of the Guardian, Observer and Money Observer were able to reward those companies they felt were trying to listen and respond by voting for them in the Consumer Finance Awards.

These awards, which were announced at a ceremony in London on 14 March, were an opportunity for firms which showed the very best in customer service to be recognised. Voters were invited to respond to advertisements in each of the three publications and the results were collated.

In the articles in this special report, we explain exactly why we believe customer service is so important - and yet so difficult - for financial services companies, and profile the winners in each category.

fields.headline: Best unit trust/OEIC
fields.standfirst: Jupiter Unit Trust Managers
fields.trailText: The winner of the unit trust/OEICs category, Jupiter Unit Trust Managers, a division of Jupiter Asset Management, is the type of group that gives active management a good name. Not only has it turned £100 invested in its funds into an average of £361 over the past five years, it has also achieved better returns than its rivals over all intervening periods.
fields.body:
The winner of the unit trust/OEICs category, Jupiter Unit Trust Managers, a division of Jupiter Asset Management, is the type of group that gives active management a good name. Not only has it turned £100 invested in its funds into an average of £361 over the past five years, it has also achieved better returns than its rivals over all intervening periods.

Jupiter's fund management skills have won growing recognition in recent years among professionals and private investors alike. While it is best known for its large flagship funds - Income, UK Growth and European - its strengths are not restricted to these areas. Its range of funds has become increasingly diversified in recent years, but this has not diluted returns.

The secret of the group's success does not lie in strict management discipline. On the contrary, investment director Edward Bonham Carter is scathing about anything resembling a committee approach to investment or that stifles individual managers' initative. "That is not how you get outperformance," he says.

Now almost a household name among investors, it is hard to believe that just five years ago Jupiter Asset Management was barely known outside investment cognoscenti. Even more surprising perhaps is that a group which only this year celebrates its 13th birthday should currently be selling more Isas than most of its older established rivals put together.

Since its launch in 1985 it has gone from strength to strength. It has climbed the fund managers' league table, leaving other unit trust wannabes like Virgin Direct well behind. Currently in 17th position with some £4.4 billion under management, there seems little to stop it reaching the superleague alongside Fidelity and M&G within a few years.

Behind this progress lies Jupiter's stunning investment performance record. Even its rapid expansion in the last few years seems to have done little harm, with 85 per cent of its funds in the top quartile of their sectors since launch. Investment director Edward Bonham Carter's explanation of how this has been achieved sounds deceptively simple.

"The key factors have been attracting and keeping talented people, making sure one person is closely associated with the performance of a fund and still providing a team environment so that those talented individuals can discuss ideas constantly."

One of the ways the group gets the best out of all its fund managers is its policy of seeing as many companies as possible in its offices rather than going on the road. Several fund managers then at once sit down to grill them.

Bonham Carter explains: "First of all this approach is more time efficient. It means we can sometimes see three or four companies in a day. But more importantly, because everybody sees things in a different way, it means people will ask questions about what they are interested in - the financial side, the management and so on - and can then debate these matters with their colleagues."

Although an agreed position may be reached, whether individual managers decide to put a company in their funds or not is up to them. Managers are not left entirely to their own devices, however. Every two months, as a risk control mechanism, fund portfolios are monitored to ensure they do not have too many unquoteds or one big holding that is getting out of proportion.

Another aspect of the Jupiter approach is its flexible and pragmatic investment culture. Bonham Carter explains: "We don't focus rigidly on large or small companies or pursue a growth or value approach; we invest in what we think is right at the time. We look at where a company's growth is coming from, what the risks are and whether there are barriers to entry which will enable them to defend their profits."

In the end, though, he argues: "Fund management is an art. It is a subjective process." And this is, of course, where the talents of the individual managers come in.

fields.headline: Best share dealing service
fields.standfirst: Saga Sharedealing Service
fields.trailText: While the Charles Schwabs and Barclays Stockbrokers of the sharedealing world have been making all the headlines, Saga's stockbroking service has been quietly winning praise and custom from the over-50s franchise it has made its own. Its reward is first place in the best share dealing service category.
fields.body:
While the Charles Schwabs and Barclays Stockbrokers of the sharedealing world have been making all the headlines, Saga's stockbroking service has been quietly winning praise and custom from the over-50s franchise it has made its own. Its reward is first place in the best share dealing service category.

Launched three years ago as part of Saga's Investment Direct business, the Saga Sharedealing Service has enjoyed phenomenal year-on-year growth and has carried out more than £1bn in trades during the last 12 months.

"We spend a lot of time researching what our customers want," says Andrew Goodsell, managing director of Saga Services. "They told us they were unhappy with the service they were receiving from the banks and from independent financial advisers. We saw that Saga had a part to play in delivering those sorts of investment products.

"We looked at the stockbroking marketplace. Historically it has been a very complex marketplace dominated by men in stripy suits, and not everyone feels comfortable with that. There seemed to a lot of hoops to jump through, and the whole experience of sharedealing seemed pretty intimidating and jolly expensive.

"In contrast, there's a lot of trust in the Saga brand that makes our customers very comfortable with us. So we set out to create a service where it was easy to register. In terms of pricing, we've also made it one of the cheapest stockbroking services in the marketplace. Few of our customers have bad debts and therefore it isn't necessary to submit customers to the same rigorous and costly vetting process used by other sharedealing services."

To use the sharedealing service - which is offered in conjunction with clearing house Pershings - investors must be over the age of 50 and registered with Saga, but with a 5m customer database and a sizeable chunk of the population of ABC1s over the age of 50, there is plenty of headroom left for further growth.

"People over the age of 50 are becoming wealthier with pensions and inherited wealth and they are becoming increasingly comfortable with buying and selling shares," says Goodsell. "They like to read the papers each day and play the market.

"We have created a true affinity group here at Saga. There isn't a great deal of affinity with other stockbrokers, but our customers buy a whole range of services from us, from savings products to holidays.

"Customer service comes top of our list of priorities, and we are striving very hard to surprise and delight our customers, For example, we've launched a frequent traders service for customers who want to trade more regularly, offering them even keener prices."

Goodsell says Saga is also in the process of unveiling its own sharedealing internet site. "We plan to have a whole range of services with lots of interactive services such as research, information and portfolio management," he says. "We decided not to jump on to the internet band wagon too early. We're rabid about customer service and we wanted to get it right before we leapt in."

fields.headline: Best savings account
fields.standfirst: First Direct
fields.trailText: All that savers want from a savings account is a keen rate of interest. Right? Wrong, says David Mead, customer services director at First Direct, the winner of the best savings account provider category. "There will always be someone out there offering savings products with higher interest rates, but we believe savers want more than that - they want longer-term value," he says.
fields.body:
All that savers want from a savings account is a keen rate of interest. Right? Wrong, says David Mead, customer services director at First Direct, the winner of the best savings account provider category. "There will always be someone out there offering savings products with higher interest rates, but we believe savers want more than that - they want longer-term value," he says.

"We have a number of attractive savings products available, but we have done a lot of learning over the last few years and realised that part of the reason customers enjoy saving with us is because we have become better at holding conversations with them.

"It might start when one of our banking representative gets into a discussion with a customer who expresses an interest in savings products. The customer will then get the opportunity to talk with a savings representative. And eventually that might lead to a discussion with one of our financial planning representatives. The key is finding out what the customer's savings objective is, and we get into some great discussions with our customers about what is best suited to their needs."

First Direct places huge emphasis on product knowledge among its representatives - new recruits are given at least six weeks training before they are given the opportunity to speak to customers as banking representatives. And to join First Direct's team of 20 savings representatives, staff must have served at least two years as a banking representative.

"By the time they reach the position of savings representative, they will have a significant amount of knowledge about all our products," says Mead. "We empower our people. We don't script them and they are genuinely passionate about customer service.

"We're extremely careful in our recruitment policies. We use talented people who won't just be happy with a customer saying 'I want to open a savings account'. They will want to find out what that customer's savings objective is, rather than going for the easy option.

"We also like to be pro-active in helping to meet our customers' savings needs. If, for example we see a customer sitting with a significant current account balance we'll ring them up and see if they would like to put some of that money into an interest-paying savings account. We're constantly monitoring the financial affairs of our customers - even more than customers do themselves sometimes.

"We have always regarded savings products as a core part of our banking proposition. We acquire customers with cheque accounts but the savings account is one of the first ports of call. A very high proportion of our cheque account customers hold savings products with us too. We give them 24-hour banking and make moving money around accounts extremely easy.

"Our savings products are designed to be simple, transparent. The clarity of our literature is something we pride ourselves on. We're also fortunate in having a number of products that we can use from the HSBC (First Direct's parent) range such as the Household Names unit trust."

According to Mead, the next challenge will be integrating the new 50-strong financial planning team into each area of First Direct's operations. "It's one of the largest telephone-based financial planning teams in the UK and we want to have more discussions with customers about their savings, investment and protection needs. Our goal is to offer customers a completely integrated, holistic way of managing their finances."

fields.headline: Best personal pensions
fields.standfirst: Equitable Life Assurance Society
fields.trailText: The Equitable Life Assurance Society has won the award for best customer service in the personal pensions category.
fields.body:
The Equitable Life Assurance Society has won the award for best customer service in the personal pensions category.

Founded in 1762, the Equitable is the oldest mutual life office in the world and prides itself in being different from the majority of its rivals. As a mutual, it has no shareholders and is owned by its members, the with-profits policyholders.

It is unusual in never having paid commission to third parties for the introduction of new business. Instead it deals direct with its customers through its own highly trained sales force, made up of around 400 representatives based in 32 branches around the country, and also via its direct telephone service Equitable Direct.

"Our sales force is the most highly productive in the UK, bringing in an average of £6.4m in new business per year per head," says spokesman Alistair Dunbar. "They are able to deliver because of a combination of the high quality of our products, the strong performance of the business and the ongoing service of the customers."

Most new business is generated through recommendations from existing customers plus newspaper advertisements and the sales force usually follows up initial enquiries on a face to face basis at the customer's home or office. More straightforward queries or requests from existing customers may be dealt with over the phone or via the Internet. Using the Equitable On-line Client Service customers may, for example, switch investment holdings, change their contributions or make extra payments.

The Equitable Personal Pension Plan offers customers the choice of investment routes encompassing a with-profits fund and a range of 17 unit-linked funds from which they can pick any combination. The plan is notable for its low charges, its flexibility and, above all, its long term investment performance.

"Our focus is entirely upon giving our customers the best deal we can," Mr Dunbar says. "We run our personal pension plan at below the basic charges written into the contract so we've been enhancing benefits by putting money back into the policies. Our costs are a fraction of the industry's norms, which is reflected in our low charges and, therefore, our results."

Since 1974 the industry journal Planned Savings has monitored the investment performance of regular contribution with-profits personal pension plans maturing over different time periods. In the 60 performance tables published since the surveys began, the Equitable has appeared in the top 10 on 47 occasions, more times than any of its rivals.

The performance record of the Equitable's personal pension plan is also highlighted in annual pensions surveys by trade journal Money Management. It is one of only two companies to have gained a 5 Star "best buy personal pension" award on every occasion that these surveys have been run.

The flexibility of the plan stems from the fact that instead of being structured as an annual premium contract - as most personal pension plans are, where there is a requirement to pay fixed amounts every month - it is effectively structured as a series of recurrent single premium contracts. "This means that each premium buys its own separate piece of benefit so you can pay what you like when you like and not be penalised if you don't follow a set payment pattern," says Mr Dunbar.

Similarly, unlike many other plans, plan holders are able to retire when they choose, taking benefits as early as age 50 if they wish, without the need to give a pre-set retirement date and without any financial penalty. "This flexibility aids our continuing drive for simplicity and transparency, making products as easy as possible to understand," Mr Dunbar says.

fields.headline: Best mortgages
fields.standfirst: Standard Life Bank
fields.trailText: Standard Life Bank has won the award for best customer service in the mortgages category.
fields.body:
Standard Life Bank has won the award for best customer service in the mortgages category.

The bank was launched in January 1998 as a wholly owned telephone bank subsidiary of Europe's largest mutual life insurance company Standard Life and now claims to be Britain's fastest growing bank.

After starting out with competitive savings products, the bank launched its first mortgage product Freestyle - one of the new breed of flexible mortgages - in January 1999.

Freestyle's popularity has been such, particularly among remortgagers, that within the first year the bank completed £4.1bn worth of mortgage business, acquiring 10,000 borrowers, and took 11.4% of net new lending in the market.

"Freestyle has been so successful because it's an excellent, flexible, easy to understand product that suits virtually all needs," says the bank's managing director Neil Ross. "It's very much a straightforward, single product so customers aren't confused by variation and it offers a very competitive interest rate."

With a standard variable rate of 6.75% and a discounted rate of 6.06% for the first six months of the mortgage (rates correct at time of going to press), there are neither arrangement fees nor compulsory insurance fees attached to Freestyle mortgages, which can be from £25,001-£300,000, maximum 90% loan-to-value. A further incentive for new borrowers is free legal fees if they use the bank's panel of lawyers or £200 towards fees charged by their own solicitor.

Freestyle's main claim to flexibility comes from the fact that the borrower can choose to overpay by lump sum or increased monthly payments whenever they like without penalty after the first year. So those who receive bonuses or lump sum windfalls can reduce their outstanding loan immediately. And because interest is calculated on a daily basis, they receive the immediate benefit of any overpayment.

On the other side of the flexibility coin, when there's a blip in a borrower's cashflow, they can ease their financial burden by opting to take up to two months' payment holidays each year (after six consecutive monthly payments).

Freestyle loans are made by the bank on the basis of 'affordability' tests rather than income multiples, which means customers may be offered more than they actually need to borrow at the time. In this case, the surplus remains available for drawdown at any time in the future with no extra hassle or charges.

In other words you can borrow whenever you like at the standard mortgage rate to fund major expenses like holidays, cars and home improvements. Overpayments are also available for drawdown at any time.

When someone rings the call centre to apply for a mortgage, they get through to a trained and experienced member of staff who asks them about their mortgage needs, the property, their income and outgoings, and carries out initial credit checks while they are chatting.

"We aim to reach the conditional offer stage after eight to nine minutes on the phone," says Mr Ross, "And we reckon on turning about 30% of calls into mortgages." The mortgage advance then comes through within about a month, allowing time for any further financial health checks to be made.

Apart from the attractiveness of the product and the simplicity and speed of the application process, the third important element from a customer services point of view is the quality of the bank's call centre staff.

"We use psychometric tests when selecting staff to pick out people-oriented people who get a buzz out of dealing with customers over the phone and we train them well so that they know the products inside out," Mr Ross says. "We aim to pick up on 100% of calls within six rings and are consistently hitting 98% which means people aren't left hanging on the line."

Since winning the award with Freestyle, Standard Life Bank has recently launched two new mortgage products, a fixed-rate loan and Freestyle Plus, a hybrid allowing customers to mix and match fixed and variable rates on portions of their loan. The bank is also promising to offer an internet mortgage application route later this year.

Freestyle's popularity has been such, particularly among remortgagers, that within the first year the bank completed £4.1bn worth of mortgage business, acquiring 10,000 borrowers, and took 11.4% of net new lending in the market. "Freestyle has been so successful because it's an excellent, flexible, easy to understand product that suits virtually all needs," says the bank's managing director Neil Ross. "It's very much a straightforward, single product so customers aren't confused by variation and it offers a very competitive interest rate." With a standard variable rate of 6.75% and a discounted rate of 6.06% for the first six months of the mortgage (rates correct at time of going to press), there are neither arrangement fees nor compulsory insurance fees attached to Freestyle mortgages, which can be from £25,001-£300,000, maximum 90% loan-to-value. A further incentive for new borrowers is free legal fees if they use the bank's panel of lawyers or £200 towards fees charged by their own solicitor. Freestyle's main claim to flexibility comes from the fact that the borrower can choose to overpay by lump sum or increased monthly payments whenever they like without penalty after the first year. So those who receive bonuses or lump sum windfalls can reduce their outstanding loan immediately. And because interest is calculated on a daily basis, they receive the immediate benefit of any overpayment. On the other side of the flexibility coin, when there's a blip in a borrower's cashflow, they can ease their financial burden by opting to take up to two months' payment holidays each year (after six consecutive monthly payments). Freestyle loans are made by the bank on the basis of 'affordability' tests rather than income multiples, which means customers may be offered more than they actually need to borrow at the time. In this case, the surplus remains available for drawdown at any time in the future with no extra hassle or charges. In other words you can borrow whenever you like at the standard mortgage rate to fund major expenses like holidays, cars and home improvements. Overpayments are also available for drawdown at any time. When someone rings the call centre to apply for a mortgage, they get through to a trained and experienced member of staff who asks them about their mortgage needs, the property, their income and outgoings, and carries out initial credit checks while they are chatting. "We aim to reach the conditional offer stage after eight to nine minutes on the phone," says Mr Ross, "And we reckon on turning about 30% of calls into mortgages." The mortgage advance then comes through within about a month, allowing time for any further financial health checks to be made. Apart from the attractiveness of the product and the simplicity and speed of the application process, the third important element from a customer services point of view is the quality of the bank's call centre staff. "We use psychometric tests when selecting staff to pick out people-oriented people who get a buzz out of dealing with customers over the phone and we train them well so that they know the products inside out," Mr Ross says. "We aim to pick up on 100% of calls within six rings and are consistently hitting 98% which means people aren't left hanging on the line." Since winning the award with Freestyle, Standard Life Bank has recently launched two new mortgage products, a fixed-rate loan and Freestyle Plus, a hybrid allowing customers to mix and match fixed and variable rates on portions of their loan. The bank is also promising to offer an internet mortgage application route later this year.

fields.headline: Best investment trust
fields.standfirst: Dresdner RCM Global Investors
fields.trailText: For an unprecedented third year running, the winner of the investment trust category - judged by the average net asset value return of all eligible trusts over five years - is Dresdner RCM Global Investors.
fields.body:
For an unprecedented third year running, the winner of the investment trust category - judged by the average net asset value return of all eligible trusts over five years - is Dresdner RCM Global Investors.

The group has built up a strong investment process and backed this up with good use of gearing. Its larger trusts have been in strong sectors such as Europe, the UK or International, whereas its only Pacific Basin exposure has been through a small emerging markets trust.

Having 37,000 people keep an eye out for investment opportunities undoubtedly helps the group stay a step ahead of the competition and the market. Dresdner's 'Grassroots Network' of contacts acts as a sounding board for the group's industry-based research specialists. Simon White, who has headed investment trust operations since 1992, says it has been invaluable in alerting the group early to opportunities in technology-related sectors.

"In a fast-moving environment, it allows us to talk to those actually using the new technologies and avoid becoming either over-exuberant or missing the picture. It is a way of challenging analysts' perceptions," he says. Towards the end of last year, reveals White, the group was top-slicing many of its most successful holdings and reinvesting the proceeds in companies that had not yet caught the market's attention.

White claims Dresdner RCM is not dogmatically growth-oriented and has recently been assessing sectors such as oils and mining. In addition, the group's early recognition of the telecom revolution worked wonders for a number of its trusts last year.

White says much of the credit for the group's success is due to Stuart Fowler and his pan-European team. He says the London-based team also benefits greatly from a morning briefing from the team in the Far East and an evening call to the US team. "It is a continuous exchange of views that really does produce benefits," he says.

The group has also done well because its largest and most successful trusts are in areas that have been buoyant over the past five years. Its lack of Far East exposure could become a disadvantage if Japan does as well as White expects.

However, the group has limited its recent trust launches to endowment policy trusts and one split-capital trust. White is wary of launching further splits given the high hurdle rates and complicated structures required to compete on yields.

Dresdner is an enthusiastic supporter of the 'its' campaign and is backing it up with strong marketing. It has also been active in share buy-backs.

Despite the loss of two high-profile trusts in 1996 and 1998, White has steered Dresdner's investment trust interests on to a sound footing, and he is backed by a stable management team.

There appears little reason why the group should not win mandates from some of its less successful competitors or launch an investment trust pension fund to widen the market for some large, liquid and well-managed trusts.

fields.headline: Best independent financial advisers
fields.standfirst: Co-operative Bank Financial Advisers
fields.trailText: Co-operative Bank Financial Advisers (CBFA), a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Co-operative Bank, are the outright winners of the award for best customer service in the independent financial advisers (IFAs) category.
fields.body:
Co-operative Bank Financial Advisers (CBFA), a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Co-operative Bank, are the outright winners of the award for best customer service in the independent financial advisers (IFAs) category.

CBFA has been going in its current form for 11 years and is the bank's only means of promoting regulated financial services to its customers and others. Unlike its high street rivals, which all have a tied advisory or bank assurance operation promoting the investment, life and pensions products of just one supplier, the Co-op has gone the independent advisory route.

The 75 IFAs working around the country for CBFA do not sell Co-op Bank products, but offer a full financial planning service recommending the best products from across the whole spectrum of the market to suit a client's individual's needs.

CBFA's services are available to anyone though, historically, the majority of clients are Co-op Bank customers who come through branch and telephone banking referrals. Its concentration of advisers tend to mirror geographically the locations of the Co-op Bank, so they are strongest in the north-east, north-west, the Midlands and south Wales.

"We offer a very good service from highly trained individuals," says CBFA managing director David Cox. "They are all recruited from within the industry and we insist they have the top level (Level 3) Financial Planning Certificate plus a minimum of two to three years experience."

CBFA advisers work on a two-stage basis. When a new client contacts CBFA, an initial face-to-face, fact-finding meeting is set up for them within a few days at their home, office or the nearest Co-op bank branch.

At this free introductory meeting, which can take up to two hours, the IFA collects all the mandatory information about the client's finances which enable them to go away and come up with future financial planning recommendations.

Reflecting the parent bank's famed ethical investment philosophy, a fundamental part of CBFA's financial planning questionnaire asks customers whether they want an ethical slant on their investments.

"Around 50% go for that and every one of our IFAs is able to advise on ethical investments," Mr Cox says. "I think the fact that we offer the opportunity to invest ethically is very important to many of our clients and is one thing that makes us different from other IFA groups."

It's also clearly explained at this first meeting that clients can choose to pay for their future advice on a set fee basis, a commission basis where the IFA will take a commission on any regulated product the client buys, or a combination of both. "Some 90% of our clients go for commission basis because that way, if they decide not to go ahead with our recommendations, they know they won't be out of pocket," Mr Cox says.

The adviser then takes the information gathered and gives the client a guarantee that they will be back within 10 working days with their recommendations.

"The philosophy is to offer a full financial planning service, which means getting enough information to be able to recommend what we believe the client needs and not what he perceives he needs," Mr Cox says.

"If, for example, a client comes to us with £20,000 to invest, but has a young family and no life cover, we will recommend that he puts part of the money into family protection products. And part of our financial planning policy dictates that a certain proportion of people's savings must be in emergency instant-access deposits."

This award backs recent CBFA market research findings which found that 90% of its customers were "very or quite satisfied" with its service. When asked about the most important factor influencing their decision to deal with CBFA, 31% said it was because the advice given was independent, 30% because it was part of the Co-operative Bank and 19% because of the bank's ethical policy.

fields.headline: Best financial services website
fields.standfirst: Fidelity
fields.trailText: Fidelity, the UK's largest independent seller of equity-based ISAs and second largest unit trust/OEIC manager with a range of 35 onshore funds, has won the award for best customer service on a financial services internet site.
fields.body:
Fidelity, the UK's largest independent seller of equity-based ISAs and second largest unit trust/OEIC manager with a range of 35 onshore funds, has won the award for best customer service on a financial services internet site.

Worldwide, Fidelity is the largest independent fund management organisation with over £536bn under management for more than 15m clients. It was set up in the UK in 1979, becoming the first company to go into the Pep market in 1987 and, later, one of the first to offer Isas.

Fidelity launched its website in 1996, since which time it has been revised several times with the aim of making it increasingly comfortable for customers to find their way around and use to make transactions quickly and efficiently.

Executive director Paul Kafka says: "Our aim has always been to convince customers that their business is best handled through Fidelity. To achieve that we have invested heavily for the past seven years in technology, more recently in internet technology and that commitment is ongoing. It's an essential part of building trust between us and the customers. We are huge believers that the internet is the key to giving customers the power to control their own finances both now and in the future and our objective is to achieve that more and more comprehensively."

An important point of change for Fidelity and its customers was April 6 last year when the government, for the first time, gave the go ahead for investors to open and operate Isas by electronic signature. Now individual investors can open an Isa from scratch via Fidelity's website and, thereafter, access and operate their account 24 hours a day, seven days a week using its state-of-the-art WebXpress Service.

"This facility allows customers to control their investment portfolio online, effectively letting them set up their own individual website," Mr Kafka says. "They can, for example, analyse their portfolio, breaking it down by sector geographically or by asset type, do 'what if' scenarios, switch funds, top up their investments and withdraw funds."

On the security front, Mr Kafka says the encryption system Fidelity employs on its website is the most secure on the market. "You are more secure making investments with plastic cards over the web with us than you are, for example, giving your card number over the phone to buy cinema or theatre tickets."

The Fidelity site also gives customers access to online educative texts explaining the basics of Isas, building a portfolio and so on. Customers also check the price of any fund in the market through the FundScope facility.

The latest project is to launch a one-stop-shop Investment Supermarket via the site later this year where investors will be able to review funds across the whole market, buying and selling online as they wish with a discount on unit purchases.

Around 30,000 of Fidelity's 1m UK customers now operate their accounts online and that number is growing fast with one in five Isas now opened online. Behind the scenes, some 1,100 staff in systems and customer support serve Fidelity's web-based customers.

"Everything we've done technologically speaking, we have done before our competitors," Mr Kafka says. "We've tried to raise the technological standard across the market place and we've tried to stay ahead in terms of simplicity of language, design and ease of making transactions."

fields.headline: Best current account
fields.standfirst: First Direct
fields.trailText: Most banks find it difficult to get excited about such a bread-and-butter product as a cheque account. But for First Direct - the winner of the best current account provider category - cheque accounts are not just core to its business, but a vital means of establishing a relationship with its customers.
fields.body:
Most banks find it difficult to get excited about such a bread-and-butter product as a cheque account. But for First Direct - the winner of the best current account provider category - cheque accounts are not just core to its business, but a vital means of establishing a relationship with its customers.

"Some of our success is due to the appeal of our brand and people like associating themselves with a modern, futuristic brand like First Direct," says commercial director Peter Simpson. "But cheque accounts are at the heart of our business - a mechanism for us to deal with our customers every day, and we've developed all our infrastructures around the cheque account.

"Cheque accounts are a bit like the wiring in your house. You have to have it but it's also got to work effectively and efficiently."

According to Simpson, operating an effective and efficient cheque account service can be extremely complex. "If you think about all the transactions which have to be processed every day, the humble cheque account is a much more complex product than savings, mortgages or credit cards."

However, the key factor which differentiates the First Direct cheque account from others, says Simpson, is how staff interact with customers. "There is something about the conversations we have with our customers. We employ around 4,000 people here and visitors say there is a buzz about the place. We have created a culture which people seem to enjoy and that comes across on the phone - a little sparkle with the customer.

"We have very little scripting in our call centre, and our representatives can see a total picture of our customers - we call it totally integrated customer services.

"We also try to respond to the mood of the customer - if they seem to be in a hurry, we won't keep them back. If they are chilled out on a Sunday night we'll respond in a similar manner. It's these soft issues which are important with customers.

"We are currently changing our internet interfaces, but we intend to put some personality into the service. We don't envisage interfaces being purely screen-focused. We still want people to speak to us."

Simpson also believes it's time to develop the cheque account further if customers are to continue receiving the quality of product and service they have come to expect.

"Our cheque account was very innovative 10 years ago when it was the first to offer an overdraft buffer, but while our prices are OK, I'm not mad about our unauthorised overdraft charges or credit interest. The time for any organisation to invest in its products is when they're doing well, so we'll be addressing those issues soon."

fields.headline: Best car and home insurance
fields.standfirst: Churchill
fields.trailText: The 2,500 employees at Churchill, the UK's second biggest direct insurer, will be pleased, but maybe not altogether surprised, to win the award for best customer service in the car and home insurance category.
fields.body:
The 2,500 employees at Churchill, the UK's second biggest direct insurer, will be pleased, but maybe not altogether surprised, to win the award for best customer service in the car and home insurance category.

"We are genuinely passionate about customer service here. It has always been the highest thing on our agenda," says company spokesperson Kay Gorman. "Our aim is to deliver the unquestioned, publicly acknowledged best customer service in the insurance industry and we are very, very dedicated to that."

Chief executive Martin Long, who started Churchill in June 1989, set the company tenet from day one: not just to satisfy customers, but to delight them. "Following that philosophy through has paid off. It means staff always question whether something can be done better and go that step further to help. If, for example, an assistant says they will phone a customer back within 48 hours, they'll aim to 'delight' the customer by calling back sooner than expected. Or if, say, a customer needs a Green Card or insurance certificate urgently, we'll e-mail the whole company to see if anyone can drop it off that day on their way home," Ms Gorman says.

Churchill, one of the first telephone-based direct insurers, started off with 89 staff selling just car insurance direct to the public. A year later it added home insurance to its product range and, more recently, travel and pet insurance. Now, with 1.35m policyholders, two-thirds with motor and a third with household policies, it is the sixth largest motor insurer and 17th largest home insurer.

It has 1,400 customer service assistants manning the phones at its main call centre in Bromley, Kent and a further 300 at its new call centre in Teeside. On the motor and home insurance front, the company underwrites the business itself and deals with all administration and claims in-house, keeping responses as speedy as possible.

As the company has developed, it has scored a number of firsts. It was the first to provide a total telephone claims system. "All you have to do is make one call, quote your policy number and we deal with everything else from there, whether it be organising repairs, informing the police, advising third parties or replacing damaged or stolen goods," Ms Gorman says. "It is all dealt with very quickly. If, for example, something really disastrous happens to a customer's home so they can't live in it, we guarantee to re-house them within three hours."

Churchill was also the first motor insurer to set up its own network of accident and repair centres around the country, which deal with repair and accident referrals within a 50 mile radius. When a customer calls in with a claim, the assistant will automatically e-mail or fax the nearest centre which in turn contacts the customer and makes all necessary arrangements within 24 hours. This includes fulfilling the guarantee to supply every customer with a courtesy car while his or her car is being repaired - another company first.

Key to the company's customer service philosophy is the internal motto of 'SYNN' which stands for, 'say yes, not no'. "For example, up to 20% of our calls asking for a motor quote are deemed too high a risk by our computer system which will generate a 'no quote'," Ms Gorman says.

"But our staff won't automatically accept the computer's verdict and say 'no' to a high risk customer. They are empowered to query this, look further and try to find a valid reason for saying yes." Staff can also transfer calls from very high risk customers straight through to Anglia Countrywide, a telebroker company dealing with non-standard risks which Churchill bought 18 months ago. "This means we can help everyone who phones us in some way."

Other feathers in Churchill's customer service cap include a Plain English Society Crystal Award for its customer literature and a British Standards award for customer service.

"It is all dealt with very quickly. If, for example, something really disastrous happens to a customer's home so they can't live in it, we guarantee to re-house them within three hours." Churchill was also the first motor insurer to set up its own network of accident and repair centres around the country, which deal with repair and accident referrals within a 50 mile radius. When a customer calls in with a claim, the assistant will automatically e-mail or fax the nearest centre which in turn contacts the customer and makes all necessary arrangements within 24 hours. This includes fulfilling the guarantee to supply every customer with a courtesy car while his or her car is being repaired - another company first. Key to the company's customer service philosophy is the internal motto of 'SYNN' which stands for, 'say yes, not no'. "For example, up to 20% of our calls asking for a motor quote are deemed too high a risk by our computer system which will generate a 'no quote'," Ms Gorman says. "But our staff won't automatically accept the computer's verdict and say 'no' to a high risk customer. They are empowered to query this, look further and try to find a valid reason for saying yes." Staff can also transfer calls from very high risk customers straight through to Anglia Countrywide, a telebroker company dealing with non-standard risks which Churchill bought 18 months ago. "This means we can help everyone who phones us in some way." Other feathers in Churchill's customer service cap include a Plain English Society Crystal Award for its customer literature and a British Standards award for customer service.

webTitle: Police build photo database of missing children

fields.headline: Police build photo database of missing children
fields.trailText: Computer-ageing technologies will be used to help trace some of the 100,000 British children who run away from home each year, the Metropolitan police announced today.
fields.body:
Computer-ageing technologies will be used to help trace some of the 100,000 British children who run away from home each year, the Metropolitan police announced today.

Their photographs are to be displayed on www.missingkids.co.uk in an effort to improve international co-operation. They will include aged photos of Ben Needham, who disappeared on the Greek island of Kos in 1991 when he was 21 months old.

About 400 missing British children are expected to be shown on the site within six months, and photographs of more than 1,700 children from Europe and north and south America are already online. Visitors can search by region and by filling in details of the child's age, height, hair colour and other physical traits.

Detective superintendent Ian Brown, head of the Met's missing person's bureau, said: "One of the big advantages [of the database] to us is for parental abductions, because before you had to go through rigorous procedures to get that information circulated."

The vast majority of the children on the site would be either runaways or children who had been abducted by one parent, he said. Staff would produce pictures showing what babies were likely to look like years later, by analysing photographs and their family's physical traits.

According to the Children's Society, one in nine children spend at least one night away from home without permission by the time they are 16. Girls are more likely to run away, but boys are more likely to sleep rough and face a greater risk of assault.

webTitle: A war of words will not end the killing

fields.headline: A war of words will not end the killing
fields.standfirst: Former foreign editor Simon Tisdall analyses the latest US spat over gun control
fields.trailText: Former foreign editor Simon Tisdall analyses the latest US spat over gun control
fields.body:
The fierce spat between President Bill Clinton and US gun-lovers will not impress election-year voters or have much impact on the appalling death toll on America's streets and increasingly, in its schools.

Mr Clinton clashed with the National Rifle Association - the main pro-gun lobby - after the NRA's executive vice-president, Wayne LaPierre, accused him on Sunday of deliberately tolerating gun violence. Mr Clinton and Al Gore, the Democrats' chosen candidate in this November's presidential poll, were "willing to accept a certain level of killing to further [their] political agenda," he claimed. In Wayne's world, it is people, not guns, who pose the menace to public safety. And anyway, argues the NRA, existing gun control laws are not fully enforced.

An angry Mr Clinton replied that he was "just trying to keep more people alive... The NRA's main mission in life seems to be to stop any kind of collective action that will help us keep guns out of the hands of criminals and children." In Bill's world, the Republican-controlled congress, heavily lobbied by the NRA, is at fault for refusing to enact legislation designed to restrict firearms availability.

The NRA's central charge against the White House is insulting and unfair. But in a broad sense, both Mr LaPierre and Mr Clinton are right. In a society which tolerates, indeed encourages, state-sanctioned violence, it is difficult to persuade people that guns are not a legitimate form of self-defence in the hands of responsible individuals (as the US constitution avers).

Since 1976, when the supreme court reinstated the death penalty, more than 600 people have been executed in the US. Approximately 3,600 languish on death row. Despite a protest campaign led by Amnesty International, roughly 75% of Americans still back capital punishment.

George Bush, the Republican candidate this November, has led the way in sanctioning judicial killings. In Texas, where Mr Bush is governor, 120 people have been put to death since he took office in 1995. Mr Gore also favours the death penalty.

The sometimes extreme gun violence portrayed on American television; and incidents such as that in New York - where an unarmed man was gunned down recently in a hail of 19 bullets fired by police who were later acquitted of wrongdoing - also indirectly accustom and condition the public to use of guns. When it comes to controlling and renouncing violence, most US states, most law enforcers, and most of America's national leaders, set a poor example.

But Mr Clinton is right, too. Although he has done little of any practical import to encourage gun control in his eight years in office, congress has been sitting on a modest set of proposals to impose some limits (restricting gun show sales and introducing child-proof safety triggers) since last year. The prime reason for congressional inaction lies with the support, financial and electoral, which many members receive from the gun lobby.

In the meantime, there have been tragedies such as the recent fatal shooting in Michigan of a six-year-old girl, Kayla Rolland, by a same-age classmate. Asked why he did it, her assailant said: "Well, that kinda thing happens on TV." Everybody deplores such horrors; but nothing much changes.

Violence, official and unofficial, is endemic in US society. To eradicate it will take an effort of will by all Americans. Gun control is becoming a hot issue in this year's presidential campaign. Voters should also apply pressure to those running for the senate and the house of representatives. Reform demands a change of heart across the board - including making the connection with America's continuing, shaming use of the death penalty.

A war of words between the president and the NRA may grab the headlines. But it will not end the killing.

fields.headline: Business as usual
fields.standfirst: The flotation of Lastminute.com proceeded smoothly, writes financial editor Paul Murphy. Now the real work begins
fields.trailText: In the event, it was nothing much out of the ordinary. After months of hype and anticipation, in the face of warning after warning that this could be the one to prick the so-called dot.com bubble, share trading in the online retailer Lastminute.com finally kicked off this morning.
fields.body:
In the event, it was nothing much out of the ordinary. After months of hype and anticipation, in the face of warning after warning that this could be the one to prick the so-called dot.com bubble, share trading in the online retailer Lastminute.com finally kicked off this morning.

The stock market did not crash. Stockbrokers did not find their websites and phone switchboards jammed by thousands of frenzied speculators. In fact, it was very much like any other day on the London stock market.

As expected, shares in Lastminute - which began offering cheap flights on the web before branching out to selling everything from chocolates to theatre tickets to panic purchases - went up. Against a flotation price of 380p, the shares were trading at 520p by mid-morning, valuing this 19-month-old company at a cool £680m.

This might have been considered a disappointment when the "grey market" operated by financial spread betting firms was suggesting until today that Lastminute might be worth £1bn once dealing got under way. But a first morning premium of 40% will probably be considered the perfect price move by Lastminute's financial advisers, the US investment bank Morgan Stanley. It is not so high that the media start banging on about greedy investors and not so low that market pundits begin questioning whether Lastminute.com really is the quite the extraordinary investment it was cracked up to be.

The only disappointment was for the 250,000 private investors who applied for shares in the flotation. A quarter of the company - 33m shares - was being offered for sale, and the bulk of these shares were destined for the big institutional investors, such as pension funds.

Usually in such cases of huge oversubscription, when a company joining the stock market suddenly captures the public's imagination, investors' applications go into a ballot so that just a portion of applicants each get a reasonable number of shares.

Lastminute wanted to avoid going down this road, worried that disappointed investors would become disaffected customers of the website. But trying to keep everyone happy means that each of the 250,000 applicants is receiving just 35 shares. These were worth £133 at the flotation price and £182 at lunchtime today.

As for the founders of the business, 31-year-old Brent Hoberman and Martha Lane Fox, 27, their own paper wealth now stands at around £300m - although from the slightly forced professionalism the two entrepreneurs were showing this morning as they faced the TV cameras, the money has not changed them too dramatically just yet.

Their job - justifying the £680m stock market value placed on a business which turned over little more than £400,000 last year - has only just begun.

webTitle: Proof that knowledge is good for the brain

fields.headline: Proof that knowledge is good for the brain
fields.standfirst: NetNotes on brainy cabbies
fields.trailText: It's official. London taxi drivers have The Knowledge, and they have bigger brains because of it.
fields.body:
It's official. London taxi drivers have The Knowledge, and they have bigger brains because of it.

London researchers report today in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences - a prestige-laden US journal - that they scanned the brains of 16 right-handed London cabbies and found that in all cases, the size of a region of the brain called the hippocampus was millimetres larger than in a comparable group of 50 ordinary righthanded men who did not drive cabs

The hippocampus is closely associated with spatial memory - where the brain keeps its maps. London taxidrivers, famous for knowing routes between thousands of places in the city, spend two years assembling a detailed map which they file away in the memory.

"The hippocampus is where we store the things we consciously remember. As part of that, we would include navi gation. We know in animals that navigation and the hippocampus are intimately linked. So, it would seem now, is the human hippocampus," said Eleanor Maguire, of the institute of neurology at University College, London.

Tests with rats, squirrels and birds had shown that if the hippocampus is damaged, the creature can no longer find its way around.

Ordinary mortals too have shown that they use the hippocampus to find their way around. But the brains of London taxi drivers grew to accommodate the gazetteer of a whole city. The better they knew their way around, the bigger the hippocampus.

"The taxi drivers have an inordinate amount of knowledge. They have a really elaborate map of a very large city which they are using con stantly and that, it would seem, has impacted upon the distribution of grey matter in the hippocampus," Dr Maguire said.

"What we did was look at the amount of time spent as a taxi driver and then looked at a brain scan. We found a significant correlation, in that the posterior of back part of the hippocampus increased in size. The longer you were a taxi driver the bigger it got."

The researchers had previously placed volunteer drivers in scanners, quizzed them on the best routes around London, and watched the brain fire up. This time, they simply invited them to lie back - silently - and have their gray matter measured by two different techniques.

"They are an excellent group of people to study," she said. "They have already acquired a vast amount of spatial information. It's the kind of study you can only do in this city, because taxi drivers elsewhere aren't licensed in the same way."

fields.headline: Brainy cabbies
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about clever drivers on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about clever drivers on the net
fields.body:
1. London cabbies have bigger brains than the rest of us, according to American science journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

2. Navigating the metropolis gives the grey matter such a workout that brain scans of 16 cabbies showed that, in all cases, they had a brain physically bigger than 50 ordinary men who do not drive taxis.

3. So after years of maintaining that they know it all, (especially when one of their number, Fred Housego, won the quiz game Mastermind) now it seems that they really do.

4. Their expertise comes from an enhanced hippocampus, a region of the brain where maps are kept.

5. Cabbies spend two years learning The Knowledge: to get an all-London licence they need to have a detailed knowledge of the 25,000 streets in a six-mile radius of Charing Cross, with a more general knowledge of the major arterial routes throughout the rest of London.

6. For the written exam, the regulatory office demands that London's 20,000 cabbies know direct routes around the inner London boroughs and every restaurant, hospital, railway station, etc. in that area too.

7. The exams were introduced in 1851 following the Great Exhibition in Hyde Park, when drivers were severely criticised for not knowing where they were going.

8. Today, the London cabbie is a perfect synthesis of man and machine. Not only do they know every side street and hotel, but their vehicles are so manoeuvrable they can turn a complete circle in just over seven metres.

9. And the longer you're a taxi driver, says Eleanor Maguire, one of the researchers, the more your brain grows.

10. So how big's your hippocampus? Take the test to see if you have the knowledge.
