webTitle: Serb genocide trial starts in the Hague

fields.headline: Serb genocide trial starts in the Hague
fields.trailText: The Bosnian Serb general accused of leading the 1995 Srebrenica massacre went on trial yesterday, charged with genocide.
fields.body:
The Bosnian Serb general accused of leading the 1995 Srebrenica massacre went on trial yesterday, charged with genocide.

"Atrocities on a scale not seen since the second world war" were committed when at least 7,500 Muslims were slaughtered in what was meant to be a UN safe haven, the Hague war crimes tribunal was told by the prosecution.

General Radislav Krstic, 52, is the most senior officer to stand trial at the international criminal tribunal for former Yugoslavia.

"This is a case about the triumph of evil, about men who professed to be professional soldiers [who] organised, planned and willingly participated in the genocide, or stood silent in the face of it," the UN prosecutor, Mark Hamon, told the judges from Portugal, Egypt and the US. "Thousands of civilians who had laid down their arms were systematically murdered by the Bosnian Serb army and the accused."

Photographs submitted as evidence showed corpses, a skull wrapped in a blindfold and a victim's wrists tied with a metal wire.

Gen Krstic, commander of the Drina Corps, was promoted to general soon after the fall of Srebrenica, a UN-designated "safe area", in July 1995. He was seized by Nato troops in December 1998, and has denied all charges.

Thousands of Muslim men and boys were executed in an operation requiring 50 to 60 buses, fuel, detention centres, hundreds of guards, blindfolds, ligatures and heavy digging equipment.

Wearing a grey jacket, black shirt and tie, Gen Krstic appeared to listen unmoved to the five-hour hearing as Mr Hamon described how Serb forces entered the enclave, which was guarded by 100 lightly armed Dutch peacekeepers.

"The victors abandoned all sense of humanity and committed atrocities on a scale not seen since the second world war," Mr Hamon said, adding that 7,574 people were still listed as missing, presumed dead. Forensic experts have exhumed 1,800 corpses, while 2,500 more remain in mass graves.

"The manner in which these people perished is incompre hensible by all standards known to mankind," Mr Hamon said.

He added that Gen Krstic was fully aware of events, and his immediate subordinates commanded the operations.

The prosecutor described a phone call between Gen Krstic and one officer. "[The officer] complained that he had 3,500 parcels to distribute and he had no solution and he asked Gen Krstic for more men for the job," Mr Hamon said, adding that "parcels" was code for Muslim men and "distribute" code for murder.

At least 50 witnesses will be called by the prosecution, whose case is expected to last up to six weeks. Secret US spy satellite data has been made available to the tribunal.

Gen Krstic's trial is the first of three involving Bosnian Serb military chiefs and a further sign that the UN tribunal is now focusing on those ultimately responsible for the atrocities committed during Bosnia's 1992-95 war.

The cases will be a significant test for prosecutors, who have yet to secure a genocide conviction.

The stats don't lie. He dominated the game; he almost re-invented it. His success sealed Australia's maturity as a nation, an achievement unparalleled by a sportsman anywhere else in the world. His judgment and influence lived on, long after his playing days were over.

"Impact on the public" was one of the factors the voters were asked to consider. To me, Compton was a cert on that basis. I'm not sure whether he could waggle his ears while sticking his tongue out. He could do everything else on a cricket field. He was the best batsman whenever he played, and near-enough the best fast bowler and spin bowler as well. West Indies effectively had 13 men every time he turned out.

He's the best player I've seen in nearly 30 years reporting cricket, so that's worth something. No- one else has hit the ball harder, further, more certainly. But there was more: his style, his swagger, his refusal to wear a helmet - everything was awesome. He was a one-man rebuttal of colonial history.

fields.headline: To love, honour and adorn
fields.standfirst: Pity poor Cherie Booth: drags herself off to Russia to stand by her man and do her bit for Britain, only to be lambasted by her sister for being a trophy wife.  Maureen Freely sticks up for the spouses
fields.trailText: Pity poor Cherie Booth: drags herself off to Russia to stand by her man and do her bit for Britain, only to be lambasted by her sister for being a trophy wife.  Maureen Freely sticks up for the spouses
fields.body:
What does a Prime Minister's wife have to do to be beyond reproach these days? It is no longer enough, it seems, to smile while fading into the woodwork and saying "No comment". It's not enough, that is, if everyone knows you are not just Cherie Blair, mother-of-three-with-another-on-the-way, but also Cherie Booth QC. Never mind that she has been skilful in avoiding all conceivable conflicts of interest and keeping the two parts of her life separate.

And talk about good manners! Just think of all the times you or I would have had to say something and she's had to bite her tongue. But even when she's on her very best behaviour (and when I think back on the past three years, I can't think of a single instance when she wasn't), she still manages to get an awful lot of people terribly upset. She upsets people just by being there. In a survey last month, it emerged that many ordinary women saw her as a negative role model because she was coming across as too careerist. She implied by her example that it was OK to be a workaholic. They implied that she didn't spend enough time with her family.

So you'd think they would be happy when she decided to accompany her husband on his state visit to Moscow. But this, too, turned into an "episode" after her half-sister, Lauren Booth, told Michael Parkinson on Radio 2 that she was yet again setting a bad example for political wives world-wide. Wasn't it about time, Lauren said, that "MPs stopped dragging their wives abroad? There's a lady here who's 44 years old, seven months pregnant, three kids at home, prime minister for a husband and she's supposed to go to Russia to watch some boring ballet."

Asked if her sister might, like other politicians' wives, be there because she wanted to be there, Lauren blurted: "But these are wheeled out like little cakes at the side of prime ministers across the world. Haven't we grown out of this trophy wife thing?" As usual, Cherie Booth's response was to remain stoically silent. But her friends and allies were outraged by this implied slur and quick to point out that no one deserved the trophy wife label less.

I couldn't agree more. I am perplexed by the way this woman is portrayed in the press. I wish it would end this obsession with her hair and her clothes and her nannies and her crowded diary and the size of her bump, and just let her get on with it. That said, I still think her sister has a point. Relations between ordinary men and women may have changed enormously over the past few decades, but - as we hear year after year in study after study - life on the other side of the glass ceiling has changed rather less. It is still a man's world up there. The wives of the rich, the powerful and the august do still get wheeled in and out like cakes.

The fact that more and more of these cakes lead independent lives off-stage is neither here nor there. As wives, it is pretty much as it was for their mothers and their grandmothers. They are assets only if they look right, act right and decline to speak out of turn. And if they break the rules? Well, just imagine what people would have said if Cherie Booth had gone to that boring old ballet and yawned openly. If she had admitted to a journalist that she would have preferred to stay at home. People would have felt she was letting the side down, representing her country badly, "not doing her job". And of course they would be right, because it is a job. And an exhausting, exacting, time-consuming job it is, too.

Sadly, people only ever seem to notice this when a cake's wheeled in that clearly isn't up to it. The saddest thing is that it's not just their husbands and their husbands' colleagues who judge them by this antiquated code. The way we talk about Cherie Booth is proof that we all do it.

Her friends were right to point out that she should be given the dignity to make her own choices. She should not have to worry about what signals she is sending out to the nation every time she makes a decision about when to put what first. It is hard enough as it is.

But if I were a trophy wife, Cherie Booth would have me worried. She makes it all look so easy. Wherever she goes as wife-of-Tony, she must make other husbands wonder why it is they have settled for women who don't have her accomplishments. Do some of them ask themselves if the time hasn't come for them to trade the old trophy in for a new model that is brainy and all the other things a good asset should be?

It is impossible to know how people end up choosing their real mates, but I think I see a hint of a worrying shift in those interviews we've all been reading lately with the young internet millionaires. When asked about their ideal mates, many of these young men talk about looking for women who are beautiful and appreciative of their generous gifts, but not materialistic and very giving, willing to "be there" for them. Much, you might say, as their fathers might have done.

But it is not enough. They also want to find someone who is (as one neonate millionaire put it) "an independent woman with her own life. Someone with a demanding job of her own, who understands that work doesn't start at 9 and finish at 5". Someone like Cherie, in other words.

I suspect Cherie would be the first to want to tell this guy no wife should be held to such a punishing programme. Of course she can't utter a single honest word on this subject, not without causing another commotion. But I do wish that, from time to time, she'd let the side down, just a little, and give out a symbolic hint.

fields.headline: Is Labour losing the plot?
fields.standfirst: After PR disasters such as London's mayor, grammar schools and trial by jury, Labour has been accused of spinning out of control. Is it really messing up with increasing regularity or just failing to convey its successes to a hostile media? asks Patrick Barkham
fields.trailText: After PR disasters such as London's mayor, grammar schools and trial by jury, Labour has been accused of spinning out of control. Is it really messing up with increasing regularity or just failing to convey its successes to a hostile media? asks Patrick Barkham.
fields.body:
A mayor for London

The cynical hack says
Tony Blair's ill-fated commitment to devolving power in London is symbolic of the government's control freakery. The mayoral post lacks any real authority, yet the prime minister authorised a scandalously undemocratic fixing of the ballot to "choose" Frank Dobson as Labour's candidate. In one stroke of his fixer's pen, Mr Blair managed to alienate many in Labour's heartlands and elevated Ken Livingstone into a folk hero. Mr Livingstone is set to triumph in May and if he fails to transform the tube you can be sure he will let Londoners know that Mr Blair is to blame.

The spin doctor says
Tony Blair's creation of a London mayor is part of a radical devolution programme which, in time, could lead to a series of city mayors across the English regions. It is a measure of the man that no other recent political leader would contemplate giving away his own power. The ballot which elected Mr Dobson was almost identical to the one which gave Mr Blair the leadership of the Labour party. That Ken Livingstone would not accept the result is testimony to his egotism and personal ambition.

Verdict
The prime minister's ill-fated attempts to fix the outcome have only boosted Mr Livingstone's popularity and left Mr Blair to take the blame if the mayor is unable to alleviate London's transport and social problems. But voters in the rest of the country are so fed up about the national media's metropolitan obsession that they could not care less.

Grammar schools

The cynical hack says
David Blunkett's rash George Bush parody - "read my lips - no more selection" - could hardly be a clearer commitment to abolishing grammar schools, yet Tony Blair also promised that "a Labour government will not close your grammar schools". The government has been castigated by both the pro- and anti-selection sides for allowing parental votes on the subject to be "rigged", probably because it lacked the courage to make clear its convictions in the first place. The spin doctor says
Labour's 1997 election manifesto pledged never to put dogma before children's education. The party promised that "any changes in the admissions policies of grammar schools will be decided by local parents". David Blunkett stood by this after parents voted against abolishing Ripon grammar school. "We are against the 11-plus and we remain against it. But we aren't in favour of putting this issue over standards."

Verdict
Selective schooling is an emotive subject and Labour rightly chose to "let the people decide". There are only 166 grammar schools in the country, and more important will be how Labour is judged to be meeting its much-vaunted priority of "education, education, education" and its commitment to improving standards and reducing class sizes. Those promises look much harder to keep.

Abolishing jury trial for minor offences

The cynical hack says
Before Labour came to power, Jack Straw attacked Tory plans to abolish a defendant's right to jury trial for a range of minor offences, such as theft, as "shortsighted and wrong". As home secretary he changed his mind. His bill was defeated by the Lords, but Mr Straw persisted in introducing another. His estimate of how much it will save has recently risen from an optimistic £105m to a fanciful £128m. Many lawyers, Labour peers and civil liberties groups argue that his decision will not save money and will create a two-tier system of justice which discriminates against the poor and ethnic minorities.

The spin doctor says
The present system is abused by criminal defendants who spin out their cases or choose an expensive jury trial because the chance of acquittal is much higher. All the fuss about Englishmen being denied the right to trial by their peers is nonsense, jury trial will remain for all serious cases. No high principle is at stake in the practical reform, it is more a minor matter of improving the administration of justice and saving more than £100m in the process.

Verdict
One of Labour's more minor misdemeanours, it seems to demonstrate a lack of consistency and an occasionally cavalier approach to justice. But as with devolution, vacillation over electoral reform and the release of General Augusto Pinochet, it is something to outrage the chattering classes at dinner, rather than swing voters at an election.

Refusing to commit to the euro

The cynical hack says
Like redistributing wealth, the government knows the right thing to do and is nudging towards it, but despite a 171-seat parliamentary majority lacks the guts to embrace it. Three years of refusing to commit to the single currency has eroded support for the euro. Failing to join in the first phase has again left Britain on the sidelines in Europe, and means that a profitable convergence of its economy with euroland is even more unlikely.

The spin doctor says
The government has maintained an utterly consistent position: membership of the single currency "must be determined by a hard-headed assessment of Britain's economic interests," as the 1997 manifesto stated. This remains its position. If suitable economic circumstances arise, the government will submit the decision to a referendum.

Verdict
Labour has allowed the Conservative party to unite around a rhetorically more sceptical position and this Tory view is closer to popular opinion than Labour's fudge. But the Conservatives could also come undone with their policy, which is ultimately broadly similar to Labour's. The fact that both the government and opposition have adopted a "not now, not never" position, despite their different instincts, suggests that the single currency is not a topic which currently allows either party much room to manoeuvre.

Tony and Cherie's baby

The cynical hack says
Alastair Campbell could not make it up.

The spin doctor says
It will be a joyous moment, showing Tony and Cherie to be at the heart of an ordinary, loving family. Both will prove what genuine, doting parents they are when May 24 dawns. However, the Blair family must be allowed their privacy.

Verdict
The Blairs should not milk good publicity from the birth and complain later of a lack of privacy, Tony and Cherie's place as a much-loved modern day monarchy is assured - for another term at least. Where Margaret Thatcher and John Major enjoyed "khaki" election victories shortly after military successes, could Mr Blair win a second term for Labour in a triumphant "nappy" election?

fields.headline: How Kamran Abbasi kept getting it right
fields.standfirst: A reminder of several startlingly accurate pieces of crystal-ball gazing by our Anglo-Asian columnist, Kamran Abbasi
fields.trailText: First he called for the heads of Wasim Akram and Sachin Tendulkar. They obliged. But Abbasi still wasn't happy. In a follow-up piece, he argued that the new Pakistan captain, Saeed Anwar, would have to go. And he would have to be replaced by Moin Khan. Both happened. He also said that India's new leader should be Sourav Ganguly. Guess what? That happened too.

webTitle: Rifles destroyed 'to foil Bloody Sunday inquiry'

fields.headline: Rifles destroyed 'to foil Bloody Sunday inquiry'
fields.trailText: The army began to destroy rifles used on Bloody Sunday just three days before Tony Blair announced a fresh inquiry, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
The army began to destroy rifles used on Bloody Sunday just three days before Tony Blair announced a fresh inquiry, it emerged last night.

Families of the 14 victims said the revelation indicated that senior figures in the military were intent on frustrating the work of Lord Saville of Newdigate's forthcoming inquiry. It begins to take oral evidence in Londonderry's Guildhall on March 27.

The army went on to destroy 14 of the 29 rifles. Ten were sold to private companies. It also destroyed two of the remaining five rifles three months after Lord Saville had decreed they should be kept safely for his tribunal. A police investigation, involving detectives from West Mercia, is under way.

John Kelly, 51, whose younger brother Michael was among those shot dead, said: "We believe the destruction of the guns just before Mr Blair's announcement of the new tribunal proves there was a deliberate attempt to pervert the course of justice.

"How come they are intact for 26 years, and then three days before an announcement which means they will be subject to modern-day forensic examination the army suddenly begins to destroy them?"

One of the two rifles recently destroyed fired the bullet that killed Michael Kelly. The other claimed Gerard Donaghy, 17.

Paratroopers shot dead 13 unarmed Roman Catholics during an illegal civil rights demonstration in Londonderry on January 30 1972. Another man who was wounded died five months later.

Lord Widgery, the then lord chief justice, in effect exonerated the army in his tribunal later that year, sparking fury among the bereaved. They fought hard for a fresh inquiry and Mr Blair bowed to their request in January 1998. His decision was communicated in advance to the ministry of defence, which is understood to have been opposed.

Examination of the rifles now would have thrown light on the ramifications of Major-General Robert Ford's controversial memo three weeks before Bloody Sunday. He was in day-to-day command of troops in Northern Ireland, and was in Londonderry on Bloody Sunday. Maj-Gen Ford recommended that rioters should be shot, and suggested modifying rifles to fire smaller bullets less likely to cause what he termed collateral damage. It is known he had 30 of the rifles sent to Londonderry for training purposes. It is unclear if any were used on Bloody Sunday.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Winterbottom wants to use real corpse for new flick, Tommy Lee Jones and William Friedkin set to work on second film together this year, Oliver Stone in hot water over beer commercial, and South Park ditty Oscar nomination makes someone happy - sort of
fields.body:
 Director Michael Winterbottom is determined to use a genuine human corpse in his new picture, Kingdom Come, currently filming in rural Canada. Known for the dour authenticity of his filmic vision (best evidenced in Welcome to Sarajevo, Jude and Wonderland), the British director has instructed production staff to negotiate with Canadian medical authorities for the use of a fresh cadaver. The selected candidate would gain posthumous fame as a movie star in the opening scene of Winterbottom's 1840s-set drama about the California gold rush. "We want to show the harshness of the conditions and that death was something these people saw all the time," Winterbottom told the Sunday Times.

 Tommy Lee Jones and William Friedkin look set to collaborate on a film for the second time in under a year. The director and star are in negotiations to work on the Paramount production Shooter, a Manchurian Candidate-style political thriller about a war vet who becomes the unwitting stooge in a labyrinthine plot to kill the president. Jones and Friedkin recently completed work on another thriller, Rules of Engagement, which opens in the US on April 7. Shooter is adapted from the novel Point of Contact by Stephen Hunter and is scheduled to begin shooting in August or September.

 No stranger to controversy, Oliver Stone is in more hot water over a beer commercial he has directed for the Hong Kong market. The South China Morning Post reports that the creator of JFK and Natural Born Killers has come in for criticism for including not one Chinese or Asian actor in the ad. Responding to the complaints, Stone claimed that his employers, Heineken, requested a "European look" for the film, while Heineken Hong Kong's marketing manager, Ralph Hooglandt, admits that the company took full responsibility for the casting. The Heineken spot is the first venture in commercials directing for Stone, whose current feature, Any Given Sunday, is released in the UK on March 31. "I view commercials as an assignment," he claims. "It's sort of like working out between films, exercising, staying in shape by shooting."

 The maligned South Park song Blame Canada needs all the friends it can get. Nominated for an Oscar in the category of Best Supporting Song, the Trey Parker ditty will find itself either bleeped or cut during its ABC broadcast at this year's Academy Award ceremony. But singer-songwriter Randy Newman, nominated for his schmaltzy Toy Story tune When She Loved Me, has sprung to Blame Canada's defence - albeit in a half-hearted fashion: "I'm glad something got nominated from South Park, because it's better than Cats," Newman told Mr Showbiz. "I like it. I like my song better, though."

fields.headline: Testimone
fields.standfirst: Film director  Franco Zeffirelli explains his love of Fiorentina as they head to meet Man U
fields.trailText: Film director Franco Zeffirelli explains his love of Fiorentina as they head to meet Man U
fields.body:
Ci sono due Fiorentine: una è una squadra che non rientra nei canoni e nel grande pasticcio economico, che di sportivo finisce per avere ben poco, che si è impossessato del campionato italiano. Credo che la Fiorentina abbia rinunciato fin dall'inizio all'idea di competere per lo scudetto, lasciando il campo a quelle grandi multinazionali del calcio che sono Juventus, Milan, Inter, Lazio e Roma. Nel nostro campionato siamo in una posizione abbastanza intermedia, ma è una squadra con uno straordinario potenziale internazionale.

Mi pare che l'ambizione di Trapattoni sia di portare la Fiorentina in alte posizioni nella Coppa dei Campioni: la vittoria sul Manchester United, e quella sul Valencia nel girone di andata sono molto promettenti. Due settimane fa ho visto proprio la partita con il Valencia, ma non mi è tanto piaciuta, perché abbiamo strappato la vittoria con molta fatica. Batistuta sembrava l'ombra di se stesso. Però è una squadra inaspettata, di puledri di razza, che se scatta, scatta. Assistetti a questo alla fine dell'anno scorso, quando si batterono come leoni per entrare in Champions League, dove la Fiorentina è quella vera.

Quando vado allo stadio a Firenze mi agito troppo, soffro troppo e mi ritornano tutti i ricordi dell'infanzia e i fantasmi del passato: le rabbie, le gioie, le delusioni, le esaltazioni. Sono settant'anni di vita nello stadio che mi ritornano addosso. La grande magia del calcio è questa: nello stadio siamo tutti ragazzi, tutti della stessa età; si parla nella stessa maniera e ci si esalta allo stesso modo. È un fenomeno psicofisico straordinario, un'esperienza diversa dall'andare al cinematografo o a una corsa di cavalli. È la passione ancestrale della tribù, dell'identità con una città, con una storia.

pasticcio muddle

puledro colt, foal

di razza thoroughbred

scattare to spring

strappare to snatch

fields.headline: Youssou N'Dour, l'enfant prodige
fields.standfirst: As the star from Senegal releases his latest album,  Zo Eisenstein asks French youngsters whether his music is becoming less African
fields.trailText: As the star from Senegal releases his latest album,  Zo Eisenstein asks French youngsters whether his music is becoming less African
fields.body:
"Les voyages influencent ma musique, mais mon objectif est aussi d'exporter les vibrations de Dakar et d'amener de nouveaux sons aux Occidentaux."

Ainsi Youssou N'Dour explique le melting pot sonore de son nouvel album, Joko (From Village to Town) . En effet, Joko est la fusion entre musique pop et chansons africaines, entre le wolof et l'anglais. Peut-être aussi entre l'Afrique traditionnelle et la nouvelle Afrique ? À l'âge de 12 ans, le jeune Sénégalais chante déjà, dans la Médina, le quartier chaud de Dakar.

Aujourd'hui, il est connu sur la scène musicale internationale. Mais est-ce que Youssou est en train d'oublier ses racines pour mieux exporter sa musique ? J'ai parlé avec Maurine (23 ans), Diadji (26 ans) et Henri (19 ans).

Qu'est-ce que tu penses de son nouvel album ?

Maurine: Ça se situe tout à fait dans l'évolution de sa musique qui va vers la commercialisation de plus en plus poussée. J'aime pas quand il chante en anglais. Ce qui était chouette dans sa musique avant, c'était qu'elle était sénégalaise spécifiquement.

Diadji: Il est pas mal. Mais dès que Youssou N'Dour fait un disque qu'il veut vendre dans le monde, ça perd de son authenticité. Chez nous, il fait du Mbalax, de la musique à base de percussion, alors qu'à l'étranger, c'est presque de la pop.

Henri: J'ai surtout connu Youssou N'Dour quand je suis allé au Sénégal en voyage. On entend sa musique un peu partout. Je l'ai connu d'abord par la chanson qu'il a faite avec Neneh Cherry.

Le sous-titre de son disque est From Village to Town...

Maurine: Des racines jusqu'au progrès industriel de la ville qui est l'américanisation et la globalisation.

Diadji: Lui, il n'est pas né dans un village mais son père est né dans un village. Il veut parler de l'exode rural.

Et Youssou, le personnage ?

Maurine: Il sort de la Médina, le quartier populaire de Dakar. Maintenant, c'est la star internationale qui chante avec les grands artistes : en quelque sorte, il se vend. Et je trouve ça dommage.

Diadji: C'est clair, c'est un immense artiste, le plus grand au Sénégal sur la scène musicale. Il a fait une percée que personne n'avait faite. Moi j'ai rien contre sa world music.

Henri: C'est un success story à la sénégalaise. Il a une boîte de nuit, beaucoup d'albums qui se vendent en millions d'exemplaires partout dans le monde . . . C'est un beau gosse très riche, ce que rêvent d'être plein de Sénégalais.

Un ambassadeur culturel ?

Diadji: Il a même été nommé ambassadeur culturel par l'Unesco. Il fait énormément d'actions de charité avec d'autres artistes comme Sting et Peter Gabriel. C'est au nom du Sénégal qu'il fait ça.

Henri: Ce qui m'a surtout frappé quand j'étais au Sénégal, c'est l'importance qu'il a pour les gens là-bas. En plus, il est vraiment connu partout dans le monde, surtout en Afrique occidentale.

Qu'est-ce qu'il représente au Sénégal ?

Maurine: Il est bien plus reconnu que d'autres qui chantent toujours de la musique populaire. Ils sont moins connus parce que justement ils n'ont pas su se vendre comme Youssou.

Diadji: Il est admiré, c'est presque un saint. Il a une très grande importance au niveau de l'identité culturelle au Sénégal. C'est le Michael Jackson du Sénégal.

Henri: Le fait qu'il est écouté partout au Sénégal, dans tous les petits villages... Même si lui est entouré par son succès et sa richesse, sa musique est dans les curs de tous les Sénégalais.

Et son image en France ?

Maurine: Son nom sonne tout de suite différent et africain et sénégalais. Ça commence à être assez populaire. Ça fait partie des musiques du monde - dans le même panier que la musique tzigane, algérienne - la world.

Diadji: Les Français ne peuvent pas le voir comme les Sénégalais le voient. Il n'y a rien à voir entre la façon dont il est adulé au Sénégal et dont il est admiré ici. Ici, ils connaissent plutôt sa musique world alors que là-bas, quand tu dis Youssou N'Dour, c'est la musique authentique Mbalax sénégalaise.

Henri: Ils aiment bien, ça fait bien d'écouter de la musique africaine, être branché. C'est difficile quand on n'est pas allé là-bas de se rendre compte de l'importance qu'il a pour les Sénégalais.

beau gosse (coll) good-looking guy
chouette (coll) wicked
dommage a pity
être branché (coll) fashionable
faire une percée to break through
Mbalax traditional Senegalese music
musique tzigane gypsy music
quartier populaire working-class area
rien à voir nothing to do with
se vendre to sell oneself, to promote oneself

webTitle: 'Creative differences' led Spielberg to drop Potter

fields.headline: 'Creative differences' led Spielberg to drop Potter
fields.trailText: Steven Spielberg's abandonment of the Harry Potter project last month was due to "creative differences" with its author, it was reported this week. An article in the Sunday Express claims that Spielberg - in keeping with his position at the top of the Hollywood pile - wanted full control of the film adaptation of the best-selling stories about a plucky boy wizard, but was blocked by author JK Rowling.
fields.body:
Steven Spielberg's abandonment of the Harry Potter project last month was due to "creative differences" with its author, it was reported this week. An article in the Sunday Express claims that Spielberg - in keeping with his position at the top of the Hollywood pile - wanted full control of the film adaptation of the best-selling stories about a plucky boy wizard, but was blocked by author JK Rowling.

The paper quotes an unnamed executive at Warner Bros claiming that "it wasn't going to be Spielberg's vision. It would have to be a shared vision with the author. Spielberg has a more fanciful approach, and to be true to the book, he would have had to portray her vision, not his." One major bone of contention was the casting. Spielberg, apparently, was dead set on signing The Sixth Sense's star Haley Joel Osment to play Potter, while Rowling insisted that the part should be taken by a young British actor.

If nothing else, the rift highlights the impressive influence of the Scottish writer, who has used the astounding popularity of her children's books as a leverage against one of the most powerful men in Hollywood.

The downside, of course, is that Harry Potter is currently without a director. Spielberg has now moved on to film the thriller Minority Report with Tom Cruise. The comparatively low-profile Brad Silberling (best known for his Americanised Wings of Desire remake City of Angels) is currently the favoured replacement.

webTitle: Cricket writing bridges the gender gap

fields.headline: Cricket writing bridges the gender gap
fields.trailText: When Another Bloody Tour by Frances Edmonds hit the bookshelves in 1986 it caused a sensation. Hailed "cricket book of the year" by the Evening Standard, it was an intelligent, wickedly funny report of England's disastrous 1985-86 tour of West Indies. A book which gleefully reported such snippets as the line - said by a hack to the wives of Allan Lamb and Paul Downton - "If you don't manage to score with the team there are always plenty of press men around for consolation prizes", was bound to be a bestseller. And in the days when English cricket was almost up there with football in the national consciousness, it made Frances Edmonds more famous than her husband.
fields.body:
When Another Bloody Tour by Frances Edmonds hit the bookshelves in 1986 it caused a sensation. Hailed "cricket book of the year" by the Evening Standard, it was an intelligent, wickedly funny report of England's disastrous 1985-86 tour of West Indies. A book which gleefully reported such snippets as the line - said by a hack to the wives of Allan Lamb and Paul Downton - "If you don't manage to score with the team there are always plenty of press men around for consolation prizes", was bound to be a bestseller. And in the days when English cricket was almost up there with football in the national consciousness, it made Frances Edmonds more famous than her husband.

But 14 years later, it hardly looks like a breakthrough work. The canon of female cricket writers can be counted on one hand: Margaret Hughes, Bridgette Lawrence, Michelle Savidge, Teresa McLean and Edmonds. So what? you might ask: cricket is, after all, a game still dominated by men. But that misses the point, because although the market for cricket literature isn't that large, the number of cricket books that make it into print remains phenomenal. And, as Stephen Chalke, author of Runs in the Memory, reveals in April's WCM, self-published books can be a success.

WCM receives plenty of potential manuscripts each year, (usually bound and stamped British Rights Reserved) and without exception they are from men. But, in February, something extraordinary happened: each member of the editorial staff recieved a copy of a potential book together with a two-page letter - from a woman.

The phenomenon behind So-Fa Not So Good (a light-hearted diary of a Surrey obsessive) was Caroline Kemp, a 30-year-old who owns a (soon to be sold) print and design business with her husband, Andy. She has been cricket-mad for nearly ten years and has followed Surrey and England all round the country.

So what made her think she had a book in her? "I watch loads of cricket, usually by myself (though don't dismiss me as an anorak), so I've had lots of adventures. I often go home and tell my friends all about it and they say, 'you should write a book about this'. I always dismissed them, but suddenly I thought why not? "

But does she really think the swollen cricket market needs another book? "I don't read much fiction: what I read is sports books, including lots of cricket books and I feel there is a gap for something written from a woman's point of view."

She bemoans the lack of female writers, but how would she tailor her work to a specifically female audience? And does that female audience even exist? "I don't think that my kind of writing is going to entice more women to watch cricket. I'm not trying to change the world. I'm really aiming at anyone who follows a county side on a fairly regular basis."

She might not change the world, but if she succeeds in having her book published she will probably achieve more than most current English cricketers. She will have become a household name.

If anyone is interested in calling Caroline Kemp, please contact the Wisden office on 0171-565 3113.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of wisden.com

webTitle: Art treasure looted by Nazis finally returned to family

fields.headline: Art treasure looted by Nazis finally returned to family
fields.standfirst: Nazi war criminals in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: A small change made yesterday to the label of a painting in the Royal Academy's blockbuster exhibition, Art at the Crossroads, marked a moment in history. It was the first restitution in Britain of a painting looted by the Nazis to its rightful owners.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
A small change made yesterday to the label of a painting in the Royal Academy's blockbuster exhibition, Art at the Crossroads, marked a moment in history. It was the first restitution in Britain of a painting looted by the Nazis to its rightful owners.

The label now states that The Three Stages of Life, a grimly imposing 19th century German triptych by Count Leopold von Kalckreuth, is on loan from "a private collection", instead of the Neue Pinakothek in Munich, whose director had just handed over a formal document renouncing any German state claim to the picture.

The "private collection" is Marietta Glanville, 70, and her brother Ernest, 75, who live 10 minutes apart in north London, and could hardly believe that their family's half-century hunt was over.

They lodged a claim with the commission for looted art in Europe only a month before the academy exhibition opened in January.

The commission's research director, Diane Michaels, attended a private view of the show, which reassembled famous and once famous pictures originally shown together in Paris in 1900. She was astounded to be confronted by the original of the painting about which she had a file of notes on her desk.

After decades of the family being told by the German authorities that they had no case in law, because their claim was lodged too late, it took just 10 weeks to resolve the case.

One of the few Glanville family treasures to survive the Nazi years was a black and white photograph of the picture hanging on their dining room wall in Vienna.

It had been a wedding present from their grandparents to their mother. The picture profoundly affected Marietta, whose seat at the table was directly opposite the monumental figures portraying a woman's life from buxom girl to broken crone. "It was an icon of our family," she said yesterday.

The war began for the family exactly 62 years ago, with the Anschluss, the forced union of Austria with Germany. Mr Glanville spoke movingly yesterday of a boy's baffling and terrifying experiences in the days which followed. "I had been treated as a little gentleman, suddenly I became a dirty Jewish pig. When I went back to school on the Monday my chums, who had all been happy to come to my birthday party the previous week, who had been shouting their loyalty to free Austria, were shouting Sieg Heil, Heil Hitler!

"And the teachers were exactly the same, they all had their little swastikas on their pockets. I was so utterly confused: I was no longer allowed to go to the park, I couldn't sit on a bench, I wasn't allowed to buy an ice cream."

Life rapidly became more frightening. The family was actually Catholic, but with one set of Jewish grandparents. Their father, a banker, as a member of the Austrian independence party, was doubly marked.

"Soon he was tipped off that the next day he would be transported to Dachau, and that night he took a case and went immediately to the station and got the first train he could to a country where he didn't need a visa , which happened to be Yugoslavia."

Within a month the children and their mother left, first to Switzerland, and then finally to join their father in London.

Despite being an enemy alien, Mr Glanville said he was grateful for being permitted to finish his education, and even to join the home guard at St Edmund's boarding school.

"My instructions were to take my dummy gun and packet of Woodbine cigarettes, and defend the cricket and rugger fields against possible attack by German parachutists dressed as Dutch nuns. And I was very successful, we were never attacked by German parachutists dressed as Dutch nuns."

Immediately after the war their mother, Elizabeth, lodged a formal claim for the return of her picture, but it was apparently never forwarded to Munich, where the gallery had bought it from a private collector in Vienna without inquiring too closely into its provenance.

When the family discovered that it was in the stores of the Neue Pinakothek which was bombed and not rebuilt until the 1970s the claim was thrown out because too much time had passed.

The restitution yesterday was agreed on moral, not legal grounds, but Reinhold Baum stark, director of the Bavarian state collection of paintings, who made the formal hand-over, said he personally believed all such pictures should be returned.

Anne Webber, chairwoman of the commission on looted art, which is pursuing hundreds of similar claims, said it set an inescapable precedent for the British government, and the British national collections, which earlier this month published a list of 350 works of art with doubtful provenance in the war years.

David Gordon, the secretary of the academy, thanked the family for allowing their picture to remain with the exhibition, and go to the Guggen heim in New York next month.

Dr Baumstark said he realised when he sent the painting to London that it might never return to Munich. "I had received the claim from the commission in December, but the agreement with the academy had already been made. I took the decision that it was right for people to see this picture again, that it was time for us to stop hiding it."

The brother and sister have not yet agreed which of their homes it should hang in. Marietta's husband, Paul, undertook to move a few radiators to make room for it.

"Ende gut, alles gut," said Mr Glanville, "in the end it's all come right."

webTitle: A family affair:  Redgrave archive handed to theatre museum

fields.headline: A family affair:  Redgrave archive handed to theatre museum
fields.trailText: The Redgrave archive, detailing five generations of Britain's most colourful acting dynasty, has been preserved for the nation, writes Fiachra Gibbons
fields.body:
The Redgrave archive, detailing five generations of Britain's most colourful acting dynasty, has been preserved for the nation.

The diaries, letters, photographs and recordings were amassed by the family patriarch, Michael Redgrave, and handed over yesterday by his children, Lynn, Vanessa and Corin, and his grandson Ben, 31, who has bucked the family tradition to be a pilot.

Rachel Kempson, 89, Sir Michael's widow, who wrote frankly and movingly of his affairs with Noel Coward and Edith Evans, sold the archive for £200,000 to the Theatre museum in Covent Garden, London, which he helped found; it could have sold abroad for far more.

Sir Michael, who died in 1985, shares a place with Laurence Olivier and John Gielgud among the greats. Complex, intellectual and bisexual, his left politics and willingness to embrace new ideas set him apart from the insular and conservative postwar theatre. There are rare and revealing letters to his wife and children (despite his divided sexuality, he was a devoted family man), as well as an account of the actor's reunion with Guy Burgess in Moscow in 1958, which formed the basis of Alan Bennett's TV play, Englishman Abroad.

webTitle: Meet the David Bowie of philosophy

fields.headline: Meet the David Bowie of philosophy
fields.standfirst: Jean Baudrillard is a consummate self-inventor, radical thinker - and takes a fine photograph, too. He talks to  Steven Poole
fields.trailText: Jean Baudrillard is a consummate self-inventor, radical thinker - and takes a fine photograph, too. He talks to Steven Poole
fields.body:
Jean Baudrillard's lecture in London last Friday did not take place. But don't be alarmed: the aim of thought, after all, is not truth or reality. Thinking is the art of making things disappear. Let's try, then, to make this impish, septuagenarian matre à penser disappear too.

Picture, if you will, Baudrillard in the chemistry lecture theatre of University College, London. Gazing down from a side wall is a vast chart of the periodic table, whose elements huddle together for comfort, anxious at the appearance in their midst of this unpredictable catalyst. Baudrillard looks wonderfully like a hyperreal cafe Frenchman: short, rotund, in a crumpled suit, with tufts of golden-grey hair poking out from his temples. But that appearance is a mask.

To an audience of alternately amused and blankly bamboozled architecture students, Baudrillard delivers an hour of sizzlingly dense, rococo argumentation in his warm but near-impenetrable Gallic tones. He explains his love of taking photographs, and mercilessly dissects the poverty of modern art. He laments the loss of magic, the fact that in an age of technical explanation, the universe has now "fallen" into a banal reality. The universe is given to us ready-made, like Duchamp's urinal. And art has no answer to this; it can only rehearse the disaster. "To turn an object into art," Baudrillard smiles, "you just have to make it useless." But the idea of uselessness is itself useless. Today, we merely enjoy the idea of art, not art itself.

Why? Baudrillard calls it "image-feedback". The image masks itself with an idea of itself. It constantly transforms itself into a message, and thus prevents us from seeing. Meaning, the omnipresent, choking smog of the post-industrial era gets in the way. This is true of all visual media. "It is the TV that looks at us," he insists, "from a blind spot, from nothing." Our gaze is turned back from this dead zone and blinds us.

And yet there is hope. Perhaps a certain sort of image could "break the screen". And perhaps photography is the weapon for this violent liberation. Because photography, if it avoids being assimilated to a message, can be unintelligible: the opposite of thinking. The potential for "something that is neither true nor real, but is beautiful". That is Baudrillard's plea, his challenge.

Across the road after the lecture we congregate in the bar, drinking beer while Baudrillard's own photos are projected in triptych on the walls. The images are inscrutable. An empty red armchair faces out at the viewer, enacting the disappearance of a human body, whose shape remains, in Baudrillard's own beautiful phrase, "like a smile". Close-ups of brick walls or alleys radiating in ecstasies of brown and blue; a lone bicycle gazing out over a golden river; a philosopher's still-life of book, pens, ashtray and coffee bowl; keys on a cafe table; splotches of red and black paint on a wall, almost humanoid. These stories of charged absence continue to glow on the walls as the bar empties and the chatter fades.

The next morning I meet Baudrillard at his hotel in South Kensington. "Oh, the grand homme himself!" chirps the receptionist, after I repeat the magic code of his name. Downstairs in the bar, Baudrillard drinks black coffee and smokes a cigarette he has rolled in advance; he delivers a rolling monologue in an English-French hybrid. It's early, but the twinkle in his eyes bespeaks pure joy in thought. "Ouf, it's a game!" he says, as if astonished that anyone could think otherwise of thinking.

But sometimes even champions need a break. That's why Baudrillard took up photography, as a way of escaping writing and thinking. "I began to photograph without any ambitions," he says, "not to be exhibited. It was just surprise encounters with objects, with situations, with lights." He had tried to take portraits of people, but "it's a disease of mine before human beings," he confesses. "I cannot take them as subjects. With objects it's an elective affinity, as far as they are traces of the living human world."

His photographs, he hopes, are without "meaning". For Baudrillard adores unintelligibility. There is not enough of it around. "Gone is the innocence of nonsense," he said wistfully in his lecture. But he tries his best: "It is the task of radical thought, since the world is given to us in unintelligibility, to make it more unintelligible, more enigmatic, more fabulous."

That is why we love Baudrillard: because he can do this. But that is not to say he is a mere conjurer of nonsense. Baudrillard foresaw the allure of virtual reality long before William Gibson; he was in the vanguard of Marxian critiques of modern consumerism; before it became fashionable, he wrote a scintillating analysis of man's sentimental exploitation of animals. Baudrillard got there first, many times. And now his self-imposed task is "this art of taking reality as fiction, taking fiction as a hyperreality". To shock us into realising that thought and the world need not be as they are.

That is why we love him; it is also why he enrages a certain stodgy, anti-imaginative Anglo-American sensibility. Baudrillard is most infamous in non-philosophical circles for having said that the Gulf war did not take place. The theory is that these days, the "model" precedes the event and exhausts it totally in advance. The Gulf war was played out as simulation before any tanks began rolling, and then it was played out again as simulation through videogame-style missile-runs on TV. Behind this orgiastic virtuality, the "real" event was nowhere to be seen.

Baudrillard's pioneering analysis is now common - so thoroughly domesticated as to figure in such books as Michael Ignatieff's recent Virtual War. A few years ago, Baudrillard also claimed that the year 2000 would not happen. So? Did it? "No," Baudrillard insists gleefully. "Because we were already in the 21st century long before we came to this dead point. We abused the scenario of the millennium long before it happened. Now, we stay in the 20th century. We have not really passed over. We don't live in a rational time..."

But what, pray, is a "rational time"? The most high-profile charge levelled against Baudrillard's game of thinking came a few years ago from Alan Sokal's and Jean Bricmont's book, Intellectual Impostures, which named Baudrillard among a phalanx of French "postmodernist" thinkers who regularly abuse scientific concepts. It caused a huge storm in France, and an ejaculation of happy sneering over here, fortifying the complacent impression of those who had never bothered to read any French philosophy that it was all a load of rubbish.

Up until now, Baudrillard has not dignified the attack with a public reply. I ask him about it, and he sighs simply: "It's a misunderstanding of metaphor." It is further, in his view, based on an outmoded idea of the scientific process. Nowadays, Baudrillard argues, we know that hypotheses are never verified - "they give way to other hypotheses. And thought has always been like that... I was surprised that no scientist ever answered to Sokal himself as a scientist." And then he adds, with a devious grin: "In a way it was a compliment."

To be accused of imposture, after all, is not necessarily a bad thing. "There is a good use of imposture," he points out slyly. "It is the art never to take a definite posture. The ability to metamorphose posture." Indeed, Baudrillard's own career has been an exercise in balletic shifts of pose. In 1991 he summed up his intellectual journey: he had been a pataphysician at 20 (the term is Dadaist: a scientist of imaginary solutions), then "situationist at 30, utopian at 40, transversal at 50, viral and metaleptic [having seizures about seizures] at 60. That's my history."

Now Baudrillard is 70: so what is it this time, monsieur? He laughs: "I ought never to have said that. Well, let's see, at 70, I would say that I am... beyond the end. It was my fateful strategy to go beyond the concept, so as to see what happens beyond."

So where next for the perpetually self-reinventing man, the David Bowie of philosophy? Becoming digital? Well, Baudrillard rather likes the idea of the internet voraciously sucking up the world, because that would "leave thought alone in its radicality", although he doesn't use the net himself. "I cannot see a text, a modulation of thinking, on a screen - on a screen I can only see an image..." Yet nor does he prophesy cyber-doom. "I did this critique of technology, but I would not do that any more. I am not nostalgic. I would not oppose liberty and human rights to this technical world."

For now, Baudrillard has another book due out in France - the final volume of his delightful journals, Cool Memories. And then? "After that, maybe I become an artist." I wish him luck. "Ouf, on verra! " he chuckles, and with that, Jean Baud-rillard puffs on his cigarette and wanders back upstairs, leaving only the traces in my notebook behind.

fields.headline: The best postman scene
fields.standfirst: Next Friday
fields.trailText: Next Friday
fields.body:
Having been sent to live with his uncle in the Californian suburbs, Craig (Ice Cube) reclines on the sofa, enjoying a daydream about the girl next door. Suddenly, his rapture is interrupted by a banging at the door. The postman (Michael Rapaport) stands outside.

"Got a delivery!" he bawls. "Hello!"

Craig stumbles to his feet.

"Who is it?"

"Got a delivery. Come on, spark plug, it's kinda hot out here."

Craig looks through the spyhole in the front door and sees the very pale, very ginger figure outside. He opens the door.

"Whassup?"

The postman steps back in shock.

"Nice house. I didn't expect you to answer. What are you, one of those entertainment guys? Or you play sports? What team do you play for?"

"I play for the Cucamunga Cracker Killers", answers Craig. "You want tickets?"

The postman waves his hands in alarm.

"Woah, I don't want any trouble. You don't have to send your posse out to do a 187 in my ass. I just got a little mail for you to sign_ pardner."

Craig signs the paper.

"What's this?"

fields.headline: Costner is latest Traffic casualty
fields.trailText: The trouble-hit pre-production of the Fox Searchlight drama Traffic suffered another jam with the news that Kevin Costner has pulled out of negotiations to play the lead role of a drugs tsar. Costner stepped briefly into the breach after Harrison Ford bailed out a fortnight ago to film an as yet untitled action movie.
fields.body:
The trouble-hit pre-production of the Fox Searchlight drama Traffic suffered another jam with the news that Kevin Costner has pulled out of negotiations to play the lead role of a drugs tsar. Costner stepped briefly into the breach after Harrison Ford bailed out a fortnight ago to film an as yet untitled action movie.

Once again, it appears that salary was the sticking point. Fox remains determined to keep Traffic's total budget at around the $30m mark, and this comparatively low sum necessitates a cut in the asking fee of any big-name actor who comes on board.

Ford was rumoured to have been unwilling to dip much below his traditional price tag of $20m, and became frustrated with the slow pace of the negotiations and the more chaotic and unruly world of low-budget film-making. Costner is also thought to have demanded more money than the studio was willing to pay.

The movie's subject matter may have been another factor in scaring him off. Loosely based on a BBC drama, Traffik, the film paints a harsh, warts-and-all portrait of the US drugs trade. The lead character is an upstanding federal judge who becomes appointed drugs tsar, but finds his integrity compromised when his teenage daughter becomes addicted to crack cocaine. Traffic will be directed by Steven Soderbergh, a one-time renegade, currently riding high in Hollywood on the back of recent hits like Out of Sight and Erin Brockovich.

But whispers within Hollywood are increasingly speculating that Costner has over-priced himself. In the past five years, his bankability has been damaged by big-budget flops like The War and The Postman, leaving studios unwilling to pay him the fees he commanded in his early 90s heyday.

The breakdown of the Traffic talks follows hot on the heels of a similar situation on the elephantine Disney production Pearl Harbour. Costner had been in line to play Congressional Medal of Honour-winner General James "Jimmy" Dolittle, but backers were reportedly unable to match his asking price. The role has now gone to Alec Baldwin.

Meanwhile, the Traffic role remains up for grabs. The latest candidate is reported to be Michael Douglas, who was initially offered the role at the end of last year. One possible incentive for Douglas is the chance to work alongside wife Catherine Zeta-Jones, though the pair would actually have no scenes together. In a parallel plotline, Zeta-Jones is scheduled to play the unwitting wife of a big-time cocaine dealer.

Fox are still hoping to begin shooting Traffic in April, but with no lead actor yet in place, time looks to be fast running out.

webTitle: A lot of Community Rehabilitation And Protection

fields.headline: A lot of Community Rehabilitation And Protection
fields.trailText: It must be awful being home secretary. Decisions all carry a trolley load of philosophical baggage. Every day you wrestle with problems that make the topics on The Moral Maze sound as pressing as: "D'you want fries with that?"
fields.body:
It must be awful being home secretary. Decisions all carry a trolley load of philosophical baggage. Every day you wrestle with problems that make the topics on The Moral Maze sound as pressing as: "D'you want fries with that?"

While you try to weigh all the issues in each judgment, adding a gram to one side of the scales, a scruple to the other, innumerable and vocal critics assert that they alone are right, that they alone carry the torch of rectitude. To be even grudgingly approved by one side means being damned by the other.

So it must be quite a relief when discussion turns to Michael Fabricant's mother. I have not had the pleasure of meeting Mrs Helena Fabricant, but it does not sound as if she is hard-wired into Mr Blair's e-Britain.

At home office questions, Jack Straw had been asked about the possibility of electronic voting, of which he is broadly in favour. Mickey sprang to his feet. "People like my mother, who lives in Lichfield," he said, "are quite nervous about using ATM cards. She likes writing out cheques. And when she votes, she likes to make a cross, the old-fashioned way."

Mrs F's unease with modern technology may account for a lot. I suspect that when she was carrying young Mickey, she may have been frightened by a Morris Oxford.

Then there was the matter of the new name for the probation service. Very unwillingly, Paul Boateng, the vengeance minister (not his real title), has agreed that this should now be called the national probation service.

"My joy at that announcement is literally boundless," cried John Bercow. "You will earn a shower of plaudits."

This seems a little over the top, even for Mr Bercow, until you realise that up to yesterday the government was clinging to its earlier decision to call this body the Community Rehabilitation And Probation service. Clearly no one had bothered to read the acronym.

Still, it cannot have caused Mr Straw to lie awake during the long dark nights of the soul. Nor would he have been troubled by Ann Widdecombe's assault over police numbers, one of those rows in which each side hurls carefully selected meaningless statistics, all yanked out of context.

Miss Widdecombe was wearing a garment new to me, a loose black jacket covered in what appeared to be green bamboo shoots, so that she looked like a giant panda that had been rolling round in its lunch.

Then suddenly we were on to the James Bulger murder, and the European court of human rights' decision over the murderers, Thompson and Venables. (I have said that I feel as sorry for their parents as for the Bulgers, for they too have lost their sons, and also have a burden of guilt, shame and public odium that few of us could live with. But MPs are not allowed to think like this.)

I myself was slightly perturbed by Mr Straw saying that, when it came to sentencing, he plans to "ensure that the views of the victims and their relatives are taken into account".

Memo to villains: you might get off lighter if you mug Quakers, Hampstead liberals, and Guardian read ers rather than Essex blokes with earrings and big dogs.

Miss Widdecombe said that the court ruling would cause "great disappointment and offence". Mr Straw can't talk like that. But asked by Michael Howard to say why politicians should be allowed to set sentences for adult killers but not children, he waved a contemptuous hand at the court's thick ruling.

"Bound in the dense text of this judgment, there may be some elucidation. But not, perhaps, illumination."

The home secretary came no nearer to telling the Strasbourg lawyers to get knotted. But it must have been a pleasant short relief before he returns again to the endless moral agonising his job entails.

webTitle: Symonds sparkles as Queensland finish top

fields.headline: Symonds sparkles as Queensland finish top
fields.trailText: Australia
fields.body:
Australia

Andrew Symonds hit a rasping undefeated 140 from just 154 balls to set up Queensland's eighth victory of the season, over South Australia at the Allan Border Field, Brisbane, and confirm their position at the top of the Pura Milk Cup standings. With the league stages now complete, Queensland will have home advantage against Victoria in the five-day final, which begins on March 17.

Symonds made up for a first day that was lost to rain by blasting 17 fours and four sixes in Queensland's first innings of 290 for 9 declared. With quick runs paramount, SA replied with 175 for 6 declared as Darren Lehmann made 104, his seventh first-class century of the season, to finish top of the league-stages run-list, with 995 at 58.72. Andy Bichel picked up 4-44. Queensland opener James Maher then hit a hundred of his own (102*) as his side made the game's third declaration to leave SA needing 274 to win. They managed just 217, despite 85 from opener Shane Deitz.

Queensland 290 for 9 decl. and 158 for 5 decl.
South Australia 175 for 6 decl. and 217
Queensland won by 56 runs

Victoria warmed up for the final with what turned into a high-scoring draw against Tasmania at Hobart. Victoria began reasonably with 279 for 9 as Ian Harvey made a fighting 92 and Paul Reiffel a face-saving 46*, but from then on, the batsmen were indisputably in charge. Tasmania replied with 421, thanks to 153 from Andrew Dykes and 106 from one-time Gloucestershire player Shaun Young. The pair added 219 for the fifth wicket. Reiffel claimed 4-79 to become one of only two players (along with Western Australian quick Brad Williams) to finish the league stages with 50 wickets. But Victoria had little problem batting out for the draw: Matthew Elliott hit 100, Brad Hodge 96, Matthew Mott 86, and Harvey chipped in with 78* as the match petered out.

Victoria 279 for 9 decl. and 477 for 5 decl.
Tasmania 421
Drawn

Western Australia finished third in the table after whipping hapless New South Wales by an innings at the SCG. NSW, who went down to their eighth defeat of the season to cement their place at the bottom of the table, opened with 255, with former Test paceman Jo Angel taking 6-64. NSW were rescued by a sixth-wicket stand of 110 between Bradley Haddin (67) and Michael Clarke (58). WA then racked up 438 for 7 declared in just 91 overs after Michael Hussey (172) shared stands of 197 for the first wicket with the red-hot Ryan Campbell (93) and 151 for the second with Simon Katich (76). Stuart MacGill left the field with figures of 17-0-112-2. Not for the first time, NSW didn't have the stomach for the fight, and were skittled for 149, as Bradley Hogg claimed 5-53.

New South Wales 255 and 149 (Michael Bevan 49)
Western Australia 438 for 7 decl.
Western Australia won by an innings and 34 runs

Final standings (10 matches): 1 Queensland 48pts, 2 Victoria 36, 3 Western Australia 30, 4 South Australia 24, 5 Tasmania 18, 6 New South Wales 5.6.
Queensland and Victoria qualify for the final.

South Africa

Boland reached the final of the one-day Standard Bank Cup by beating Easterns 2-0 in the first of the best-of-three semi-finals. They will meet either Eastern Province or league-winners Gauteng in the final.

Boland won the first game, played on an uneven Benoni wicket, by 25 runs after making a score (190 for 3) which suggested a frustrating time of it for both batsmen and bowlers. Jonathan Trott made a patient 76 and Indian Pravin Amre injected some impetus towards the end with 42* from 49 balls. Left-arm seamer Neil Carter took 4-31. But Easterns failed to come to terms with the wicket and were dismissed for just 165, after folding from 87 for 1.

Boland 190 for 3 in 45 overs
Easterns 165 in 42.4 overs
Boland won by 25 runs

The second match, at Paarl, contained more runs - but ended with a similar result as Boland ran out winners by 30 runs. James Henderson hit 60 to help Boland to 240 for 7, before Easterns subsided to 111 for 7. Johannes Morkel (40) and Pierre de Bruyns (32) staged a mini revival, but it wasn't enough.

Boland 240 for 7 in 45 overs
Easterns 210 in 43.4 overs
Boland won by 30 runs and qualified for the final

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

webTitle: Heart surgery down because of bed shortage, surgeon says

fields.headline: Heart surgery down because of bed shortage, surgeon says
fields.trailText: The number of heart operations carried out in Britain fell last year for the first time in 25 years because of a shortage of intensive care beds, a leading surgeon said today. "It's intensely depressing having to cancel an open heart operation, when you have the patient waiting in the hospital, simply because you don't have the recovery beds," Jules Dussek, the head of the Society of Cardiothoracic Surgeons, told BBC Radio 4's Today programme. Mr Dussek said that, according to the society's research, the United Kingdom came bottom in Europe in terms of the number of heart operations performed compared with those needed. "There is a risk of dying when waiting for that sort of operation," he said.
fields.body:
The number of heart operations carried out in Britain fell last year for the first time in 25 years because of a shortage of intensive care beds, a leading surgeon said today. "It's intensely depressing having to cancel an open heart operation, when you have the patient waiting in the hospital, simply because you don't have the recovery beds," Jules Dussek, the head of the Society of Cardiothoracic Surgeons, told BBC Radio 4's Today programme. Mr Dussek said that, according to the society's research, the United Kingdom came bottom in Europe in terms of the number of heart operations performed compared with those needed. "There is a risk of dying when waiting for that sort of operation," he said.

Mr Dussek said that according to figures compiled by the UK's Cardiac Surgical Register, the number of heart bypass operations fell by around 600 last year to 25,083.

Department of health figures show that heart operations in England - excluding Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland - increased to 23,663 from 22,181 in 1999.

However, Mr Dussek said he was confident his figures were correct. "We collected them from every single unit in the UK and we also collect them from every single surgeon.

"We also phoned round all the units in England a couple of weeks ago and found they were doing 20% to 25% less work that day than they aimed to do."

Surgeons and other staff were "twiddling their thumbs" because there was a desperate shortage of intensive care beds for patients after surgery, he added.

Health secretary Alan Milburn launched a £50m "crusade" against coronary heart disease this month and unveiled plans to cut heart deaths by 40% by 2010. The plan includes the creation of 100 "rapid reaction" chest pain clinics across the country by 2002 to guarantee patients an appointment with a specialist within two weeks of seeing their GP. Mr Dussek welcomed the plan and said the number of heart operations carried out in 2000 could increase by 2,000 to 3,000 due to extra government funding and initiatives, though he cautioned that the government measures amounted to only a "drop in the ocean". He also said that the government's target of reducing death from heart disease by 40% by 2010 was optimistic.

Coronary heart disease kills one in four men and one in five women in Britain, one of the highest death rates in the world. About 1.4m people in the country suffer from the disease.

fields.headline: Help from the big boys
fields.standfirst: Coke boss puts fizz into government bid to recruit business to new councils
fields.trailText: Business ought to be chuffed. When the new system for post-16 training and education comes into force next year, its feet will be firmly under the table.
fields.body:
Business ought to be chuffed. When the new system for post-16 training and education comes into force next year, its feet will be firmly under the table.

The government's only guarantee to date about the 47 new Local Learning and Skills Councils is that people with industrial or commercial experience will fill two-fifths of the places on them. So business ought to be raring to grab the chance of a say in shaping the national workforce and of helping to decide how £6bn is spent, says Chris Banks, the managing director of Coca-Cola Great Britain.

The existence of the Post-16 Business Champions Group suggests that it is not as simple as that. The champs - who consist of Banks and nine other leading British businessmen from Unipart, Jaguar, Nortel, Perkins and the Post Office - were asked by Tony Blair and David Blunkett to assist in recruiting businessfolk to the councils.

Those who agree to serve on the councils will in effect be non executive directors on the board of companies with annual turnovers exceeding £100m apiece.

Last week Banks joined Malcolm Wicks, the lifelong learning minister, on a trip to Bristol to spread the good news. There was undoubted interest in the audience, but not unadulterated delight.

Some people wanted solid proof that the councils would have real control over budgets. And representatives from smaller businesses were sceptical that they could afford to give time to a Learning and Skills Council if they were not remunerated.

The champions group have rejected the idea of payment. But won't this mean that only big business will be able to afford to spare staff to serve on the councils?

Back in his west London office, Banks remains upbeat.

"My experience is that when business people feel they can make a genuine difference, then they prioritise their time accordingly."

He is keen that the councils should attract people from small- to medium-sized firms and representatives from ethnic minorities.

"I do understand that it's easier for managers in big companies to serve, but I'm sure that it is not a question of money. I don't think that if you had a small fee for doing it, it would necessarily make any difference."

The lure of wielding influence will override people's reservations, he reckons. The councils will be directly responsible for allocating up to 15% of the £100m odd annual budgets to local education and training needs. They will also have a critical role, he says, in deciding precisely what kind of education and training the remaining 85% of the money is spent on locally.

"If you are a business person or an employer, consider putting yourself forward to be on one of these councils, because they really will make a difference. They are our opportunity to ensure we get the highly skilled, trained and motivated 21st-century workforce that we will need to compete.

"These are not talking shops. These are important groups with decision-making powers."

To colleges fearful of losing their autonomy, he emphasised that the councils are designed to balance the needs of the various interested parties - students, colleges, other providers and employers. One of his company's fundamental beliefs, he said, is that its employees should be active model citizens and welcome partners in their local communities.

His underlying message seems to be that those in the wider business community could do worse than follow Coke's example and step forward to serve when the call comes.

Those who agree to serve on the councils will in effect be non executive directors on the board of companies with annual turnovers exceeding £100m apiece. Last week Banks joined Malcolm Wicks, the lifelong learning minister, on a trip to Bristol to spread the good news. There was undoubted interest in the audience, but not unadulterated delight. Some people wanted solid proof that the councils would have real control over budgets. And representatives from smaller businesses were sceptical that they could afford to give time to a Learning and Skills Council if they were not remunerated. The champions group have rejected the idea of payment. But won't this mean that only big business will be able to afford to spare staff to serve on the councils? Back in his west London office, Banks remains upbeat. "My experience is that when business people feel they can make a genuine difference, then they prioritise their time accordingly." He is keen that the councils should attract people from small- to medium-sized firms and representatives from ethnic minorities. "I do understand that it's easier for managers in big companies to serve, but I'm sure that it is not a question of money. I don't think that if you had a small fee for doing it, it would necessarily make any difference." The lure of wielding influence will override people's reservations, he reckons. The councils will be directly responsible for allocating up to 15% of the £100m odd annual budgets to local education and training needs. They will also have a critical role, he says, in deciding precisely what kind of education and training the remaining 85% of the money is spent on locally. "If you are a business person or an employer, consider putting yourself forward to be on one of these councils, because they really will make a difference. They are our opportunity to ensure we get the highly skilled, trained and motivated 21st-century workforce that we will need to compete. "These are not talking shops. These are important groups with decision-making powers." To colleges fearful of losing their autonomy, he emphasised that the councils are designed to balance the needs of the various interested parties - students, colleges, other providers and employers. One of his company's fundamental beliefs, he said, is that its employees should be active model citizens and welcome partners in their local communities. His underlying message seems to be that those in the wider business community could do worse than follow Coke's example and step forward to serve when the call comes.

fields.headline: Much ado about Hamlet
fields.standfirst: Donald Hiscock  sees his students go from bard to worse
fields.trailText: Donald Hiscock sees his students go from bard to worse
fields.body:
It was ironic that the coach trip to see a production of Hamlet should end up the way it did.

I don't mean that it ended up with bodies all over the place, fighting, procrastination and outbreaks of insanity. Actually, come to think about it, I do mean it in that way.

Encouraging my access students to fill up the empty places turned out to be a mistake. A group of adults aiming for undergraduate study were cajoled into spending an evening with their younger fellow students in London.

Your average A-level student endures the theatre experience. They go, sneak a bottle of vodka onto the coach, come back, have little to say about what they saw and then move on to the next trip. It's quite predictable really.

But my access group went for the experience, experienced it in a big way and are still experiencing it now.

Right from the first meeting the access class had taken on the feel of a therapy group. Everyone seemed to want to share the experience of being late. A discussion of the unreliability of the number 25 bus took on an absurdist philosophical edge. Subsequently, there were regular confessional outpourings, inspired by some line of poetry or prose. I found it hard to stop them.

It was all my fault anyway. I had stressed in that first lesson how a strong personal response was important. I urged them to relate their own experiences to those being described in the texts. I wanted them to rely on their own feelings. Big mistake.

It was Sandra who normally took the lead. She could latch on to the smallest detail and make it her own. Sheldon revealed dark moments about his time in Vietnam. None of us believed him, but we were too frightened to challenge him on the subject. Gerda was good at re-marriages. Frank liked to share his religion with us. Solitaire had to leave the room whenever death was mentioned. The version of Hamlet we ended up discussing became an upbeat romantic comedy, so anxious was I not to upset anyone's sensibilities.

The play turned out to be excellent. I had not told the access group in advance about the all-female cast and the 1930s Stalinist setting. I spent much of the performance looking at my adult students for signs of distress, but they were transfixed. Solitaire crunched mints for the entire three hours and Frank only emitted one of his characteristic low groans on a couple of occasions.

They may have been subdued on the coach journey home, but when the access group next met it was clear that responses had been bottled up. There was an ominous silence at the start of the lesson during which I expounded upon the happy-go-lucky world of Elsinore where all problems are resolved. Shortly after mentioning madness things went out of my control.

I think you can imagine what happened. Sheldon wanted to tell us about effective methods of poisoning, Gerda told Frank what she thought of his proselytising, Solitaire sobbed. My teaching career seemed to flash before my eyes. There were bodies of opinion everywhere.

If this is what Shakespeare's Denmark had done to my students, I was definitely in a pretty rotten state.
