fields.headline: Paradise postponed
fields.standfirst: The much-needed change and progress that devolution brought to colleges in Northern Ireland is being smothered by the reimposition of direct rule
fields.trailText: The much-needed change and progress that devolution brought to colleges in Northern Ireland is being smothered by the reimposition of direct rule
fields.body:
Further education in Northern Ireland is entering a "revolutionary" phase and holds one of the keys to lasting peace. So says David Hunter, who is director of the Association of Northern Ireland Colleges.

"The really strange thing was that that border was like the Berlin wall. Everything stopped at it."

Northern Ireland's 17 further education colleges were working within a very small geographic and population area, dominated by the violence. Since 1972, decisions had been made by Westminster direct rule ministers, whose interests were primarily English. There were no links with colleges in Ireland, no sharing of expertise and no access to the much more vibrant Irish economy. Protestants hesitated to seek contacts.

"Change now is down to agencies like ourselves," Hunter says.

Sadly the politicians in London and Belfast seem determined to block that revolution. The reimposition in February of direct rule from Westminster after the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, threatened to resign as First Minister, was, Dr Hunter believes, little short of tragic.

When devolution came last November the education departments were reorganised, giving responsibility for training, further education and higher education to one minister and all pre-16 education to another. Dr Sean Farren, the Social Democratic and Labour Party member to whom the higher and further portfolio fell, lectured for 25 years at the University of Ulster in Coleraine. Many decisions had been put on hold during the talks which took place between the Good Friday agreement and devolution, and were now hurried through.

Dr Farren spent his first fortnight as a minister doing the rounds of further education and training personnel, admitting his lack of knowledge.

"I recognise that people will assume that my real interest is higher education," he said, "but I recognise that further education has been the Cinderella and I want to see equality in provision and in funding."

He instituted an immediate enquiry into student funding, including fees, looking at Scottish developments and was considering giving further education students parity with higher education. That enquiry is continuing, but with no local minister to report to. He promised to encourage links between further education colleges and the Northern Ireland universities, and to promote franchising of degrees. Almost his last decision was to approve a new university campus with further education links at Springvale on the peaceline in Belfast.

The imposition of fees by the British government has raised a barrier in Ireland that Dr Hunter believes is culturally damaging. A social scientist, he taught at the Belfast Institute until he became the Association's second director a year ago.

"We taught an HND Social Care course. It was useful having people in the class who came from the other jurisdiction. It is useful to see that there is another point of view if you teach community relations. A lot of people ignore the differences, but you don't solve anything that way." Now far fewer southerners can afford to come north.

David Hunter was impressed by devolution. "I think we had a minister who wasn't from England, who had a real interest. We were seeing a greater focus. We were trying to solve our own problems. It became our responsibility not the responsibility of somebody who did not have to report back to a democratic body in Northern Ireland. What we appreciated was that he had a real commitment to social inclusion."

Dr Hunter is an adult learner himself, having worked in England, then returned to college to take A levels. His first job back in Northern Ireland was with the Shankill Initiative, a development programme to regenerate a poverty-stricken and fiercely loyalist area of Belfast. His wife, a nurse, is finishing an Open University degree. His ambition is a secure future in Northern Ireland for his children.

His son has just passed his 11-plus and his daughter is 17 and considering university.

Like so many other parents, particularly Protestants - who are witnessing a disproportionate brain drain of student children because they fear unionism has no future - he hates the thought of them going to Britain to study and never returning. The arrival of devolved government meant, he had hoped, "that my children could have normal lives here."

The further education revolution was encouraged by the IRA ceasefires, and given momentum by the 1998 Good Friday Agreement. Two years ago Northern Ireland's further education colleges were removed from the control of the Education and Libraries Board and followed the English colleges into incorporation. They combined to form the Association and instituted cross border partnerships to pool knowledge. Colleges north and south were asked to consider shared teaching and moderation and swapping of expertise in specialist areas.

Last October the Association took 150 people involved in further education to Innis, County Clare, Ireland's e-town.

"What we saw there was the town of the future. Schools, colleges and businesses were all linked through the internet."

A meeting in Athlone of principals from north and south followed, and partnerships have been made with employers and local authorities. The Association began nurturing initiatives in eight curriculum areas, designed to increase technical skills within Northern Ireland and to give people wanting leisure learning access to everything from Tiffaney glass to computing.

Northern Ireland retains the 11-plus and has an education system that, at its best, produces much higher results than Britain, but, at its worst, nurtures significantly higher levels of adult illiteracy. A recent report by a team from Queen's and the University of Ulster shows the 11-plus has increased social and academic disadvantage.

There is also a skills shortage in vital modern technical and information technology areas, where the north lags behind the south. Information technology and call centres are gold mines for remote areas.

The skill gaps - together with currency disparities because Britain is outside the European currency union - make it more difficult for the north to attract IT industries. North-south disparities mean skilled workers head south, where the economy is booming.

"It is impossible to get a plumber or an electrician in the north," Dr Hunter said. "There is a major skills drain. You have only got to look at what Xerox is doing in Dundalk to see what is happening." Xerox is building a huge plant in Dundalk, five miles south of the border. It has turned one of the wildest of the bandit-country safe havens for terrorists into a boom town.

Direct rule threatens progress, Dr Hunter said. "The difference with devolution is the ability of our ministers to get involved and understand detail. The big problem is that that momentum is lost."

fields.headline: On the money
fields.standfirst: We must spend ten times more on learning, says  Martin Yarnit
fields.trailText: We must spend ten times more on learning, says Martin Yarnit
fields.body:
The 1870 Education Act has outlived its usefulness. We must throw off its baleful influence, if we are to move forward.

The truth is that its underlying elitist assumptions are as strong now as they ever were. It has helped to legitimise a class-divided education system, led by Oxbridge, fed by fee-paying schools, and subsidised by the majority who still leave formal education at 16 or even earlier.

What should we replace the 1870 Act with? The forthcoming Urban white paper provides an opportunity to redesign our learning system at the same time as we set about preparing the urban renaissance. Learning City Network has teamed up with the Local Government Association and the think-tank, Demos, to devise a Manifesto for Urban Learning aimed at shaping the government's thinking about learning's contribution to dynamic, wealth-creating, but inclusive and sustainable cities and communities.

Issues which go to the heart of this transformation are content, organisation and funding.

Learning how to learn creatively and critically is the key skill. A recent Demos study of new approaches to learning in Sweden and Canada shows that creativity is not an inherent talent, but a quality that can be learnt. Although still in its infancy, Microsoft's Anytime, Anywhere Learning (AAL) initiative, based on portable communications, shows the right direction. AAL classrooms are marked by a new sense of purpose with learners taking charge of their own learning.

And there are signs of a new system emerging, characterised by all-day, all-year, high-street or neighbourhood access, with effective guidance and support. Our aim should be an entitlement for all - prioritised to favour people without qualifications - to learning throughout life. If necessary, as Alan Wells has argued here, we should pay people to become literate and numerate. What we need is a push by government to bring a new collaborative system into existence and to give it shape.

Finally, there's funding. Moving to a mass education system will cost. And if education is that important, the tax system will have to be redesigned around it. Employers who take their company's learning seriously should be rewarded through the tax system too. A 10-fold increase in the value of Individual Learning Accounts, to £1500, might just begin to expand the market for learning.

 Martin Yarnit is a co-director of LCN - the Network for Learning Communities.

fields.headline: Poacher pays
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston on a new government solution to a desperate skills shortage
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston on a new government solution to a desperate skills shortage
fields.body:
Severe shortages of skilled manual workers in many industries have forced government to consider lending employers the cash to train more people.

The gas industry, which is hit by an acute scarcity of qualified service, maintenance and installation engineers, is to pilot a loan scheme.

The industry managed to train only 128 new engineers under the age of 25 last year, which falls drastically short of the 2,500 needed to replace staff who retire. Employers say the main barrier to training new staff is the considerable cost and the risk that a competitor will immediately poach them, wiping out their investment.

Under the proposed transferable loan scheme, a company could be lent up to £5,000 towards the costs of training an employee. The money would be advanced in the individual's name, but paid back by the employer over an extended period at a reasonable rate of interest.

If another firm tried to hire the employee, the onus for repayment would pass to the employee, or to the new employer.

"We need a mechanism to encourage employers to train personnel - without incentives it won't happen," said a senior DfEE official.

The shortage of workers in the gas industry, which could start to pose a threat to safety if not reversed, has come about since British Gas lost its monopoly position as a public utility in 1986. It could then afford to train about 2,500 engineers a year.

Now there are some 97,000 people on the Council for Regulating Gas Installers (Corgi) register. More of them are over 60 than under 25. Their employers have to register as well. There are about 45,000 companies on the Corgi list, 37,000 of them one-person outfits. Only one company has more than 1,000 staff, and only six have more than 100.

"Many other sectors are keen to see how this scheme works because they have similar problems," said the DfEE official.

The sectors include hospitality - particularly at the top "chef" end, heavy goods vehicles, textiles, film production, electricity, and construction. The third report of the Skills Task Force recently highlighted their problems.

Many industries used to impose levies on firms to support training costs, but these faded out in the last 30 years of the 20th century. Now only the construction sector retains a levy system, but many firms claim exemption. Restoring a levy system would now be out of the question politically, government realises.

But the loan proposal has been greeted with enthusiasm, according to David Salisbury, chief executive of the Gas Industry National Training Organisation (GINTO).

So far the shortage has posed no threat to safety, he said.

"In five years' time, if nothing's done about it, there'll be a problem."

PriceWaterhouseCoopers is carrying out a feasibility study and weighing up the risks of a loan scheme. HSBC bank looks keen to finance it.

The most likely option for the scheme, which is due to start in late spring, would be to loan the £5,000 sum in the name of the individual to be trained. This would offset the training cost of £2,000-£3,000, and help with a typical training salary of about £9,000. The loan would be repaid by the employer over three and a half years at 8.5% interest.

If, however, the individual moved jobs, responsibility to repay the loan would go with them.

fields.headline: Occupational therapy
fields.trailText: Occupational therapy
fields.body:
What do occupational therapists do? They assess and treat people with a wide variety of psychological and physical afflictions, which may be temporary or permanent.

Sort of super doctors, by the sound of it. Not exactly, although you'll certainly find them working in hospitals. They also operate within social service departments, and in day centres for children and the elderly. They might also be found in specialist burns or spinal injuries units. And they visit patients at home.

They get about, so to speak. They certainly do. Many companies are using occupational therapists within the workplace as a means of preventing problems. And as patients now spend less time in hospitals convalescing, there is more emphasis on caring in the community where the skills of occupational therapists are in increasing demand.

But what do they do? Their aim is to enable patients to be as independent as possible in all aspects of their life, whether it be work, leisure or daily living, regardless of old age, disability or illness.

Bit of a toughie, I should have thought. How do they do that? By establishing the reasons behind the patient's difficulties, the therapist and the patient work together using a program of carefully selected and graded activity, which can be of a physical or mental nature.

What sort of activity are we talking about here? It could involve music, art or drama, for instance.

Yeeuch! Is there no fun? It doesn't have to be art or drama, as enjoyable as very many people find them. It could be anything to help increase self-reliance and self-care and to suit the patient's lifestyle.

So, what do occupational therapists need? A caring, understanding and sympathetic nature is essential. And the ability to get on with a wide range of people, from health workers to the very ill. Good judgement and observational skills, and excellent communication are all desirable. Plus bags of stamina and energy to deal with and adjust to the problems encountered.

That's a lot of requirements... There's more. They may be needed to provide counselling for people suffering chronic or worsening illness, to help them prepare and plan for the oncoming stages.

Some courses may expect more passes and specific grades. There should be at least one pass in a science subject. Biology A level is useful, and sometimes a requirement. There are various professional development awards in occupational therapy support: eg creative therapy, hospital play, and there are college awards in art therapy, person-centred art therapy, dance movement. There's even a National Certificate in agricultural and horticultural therapy.

fields.headline: Putting the story in history
fields.standfirst: How can you make history fun? Lindsey Fraser picks out the books that bring the past to life
fields.trailText: How can you make history fun? Lindsey Fraser picks out the books that bring the past to life
fields.body:
A recent car journey, during which I was regaled from the back seat with a semi-dramatised version of Bonnie Prince Charlie's spirited but doomed attempt to squash the English, was testament to the skills of a good teacher but also to the power of stories. Apart from the tremendous thrill of legitimately, and repeatedly, using the word "bloody", it was the story which caught that child's imagination.

Philip Ardagh's Get A Life! series (Macmillan, £2.99) adopts a conversational tone but diligently packs in the facts. In his Queen Elizabeth I, the complicated circumstances surrounding the monarch's accession to the throne and her feisty manoeuvring to maintain control are told in a series of headlined paragraphs, the facts dotted with a series of cartoons and dry one-liners which 8-11s will love.

Ardagh is an enthusiastic explainer, and he revels in the complexity of British history. He avoids the temptation to embellish unnecessarily - the extraordinary stories are left to speak for themselves.

Every school child seems to "do" the second world war at least once. Bob Fowke's What They Don't Tell You About... World War II (Hodder, £3.99) gives a guided tour through the eyes of Linda Hand, a Land Army girl. Despite the jokey cover, the contents are weighty but highly accessible, and may well inspire conversations with relatives who remember that time. This is a detailed resource for 9- to 12-year-olds giving the wider context of the war in Europe and conveying the unsettling fact that, although the dates of the war are now second nature, the 1945 ending was not pre-programmed.

Paris 1789 (Sightseers, Kingfisher, £5.99) offers a historical picture of the city in the form of a travel guide. There is illustrated advice on clothing, health, art and accessing French society, set against the growing division between King Louis XVI and Queen Marie Antoinette and their subjects. Children from 8-12 will need supplementary information if they are to grasp the facts of the French Revolution, but this tangential approach is useful in putting the conflict into a social context.

More than 30 years ago, man landed on the moon. The event is now history, and all the more distant because it hasn't been repeated in the lifetime of schoolchildren. What Would You Ask Neil Armstrong? (Belitha, £8.99) tells the story of the first astronaut to walk on the moon, a man who fulfilled an extraordinary ambition and then, literally and metaphorically, came back down to earth. The book provides lots of technical and personal details which put the programme into context for 7-11s.

fields.headline: Death of a dream
fields.standfirst: After their ferocious attacks on Chechnya are Russian troops guilty of war crimes?
fields.trailText: After their ferocious attacks on Chechnya are Russian troops guilty of war crimes?
fields.body:
As fighting in the remote republic of Chechnya enters its seventh month, forces in Chechnya are being accused of war crimes, including the murder, rape and torture of civilians. Countries such as Britain are demanding that these stories are investigated, but in Russia the brutal campaign against Chechen forces has increased the popularity of acting president Vladimir Putin.

Where is Chechnya?

Find the Black Sea on a map of Russia and go east until you spot Grozny. This is the Chechen capital - now in ruins. Chechnya is a bit smaller than Wales. It is a land of grassy hills and in the south the foothills and high peaks of the Caucasus Mountains provide the remaining Chechen forces with cover for ambushes. The fertile middle of the country is dotted with villages. Here ordinary people have been in the firing line.

What caused this conflict?

In 1991, Chechen leaders declared that Chechnya was an independent state. Russia never accepted this. It blamed the Chechens for numerous acts of banditry against railways, buses and oil pipelines and decided to invade in December 1994. The result was a total defeat for the Russian army. Over 5,000 Russian troops may have died. Russia's desire to get even for this is a factor behind today's fighting. It also explains why the Russians have bombed Grozny and other settlements to smithereens rather than send in troops: the Chechens are expert street fighters.

Why did the end of the war not bring peace?

Since 1996, Chechnya's leaders have found it impossible to keep control. The raiding has continued and a campaign of kidnapping began. Among the victims were border guards, foreign visitors, Russian officials and businessmen. Many were killed - often by beheading. In August 1999, a strong force under the leadership of the popular Chechen commander Shamil Basayev and a Saudi Arabian called Habib Khattab attacked the neighbouring republic of Daghestan, hoping to unite it to Chechnya and create a single Islamic state. The Russian army was called to defend Daghestan and then moved into Chechnya to crush the "rebels".

So why should anyone care about what happens in Chechnya?

Any conflict that results in terrible slaughter should worry us. The citizens of Grozny and nearby villages have been the victims of the Russian bombardment and have been used as cover by Chechen fighters. Multiple rocket launchers and vacuum bombs, which create a fire storm and cause terrible blast injuries, have been used.

Are there rules controlling such conflicts?

There are international laws that are meant to regulate wars and conflicts. The 1949 Geneva Conventions cover the treatment of prisoners and civilians and, if they are broken, those responsible are guilty of war crimes. Unfortunately, the conventions are designed for fighting between countries. Internal wars are covered by a separate but weaker international agreement (Protocol II). The Russians are not even accepting that this is an "internal conflict" as defined by the Protocol. They call Chechen fighters terrorists and the fighting a "police action". Many Russians agree.

But what about the killing of civilians?

Human Rights Watch say Russian troops have been responsible for a series of massacres of ordinary people. The guards running special Russian "filtration camps" have been accused of torturing and raping Chechens. These human rights abuses are punishable, but Russia will have to cooperate.

What else can be done?

Western countries could try to reduce aid to Russia, but as much of this is helping to pay for Russian nuclear disarmament, no one wants to do that.

Who benefits from this war?

Vladimir Putin. He is likely to win the coming presidential election because of his strong stand. The Russian army has won pride after the 1996 disaster. The republics bordering Chechnya may be relieved there will be no Chechen invasion.

Will the killing stop?

It is likely to carry on, with Chechens ambushing Russian troops and Russian forces raiding. The republics bordering Chechnya are probably relieved there is no risk of a Chechen invasion.

Further information

Special report
Human Rights Watch
Institute for War and Peace Reporting
www.crimesofwar.org

fields.headline: Get your book into print
fields.standfirst: Have you got what it takes to be an author or an illustrator - do you think you could create a fantastic book for the Children's Laureate, Quentin Blake?
fields.trailText: Have you got what it takes to be an author or an illustrator - do you think you could create a fantastic book for the Children's Laureate, Quentin Blake?
fields.body:
Have you got what it takes to be an author or an illustrator - do you think you could create a fantastic book for the Children's Laureate, Quentin Blake? If you or your class enter our competition, you could win an invitation to the Laureate's Party, which we'll be celebrating with Quentin Blake himself! Your book can be an individual work, or by a group or a class.

The subject is up to you. It could be based on your favourite hobby or teacher or be an interpretation of the book you have enjoyed the most.

The winning class and prize-winning individual will each get an expenses-paid trip to the Laureate's Party in Birmingham on May 25, plus a selection of Red Fox books for their school library. Send your books to The Laureate's Party Competition, PO Box 1375, 20 Vauxhall Bridge Road, London SW1V 2SA. Keep a copy - entries cannot be returned. The closing date for entries is April 14.

fields.headline: Educating Gita
fields.standfirst: The pupils in India are eager, but there are many obstacles: tigers, monsoons and disappearing teachers
fields.trailText: The pupils in India are eager, but there are many obstacles: tigers, monsoons and disappearing teachers
fields.body:
Coming some way behind the camel corps and the elephants, the float honouring education in India's constitution day parade in Delhi the other week represented, as so often in the subcontinent, a triumph of hope over experience.

The eager pupils on the float tapped away industriously at their mock computer terminals, illuminated by the ubiquitous Microsoft logo, shining symbols of the country's aspirations. But unfortunately, by the time they floated past the crowds along the Rajpath, governmental Delhi's imperial highway, the attention of the spectators was already wandering, dazzled as they were by the much lengthier, earlier display of India's military might, its MiG fighters, tanks and weapons systems to counter the threat from Pakistan.

There was little question as to which elements of the parade had received most care and resources from India's politicians. Although successive governments have launched initiatives and paid lip service to the importance of education, spending remains woefully low and the degree of the authorities' real commitment is questioned.

India spends 3.9% of its GDP on education - that includes private sources as well as public - compared with 4.7% in Britain. Kailash Satyarthi, whose charity rescuing children from bonded labour in factories does not endear him to the authorities, said: "There is a kind of hidden conspiracy. Everything is reserved into the hands of the high-class elite of society. If you opened everything up through education, their position would be threatened."

Surveys even among the poorest rural labourers show parents increasingly keen for their children to be educated. And unlike 20 years ago, that includes girls. In Keonjhan, Orissa province, they have a saying: "The educated have four eyes, whereas the uneducated are blind." Parents there told researchers that education was useful to avoid being cheated or to help set up a business. "Men view education as a means of income generation, whereas women see it as an opportunity for enlightenment, earning respect and... improving marriage prospects."

In Delhi you don't have to wander far to watch troops of children in immaculate school uniforms, their white shirts gleaming, picking their way home across the piles of rubbish that line the city's streets. On your flight back home to the west, you are quite likely to be seated next to an earnest young Indian student jetting off to Minnesota or Memphis to pursue his studies in microbiology or business.

India is justly proud of such high achievers. Sadly, they remain the exception rather than the rule. In a country of 577,000 primary schools, where education in the local language was supposed to be guaranteed to every child as a right 30 years ago, insuperable problems remain and they may be getting worse.

Against the goal set in the constitution 50 years ago, that every child should have access to free state education (a target which should have been reached by 1960), the Indian government can claim that 95% of the country's children now live within 1km of a school. Unfortunately, only two-thirds of six- to 10-year-olds manage to make it that far. Researchers note a series of reasons why some children do not get to school regularly even when their parents wish to send them: from floods washing away paths to tigers and cobras lurking in the verges.

A recent report illustrates the problem: "In Doodapura, Rajasthan, the school is located on a separate hill. Small children find it difficult to get there. During the monsoon, the path is under water and the school remains closed for weeks or even months at a time. There is no school in Chaktodar, Uttar Pradesh. The governing school in the neighbouring village of Gyanpur has to be approached through the bazaar. This makes it unsafe for children and compounds the distance problem," inspectors noted.

Of those who do get to school, up to 80% of those in rural areas don't finish the course, leaving at least 33m children without any education at all. Only just over 52% of men and 39% of women across the country as a whole are literate.

Even for those who get to school, the experience is often unrewarding. Although the school is usually the largest and best equipped building in the village, that is not always saying much. As recent researchers for a Probe (public report on basic education) survey remarked: "Of the schools, 30% were used for non-teaching purposes. At least five were used by the teachers for residential purposes (spanking new schools built with World Bank aid seem to be one of their favourite dwellings).

"Other cases of gross misutilisation included their prolonged use as a storage space, a police camp, a place to dry cow dung cakes, a cattle shed and even a community latrine... Most school premises range from mildly unattractive to frankly repulsive.

"Rajkiya Draupadi Kanya Prathmik Vidhyalaya in Vangaon (north Bihar) is one of the few schools that boasts as many as four classrooms. However, these are close to disintegration. Six children were injured in three separate incidents when parts of the building fell down and even now there is an acute danger of terminal collapse. The children huddle in two rooms on sacking brought from home. There is no teaching equipment; blackboards are broken and there is no chalk.

"The playground is full of muck and slime. The overflowing drains could easily drown a small child. Mosquitoes are swarming. There is no toilet... teachers complain of neighbours using the playground as a toilet in the morning."

The most ubiquitous teaching aid is the stick. Three quarters of schools now have blackboards, but only 23% have what could be called a library and 33% have what counts as equipment - sometimes even this is locked away by teachers who fear they may be charged if it is damaged.

Tarun Sarwal, Oxfam's deputy director in India, says: "There has been a huge increase in the media available. Most villages now have access to national television. They now have role models in their lives. Unfortunately, I have yet to see a rural school with a working computer. Most do not even have electricity."

The Probe reporters found schools where teachers did not turn up, or arrived late or drunk. Fewer than 60% had had even a week's training. Only one in five were female - it is a difficult profession for a woman in a society where girls are expected to live at home until their marriage and there are likely to be suspicions if they are sent by the authorities to schools miles away across the state.

Much teaching is done by rote, to centrally laid-down criteria, established by non-teachers, often taking little account of pupils' needs or aptitudes. Researchers found eight-year-olds being taught regulations for drivers under the highway code. Little wonder that attainment tests have to be adjusted downwards to ensure that at least some children pass.

Snehlata Gupta, a Delhi teacher, says: "The curriculum is drastically at variance with the life these children lead... They are simply unable to relate to the finer subtleties of birthday parties, balanced diets, family holidays or multi-storey homes... Much teaching is conducted in an abusive and callous manner. For these children, school does not open up a new world of learning and knowledge."

A series of initiatives - Operation Blackboard, to establish minimum criteria for primary schools, Lok Jumbish, an attempt to involve local people more in the running of schools, which is supported by Britain's Department for International Development, the National Literacy Mission - have all had some effect. Regions such as Kerala, in the far south of the country, have achieved success by devoting higher priority to education than the more caste-bound states of the north.

The smart money is on India to become one of the tiger economies of the 21st century. But if it is to do so, one of the world's great civilisations will have to do more for all its children.

Global Week of Action

Ten years ago, the world's governments promised "education for all" by 2000. Their priorities were to give all children a primary education and reduce adult illiteracy, especially among women. But these promises were not kept. At a world summit in 1995, they re-wrote the targets. This time they set the deadline for 2015. But who's to say they won't break their promises again? From April 3-10 there will be a Global Week of Action when the world's governments will meet. In association with the Guardian, Oxfam and the NUT, the charity ActionAid has produced free resource packs. Distributed in March to all schools in England and Wales, Broken Promises uses real case studies from developing countries where ActionAid and Oxfam work and invites schools to take part in the Charter for Change competition, where they can help to influence the decisions of governments.

"Rajkiya Draupadi Kanya Prathmik Vidhyalaya in Vangaon (north Bihar) is one of the few schools that boasts as many as four classrooms. However, these are close to disintegration. Six children were injured in three separate incidents when parts of the building fell down and even now there is an acute danger of terminal collapse. The children huddle in two rooms on sacking brought from home. There is no teaching equipment; blackboards are broken and there is no chalk. "The playground is full of muck and slime. The overflowing drains could easily drown a small child. Mosquitoes are swarming. There is no toilet... teachers complain of neighbours using the playground as a toilet in the morning." The most ubiquitous teaching aid is the stick. Three quarters of schools now have blackboards, but only 23% have what could be called a library and 33% have what counts as equipment - sometimes even this is locked away by teachers who fear they may be charged if it is damaged. Tarun Sarwal, Oxfam's deputy director in India, says: "There has been a huge increase in the media available. Most villages now have access to national television. They now have role models in their lives. Unfortunately, I have yet to see a rural school with a working computer. Most do not even have electricity." The Probe reporters found schools where teachers did not turn up, or arrived late or drunk. Fewer than 60% had had even a week's training. Only one in five were female - it is a difficult profession for a woman in a society where girls are expected to live at home until their marriage and there are likely to be suspicions if they are sent by the authorities to schools miles away across the state. Much teaching is done by rote, to centrally laid-down criteria, established by non-teachers, often taking little account of pupils' needs or aptitudes. Researchers found eight-year-olds being taught regulations for drivers under the highway code. Little wonder that attainment tests have to be adjusted downwards to ensure that at least some children pass. Snehlata Gupta, a Delhi teacher, says: "The curriculum is drastically at variance with the life these children lead... They are simply unable to relate to the finer subtleties of birthday parties, balanced diets, family holidays or multi-storey homes... Much teaching is conducted in an abusive and callous manner. For these children, school does not open up a new world of learning and knowledge." A series of initiatives - Operation Blackboard, to establish minimum criteria for primary schools, Lok Jumbish, an attempt to involve local people more in the running of schools, which is supported by Britain's Department for International Development, the National Literacy Mission - have all had some effect. Regions such as Kerala, in the far south of the country, have achieved success by devoting higher priority to education than the more caste-bound states of the north. The smart money is on India to become one of the tiger economies of the 21st century. But if it is to do so, one of the world's great civilisations will have to do more for all its children. Global Week of Action Ten years ago, the world's governments promised "education for all" by 2000. Their priorities were to give all children a primary education and reduce adult illiteracy, especially among women. But these promises were not kept. At a world summit in 1995, they re-wrote the targets. This time they set the deadline for 2015. But who's to say they won't break their promises again? From April 3-10 there will be a Global Week of Action when the world's governments will meet. In association with the Guardian, Oxfam and the NUT, the charity ActionAid has produced free resource packs. Distributed in March to all schools in England and Wales, Broken Promises uses real case studies from developing countries where ActionAid and Oxfam work and invites schools to take part in the Charter for Change competition, where they can help to influence the decisions of governments.

fields.headline: Expression of science
fields.standfirst: How do you follow the success of winning the Top UK Young Science Presenters Award in 1999? The answer was simple for pupils at Aylesbury Grammar School: organise your own science conference.
fields.trailText: How do you follow the success of winning the Top UK Young Science Presenters Award in 1999? The answer was simple for pupils at Aylesbury Grammar School: organise your own science conference.
fields.body:
How do you follow the success of winning the Top UK Young Science Presenters Award in 1999? The answer was simple for pupils at Aylesbury Grammar School: organise your own science conference. Having sent out 300 letters, secured the sponsorship of British Energy and the attendance of Dr Mark Davies of the Open University Earth Science department, the Survival 2000 conference took place on March 10.

Eight schools presented their findings on topics as diverse as the effect of muntjac deer on fenland agriculture to living with diabetes.

A conference like this is not new. The Pupil Research Initiative, Express Yourself, has been running for seven years and has provided Aylesbury Grammar with many plaudits. The aim is for pupils to undertake research that is not constrained by the national curriculum. In the words of Dr Tony Sherborne, a leading figure in Pupil Research, "pupils are so often just on the receiving end, but here they can be in the driving seat."

Express Yourself holds regional conferences to hear and judge the findings of young scientists from across the UK, leading to a grand final held at the Royal Institute.

In the past there has been one vital ingredient missing from such projects: a sense of a scientific community working together and exchanging ideas. To this end, the Synergy website was launched in 1999. It encourages schools to work together on research and to communicate via the internet. Pupils at Aylesbury Grammar helped to design the site.

For further information about the Pupil Research Initiatives, call Dr Tony Sherborne on 0117-928 8718

webTitle: Getting the most out of parents evening

fields.headline: Getting the most out of parents evening
fields.standfirst: Our daughter is in her first year of secondary school and is finding it hard to settle in. In some subjects, she seems completely at sea and is not getting much help from the teachers. As a parents evening is approaching, how should we broach the subject without appearing as whining parents?
fields.trailText: Getting the most out of parents evening
fields.body:
Claire Dannatt is head of year 7 at Orleans Park School in Twickenham, Middlesex.

It is easy to forget how traumatic the move from primary to secondary school can be, and speaking to your child's teachers at parents evenings can be a good starting point in easing anxieties.

Find out the protocol for making appointments and make as many as you can, especially with the teachers of subjects causing concern. If you cannot do this, leave a message for the specific teacher saying you would like them to call you to discuss your child's progress. Include a contact number but try to be as flexible as possible, as teachers can rarely commit to a specific time.

Whenever meeting with teachers, it is useful to prepare the questions you want to ask. Check whether your child is expected to attend. If you are worried that your child may have more serious learning or emotional difficulties, make arrangements to see the learning support department, the head of year and the form tutor.

Go to such meetings with an open mind. It is quite possible that you are getting one side of the story, and that your child in school is not the same as the one you have at home! The form tutor should be your primary contact regarding concerns about your child's social and educational well-being in school.

However, on occasion, you may feel that your concerns are too serious to be dealt with like this. In that case, do not hesitate to contact the head of year. Good communication between home and school is invaluable in avoiding misunderstandings and ensuring everyone is 'pulling in the same direction'.

Use the planner/diary to notify the form tutor of absences and other issues not of a confidential nature. Remember, by letting the school know as early as possible of absences you can help to identify pupils who are truanting, for whatever reason - including unhappiness at school. This is a problem that can then be dealt with quickly and effectively, and with parental knowledge and collaboration.

Finally, a bugbear for children, parents and teachers can be homework - or the lack of it. You can help your child to get into a routine by checking their planner/diary regularly to monitor that homework is being set; by discussing and agreeing a specific time when homework can be done without interfering with equally important free time. By trying, as far as possible, to provide a quiet area with a chair and table to do it, rather than last minute on a Sunday night in front of the telly.

This way, any problems which occur can be discussed with the subject teacher in advance of the date when homework tasks are due in. Use parents evenings to discuss with subject teachers their policy and practice when it comes to homework.

Lastly, no teacher will consider a parent or guardian who is concerned about their child's welfare but keen to work in allegiance with teachers to enhance the quality of their child's educational experience as 'whining'.

Claire Dannatt's tip

Always try to attend parents' evenings and see as many teachers as you can. Go prepared but keep an open mind. Your child's form tutor is the first point of contact in discussing any problems or concerns you have regarding your child's social or educational welfare. Use the planner/diary to keep the lines of communication open between home and school.

Next week's query

Homework is a constant battle between me and my son, who is in year 10 and already getting lots of GCSE coursework. I find it difficult to get him to take it seriously and discussions about it usually end in rows. I have offered to help, but I'm not sure just how much help I should give him. He wants to go to college to study for his A levels in the future - I'm really worried that he won't even pass his GCSEs at this rate.

fields.headline: Internet know-how out of class
fields.trailText: It's not difficult using the web in class; it's less obvious how to use it to help with problems outside school.
fields.body:
It's not difficult using the web in class; it's less obvious how to use it to help with problems outside school. For every story about the curriculum, performance targets and pay structures there is another about bullying, truancy, teenage pregnancies and all the other issues relevant outside lessons that directly affect a child's academic success.

To its credit, the department of education has recently launched an invaluable website for parents. It's a good source of information on home-school agreements, school trips, school meals and advice on helping your child with homework and revision. There are also sections on the more problematic topics of exclusion, drugs and attendance, but the main focus of the site is on your rights and duties as a parent.

The recent case of Amie Salmon, whose parents kept her at home because they were dissatisfied with her school's policy on bullying, is an extreme one. If you do choose to take action, or are unsure what to do, Bullying Online may help. It takes a determined and, some might think, rather litigious approach to the problem, but it does stress the importance of communicating with teachers and setting out the problem early. You can email the site's staff for advice.

Email can be a powerful tool where children find things awkward or embarrassing. The Samaritans don't just offer a listening service on the phone and in person; they also have an email address, jo@samaritans.org, which is particularly popular among young men. The anonymity of email messages, and the opportunity to set out one's thoughts without feeling under pressure, makes it a valuable channel for communication.

The Samaritans produced an excellent youth pack earlier this year for use by teachers in the classroom. ChildLine has a useful and reassuring website.

If you're a PSHE teacher, the government's Wired for Health has advice on health and the national curriculum. The companion MindBodySoul site, linked from the same location, is aimed at key stage 4 (GCSE) pupils and informs without being patronising.

According to the New Policy Institute thinktank, breakfast might be the answer to truancy and poor attention spans. Funding is available to set up breakfast clubs - see www.breakfast-club.co.uk for a detailed guide.

If you are worried about out-of-school internet use, the Superhighway Safety pack at tackles that.

fields.headline: Biology
fields.trailText: Biology
fields.body:
Herman the Worm

****

Aimed at: everyone

A delightfully (or appallingly, depending on your viewpoint) anthropomorphic website dedicated to the anatomy, habitat and behaviour of worms. Notes for teachers explain how to set up a worm bin and organise a project at KS2 level. There are no photos, but plenty of links to them.

Virtual FlyLab

***

Aimed at: teachers

Take advantage of the FlyLab while it is still free; in September this fascinating application will become subscription only. By designing a cross between male and female fruit flies, students learn about genes. The program applies the rules of inheritance to the flies created.

Cow's eye dissection

***

Aimed at: everyone

A step-by-step guide to dissecting the eye. You can print out the full instructions or enhance the site with real audio. The photography is clear, and while many teachers will feel it is no substitute for dissection, it would certainly help to prepare for the experience. The virtual frog dissection tests pupils' knowledge of anatomy.

Biology4Kids

**

Aimed at: everyone

Another US site which, used judiciously, would make a useful revision resource for KS3 and GCSE. Cell biology, ecology and biochemistry are its main strengths.

Yucky.com

*****

Aimed at: everyone

An entertaining site which builds on children's most primitive fascinations - insects, human bodies and more worms. There are two excellent sections for parents and teachers and it has much to offer KS2 children.

New Scientist

***

Aimed at: teachers

As well as archiving all issues since the beginning of 1999, New Scientist has useful special reports on topics such as alcohol, cloning and GM foods. The Your Body and Plants and Animals categories within the Last Word section ask, and answer, biology-related questions such as "What's behind the adult navel?" and "Why does fish usually smell fishy?"

Webwise 3 Spinneret

***

Aimed at: everyone

Dr Richard Steane has assembled teaching notes on over 50 topics for GCSE double award and single subject biology. Some of the graphics have "mouseover" graphics revelations, and photos from his own lab illustrate some of the experimental results. Steane has asserted his copyright, and appreciates feedback.

Biological Collections

**

Aimed at: teachers

A useful directory of links to all things biological on the net - including wonderful finds such as the Bad Bug Book, which gives details of food-borne viruses and bacteria, how they are transmitted and notable outbreaks. You'll also find labelled photos of parasites, biotechnology and botanical links, journals and other listings that reward further investigation.

Next week: English

fields.headline: Let loose on the louse
fields.standfirst: As part of national science week, schoolchildren across the country are about to embark on a study of woodlice for a national research project
fields.trailText: As part of national science week, schoolchildren across the country are about to embark on a study of woodlice for a national research project
fields.body:
The little one that rolls up into a perfect ball is Armadillidum vulgare, the common pill woodlouse. Porcellio scaber is the common rough woodlouse and the common shiny one is called Oniscus asellus. British schoolchildren are about to get to know them in fine detail, along with most of the 35 other common species of British terrestrial Isopoda, or woodlice.

The schoolchildren will be taking part in a nationwide, six month-long internet-based experiment in biodiversity, taxonomy, systematics and field zoology and they will be doing it under rotting logs, in the rockery, and behind the compost heap.

Next week is national science week, the 7,500-event jamboree of technology, engineering and boffinpower across the nation launched on Friday (March 17). In the middle of the week, a tiny group of isopod-addicts will hatch a mass-observation experiment that could, if necessary, absorb data from every schoolchild in the country.

Walking With Woodlice is about to be outlined as a serious proposal for 22,000 science and nature teachers. It is designed to fit in with stages two and three of the national curriculum, so biologists from seven to 13 will have a stake in it. Its climax - roughly at the end of the woodlouse hunting season in September - will be a kind of woodlouse summit in South Kensington, London. In that month, at the end of the Creating Sparks festival of science, zoologists, ecologists and schoolkids will begin to work out what they have learned about the distribution of one of Britain's most extraordinary species.

Jill Nelson of the British Association for Advancement of Science is the director of the Creating Sparks festival. There have been mass experiments before but she wanted to involve kids in something that would be useful, she says. "They may have been used as experimental animals themselves but they haven't actually been mini-researchers, if you like. So the idea was to do something real. The message we wanted to get across was about biodiversity and the fact that it is important to the UK and it isn't just about the Brazilian rainforest."

So the architects of the scheme went for the woodlouse. Woodlice - also known to children and folklorists as tiggy-hogs, pill bugs, cheeselogs, chiggy pigs and rolypolies - are clean and safe and children aren't generally afraid to touch them.

Woodlice exist everywhere in Britain. They scurry along on their 14 feet (seven pairs of legs) "smelling" their way with their antennae. Woodlice don't like things too cold or too hot, too wet or too dry. They don't like toxic soils or places with nothing much to eat. They munch at rotting wood and damaged foliage and, like earthworms, they make an enormous difference to the ecosystem. Their distribution and seasonal appearances will add up to a huge database for British scientists.

Miranda Lowe of the Natural History Museum calls them an "indicator species". If they are in good shape, so are most of the wild things around them. And even though there are lots of isopods, kids can classify them. "There are the runners, and they are generally narrow, smooth and move quite quickly," she says. "There are the clingers which are quite broad and flat and slow, and there are the rollers, which roll themselves perfectly into a ball. Some of the runners can do that but they don't roll perfectly. And lastly there are the creepers, which are very slow."

The field biologists in the back garden or the school playground will be in action from May, when the little crustaceans become less torpid, until September when they prepare for winter. The children will use a website to help them identify the species. They will get practice using a taxonomist's "tree" to get the genus and species right, and they will fill in a database about what they find, and when and where. If they do that just once, that will be valuable, says Jill Nelson. If they do it every week, that will be even better. Every time they enter data into the database, they will get feedback.

"The database will come back immediately and say: thank you for your data, that's very unusual, you have a something or other; or: that's just like three people down the road who have said the same thing. It's interactive, it gives them the feeling they have just contributed to something big, and that what they have found matters. The system can cope with every kid in the country, if the kids are inclined."

The Association for Science Education is backing the idea. The Natural History Museum is working on an interactive website that should be in business very soon. At the end of the event, there will be a scientific paper based on the data, says Jill Nelson.

"The teachers will be able to take it back to the classrooms and say: 'Look, you contributed to this, this is a published piece of science.' Whether it changes the world, I can't say, until we get there."

Woodlice online

The Natural History Museum is working on an interactive website that should be in business very soon. At the end of the event, there will be a scientific paper based on the data, says Jill Nelson. "The teachers will be able to take it back to the classrooms and say: 'Look, you contributed to this, this is a published piece of science.' Whether it changes the world, I can't say, until we get there." Woodlice online

fields.headline: Visiting the troops
fields.trailText: Although it is not a legal requirement, no governors can carry out their duties effectively unless they undertake classroom visits, and I'm afraid "helping" in school doesn't count.
fields.body:
Although it is not a legal requirement, no governors can carry out their duties effectively unless they undertake classroom visits, and I'm afraid "helping" in school doesn't count. This prospect can turn the most robust person to jelly, so decide what approach will work for your school. You could hunt in pairs, matching an inexperienced governor with an experienced one. Or attack as a team and split up, to cover different areas. Just make sure you visit.

It is a good idea for your governing body to produce a simple pro forma for such visits, recording the name of the governor, the date and the purpose and outcome of the visit. Keep hold of these - Ofsted loves them.

Broadly speaking, there are three different types of visit. It could be in relation to the action plan, as it is up to the governing body to decide how to monitor this. You have produced it, so you have to monitor it. If the how is beyond you, get someone else to do it - a teacher or the head - but ensure that they do it and report back to the governing body.

The second type of visit is often more nebulous; for example, to see if the school is meeting its declared aims. You will need to discuss with the rest of the governing body how to collect evidence of this. It could be that you take photos, or speak with pupils, teachers, parent associations, or collect children's work.

Finally, you may just visit to learn about something that is going on in the school and how it works in practice; the literacy hour, for example. Whatever the purpose of your visit, there are certain things you need to do.

Make sure you prepare thoroughly before the visit. Think carefully about why you will be there. Read any policy documents and make preliminary contact with the head or teacher - this can be most beneficial, as teachers will usually then have everything ready for your visit. It also helps to build trust and respect if you work with and involve the staff. Courtesy can go a long way.

What will you do with the knowledge you gain? In some cases, you will make a written or oral report to the governing body, and in other cases you may be making some sort of recommendation.

Classroom visits can be extremely rewarding and you can learn a lot about the school. You will also appreciate far better what the teaching staff have to go through. If you want to really get in tune with your school and build strong bonds with its staff, there's no better way.

 Fred Browning is senior governor development officer for Essex local education authority.

fields.headline: Towards a learning age
fields.standfirst: Bill Lucas answers Chris Woodhead's criticisms with an explanation of the Learning to Learn initiative
fields.trailText: Bill Lucas answers Chris Woodhead's criticisms with an explanation of the Learning to Learn initiative
fields.body:
The Chief Inspector, Chris Woodhead, took issue with me personally over my insistence that learning to learn is the key skill of the 21st century. Learning to learn, he asserted, is not a skill, involves nothing more complex than some basic study skills and is certainly not new.

On the same day last week, the Campaign for Learning launched its Learning to Learn initiative. Twenty-four schools have been selected to be test-beds for more brain-friendly learning. They include nursery, primary and secondary schools throughout England and Wales. Most of them have glowing Ofsted endorsements of their work. Each school will be introducing and evaluating a significant initiative over the next academic year.

Some of the approaches to be explored include identifying the preferred learning styles of a group of pupils and planning classroom interventions, developing environments where drinking water is readily available and music is often used, training teachers in key techniques in the use of mind-maps to aid memory and applying this in the classroom, and introducing accelerated learning techniques, for example in ensuring that information is commonly transmitted in visual, aural and kinesthetic modes.

A theme integral to each school's activity will be an attempt to create more brain-friendly environments. Creating the optimal balance between high challenge and low threat, respecting learning cycles and building in feedback will be important. The emphasis throughout will be on producing replicable models with clearly identified performance benefits.

To provide base-line data for the project, the Campaign commissioned new research from MORI into the attitudes of young people. Asked which three things they do most often in class, two activities dominate - copying from the board or a book (58%) and listening to their teacher (39%). These findings suggest that, even if teachers are familiar with latest research, it has not yet been translated into practical applications. More encouragingly, interactive experiences such as group discussions (35%) and small group problem-solving (28%) also feature high. More than half (55%) think their teacher is the person they learn most from, while 68% cite their mothers and 57% their fathers.

The Campaign's initiative involves a broad alliance of organisations and draws in the wisdom of an advisory group of many eminent thinkers. Two universities are helping to make sure that the data we gather is robust.

If we can make sure that every pupil leaves secondary school motivated to be a learner for the rest of their lives, then we will have taken a real step towards the "learning age" David Blunkett writes of so lyrically.

The Chief Inspector may be right that there is not very much that is new in all this. We are not claiming that we have many new answers to long-standing and complex questions. But we do genuinely believe that reflective practitioner research of the kind we are now championing is a good way forward.

fields.headline: Mind games
fields.standfirst: John Crace finds a school thriving on unconventional methods of teaching
fields.trailText: John Crace finds a school thriving on unconventional methods of teaching
fields.body:
You could be forgiven for confusing the low-slung, pale brick exterior of West Grove primary in Southgate, north London with a leisure centre. Come to think of it, you could be forgiven for confusing the interior with a leisure centre, too.

The classrooms are bright and airy, and the children are busy organising themselves into different activities. In the reception class, one little girl has some earphones clamped to her head, a boy and a girl play race the snail, a clump of kids play with finger puppets, another group create Elmer the Elephant storybooks and a few just chill out and natter. Amid the ordered disorder, everyone is having a good time.

West Grove's headteacher, Elaine Wilmot, believes that not all children learn in the same way. "Some respond best to conventional aural and visual teaching methods, but others learn best through physical exploration," she says, "and the key to maximising a child's potential is to tailor their education to their learning styles".

This approach is everything that Chris Woodhead, the chief inspector for Ofsted, detests. In his annual lecture at the end of last month, Woodhead put the boot into all new approaches to learning in a bid to reclaim the classroom values of the 1950s. To underline the point, he launched a personal attack on Bill Lucas, chief executive of the Campaign for Learning, an organisation that endorses West Grove's teaching methods. "There's nothing really new," said Woodhead, dismissively. "It does not justify the hype. It certainly does not justify Bill Lucas's confident assertion that learning to learn will be the skill for the next century."

Lucas himself would almost certainly agree with Woodhead's assertion that there was nothing new in what he was saying. The Campaign is not hanging on to the latest, tenuous research; it is working from well-established scientific research by, amongst others, Howard Gardner and Susan Greenfield, into theories of multiple intelligences and how the brain works, which, when reduced to simple language, shows that people learn in different ways, that they respond best to high-challenge, low-threat environments, that we really only concentrate for 20 minutes at a time and most of us are almost permanently dehydrated.

The implications are potentially seismic. Far from Woodhead's claim that modern practice already takes note of this research, a new MORI survey commissioned by the Campaign into young people's attitudes to learning suggests that the opposite is the case. Classroom activities are dominated by copying from the board or a book and listening to the teacher talk. What the pupils actually wanted was more balance, including group discussion and problem-solving, more computer time, and a more brain-friendly environment with background music and the freedom to wander round and get a glass of water.

Many parents may be tempted to raise an eyebrow at the idea that children are the best judge of how they learn; my own would probably say they did best with unlimited sweets and no maths tests on Friday. But any scepticism is kicked to one side when you see the principles in action.

In most schools, the sight of kiddies wandering around the classroom mid-lesson would be enough to send a teacher apoplectic and to get the children labelled disruptive. At West Grove it is positively encouraged. "We want the children to explore for themselves how they learn best," says Wilmot. "We start with what they can do; we observe them in action and then try to reframe ideas into methods and activities that make sense to them."

Jack Newton, one of the reception teachers, explains how it works in practice. "One four-year old boy is very into enclosures at the moment," he says. "He's been playing with building blocks and his language is amazing. At one point he said, 'I'm putting this block here to increase the strength'. Another girl loves ordering things and has spent some time rearranging the books. I talk to them about what they're doing and try to get them to think about how it relates to numbers and language. I then try to suggest similar activities that will develop these skills in other ways."

It's hardly the normal way of teaching the three Rs, but Wilmot is adamant that, amongst the creativity, the basics of phonics and numeracy are still hammered home - just more gently. West Grove is an average multicultural primary school; its pupils include those from emotionally and socially deprived backgrounds, children with special needs, and a smattering of children from well-off homes. But the achievement levels are anything but average. Tiffany, aged four, writes out the word elephant from memory, spelling it correctly; Joshua, also four, happily jots down a rudimentary sentence. Now you might expect one or two gifted children in any class, but many other members of the class are also working at this level.

You find a similar story in year 1. By request of the parents, all children learn French and most can count to 30, identify the colours and can hold a basic conversation along the lines of "Who are you? What's your name?" etc. Wilmot reckons that most of the class already meet the key stage 1 assessment test a year ahead of schedule. West Grove was only established in 1998 and there are no classes above year 1, but the school has no intention of altering its approach as the demands of the curriculum increase with age.

This may sound a bit gung-ho, but West Grove is hardly out on a limb. Business has long endorsed the theories of multiple intelligence, the Department for Education's Standards and Effectiveness committee has accepted the Campaign's ideas, and over 500 schools, including whole local education authorities, applied to be one of the 24 schools on the Campaign's Learning to Learn pilot scheme that starts this September.

If Woodhead is not yet ready for the Campaign for Learning, West Grove is more than ready for Woodhead. The school has not yet received its first Ofsted inspection, but Wilmot insists that when it comes, the school will not change its practices one bit. And somehow you believe her.

webTitle: Red tape warning  Headteachers' plea to Blair

fields.headline: Red tape warning  Headteachers' plea to Blair
fields.trailText: Headteachers of the 36 most improved schools in England will warn Tony Blair today that his educational reforms are in danger of being submerged under red tape.
fields.body:
Headteachers of the 36 most improved schools in England will warn Tony Blair today that his educational reforms are in danger of being submerged under red tape.

The prime minister has invited them to Downing Street to present the first national school awards for consistent improvement over the last four years.

They include the 16 secondaries with the biggest sustained increase in high grade passes at GCSE, 15 primaries with the most improvement in tests at 11 and five special schools .

Richard Wealthall, head of St Clement's high school in King's Lynn, Norfolk, said: "I'll be telling him to allow schools to concentrate on the real business in hand."

Last year 58% of GCSE candidates at St Clement's passed at least five subjects at grade C or above, compared with 26% in 1996.

He said: "Until last year we were a grant-maintained school financed through a government funding agency. We sent them financial information on two sides of A4 paper once a quarter and had a full audit of the balance sheet at the end of the year.

"Now we are asked to send 26 pages of A4 every month. That may be more the local education authority's fault than the government's, but if the government wants to re duce bureaucracy it has to do something about it."

Mr Wealthall attributed his school's success to a big investment in staff training, new policies to involve parents and staff changes, involving the departure of less effective teachers.

"We worked hard at involving parents in their children's education. At school we have them for 17% of their time. We have to invade the other 83%."
