webTitle: In fear of fruit and veg

fields.headline: In fear of fruit and veg
fields.trailText: Next time you hear a government official spouting about supporting organic farmers and "real food" initiatives, do not believe them.
fields.body:
Next time you hear a government official spouting about supporting organic farmers and "real food" initiatives, do not believe them. Their real attitude can be found in the health education authority's new initiative to raise schoolchildren's awareness of "safe food hygiene practices". Every primary school is being sent "an interactive teaching pack" which, as well as being mind-bogglingly awful, expresses a pathological fear of real food.

Dressed up in graphics derived from the wilder end of American children's cartoons, the pack features "the Adventures of Safe-T and the H-squad" (Safety and the Hygiene Squad, geddit?). Their fun mission is to impress on children the dangers of food and food preparation. The material bristles with words like "risk", "contamination", "poisoning" and "danger". The catchy slogan is "Stop! Wipe that surface throughout the day if you want to keep the pathogens away!" Children are encouraged to "recognise risks in various situations" including studying pictures of kitchens to spot "bad hygiene practices".

What's being whipped up here is anxiety about food as dangerous, promoting the idea that the only safe food is wrapped in plastic and drenched in cleansing agents. Before starting a "food activity" teachers are warned to do "a risk assessment" and cover "all surfaces with non-permeable covers ". Children should learn their "hands are lethal weapons" and do handwashing experiments to find "effective ways of removing dirt and bacteria". By the end, children should be able to "list where pathogens are found on people".

Is this really what we should be teaching children about food? I sympathise with the importance of basic hygiene and have been known to leave a restaurant when someone from the kitchen left the toilet without washing her hands. But teaching kids to wash their hands is simple and straightforward. It shouldn't involve teaching them that handling food is like handling radioactive waste.

Indeed this is the precise opposite of what children currently need to learn. Recently I was with a child who watched me pulling up muddy leeks. "Ugh", she said, "you're not going to eat those are you?" It is the obsession with perfect-looking food in hygienic wraps which supports the serious contamination of our foods at source - the overuse of chemicals to control pests and produce uniform vegetables and fruit, or the overuse of plastic wrapping which contaminates food with dangerous toxins. These are far more serious environmental and health problems than the odd bit of dirt clinging to carrots.

Sterile compartments , plastic wrapping - with such attitudes, what remains "safe" for children? Only the things that "look" sterile, coming in sealed packets, highly processed food like crisps or ready-made snacks? Needless to say, this mindset of the food industry (joint sponsors of this project) is all over the teaching pack. The recommended cross-curricular topic on potatoes is particularly revealing. It recommends children visit a potato factory (sic) and observe "hygiene procedures that workers follow". The children should "discuss the need for special clothing - hygiene is the foremost priority of the visit". There is no mention of growing and harvesting, let alone a suggested visit to a farm. But what can you expect from people who believe potatoes come from potato factories?

This is more than ignorance. It is nothing short of food manufacture propaganda, dumping responsibility for the poor quality of their produce on our hapless children. The dreaded salmonella is caused by their practices, not by children's grubby hands. What makes it worse is that school children get almost no other teaching about food or cookery. Now it only features in design and technology, which is also in the thrall of the food industry. At best children might learn there how to design a pizza.

Schools long ago abandoned cooking lessons where children gathered round, squeezed bits of pastry to death, let hair drop in, but at least had the great joy of watching their parents eat and appreciate. In other words, learning about food is not about avoiding danger but giving pleasure.

For officialdom to extend this obsession with risk to food is pernicious. This is already a culture where, in spite of steadily rising life expectancy and good health, children can do nothing without being bombarded with messages of risk. Now they can't even go into the kitchen without military-style preparations. It's shocking that public money is being spent on such exercises. Children are far more at risk of going mad, developing excessive anxieties or disorders like anorexia, from listening to this stuff than getting ill if they don't.
fields.bodyText: Next time you hear a government official spouting about supporting organic farmers and "real food" initiatives, do not believe them. Their real attitude can be found in the health education authority's new initiative to raise schoolchildren's awareness of "safe food hygiene practices". Every primary school is being sent "an interactive teaching pack" which, as well as being mind-bogglingly awful, expresses a pathological fear of real food. Dressed up in graphics derived from the wilder end of American children's cartoons, the pack features "the Adventures of Safe-T and the H-squad" (Safety and the Hygiene Squad, geddit?). Their fun mission is to impress on children the dangers of food and food preparation. The material bristles with words like "risk", "contamination", "poisoning" and "danger". The catchy slogan is "Stop! Wipe that surface throughout the day if you want to keep the pathogens away!" Children are encouraged to "recognise risks in various situations" including studying pictures of kitchens to spot "bad hygiene practices". What's being whipped up here is anxiety about food as dangerous, promoting the idea that the only safe food is wrapped in plastic and drenched in cleansing agents. Before starting a "food activity" teachers are warned to do "a risk assessment" and cover "all surfaces with non-permeable covers ". Children should learn their "hands are lethal weapons" and do handwashing experiments to find "effective ways of removing dirt and bacteria". By the end, children should be able to "list where pathogens are found on people". Is this really what we should be teaching children about food? I sympathise with the importance of basic hygiene and have been known to leave a restaurant when someone from the kitchen left the toilet without washing her hands. But teaching kids to wash their hands is simple and straightforward. It shouldn't involve teaching them that handling food is like handling radioactive waste. Indeed this is the precise opposite of what children currently need to learn. Recently I was with a child who watched me pulling up muddy leeks. "Ugh", she said, "you're not going to eat those are you?" It is the obsession with perfect-looking food in hygienic wraps which supports the serious contamination of our foods at source - the overuse of chemicals to control pests and produce uniform vegetables and fruit, or the overuse of plastic wrapping which contaminates food with dangerous toxins. These are far more serious environmental and health problems than the odd bit of dirt clinging to carrots. Sterile compartments , plastic wrapping - with such attitudes, what remains "safe" for children? Only the things that "look" sterile, coming in sealed packets, highly processed food like crisps or ready-made snacks? Needless to say, this mindset of the food industry (joint sponsors of this project) is all over the teaching pack. The recommended cross-curricular topic on potatoes is particularly revealing. It recommends children visit a potato factory (sic) and observe "hygiene procedures that workers follow". The children should "discuss the need for special clothing - hygiene is the foremost priority of the visit". There is no mention of growing and harvesting, let alone a suggested visit to a farm. But what can you expect from people who believe potatoes come from potato factories? This is more than ignorance. It is nothing short of food manufacture propaganda, dumping responsibility for the poor quality of their produce on our hapless children. The dreaded salmonella is caused by their practices, not by children's grubby hands. What makes it worse is that school children get almost no other teaching about food or cookery. Now it only features in design and technology, which is also in the thrall of the food industry. At best children might learn there how to design a pizza. Schools long ago abandoned cooking lessons where children gathered round, squeezed bits of pastry to death, let hair drop in, but at least had the great joy of watching their parents eat and appreciate. In other words, learning about food is not about avoiding danger but giving pleasure. For officialdom to extend this obsession with risk to food is pernicious. This is already a culture where, in spite of steadily rising life expectancy and good health, children can do nothing without being bombarded with messages of risk. Now they can't even go into the kitchen without military-style preparations. It's shocking that public money is being spent on such exercises. Children are far more at risk of going mad, developing excessive anxieties or disorders like anorexia, from listening to this stuff than getting ill if they don't.

fields.headline: Comprehensively thrashed
fields.standfirst:
Despite chuntering from the heartlands, New Labour will breathe a sigh of relief at the Rippon schools vote

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Despite chuntering from the heartlands, New Labour will breathe a sigh of relief at the Rippon schools vote
fields.body:
When the chairman of the governors of Ripon grammar school peered through his glasses at the sheet of paper coughing from the fax machine he quickly realised that the opponents of comprehensive education had not merely won, but won very big indeed. The Yes camp - for change - had mustered 747 votes. The No campaign, organised not just by grammar school parents but by Ripon college, the former secondary modern, had doubled that to 1,493.

But Judge Simon Grenfell may not have reckoned that, in a perverse way, the Ripon electorate of parents of primary schools "feeding" the grammar school had delivered a welcome result to the government.

The government has two causes for satisfaction: one political and one educational. The political consequence flows from the government's attachment to the views of the Daily Mail and its readership, deemed to be the voice of middle England which voted Labour for the first time in 1997. The Daily Mail is attached to grammar schools. A string of contested reorganisations abolishing some of the 164 remaining grammar schools is not what Labour wants in the heartlands of its new electorate.

But educationally Labour has been emphasising the performance of individual schools, as the social exclusion agenda has pushed into the field of learning. Implicitly, at least, the old argument about structures had become redundant. In Ripon, the argument for change by the Campaign for the Advancement of State Education (Case) had the air of existing in a time warp. Even the launch of the bid to raise the 587 signatures necessary to force a ballot on the future of the grammar school featuring Lord Hattersley had a distinctly pre-Blairite feel to it.

Of course, Labour will face more chuntering about its working class heartlands. But the enthusiasm for comprehensive education has always come from Labour's "polytechnic", not its working-class supporters. Tony Blair is unlikely to be unduly perturbed by Hattersley's huffing and puffing: indeed, as a demonstration that New Labour has turned its back on the old agendas he may even welcome it, despite the inevitably flurries of backbench indignation.

Labour could, of course, have engineered parental ballots to provide a much truer test of sentiment about selection. It could have required each local authority to put forward a scheme of re-organisation for its grammar schools and then required a referendum on that plan. At the very least it could have ensured that when a petition had secured a ballot a clear choice should lie before the parent-voters.

It did neither. In Ripon the electorate consisted of parents in 15 feeder primary schools which had sent at least five children to the grammar over the previous three years. Neither the grammar school (roll 770) nor Ripon college (472) parents had a vote. Crucially the local authority kept out of the battle, but in a factual question and answer circular sent to parents it stated that a Yes vote would "not necessarily" ensure a single comprehensive school in Ripon. A scheme of reorganisation would follow a vote, not precede it, and would not be subject to parental endorsement. It was also clear that the government had made no provision for cash to fund a reorganisation. This enabled the No vote to argue that parents were being invited to take a leap in the dark.

The same problem will apply if pro-comprehensive campaigners force ballots in local education authorities where the whole system is selective (there are only three selective secondary schools in North Yorkshire). Although the electorate will be the whole parent body rather than the bizarre micro-electorate of Ripon, they will still be voting for the ending of selection at the grammar schools rather than for a specific scheme of reorganisation.

It must be clear that ballots in, say, Kent or Trafford or part of Birmingham within a year of the general election is not Millbank's idea of an appropriate apéritif before the main feast. David Blunkett may have said "watch my lips" but Labour's spin doctors will be watching the focus groups and a very big focus group has just spoken in Ripon.

Of course there were special factors in Ripon. The Case campaigners failed to register the progress made over the past four years by the college, culminating in the recent award of technology college status. They projected a mind-set about education in Ripon which was out of date. When the grammar school and the college combined to argue for a No vote the Case campaign was marooned. It succeeded in adding only 160 votes to the number required to raise the petition in the first place over the entire (absurdly long) five weeks of the ballot.

The government will no doubt take refuge in the argument that the choice has been devolved to parents. But David Blunkett's remarks over the weekend hardly suggests a government in sackcloth and ashes over the defeat of an idea that has been at the heart of Labour for the best part of half a century. Just 1,493 parents in Ripon may just have liberated Labour from its chains.

 David Curry is Conservative MP for Skipton and Ripon.

fields.headline: Second 'superhead' resigns
fields.trailText: The government's fresh start for failing schools was hit yesterday by the second resignation in a week of a "superhead" sent in to restore order and improve academic results.
fields.body:
The government's fresh start for failing schools was hit yesterday by the second resignation in a week of a "superhead" sent in to restore order and improve academic results.

Carol McAlpine said she would quit as head of Firfield school in Newcastle upon Tyne at the end of this term, after 18 months in the job.

The announcement came four days after Torsten Friedag, one of the first £70,000 superheads, resigned with immedi ate effect as head of the Islington arts and media college.

His resignation came amid reports of continuing indiscipline at the north London school, which was given a fresh start after failing an inspection in its former identity as George Orwell school.

The fresh start scheme has been tried so far in about a dozen schools that failed to respond to normal remedial treatment. A government spokesman said ministers never pretended it would be "a quick fix".

The Newcastle school, formerly Blakelaw comprehen sive, was failed by Ofsted in 1997 and reopened the following year as Firfield, with a new head and staff. Ms McAlpine tackled high levels of truancy by persuading parents of habitual non-attenders to educate their children at home and offering £80 bonuses for 15-16 year olds meeting behaviour and attendance targets.

However, she narrowly avoided industrial action in January when staff refused to teach disruptive pupils.

The Newcastle education authority said of her imcumbency that "improvements have been made to the learning environment in a very short period", but added there were still urgent problems in standards of numeracy, and "inconsistency" in the quality of lessons and attendance.

The authority expressed particular concern over the school's failure to overcome its poor reputation and attract more pupils.

Extra funding depended on the school becoming full within three years. This target had not been met and extra cash had not materialised. Consequently, the school would lose a senior staff member and a classroom teacher.

Ms McAlpine told the Newcastle Evening Chronicle that she could not pass up the opportunity of being head of an education action zone in Great Yarmouth, Norfolk.

The government source said that the first fresh start schools were showing improvements, particularly in truancy rates and cutting the number of children leaving school with no exam success.

"The thing to remember is that in these schools, all the alternatives have been tried. There is no alternative, other than to close the school and disperse the children or see a continued drift into failure."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said: "The reality is becoming clear that even with brilliant heads and staff, these schools do not succeed. The fault lies not with the teachers but with the kind of children that attend these schools. One or two disruptive children and the school can cope; a whole school-full and it has no chance."

fields.headline: Fees get big thumbs down
fields.standfirst: Nearly two thirds of academics in English and Welsh universities are against fees for first degrees, says a new Guardian poll.  John Carvel unravels the stats
fields.trailText: Nearly two thirds of academics in English and Welsh universities are against fees for first degrees, says a new Guardian poll. John Carvel unravels the stats
fields.body:
University lecturers are overwhelmingly opposed to the government's policy of charging the flat-rate £1,025 annual tuition fee for full-time undergraduates, according to an ICM poll conducted for Guardian Education.

It found that nearly two-thirds of academics in English and Welsh universities are against fees for first degrees. Only 26% agreed with the principle of fees at this level, and most of them wanted differentials allowing the prestige universities to charge more. That left just 10% supporting the flat-rate system introduced by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary.

This disenchantment with the government's student funding reforms emerged from a poll of 1,100 parents, teachers and lecturers commissioned by the Guardian to assess the current state of education.

Two weeks ago we reported high levels of parental satisfaction with the government's handling of education in general and the progress of their own children's schools in particular. Last week we pointed to strong dissatisfaction among schoolteachers with the declining quality of their jobs, coupled with mounting pressures to leave the profession.

Our sample of 100 lecturers was not large enough to allow a breakdown of opinion across different types of university. But the pollsters were satisfied that it gave reliable conclusions about broad trends. On tuition fees, 64% of lecturers were opposed, compared with 39% of parents with children at secondary schools and 33% in primaries. Most parents who were not opposed said they did not know enough about the subject to give a view, leaving less than one in five saying they broadly supported the scheme.

There was concern among academics that students are not as well prepared as they used to be to embark on an undergraduate programme. Only 13% thought students arriving at university are better prepared than five years ago, compared with 56% who thought they were less well prepared and 21% who saw no change.

A clear majority of lecturers did not think there had been a dumbing down of university courses. Asked if degrees had been devalued over the past five years, 57% said no, 28% yes and 15% did not know.

The lecturers were even more negative than the schoolteachers about recent changes in the quality of their jobs. Only 8% thought their jobs had improved over the past two years, compared with 16% of secondary teachers and 19% of primary teachers. About half of each group said their jobs declined over this period, but a higher proportion of the lecturers said it stayed about the same.

Just over half the academics expected to leave the profession within 10 years and 72% in 15 years. Although this was similar to the proportions of schoolteachers expecting to quit, the lecturers were more likely to cite poor levels of pay as a reason. On an unprompted question, "poor pay" was mentioned by 12% of the potential quitters in universities, compared with 4% in primary schools and 7% in secondaries.

The lecturers were more likely to say they would be leaving on grounds of age and less likely to blame stress. "Workload too heavy" was volunteered by 15% of lecturers, the second most popular answer after age, but well below the percentage recorded for schoolteachers.

The lecturers were almost unanimous in their views about bureaucracy, with 95% saying it had grown over the past three years. But while schoolteachers tended to put the entire blame for bureaucracy on the government, lecturers were more divided. Asked who was mainly to blame, 33% said the Quality Assurance Agency, 5% the funding councils, 14% their own organisation and 38% the government.

Half the lecturers said the government was too hard on them, compared with 77% of primary and 69% of secondary teachers. Another 48% of lecturers thought the government had the balance about right.

The lecturers were less inclined than schoolteachers to say David Blunkett is doing well as education secretary. Only 42% of lecturers said he is doing a fairly good or very good job, while 53% said fairly poor or very poor. Two-thirds said performance pay was a bad idea. The pollsters concluded: "Lecturers' lives, in contrast to those of teachers, appear less stressful. They will move around less and will be more likely than primary or secondary teachers to leave because of age rather than other factors."

They are more concerned than teachers about low pay, but their main frustration is bureaucracy. This offers opportunities for ministers, who are keen to use any growth in the higher education budget to expand student numbers instead of improving lecturers' salaries or reducing their workload. A cut in bureaucracy may be a cheap way to improve morale on campus - as in the schools - while staff wait for pay demands to be met.

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 505 parents of primary and secondary children, 501 primary and secondary teachers and 101 university lecturers from nationally representative samples. The interviews were carried out by telephone from February 8-15 2000.

fields.headline: Hero's welcome
fields.standfirst: Donald MacLeod  and Lee Elliot Major reveal plans to unravel a tangled web
fields.trailText: Donald MacLeod and Lee Elliot Major reveal plans to unravel a tangled web
fields.body:
British universities and colleges today announced the launch of a huge shop window in cyberspace to attract students, researchers and businesses across the world. From the autumn an internet portal called Hero will provide an information service to all those interested in UK higher education.

Hero (Higher Education and Research Opportunities) is designed to guide anyone, from the student seeking a degree course to the small firm wanting help in developing a product, through the confusing array of thousands of existing academic websites.

Researchers needing funding and businesses needing research and development will - the organisers hope - be put in touch, and universities will also have a chance to tell a wider public about their often hidden cultural riches - museums, music, drama and public lectures.

No one has tried to draw the key information about a whole country's higher education system together in this way, although Australia markets its universities aggressively abroad via the internet.

The steering group that has been planning the service has appointed the new media company, Epic, to design, launch and operate the service under contract.

Sir Brian Fender, chief executive of the Higher Education Funding Council for England, said: "Hero represents a major opportunity for the UK and all higher education organisations to present themselves in a helpful way to a wide range of users and enquirers who are bemused by the hundreds of different higher education sites."

The information will be organised into zones covering the major areas of higher education - student interests, research, knowledge transfer and collaboration with industry, learning and teaching, culture and sport, among others. The service will be aimed at prospective students and their parents, current students, industry and commerce, job-seekers and employers, international audiences, people employed in higher education and the general public.

The portal will provide relatively little content of its own. Most of the content will consist of a database of references to material held on individual websites in universities, colleges research councils, research organisations, funding bodies and other HE agencies.

Meanwhile, science ministers and officials are bidding for £100m of government funds to help UK researchers develop the next generation of the web. Director general of research councils Dr John Taylor, science minister Lord Sainsbury, and e-commerce minister Patricia Hewitt are convinced that "e-science" will pave the way for a new super-fast internet. The "grid" will allow computer users to access almost limitless amounts of information from a central computer network without the complication of time-consuming searches of the internet or having to download information onto their own computers. The Office of Science and Technology is calling for the money as part of its submission to the Whitehall spending review.

The grid addresses an emerging problem that is common throughout the sciences: information overload. Researchers working for the Particle Physics and Astronomy Research Council say the grid will help them solve the biggest computing challenge in history: decoding the billions of data to emerge when the next European atom accelerator goes into action in 2005.

But biologists and environmental scientists will also need the new technology to make sense of the huge databases being developed on the human genome and the world's weather systems. Scientists believe the grid will be quickly taken up by the commercial world.

 Further information about the Hero project can be found on the HEFCE website under "Partners".

 Lee Elliot Major is deputy editor of Research Fortnight.

fields.headline: Tears and fears
fields.standfirst: Depression, eating disorders and other signs of mental stress are increasing among students.  Elaine Williams on Leicester's bid to help staff ease the pain
fields.trailText: Depression, eating disorders and other signs of mental stress are increasing among students. Elaine Williams on Leicester's bid to help staff ease the pain
fields.body:
Nothing could have prepared Barbara Goodman, a secretary in the law department of Leicester University, for the day she opened her office door and found herself face to face with a naked male student. He wasn't being threatening, however, just cracking up, and she felt not terror but sympathy for a "boy" who was simply not coping with the stresses and strains of university life.

She regards him as one of the increasing numbers of students she sees in psychological difficulty. The pressure on students, she believes, is far greater than when she first took her job in the department 24 years ago. Some of them, for want of someone mature and comforting to turn to, turn to her.

"They'll come in quite briskly saying, 'I just want a word if you've got time,' and then all of a sudden you get the tears, they can't cope any more. Most of them think they're not coping with their studies, but when it comes out it could be all manner of things, relationship problems, financial worries, parental pressure, anxiety about jobs. These days they've got to get a 2:1 honours degree to get a training contract. When I first came they could have walked into a partnership with a third."

Help is at hand, however, for staff like Barbara on the frontline of dealing with students. Leicester University, along with Nottingham, has produced guidance and training for staff facing students in trouble. Leicester's publication Helping Students in Difficulty is based on the largest ever UK survey into student psychological health, carried out by the university's Student Psychological Health Project team, which shows that at any one time 15% of students have mental health problems that might require professional help.

As many universities have doubled or tripled student numbers without any commensurate growth in services, they are having to help growing numbers of students in psychological difficulty with fewer resources. Barbara Goodman feels that Leicester's staff guidance has come none too soon: "The university has taken this on board in a strong way and it can do nothing but good."

The survey is of 1,620 students, 70% of them second-year undergraduates and 72% of them under 21 years. It shows that 60% of students feel "highly stressed" or "distracted" by concerns over their ability to manage and complete course work and to set priorities and manage time. Just under half worry about their levels of confidence and ability to cope with sadness, depression and mood changes. Family problems and illness distract around 40%.

In the past, the university tutorial system ensured that personal tutors would be in regular contact with their tutees and would get to know them well enough to be able to spot signs of strain. These days, huge hikes in staff-student ratios mean the tutorial system struggles to survive, and students may go through their entire degree course without regular and continuing personal contact with an academic supervisor. At the same time, financial pressure, requiring that many students work to meet their costs, and the introduction of modular courses which lead to a continuous roll of coursework deadlines, requires students to be more independent and robust. For a significant number, the extra strains can precipitate psychological disorders.

The consensus among university counsellors is that the severity of emotional and behavioural disturbance among university students is increasing. The Leicester survey provides much-needed evidence to back this up. Also, problems such as depression, schizophrenia and eating disorders are likely to be in their most acute phase from 16 to 25.

The Leicester guide, written by Annie Grant, director of the university's educational development and support centre, has created an enormous amount of interest from within the university as well as nationally and in the US.

"I have been asked to talk at more departmental meetings and have had more feedback from this than anything else I have done," she says. "I think there is a crisis of confidence in staff as to how to deal with these problems."

While the guide has been written principally for personal tutors - still one of the first ports of call for students reluctant to approach counselling or clinical services - departments have been encouraged to supply copies to all staff who come into contact with students, including secretaries, technicians, porters, security staff and cleaners.

It outlines the kind of difficulties students may face and provides practical and clear advice to help staff respond to them. It also includes guidance on when a tutor should deal with a problem personally and when to refer the student to a member of the health, medical or counselling services.

On the back of the Leicester initiative, which is the largest of eight university projects on mental health funded by the Higher Education Funding Council for England, the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals is circulating its own draft guidelines on the subject. It is also launching a study into student suicide.

Catriona Walker, head of Leicester's counselling services, says demand for the service is growing "year on year", and that last year nearly 500 students used the service. Many had panic attacks, eating disorders or depression caused by anxiety about coursework or exams, money, their families or feeling worthless.

One result of widening access, says Walker, is that universities are taking in more students with poorer backgrounds. The effect of the increase in family breakdown is also being felt. A 1998 study by the mental health charity Mind into the effect of family life on the mental health of children and young people said that poverty and family discord seemed to be the most important factors in increasing the risk of mental health problems.

In their report last spring, the heads of university counselling services said there are now many students with no stable home to return to, and the level of support required by such students is often higher than those with a "traditional" stable family background. Strains on the National Health Service and Care in the Community policies mean that some student counselling services have had difficulty establishing medical responsibility for students with severe mental health problems.

According to Grant, the issue for tutors with heavy work loads is how to help students in psychological distress effectively and how to recognise the limits of their own knowledge and responsibilities. Jeremy Levesley, a senior lecturer in maths and computer studies who takes pride in the pastoral support he gives to students, says that difficulties often arise when he is approached by students reluctant to go to counselling. At the moment he finds himself uncertain how best to help a student whose work is suffering as a result of family illness and who will not seek help other than to talk to him. "She wants to get through on her own merits and that's a difficult problem for me. I find that blokes, especially, will try to tough it out when they need help, and it's hard to know what to do because I can get them to open up to me, but not to go elsewhere.

"Only this morning I had a girl saying she just couldn't motivate herself to work, and that she 'couldn't think of a good reason why she wasn't sleeping'. Students quickly get into a hole, or start to feel out of control with all the assessment these days. Often there seems to be no let up, no way out."

He praised the university for setting out a staff plan of action for students in trouble. He said: "I think it's important that we know what our responsibilities are, and that we're all working from the same hymn sheet."

Heart of the matter

Kate Ellinor, a 21-year-old archaeology student in her 2nd year, spent a whole evening recently trying to persuade an "incredibly stressed" flatmate to come out of a locked room: "He's very quiet and introverted, and he worries about things all the time. It's all just going round and round in his mind. I'm really worried about him.

"It's easy to feel very alone at university and have no one to turn to. I work in a bar three nights a week to earn money, and I don't get in until 2am sometimes, and I get really exhausted. I've just had my first set of exam results, and so far I'm on for a 2:2 and I feel stressed about that.

"I'm the first to go to university in my immediate family, but my uncle went and got a first-class degree and my cousin got a first, and I feel under a lot of pressure. But I'm a real strong believer in keeping in touch with my family and friends back at home.

"When people start uni they think they are starting a new life, but they shouldn't neglect their home life. That's where they will find their main support.

"It's sometimes difficult to pick up signs when someone's in trouble at university because you haven't known them that long. I've an old friend, I've known her since she was nine, and she's at art school and has become bulimic. It was obvious to me that something was wrong, but her friends at art school haven't a clue. They think she's great and lively and having a good time."

Robyn Knox, 22, a final-year European Studies student, said she reached a very low point in her second year: "At first it's OK because it's all new, but you can start to feel very alone. A lot of students feel they have no one that knows them personally orunderstands them. I met my personal tutor yesterday for the first time this academic year. I did go through times when I just wasn't interested in anything, when getting up was a real struggle, and I missed lectures."

Trouble brewing

What to watch out for:

 A change in appearance - for instance, weight change or a change in behaviour

Is the student:

 Failing to complete coursework
 Doing too much work
 Missing classes
 Tense or irritable
 Sad or miserable
 Behaving erratically
 Unkempt
 Smelling of alcohol or cannabis
 Withdrawn or very quiet
 Agitated or very loud
 Talking incoherently

What to do:

 Assess whether the problem is urgent - for instance, whether there is a risk of suicide, self-harm or harm to others. If they will not accept help, telephone the university health centre or counselling services to seek advice. In exceptional circumstances, GPs can visit without the patient's prior agreement.

 Be clear about the help the student requires. If you can help, listen, provide reassurance and practical advice. Follow up the conversation at another time. If you do not have the knowledge, skills or time, provide the student with the appropriate information or seek further advice. Beware of getting out of your depth.

fields.headline: Lessons from Uncle Sam
fields.standfirst: Modelled on British lines for decades, Singapore's universities are looking to US institutions for new inspiration
fields.trailText: Modelled on British lines for decades, Singapore's universities are looking to US institutions for new inspiration
fields.body:
On an occasion when education officials and government ministers in this south-east asian city-state meet to discuss plans for welcoming newcomers from the United States to their campuses, the conversation isn't about visiting lecturers or fee-paying foreign students. It's about American institutions of higher education.

After decades spent in emulation of the British university system - particularly elite institutions such as Cambridge University, where the modern republic's founding father, Lee Kuan Yew, and many of his political contemporaries, spent their formative years - Singapore's international focus has undergone a dramatic transatlantic shift.

"From Cambridge, England, to Cambridge, Massachusetts," as one popular local cliche puts it.

In 1997 there was just one US university working in collaboration with a Singaporean institution, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, which conducted an academic audit of the National University of Singapore. Today the roll-call has grown to include the California Institute of Technology, the University of California at Berkeley, and the universities of Cornell, Stanford, Chicago, and John Hopkins, the last of which recently opened a medical facility in Singapore in collaboration with the National University.

In the case of MIT, the early work involving a team of visiting American scholars has given way to an ambitious alliance between itself and Singapore's Nanyang Technological University and the National University, involving the start-up of five shared graduate programmes that are expected to be fully operational by 2001.

Lest the old world be entirely forgotten, though, student exchange programmes and joint-degree courses have also been established with Britain's Imperial College and the Ecole Polytechnique in France.

"American-style higher learning has become an absolutely crucial part of our vision for education," says Jacob Phang, the director of external relations at the National University. "The very future of our economy is based on this realisation."

In the case of Dr Phang's institution, the vision of a Little America in the tropics extends to physically recreating the look and culture of a typical American college town. The university intends to build its own jitterbugging village on campus, complete with movie theatres, jazz clubs, a concert stage and alfresco cafes, in the fashion of a slightly sanitised Harvard Square or Chapel Hill.

Further along the road, plans have been drawn up to create an avenue called Techno Street, where entrepreneurs and inventors will be encouraged to set up shop in architecturally-designed, distinctly ungrungy "garages", a scheme that gathered pace after one of the university administrators read that Apple founder Steve Jacobs began his computer company working out of a garage.

All the country's new-found links and plans, however, run second to the American connection forged at the new Singapore Management University, which opens next year, bringing to three the number of local universities. The new institution's broad-based business and management programmes have been modelled on, and set up in collaboration with, the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania.

For the first time, a local university's admission criteria has been set up along purely American lines, including the use of applicants' SAT scores - and, in common with its Pennsylvanian partner, the expectation for graduates to learn a language in addition to English, the lingua franca of Singapore.

At an undergraduate level, the university curriculum, pedagogy and information technology and library systems are a blueprint of Wharton, while much of the postgraduate research will take place on campus at the new Wharton-SMU research centre in downtown Singapore. The centre, part of a $1bn building project, will be devoted primarily to issues of mutual Asian-American interest.

Janice Bellace, currently the deputy dean of the Wharton School, has been appointed the inaugural president of Singapore Management University. She will also be director of its postgraduate research centre.

Tan Chin Tiong, the provost, describes the university as the newest and best example of what he calls the "new American paradigm" in Singaporean higher education. "We're taking on the American mindset for management education," he says, "whether it be in the area of health care, hospitality, or whatever." How long will it be for it completely to take hold? "Five or six years," Tan confidently replies.

To underline the perception of American influence on universities in Singapore, two years ago, prime minister Goh Chok Tong began encouraging institutions here to market themselves as "the Harvard and MIT of Asia" with Singapore itself starring as "the Boston of the East".

His comments came on the back of a ministry of education survey's findings that many graduates had difficulty working independently and required, in Goh's terse words, "too much hand holding", taken to mean a lack of sufficiently creative and innovative thought.

For the first time, educators began worrying aloud that Singapore might not be producing enough high-calibre graduates - particularly in the strategically important areas of medicine and engineering - to help the country maintain its position as one of south-east Asia's strongest-performing economies.

The British system inherited by Singapore from its colonial overlords "was still good in terms of its depth, rigour, and quality-control", says Dr Lim of the National University. "But the American system, we now believe, is good for its flexibility, scope and choice.

"What we've developed is really something of a hybrid," he continues. "We have gone around the world, taking the best and synthesising it to our needs and particular situation."

fields.headline: Rope tricks
fields.standfirst: Bruce Thorson joins a group of acrobats as they audition for Britain's first degree in circus
fields.trailText: Bruce Thorson joins a group of acrobats as they audition for Britain's first degree in circus
fields.body:
There's no safety net. She spins upside down 20 feet above the dark wooden floor, with only the rope around her ankle tying her to the ceiling. Across the room others arch backs, stretching beyond the conceivable, until their toes touch the back of their heads. They are warming up before the final audition for entry into Britain's first degree in circus - the BA (Hons) Theatre Practice Contemporary Circus.

Charlie Holland, program director and deputy chief executive at London's Circus Space, boils down the school's goals to four key sounds: "Ooh! I wish I could do that. Aah! That's so beautiful. Ha ha! It's funny. And Ugh! I can't believe someone can do that!" The 20 students finally accepted to the school will learn to draw these reactions from the audience.

They will endure a demanding two years of acrobatics, trapeze, tightrope, balance and theatre as well as the history and business of circus. Before London's Circus Space, in conjunction with the Central School of Speech and Drama, set up the degree, there was no opportunity to study circus skill at this level in Britain. And Holland hopes to achieve a level beyond the stereotypes: "We need to get past the immediate associations of circus with the spangly leotard, up-the-bum trapeze artist. Just as dance is more than a ballerina in a tutu."

Jaqueline Whymark, vocational education development manager for the Circus Space, points out that many circus performers no longer work under the big top. They're part of a huge international entertainment industry plying their trade in cabaret, video, film, corporate entertainment and cruise ships or setting up their own companies.

Eighteen-year-old Errol Richardson sees his future launching off from his home in Lewisham to cabarets around the world via the Circus Space degree. Richardson combines lightning-quick reactions, pinpoint precision and deft footwork with a piece of string and a couple of sticks. He is trying to master the "diabolo". A diabolo is akin to a giant yo-yo manipulated at breakneck speed between two sticks.

He admits that his friends think his career choice is a little strange. "But I already make more money with my show than most of them. So I usually end up buying the drinks and they don't mind that." As for his family, he says it is actually his mother who pushed him to pursue the degree if he really wanted to make it as circus performer.

Several hundred applicants have been whittled down to the final batches auditioning over two days. The first day tests physical stamina in acrobatics, rope climbing and juggling. By the second day it is a matter of individual performances and interviews.

webTitle: Judge to rule on boy killers

fields.headline: Judge to rule on boy killers
fields.standfirst: Bulger case: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw, the home secretary, last night handed over to the lord chief justice, Lord Bingham, the decision over how long the two murderers of James Bulger should remain behind bars.
fields.body:
Jack Straw, the home secretary, last night handed over to the lord chief justice, Lord Bingham, the decision over how long the two murderers of James Bulger should remain behind bars.

A further 140 child offenders, mainly killers, may be released earlier as a result of Mr Straw's announcement last night that he is changing the law to end the role of politicians in sentencing juveniles convicted of grave offences, including murder and manslaughter. In future the term to be served will be set by the lord chief justice on a recommendation from the trial judge.

The home secretary's announcement follows the ruling by the European court of human rights that judges and not politicians should set the minimum term to be served by Robert Thompson and Jon Venables, the killers of two-year-old James Bulger, before the parole board considers whether they no longer pose a danger to the public.

Mr Straw had been expected to announce that the two child killers would serve a minimum of 10 years in line with the original recommendation by the lord chief justice. But in handing over the decision to Britain's top judge Mr Straw apologised to James Bulger's parents and said their grief must be compounded by "what must appear to them to be a never-ending cycle of court judgments about their son's murders".

James's mother, Denise Fergus, said all she was interested in at the moment was remembering him on what would have been his 10th birthday on Thursday. "I will await the lord chief justice's final decision before I take any action myself. I will fight for justice for James."

Mr Straw said the European court had triggered a wholesale reform of the way child killers were sentenced. The changes will not only affect new cases but will involve Lord Bingham reviewing the sentences of 140 of the 250 juveniles who have all been sentenced to be detained indefinitely "at Her Majesty's pleasure" for grave crimes. He will consider fresh representations from child killers and others who have not yet served their recommended minimum sen tences. This group includes Learco Chindamo, who was convicted of the murder of the London headteacher Phillip Lawrence, and two brothers, Glenn and John Howells, who murdered their mother.

In about 25 cases where the lord chief justice originally set a tariff - the minimum term to be served - below that finally decided on by the home secretary, the convicted killers involved will see their sentences reduced. Eight of the 25 who have not had their sentences looked at again yet will be immediately referred to the parole board to see if they should be released early.

The changes in the law in this wide-ranging shake-up of the way the release dates of child killers are set will be included in a criminal justice and court services bill to be published on Thursday. It will also include new powers for the views of families of victims to be taken into account before the sentences are set.

But Mr Straw stopped short of saying that juveniles would no longer be tried in adult courts. He said it was important that serious crimes with serious penalties were heard in open court before a judge and jury. Nevertheless in future new limits will be placed on attendance in court by the press and public and further steps taken to ensure that juvenile defendants can participate in the proceedings.

The National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders welcomed the withdrawal of politicians from such sentencing decisions. "Such grave decisions should not be a political football. Allowing politicians to overrule judges' sentences flouts every principle of natural justice and the ending of this indefensible system is long overdue."

The Tory former home secretary Michael Howard, who set a 15-year tariff in the Bulger case that was ruled illegal by the House of Lords and the Strasbourg court, said he still believed it was the right sentence.

The Liberal Democrats' Simon Hughes said however serious the crime it was right that juveniles be given a chance of parole and a new start if they had understood what they had done and apologised for it.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
IBM
fields.trailText: • Delivery Hi-tech firms IBM and Motorola yesterday confirmed they will work together to provide wireless data services to business customers worldwide. The two plan to help wireless carriers cope with demand for e-business services in the worldwide wireless market. The service will focus on the delivery of email, stock quotes, news and corporate resources to people connected via wireless devices. It is expected to be available later this year.
fields.body:

The two plan to help wireless carriers cope with demand for e-business services in the worldwide wireless market. The service will focus on the delivery of email, stock quotes, news and corporate resources to people connected via wireless devices. It is expected to be available later this year.

 Under the hammer Online auctioneer QXL.com will acquire the auction business of SurfStopShop , which operates Allegro.pl, the largest online auction site in Poland, for $75,000 in cash, the company said yesterday. Jim Rose, chief executive officer of QXL.com, said the deal would give QXL.com a firm foothold in eastern Europe.

The company plans to offer free online access for ever for a one-off charge of £50, with an initial subscriber ceiling of between 200,000 and 300,000

webTitle: Domain protection firm chief wins top slot

fields.headline: Domain protection firm chief wins top slot
fields.standfirst:
Vindication for 'pick and shovel providers at mucky end of the gold rush'.

E-finance: special report
Glaxo Wellcome
Lastminute.com
fields.trailText: Jason Drummond has been ranked as Britain's wealthiest young entrepreneur by a newspaper survey.
fields.body:
Jason Drummond has been ranked as Britain's wealthiest young entrepreneur by a newspaper survey.

The unexpected news was broken to the 30-year-old businessman on Sunday morning - as he was trying to stop his young son chasing a pig around a Surrey farmyard.

A telephone call, from a friend, told Mr Drummond that his 64% shareholding in Virtual Internet, an Aim-listed internet domain name, brand and trademark protection group, valued him at £123m - £51m ahead of second placed Robert Bonnier, chief executive of Scoot.com.

"It was nice to hear but a fairly farcical situation to find out in," Mr Drummond said. "To be honest, though, the money doesn't bother me too much, it's the challenge of growing the business that I like. I'll keep on going for as long as I enjoy it."

To emphasise his point, Mr Drummond had wiped the manure off his shoes, slipped back into his suit and returned to the Square Mile by 7.30 the following morning to outline the next stage of Virtual Internet's growth strategy.

He said yesterday that the company plans to move from Aim, where it listed in January last year, to the main market and raise £33m to fund both domestic and international expansion. The planned placing is ambitious, given Virtual Internet's market capitalisation of £198m, but broker Hoare Govett is fully underwriting it and early institutional demand has been strong. "My diary for a week of presentations was filled in an hour," he said.

Virtual Internet was set up in 1996 to provide internet domain name registration, e-mail, website hosting and e-commerce services to businesses of all sizes. Most of its 45,000 clients are in the small to medium size bracket although more than half of FTSE 100 companies, including Abbey National, Glaxo Wellcome, Marks & Spencer and Rolls-Royce, are customers. New-media accounts include Lastminute.com, QXL.com, CompuServe and AOL France.

As an infrastructure provider it is a decidedly unsexy business by dot.com standards but Mr Drummond likes it that way. In a sector where combat trousers and long-term losses are increasingly the norm he sticks to sensible suits and profit forecasts.

"If you believe in the longevity of the internet then you should believe in us because we provide crucial services which allow far racier companies to function and grow in this space. We're the pick and shovel providers at the mucky end of the gold rush."

Virtual Internet now operates in five countries and is targeting more European cities once the placing is completed. "We want to become the dominant domain-based services company in Europe and the global leader in brand protection. Around £15m of the money raised will be spent on tactical acquisitions in Europe, the US and moving into Asia Pacific. The rest will invested in people, building our sales, marketing and technology teams."

Even without his newly raised profile, Mr Drummond believes he has a compelling proposition to put to potential new investors. "Lots of immature companies are coming to the market at the moment and raising a lot of money. We've been around for four and a half years, have a mature management team and investors who are becoming increasingly sophisticated, like our model. We're not dependent on unique users or subscriber numbers, we offer real services to customers who pay cash and come back."

In the year to October 31 1999 turnover was £2.07m but losses after tax were £4.4m. Since then former Schroders managing director William Slee has been recruited as chairman and a chunk of senior management appointments has been announced.

"We are making significant progress as a group, these changes have speeded things up and soon we hope to be able to illustrate that."

fields.headline: Stellar names support new Paradigm
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A cast of international financiers, including currency trader Joe Lewis, media mogul Kerry Packer's son James, former Warner Brothers chairman Terry Semel and Autonomy chief executive Dr Mike Lynch yesterday turned their hand to internet investment.
fields.body:
A cast of international financiers, including currency trader Joe Lewis, media mogul Kerry Packer's son James, former Warner Brothers chairman Terry Semel and Autonomy chief executive Dr Mike Lynch yesterday turned their hand to internet investment.

They lead a list of entrepreneurs, financiers and technology experts who plan to support a £20.7m fundraising and Aim listing by newly-created Paradigm Media Investments.

Paradigm's fund manager, Bertrand Lipworth, believes its worldwide network of contacts will enable it to identify opportunities quicker than its incubator rivals.

The chairman will be Daniel Levy, chief executive of Enic, the sports and media investment group initially backed by Bahamas-based Mr Lewis. Enic will hold a 24% stake and director Peter Dubens will join Mr Levy at Paradigm as a part-time executive director.

Messrs Lewis, Packer and Semel will sit on the international advisory panel, while Dr Lynch, Britain's first internet billionaire, will be a non-executive director.

The media and technology panel includes David Kogan and Mark Oliver, the current and former broadcasting advisers to the football Premier League. Paradigm plans to invest between £500,000 and £5m in each venture.

Beeson Gregory is broker to the float and trading in the shares is expected to start on March 30.

webTitle: Moscow hails capture of Chechen warlord

fields.headline: Moscow hails capture of Chechen warlord
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: One of the most notorious rebel Chechen field commanders has been captured by Russia's secret police and imprisoned in Moscow, giving a much needed propaganda boost to the army's campaign in the separatist region.
fields.body:
One of the most notorious rebel Chechen field commanders has been captured by Russia's secret police and imprisoned in Moscow, giving a much needed propaganda boost to the army's campaign in the separatist region.

The triumphant announcement of Salman Raduyev's imprisonment comes at a convenient time for the Kremlin, troubled by fresh setbacks to the final stages of its battle to control Chechnya.

Describing Mr Raduyev as "one of the most odious bandit leaders", Russia's acting president, Vladimir Putin, monopolised the headlines yesterday in praising Russia's security forces for the capture.

Preparations for the funerals of an entire company of 84 Russian paratroops killed during fighting in the Chechen mountains last week - when Russia suffered some of its heaviest casualties of the war - were overshadowed by the announcement.

Mr Raduyev, leader of a group of fighters known as the Lone Wolves, masterminded a hostage-taking attack in 1996 during Russia's previous war with Chechnya. The attack caused the army severe embarrassment when its attempts to crush the operation resulted in the deaths of about 100 hostages and Russian soldiers. Mr Raduyev escaped.

He has also admitted being behind two railway bomb attacks in the north Caucasus in the past two years and claimed to have organised an attempt to assassinate the Georgian president, Eduard Shevardnadze.

Related by marriage to the late Chechen leader Dzhokar Dudayev, Mr Raduyev rose swiftly in the ranks but is regarded among Chechens as a loose cannon. His influence has recently waned owing to internal feuds between rival field commanders.

His arrest was the first time Russian forces had managed to capture a senior rebel leader since the war began in September.

Seriously disfigured during an assassination attempt in 1995, Mr Raduyev hides his face behind a large beard and tinted sunglasses.

After the attempt on his life, he disappeared for several months, prompting the Russian army to report - with evident relief - that he was dead. When he reappeared a few months later, so badly scarred that he was virtually unrecognisable, he was dubbed "the man who came back from the dead".

Recently he has had extensive plastic surgery on his face, some of it carried out in Germany, and is said to have signed an agreement pledging not to take revenge on his doctors should any part of the operation have gone wrong.

State television showed the Chechen fighter, clean shaven and deprived of his glasses, being interrogated last night at Moscow's high-security Lefortovo prison.

While maximum publicity was squeezed from Mr Raduyev's arrest, there was no disguising the fact that Russia was making little progress yesterday in its attempt to seize the village of Komsomolskoye, in the mountainous south of Chechnya, the last remaining Chechen-controlled region.

The Russian army has surrounded the village and continues its relentless bombardment of the settlement, despite the presence of civilians. A week of fighting, air raids and shelling has left the village in ruins.

Russia yesterday came under renewed criticism for its excessively brutal campaign in Chechnya from a council of Europe delegation, concluding a brief visit to the region.

Calling for an immediate ceasefire and a negotiated settlement, the delegation leader, Lord Judd, said he had been "deeply disturbed by the distress and trauma suffered by civilians as a result of indiscriminate and disproportionate force by the Russian military".

He added: "It is beyond comprehension that at the beginning of the 21st century a European city like Grozny could be systematically destroyed by the forces of its own government."

The Russian army has surrounded the village and continues its relentless bombardment of the settlement, despite the presence of civilians. A week of fighting, air raids and shelling has left the village in ruins. Russia yesterday came under renewed criticism for its excessively brutal campaign in Chechnya from a council of Europe delegation, concluding a brief visit to the region. Calling for an immediate ceasefire and a negotiated settlement, the delegation leader, Lord Judd, said he had been "deeply disturbed by the distress and trauma suffered by civilians as a result of indiscriminate and disproportionate force by the Russian military". He added: "It is beyond comprehension that at the beginning of the 21st century a European city like Grozny could be systematically destroyed by the forces of its own government."

webTitle: World's largest jet cleared for takeoff

fields.headline: World's largest jet cleared for takeoff
fields.standfirst:
£10bn European Airbus 'flying hotel' with gym, shops and up to 900 passengers would create 22,000 UK jobs
Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Production of the "flying hotel," the world's largest jumbo jet, will be ready to start in 18 months after the approval yesterday of a £530m government package that would create 22,000 new jobs in the UK.
fields.body:
Production of the "flying hotel," the world's largest jumbo jet, will be ready to start in 18 months after the approval yesterday of a £530m government package that would create 22,000 new jobs in the UK.

A final decision on whether to go ahead with the twin-decked £10bn A3XX project, which could be fitted with bedrooms, a dining room, a gymnasium and shops, will be made in the summer.

Twenty airlines, including British Airways, will be asked to place orders for the new super jumbo, which could secure work for 40 years for the European consortium, Airbus Industrie, in which Britain has a 20% stake.

BAe Systems, formerly British Aerospace, will make a £2bn investment, including the government's 25% share. The other backers are Germany, France and Spain.

The aircraft will be built to the specification of individual airlines. Its regular seating capacity is expected to be around 650, but without any frills and extras, it could seat as many as 900 people.

The government has always promised some form of launch investment, so long as it is repayable as part of a private-public partnership. But Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, would not reveal any details about when the £530m would be repaid.

He said the A3XX was the most advanced civil aircraft development project undertaken in Britain. "It recognises the manufacturing excellence we have in the UK, and the importance of manufacturing our economy."

Sensation
Mr Byers said it reflected the government's approach to industrial policy: "Not standing to one side and leaving everything to the market, nor intervening to prop up failling industries, but supporting innovation and enterprise, encourage enterprise and improving productivity." He said it would be a "green giant" with 20% less fuel per passenger and quieter and cleaner than comparable planes.

BAe will build the wings at Filton, near Bristol, where a research team has been working on the project for the past three years. Among the 22,000 jobs to be created in the UK, more than 8,000 will be established at Filton, Broughton, north Wales and Prestwick, near Glasgow.

Sir Richard Evans, chairman of BAe , described the sensation of sitting on an A3XX as like being on a "small seagoing vessel'.' It was excellent news for the 62,000 people in Britain whose jobs would be indirectly affected by the project.

He believed that a considerable market existed for the new plane. "We have worked on the design of the aircraft for three years with leading airlines throughout the world, so we know what they want."

Sir Richard said it would be welcomed in "our factories around the country involved in Airbus work and by the 400 companies throughout the UK who supply parts and knowhow to these high tech programmes". He refused to divulge "confidential details" of the deal with the government, but said it would be a good deal for Mr Byers. Under a previous arrangement with the company, the government was repaid almost twice the £250m it had invested and would continue to benefit through a further royalty on each Airbus A320 delivered.

Sir Richard was cautious about how many models would be built. Airbus would start slowly, but had plans to build between 300 and 600 in the first 10 years of production. This is expected to be split at Airbus's two plants at Hamburg and Toulouse, with the wings built at Filton.

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineeering and Electrical Union, which represents the majority of workers at BAe, said: "This is no charity handout. The investment is repayable with interest, making it good news for the taxpayer as well as industry. It's the right decision for Airbus and the UK.

"It will put us at the top of the table because it will upgrade our skills and technology. It will have major economic benefits for many years."

Mr Byers said he was confident that the deal would be approved by the European Union, and did not contravene an agreement reached in 1992 with Airbus's main competitor, Boeing. The American manufacturer receives aid from the US government for research and development.

An EU spokesman said the loan would need Brussels approval if BAe was receiving preferential treatment for the financial terms on offer. He said a decision was unlikely to be made for several months, allthough both Mr Byers and BAe believe that it is copper-bottomed.

There was no immediate reaction from Boeing, although it has always made it clear that it is not about to join Airbus in the race to build the world's largest aircraft.

Airbus and Boeing are engaged in bitter rivalry. Since its formation 25 years ago by Britain, France, Germany and Spain, Airbus has gradually started to compete with its American rival. Airbus says now has 55% of the world's civil aircraft production and contributes £1bn to Britain's trade balance.

Airbus believes that airlines will want to buy as many as 1,500 of the larger-style planes over the next 20 years and that the A3XX could represent around half of these orders.

webTitle: Another fine mess, courtesy of European diplomacy

fields.headline: Another fine mess, courtesy of European diplomacy
fields.standfirst:
The top job at the IMF will probably go to the wrong candidate

The European Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The top job at the IMF will probably go to the wrong candidate
fields.body:
Big international vacancies offer jobs for the boys. Alas, they cannot be relied on to go to the best qualified boys. This is the way it looks like being with the top job at the International Monetary Fund. As a cameo of how such mismatches come about - how diplomacy can be the enemy of quality - this saga could hardly be improved on. It is a tale of our time. A bitter exercise in German stubbornness became, in the manoeuvres of diplomacy, inevitable. Yet its outcome will be negative. Mostly likely it will achieve, in transatlantic power relations, the precise opposite of its desired effect.

The managing director of the IMF is a very important person. With the disappearance of the cold-war matrix to shape the world, international bodies are becoming more not less significant. Their leadership really matters. Vacated by a Frenchman, Michel Camdessus, the Fund job was soon earmarked for a German, by a European Union consensus which the US, in particular, is accustomed to respecting. The IMF is set aside for a European boy, in exchange for an American getting the World Bank.

The first selected German, Caio Koch-Weser, was thought not good enough, especially by Washington but also by others: the EU consensus here was not complete. He reluctantly withdrew his name. Germany, however, refused to do likewise. A defiance was rising to the surface that has its roots in post-war history. Chancellor Schröder was put out of face. Trickier than that, there's the issue of Germany's difficulty in ever filling big international economic posts, a lengthy failure she shares, conspicuously, with Japan. For German politicians, such an inferiority complex must not continue to dominate their international lives.

If anything, the validity of it was endorsed rather than challenged by the candidate whom Schröder, scraping the barrel of available talent, then put up. Horst Köhler has been head of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development for the last 18 months. His record is uneven. Technically he's a competent civil servant, I was told from within the EBRD, but an irascible manager as well as the kind of official better at carrying out other people's vision than developing his own. He is, however, German. Europe, to keep Schröder sweet, is now lining up behind the second German.

It doesn't do so happily. Several people I spoke to on both sides of the Atlantic yesterday know that there's a better European candidate than Köhler. He is Giuliano Amato, the Italian finance minister. It is unusual to find such a shared assessment in the chancelleries. As well as being technically able, Amato is not a bureaucrat but a politician. He carries the clout of an ex-prime minister, the democrat who will always trump the bureaucrat, especially, one might say, in international bodies which have to grapple with national finance ministers.

As it happens, I saw Amato in action this weekend at the Venice seminar of British and Italian journalists, where he offered an unscripted tour of the world economic horizon, the breadth and suppleness of which could be matched by few politicians anywhere - certainly by no over-spun, tight-arsed British cabinet minister of the last decade. Signor Amato was at ease with everything from EU migration patterns to the global impact of e-commerce: a liberal, unsectarian, undefensive European, with a cultural range of reference that stretches effortlessly to Nashville. His intellectual honesty seems to have survived a lifetime among the political flexibilities that are habitually required of Italian leaders.

This may not be the only reason why Amato has had American support against the Germans. US-German relations are not at their warmest. They are each other's main rivals for business in Russia, a key theatre for the IMF. There are also severe disagreements over anti-ballistic missiles, and tensions over European defence. But these are mere nuances, beside the undiplomatically straightforward opinion of the US treasury secretary, Larry Summers, who has taken command of Washington's IMF vote. He is now regarded, not least by the state department, as having unilaterally liquidated the old assumption that the US would accept whichever consensus candidate the EU produced.

It was Summers who put the muscle in against Koch-Weser, on grounds of his lack of suitable experience. Less suavely diplomatic than his predecessor, Robert Rubin, he was determined the job should be filled by the right man and not the proper German. His reasoning against the second German will be much the same, though it will be more difficult for him to make it stick. Another veto would cause a rupture in German-American relations that he would surely not be permitted to make on his own.

I n the way of diplomacy, however, many people would be quite pleased if a method was found to reject Horst Köhler. While Washington may find it impossible to bar him, conceivably an alliance of other geographical regions could be covertly assembled. And among the capitals that might be quite happy with this would be London, where Tony Blair and Gordon Brown decided, against every other facet of their judgment, that Chancellor Schröder must not be humiliated. Both Downing Street and the treasury much preferred Amato to be the EU candidate. But, with other fish to fry where they need Schröder to be tending the same fire, they will help to equip the IMF with the wrong leader.

This is more than an academic matter. It has two glaring consequences. One is to produce a managing director who will have little respect inside the IMF itself. Already Germany's own second preference, Köhler will be seen, assuming he's allowed to make it, to have survived only for grubby diplomatic reasons. He will lack personal authority. The rules of national face will have been observed, but global financial best practice will have been put in its place. If anything, this is likely to damage rather than enhance German standing in the international world, and be seen as proof of Schröder's amateurish approach to foreign affairs.

It follows, secondly, that the influence which Europe is supposed to be conceded by having its hands on the IMF appointment will be much diminished. The French officials who have dominated it in recent years have a mixed record. It is becoming a more political job. In the absence of a strong leader, there will not be a vaccuum so much as a shift of power elsewhere. Where? Under a Köhler directorship, the IMF will in effect be run by its experienced and capable number two, Stanley Fischer, much admired by client as well as donor states, and a fully-fledged American in all but birthplace. So much for the brilliant diplomacy of the nation states of Europe.
