webTitle: EU scheme to fund repatriation of failed asylum seekers

fields.headline: EU scheme to fund repatriation of failed asylum seekers
fields.standfirst:
Refugees in Britain: special report
The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Thousands of failed asylum seekers in Britain will be encouraged to return home voluntarily under a new EU funded programme now being considered by home office ministers.
fields.body:
Thousands of failed asylum seekers in Britain will be encouraged to return home voluntarily under a new EU funded programme now being considered by home office ministers.

The introduction of such voluntary return programmes has been designed by the European commission to aid EU states who have difficulty enforcing expulsion orders against those who fail to qualify for refugee status.

The programme is also in tended as a "credible and humane alternative to compulsory repatriation".

The scheme is part of a European refugee fund to be created later this year, following agreement at the special EU home affairs council in Tampere, Finland, in October which was attended by Tony Blair and Jack Straw. About £23m has been set aside to finance the fund in its first year of operation.

As Britain was second in the European league table for the number of asylum applicants for both 1998 and 1999 behind Germany, it is likely that the British taxpayer will benefit from the scheme.

The fund also includes a cash reserve to help spread the burden of paying to cope with a sudden mass influx of refugees, as happened last summer during the Kosovo crisis.

The internal EU paper seen by the Guardian said there were differences in the asylum burden borne by each EU state because of "the different directions taken by the flows of persons in search of protection and the uneven distribution of populations of refugees and displaced persons in the Euro pean Union". A proposal suggests that the burden is shared according to how many asylum seekers and refugees each country has taken in the past three years.

The detailed plan drawn up by the European commission said that measures such as the introduction of voluntary return programmes are necessary to ensure that those whose asylum applications fail are returned to their country of origin "in order to safeguard asylum as a permanent and credible institution".

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdicombe, has claimed that as many as 60,000 failed asylum seekers have "disappeared" in Britain in the past 10 years.

The voluntary return programmes will include giving the people involved reliable information about the areas they have come from as well as material assistance to help them prepare for their return home.

The immigration minister, Barbara Roche, has told MPs studying the plan that the government has reservations about the way the European refugee fund would operate. Ministers want to set down a maximum level that can be spent by the fund and would rather see the cost "burden-sharing" formula decided by number of asylum seekers as a proportion of the resident population rather than how many asylum seekers have arrived in each country over the past three years.

MPs have asked for more information about the fund and the government has three months in which to decide whether to "opt-in" to the measure, although Mrs Roche said that Britain would normally participate in a scheme which did not affect Britain's frontier controls.

fields.headline: Dramas of race and class
fields.trailText: To remove DW Griffith's name from the most prestigious film directors' award is misjudged (Film directors strip award of link to Klan, March 11). Whilst I agree with those who find the racial politics of Griffith's The Birth of a Nation deeply offensive, I would argue that this film must be read in the context of a lengthy and on-going debate about the American civil war (1861-65) and the Reconstruction period.
fields.body:
To remove DW Griffith's name from the most prestigious film directors' award is misjudged (Film directors strip award of link to Klan, March 11). Whilst I agree with those who find the racial politics of Griffith's The Birth of a Nation deeply offensive, I would argue that this film must be read in the context of a lengthy and on-going debate about the American civil war (1861-65) and the Reconstruction period.

The Birth of a Nation and, indeed, Thomas Dixon's The Clansman follow about 100 stage melodramas in America between 1887-1920 debating the war and written by both northern (union-supporting) and southern (confederacy-supporting) dramatists.

What distinguishes The Birth of a Nation from its predecessors is its magnitude and scope, its innovations and development of filmic vocabularies, its marketing strategies and, unhappily, the Klan's exploitation of its huge appeal. The Directors' Guild of America, of all institutions, should have read the history of their profession and continue to honour their highly creative progenitor.
Prof David Mayer
Department of Drama, University of Manchester
david.mayer@man.ac.uk

 I was pleased to see a picture of Andrew Dennis as Apollo in Tales from Ovid as it demonstrates that black English people can play classical roles as well as modern roles (Changes of mind, Saturday Review, March 11). In fact, I would even go as far to say that Jimmy Porter in John Osborne's Look Back in Anger would be an ideal role for a black Englishman with a Brummie accent, as quite a large proportion of black English people are working class, as Jimmy Porter was. It is about time that more plays included black English people.
Jason Young
Producer, Anglo-Caribbean Productions
jasonyoung72@yahoo.com

fields.headline: Cuba first
fields.trailText: Genetic research at Cambridge may lead to a vaccine for meningitis B in several years' time (Scientists crack meningitis code, March 10). In light of public concern about this disease, it may be of interest that Cuban scientists at the Finlay Institute in Havana have produced a meningitis B vaccine which is already in use in some countries (eg Brazil). Moreover, the Anglo-US company SmithKline Beecham signed an agreement with Cuba last July to further test and then manufacture and market the vaccine, for which Baroness Gloria Hooper, a member of the SmithKline Beecham board of directors, has said that Britain would probably be the first market.
fields.body:
Genetic research at Cambridge may lead to a vaccine for meningitis B in several years' time (Scientists crack meningitis code, March 10). In light of public concern about this disease, it may be of interest that Cuban scientists at the Finlay Institute in Havana have produced a meningitis B vaccine which is already in use in some countries (eg Brazil). Moreover, the Anglo-US company SmithKline Beecham signed an agreement with Cuba last July to further test and then manufacture and market the vaccine, for which Baroness Gloria Hooper, a member of the SmithKline Beecham board of directors, has said that Britain would probably be the first market.

But the 40-year US blockade of the island closes off access to information about the state-of-the-art Cuban biotechnology industry - and to the fruits of many of those advances.
Dr Eric B Ross
Institute of Social Studies, The Hague

fields.headline: Out of the deep freeze
fields.standfirst:
Ulster's peace process needs a reality check

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Ulster's peace process needs a reality check
fields.body:
After the bleak midwinter, there are the first signs of spring. After a month in the deep freeze, the peace process in Northern Ireland is thawing back into life. The politicians were exhausted following Peter Mandelson's decision to collapse Northern Ireland's new executive and to suspend the assembly. The bargain which was meant to secure peace - devolution in return for disarmament - had failed. The IRA refused to give up its guns on what it saw as a Unionist-imposed timetable and nobody had a plan B. Peace has been on ice ever since.

This week, the effort is beginning again. In the lead-up to St Patrick's Day Northern Ireland's politicians are converging on Washington, hoping that the White House magic will work once more. What are their chances? Not great. Plenty of Unionists believe the task of peacemaking is harder now than before: republican credibility was destroyed, they say, when the IRA failed to give up the guns Unionists were expecting by the end of January. Next time they make a promise, Unionists will simply refuse to believe them. To add to the paralysis, David Trimble is in no mood to take risks right now: he could face a leadership challenge at his party's annual general meeting on March 25. One Unionist official yesterday was clear: the next move has to come from the nationalist side.

The first hints of that are apparent. From the safe distance of Sydney, Australia the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, signalled what might be a shift. Seeking to end the failed linkage of devolution and decommissioning, he suggested a new approach - centred on an IRA declaration that war is no longer an option. A more significant development may be the offstage efforts of Brian Cowen, the new Irish foreign minister. His apparent starting point is the IRA's insistence it is not hung up on guns, that there is a scenario in which disarmament is possible. OK, says Mr Cowen: tell us what it is. The IRA has been good at telling us what it cannot do; now it is time to tell us what it can do - and in clear language, rather than the tortured jargon of the army council. Once that is spelled out, then the parties can begin to work back - deducing what needs to be done to get there from here. It may be disappointing; the timeline may be in years rather than months. But at least it will be realistic. If this is where thinking in Dublin is heading, then that can only be a positive start to the new political season.

fields.headline: Chechnya whitewash
fields.trailText: Which "severe terrorist attacks" does Tony Blair believe justifies Vladimir Putin's campaign of indiscriminate slaughter in Chechnya (Blair courts outrage with Putin visit, March 11)? The bomb blasts in Moscow last August remain unsolved. In any case, how can any civilized government justify putting Grozny and countless Chechen villages to the sword? Stalin's deportation of the Chechen population in 1944 included 192,000 children under 16. It seems clear where Putin, 14 years in the Soviet terror machine, gets his inspiration.

The bomb blasts in Moscow last August remain unsolved. In any case, how can any civilized government justify putting Grozny and countless Chechen villages to the sword? Stalin's deportation of the Chechen population in 1944 included 192,000 children under 16. It seems clear where Putin, 14 years in the Soviet terror machine, gets his inspiration.

The Russian elite will arrive at the Queen Elizabeth II Conference Centre in London on April 19 for "Russia 2000", a two-day conference with western oil and metal magnates. They must expect to be met with street protest at the barbarity of New Russia, scarcely dry from its New Labour whitewash.
David Crouch
London

 Tony Blair told the BBC that "it is important to realise that Chechnya isn't Kosovo". He is correct as Russian war crimes in Chechnya, both in 1994-1995 and from 1999, are on a far greater scale than Serbian crimes in Kosovo. The Channel Four Dispatches programme (March 9) and international human rights organisations such as Helsinki Watch have documented extensive crimes against humanity in Chechnya which far exceed those committed in Kosovo. Russian media reports have speculated that the Chechen population has declined by half since military conflict broke out in 1994.
Dr Taras Kuzio
University College London
t.kuzio@moose.co.uk

 John Yates (Letters, March 10) comments on the hairlines and name suffixes linking Russian and Soviet leaders. Surely, Russia has spent a century merely losing a Ras. Between the Mad Monk and Vladimir Putin, the levels of sanity and trustworthiness are about the same.
Athar Yawar
Oxford

fields.headline: Education in lip-reading
fields.trailText: I was in the hall at the Labour conference in 1995 when David Blunkett made his "watch my lips" statement (Blunkett defends 11-plus stance, March 13). He is being economical with the truth when he suggests this was a joke. Roy Hattersley had received thunderous applause for his attacks on selection and grant-maintained schools. Blunkett used his famous phrase to win the official motion. He convinced the audience he was against selection.
fields.body:
I was in the hall at the Labour conference in 1995 when David Blunkett made his "watch my lips" statement (Blunkett defends 11-plus stance, March 13). He is being economical with the truth when he suggests this was a joke. Roy Hattersley had received thunderous applause for his attacks on selection and grant-maintained schools. Blunkett used his famous phrase to win the official motion. He convinced the audience he was against selection.

Blunkett's new stance should be repudiated at all levels in the Labour party - the end of selection and the completion of comprehensive secondary education is Labour's fundamental education policy. It is not a joke.
Max Morris
London
MMMorris@email.msn.com

 Five and half years and a major education act later, campaigners against the 11-plus in Kent know where we stand. But even in the face of government indifference, we will fight on because we know that selection in Kent is ex pensive, socially divisive and depresses educational standards. How else can David Blunkett explain why Kent has more schools on his hit list than any other county? Stop the 11-Plus Campaign.
James Parish
Jim.Parish@btinternet.com

 In Wandsworth we have a new 11-plus introduced this year: but for entry to comprehensive, not grammar, schools. In this area, 50% are selected by 11-plus and almost all the rest are siblings. Two children (out of 45) who attend the junior school adjacent to one of these "compre- hensive" schools passed the 11-plus, and four children (out of 60) from the next closest. The required pass mark seems to have been in excess of 85% and the rest of the kids are branded as failures, their places taken by children creamed off from other areas and boroughs. Please explain the joke to our children who have no place at their local school for next September.
John Valentine
Campaign for Local Education
jv_sw17@yahoo.co.uk

 While success is proclaimed by the pro-grammar lobby, I have yet to read of the cost to children of this so called victory. Namely, that about 70% of them have to be informed, at the tender age of 11, that they have failed.
M Carrington
London

 If Nick Davies is believed (Schools in crisis, March 7) we have been able to pay "non-money" to build an £850,000 extension to our middle school, thereby replacing huts which had disgraced our grounds for some 20 years; £10,000 in non-money to upgrade our computer facility, and some £4,000 for new library books.
John Thackway
Swanage, Dorset

 In rebutting allegations of "conjuring tricks" David Blunkett compounds his sins (My reply, March 10): "260 schools are benefiting from substantial building projects through public-private partnership". That is indeed the aspiration, but in fact only a handful of PFI contracts have been signed and only three new-builds completed. Many are bogged down in the complex procurement process.
Michael Ball
Vice-chair, Pimlico school governors,
London

 I was disgusted by the partiality and inaccuracy of the Nick Davies report. I am pleased, therefore that David Blunkett has put the matters straight. Unfortunately, we'll still get letters and articles from clever-dicks threatening to, or actually leaving, the Labour party. There is no way the damage done to schools over 18 years of Thatcherism can be put right quickly: only small children expect everything at once.
Ruby Weston
Long Buckby, Northants

webTitle: A bold leap in the skies

fields.headline: A bold leap in the skies
fields.standfirst: Europe's progress requires public money
fields.trailText: Europe's progress requires public money
fields.body:
The government's decision to invest £530m in the production of a new super-jumbo aircraft capable of carrying up to 900 passengers is a welcome act of faith in a bold European project. Even though it is possible, even probable, that the announcement had something to do with the gestating troubles in Labour's heartlands, that would only have affected the timing not the decision itself. The news that 8,000 new jobs could be created at BAe's factories in Broughton, north Wales, Filton, near Bristol and, more to the point, Prestwick in Scotland (close to where the Ayr byelection will take place on Thursday) is a highly convenient bonus, but not the real point. The government, for all its shilly-shallying over further European integration, is prepared to back a genuine pan-European project.

The original plans to build a European aircraft to take on the divine right of Boeing to dominate the world market was very risky. It would not have happened without public money. It would almost certainly not have been allowed to be built today because governments have recoiled from direct involvement with industry. Money is only forthcoming today because the Airbus has been a brilliant industrial (if not yet financial) success story. It now claims half of the world market for passenger aircraft, a phenomenon that would have seemed impossible years ago. But at that time Europe was playing catch-up. Now it is seizing the initiative by planning to build the next generation of "jumbo" jumbos ahead of a procrastinating Boeing. This may be the sign of an emerging European self-confidence. One of the very few other areas of major cooperation is mobile phones where the hammering out of a common standard (GSM) for mobiles is one of the main reasons Europe has a technological lead over America.

BAe (formerly British Aerospace) will build the wings for the planned A3XX range that could include gymnasiums and restaurants. They will be able to carry up to 900 passengers depending on the configuration. There is an understandable worry about aircraft getting bigger and bigger. Although they are also getting safer, it is inevitable that when an accident eventually happens it will be on a scale hitherto almost unimaginable. That said, the new range will use 20% less fuel per passenger and may also delay airport expansion by using existing slots more intensively.

The speed with which the government extended low interest (repayable) loans is in telling contrast with its reluctance to permit cheap loans (in the form of bond finance) for improvements to the London underground system. The treasury will doubtless argue that in the case of the Airbus it trusts the management to use the money effectively, but not the management of the London tube. Either way there is clearly a role still for public money in risky but important long-term projects. Almost 30 years ago the (Conservative) government baled out Roll-Royce and gave it money to fund the RB211 range of engines, derivatives of which are still with us today, and may even power many of the new European super-jumbos if they are built. Rolls never became vastly profitable but the public money generated benefits to the economy far beyond the balance sheet. The Airbus has an urgent duty to publish proper commercial accounts so taxpayers can see exactly where their money is going. But you do not have to be a genius to predict that the Airbus will probably still be around when some of today's fashionable dot.com companies are no more than memories preserved as case studies in business schools.

fields.headline: Something rotten about these emissions
fields.trailText: Your fail to recognise the connection between floods in Mozambique and the government's policy on climate change and emissions trading (UK leads world in carbon dioxide cut, March 10). The government committed itself under the Kyoto protocol to reducing the country's greenhouse gas emissions to 12% below their 1990 level by 2010. It now expects to achieve a 20% reduction and has said that it will sell the 8% difference to the US for £100m.
fields.body:
Your fail to recognise the connection between floods in Mozambique and the government's policy on climate change and emissions trading (UK leads world in carbon dioxide cut, March 10). The government committed itself under the Kyoto protocol to reducing the country's greenhouse gas emissions to 12% below their 1990 level by 2010. It now expects to achieve a 20% reduction and has said that it will sell the 8% difference to the US for £100m.

The Danes and the Germans are both committed to 21% reductions. Those countries must now regret their commitments, as they also could have offered phony targets in exchange for US cash. The UK sets a dreadful precedent as it creates yet another incentive to offer as little reduction as possible.

The government accepts the link between emissions and climate damage, but now appears willing to profit from this destruction. There could be more than 2m deaths from climate change-related disasters worldwide in the next 10 years, and the damage to property will be hundreds of billions of pounds. If these lives lost are assessed at average UK values, we can easily add a trillion pounds to the total bill. The UK's expectation of £100m through this trade - 10 times its aid to Mozambique- is another dreadful precedent.

The government must now commit itself to the UN basis of retreating from fossil fuel dependency globally, known as "contraction, convergence, allocation and trade" (CCAT). This framework is based on the convention's global prin ciples of precaution, equity and efficiency in that order, and it is already widely supported here and abroad.

Governments of heavy fossil-fuel using economies are likely to face huge claims for compensation because of the damage its continued emissions are doing. As proposed, the UK-US emissions trade amounts to a subsidy the two countries will jointly extract from the rest of the world. But the real cost is the damage and death that their continued heavy fossil fuel use brings about.

Under CCAT, revenues from emissions trading would be directed into the global development and deployment of clean and renewable energy sources.
Aubrey Meyer
Global Commons Institute

webTitle: Balkans wait in vain for western funds

fields.headline: Balkans wait in vain for western funds
fields.standfirst:
US angry at EU's foot-dragging on pact pledges

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: US angry at EU's foot-dragging on pact pledges
fields.body:
It was billed as the launch of a new era in which peace, prosperity and democracy would finally come to the Balkans - and wars like Kosovo would never happen again.

Last July, as Nato consolidated its hold on the Serbian province, President Bill Clinton visited Sarajevo's overflowing cemeteries in neighbouring Bosnia and declared that ethnic conflict had no place in the 21st century. But now the victors are at loggerheads over paying for the stability pact unveiled with such fanfare in the Bosnian capital: under the pact, donors were meant to help rebuild the Balkans, but - while Kosovo is getting some funds - the scheme has yet to deliver a penny to the wider region.

No longer concealing its irritation, Washington is demanding that EU states put hard cash on the table when donor countries meet in Brussels later this month. It looks like being an important and highly public test of the gap between rhetoric and reality - and it is already ratcheting up transatlantic tensions.

In a sharp private letter to EU foreign ministers last week, Madeleine Albright, the US secretary of state, pledged $350m (£222m) for "quick start" and "first priority" projects and nearly $400m for next year - though those figures, she warned, would depend on what other countries were prepared to spend.

"We are keen on understanding more clearly the exact commitments you are prepared to make," Mrs Albright added tartly.

Chris Patten, the EU's external relations commissioner, quickly cautioned that disagreements over money could "poison or warp" European-American ties.

Britain, Belgium and Spain have failed to meet their initial pledges to the pact. According to EU estimates, it could cost between $60bn and $100bn to rebuild south-eastern Europe - though no one is offering sums remotely near that.

The Brussels pledging conference, starting on March 29, will be looking at initial projects worth between $1bn and $2bn.

There was no price tag when Balkan countries were offered their grand bargain in Sarajevo: embrace democracy and the free market, they were told, and Europe will embrace you. The Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, who has done neither, was not invited.

Some have taken this advice to heart: Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic are already members of Nato and on track for EU membership. Romania and Bulgaria were rewarded with their promise of eventual EU membership at December's Helsinki summit.

Macedonia has just been given a "stabilisation and association agreement" with Brussels. Croatia will get one as soon as its new democratic government - being wooed by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, yesterday - fulfils its promises to allow Serb refugees return home and cooperates with the Hague war crimes tribunal.

Impoverished Albania is complaining loudly that it is not getting its share of the pie, while EU officials speak with mounting concern about exaggerated expectations and the dangers of a creating a "culture of dependency".

Most experts agree that a regional approach is right. Transfrontier transport and other infrastructural projects are stability pact priorities, building on the idea that countries which trade with each other will not easily go to war.

Yet hardly anyone has a good word for the pact and its coordinator, Germany's Bodo Hombach, who is seen as adding another layer of bureaucracy to an already chaotic scene.

"Up to now the pact has delivered nothing and appears characterised by delays and lack of coordination," is Oxfam's gloomy assessment.

"Frankly it has produced very little," said one EU diplomat. "We are definitely approaching the moment of truth at this conference."

James Lyons, a Balkan specialist with the International Crisis Group, warns that pledges made in Brussels may well turn out to be existing money repackaged, though he argues that Mrs Albright has good reason to complain about the performance of the Europeans.

"The EU is always the Johnny-come-lately - not a month, but a year or more late," he says. "The US comes in quickly while the Europeans pronounce and take years to get their act together. By the time they do, the impact is squandered."

But Balkan prosperity is not just about donor generosity: recipient countries need to tackle the high levels of corruption and organised crime that hinder economic development and frighten potential foreign investors.

Montenegro - which many fear will be the region's next flashpoint - is likely to be an important test of western resolve. Because it is still part of the Yugoslav Federation, the mountainous republic is not eligible for World Bank or IMF loans. EU help, Mrs Albright declared, was "critical."

Looking back a year after the war, the victors of Kosovo need to take many more costly decisions, as stability pact documents graphically illustrate. Project costs are divided into three neat vertical columns - sum needed, sum pledged, sum outstanding. In the vast majority of cases, the middle column is still blank.
fields.bodyText: It was billed as the launch of a new era in which peace, prosperity and democracy would finally come to the Balkans - and wars like Kosovo would never happen again. Last July, as Nato consolidated its hold on the Serbian province, President Bill Clinton visited Sarajevo's overflowing cemeteries in neighbouring Bosnia and declared that ethnic conflict had no place in the 21st century. But now the victors are at loggerheads over paying for the stability pact unveiled with such fanfare in the Bosnian capital: under the pact, donors were meant to help rebuild the Balkans, but - while Kosovo is getting some funds - the scheme has yet to deliver a penny to the wider region. No longer concealing its irritation, Washington is demanding that EU states put hard cash on the table when donor countries meet in Brussels later this month. It looks like being an important and highly public test of the gap between rhetoric and reality - and it is already ratcheting up transatlantic tensions. In a sharp private letter to EU foreign ministers last week, Madeleine Albright, the US secretary of state, pledged $350m (£222m) for "quick start" and "first priority" projects and nearly $400m for next year - though those figures, she warned, would depend on what other countries were prepared to spend. "We are keen on understanding more clearly the exact commitments you are prepared to make," Mrs Albright added tartly. Chris Patten, the EU's external relations commissioner, quickly cautioned that disagreements over money could "poison or warp" European-American ties. Britain, Belgium and Spain have failed to meet their initial pledges to the pact. According to EU estimates, it could cost between $60bn and $100bn to rebuild south-eastern Europe - though no one is offering sums remotely near that. The Brussels pledging conference, starting on March 29, will be looking at initial projects worth between $1bn and $2bn. There was no price tag when Balkan countries were offered their grand bargain in Sarajevo: embrace democracy and the free market, they were told, and Europe will embrace you. The Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, who has done neither, was not invited. Some have taken this advice to heart: Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic are already members of Nato and on track for EU membership. Romania and Bulgaria were rewarded with their promise of eventual EU membership at December's Helsinki summit. Macedonia has just been given a "stabilisation and association agreement" with Brussels. Croatia will get one as soon as its new democratic government - being wooed by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, yesterday - fulfils its promises to allow Serb refugees return home and cooperates with the Hague war crimes tribunal. Impoverished Albania is complaining loudly that it is not getting its share of the pie, while EU officials speak with mounting concern about exaggerated expectations and the dangers of a creating a "culture of dependency". Most experts agree that a regional approach is right. Transfrontier transport and other infrastructural projects are stability pact priorities, building on the idea that countries which trade with each other will not easily go to war. Yet hardly anyone has a good word for the pact and its coordinator, Germany's Bodo Hombach, who is seen as adding another layer of bureaucracy to an already chaotic scene. "Up to now the pact has delivered nothing and appears characterised by delays and lack of coordination," is Oxfam's gloomy assessment. "Frankly it has produced very little," said one EU diplomat. "We are definitely approaching the moment of truth at this conference." James Lyons, a Balkan specialist with the International Crisis Group, warns that pledges made in Brussels may well turn out to be existing money repackaged, though he argues that Mrs Albright has good reason to complain about the performance of the Europeans. "The EU is always the Johnny-come-lately - not a month, but a year or more late," he says. "The US comes in quickly while the Europeans pronounce and take years to get their act together. By the time they do, the impact is squandered." But Balkan prosperity is not just about donor generosity: recipient countries need to tackle the high levels of corruption and organised crime that hinder economic development and frighten potential foreign investors. Montenegro - which many fear will be the region's next flashpoint - is likely to be an important test of western resolve. Because it is still part of the Yugoslav Federation, the mountainous republic is not eligible for World Bank or IMF loans. EU help, Mrs Albright declared, was "critical." Looking back a year after the war, the victors of Kosovo need to take many more costly decisions, as stability pact documents graphically illustrate. Project costs are divided into three neat vertical columns - sum needed, sum pledged, sum outstanding. In the vast majority of cases, the middle column is still blank.

fields.headline: Death lurks in the fields
fields.standfirst:
Unexploded bombs: Kosovo tries to clean up after air strikes

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: The US is refusing to allow American troops to remove the thousands of unexploded cluster bombs dropped by Nato planes on Kosovo last year.
fields.body:
The US is refusing to allow American troops to remove the thousands of unexploded cluster bombs dropped by Nato planes on Kosovo last year.

As the snows melt and the first planting season since the Nato air strikes approaches, Albanian and international officials fear that the death toll from bomb casualties will rise as farmers start to plough, children play in the fields and people go into the woods to collect timber for cooking.

Cluster bombs are far more deadly than landmines and around 10% failed to explode. But for fear of the "bodybag syndrome", whereby the bodies of US casualties are returned home in bags, the Pentagon has ruled that it will not order its professional disposal experts to defuse them. The job is being dumped on underfunded civilian teams, largely staffed by Albanians.

Each cluster bomb unit contains up to 200 weapons the size of a tennis ball canister. The unit opens up at about 2,000ft, unleashing a hail of the bomb canisters that swamp an area the size of four football pitches with lethal shrapnel. Designed as an anti-tank weapon, each bomb can also penetrate five inches of steel.

During the Kosovo war, US and British pilots were under orders to drop them from above 15,000ft to keep their aircraft safe from enemy fire. Hundreds of the bombs missed their targets.

"Nato gave us information about where they thought they dropped them. These were detailed grid references, but many turned out not to be correct," says John Flanagan, a colonel from New Zealand, who heads the UN's mine action coordination centre in Kosovo. "They may have intended to drop six bombs on one target and four go off somewhere else, as much as one kilometre from the intended spot."

The UN coordinates the work of several civilian demining teams. As well as falling wide, about 28,000 of the deadly canisters failed to explode. If they stay on the surface and can be seen, they can be detonated by putting an explosive charge beside them. But most go through the soil and are lying between 10cm and 20cm underground, ready to blast a tractor or a person who steps on one. When hidden, they are far harder to detect and dispose of than ordinary landmines.

"Nato doesn't want to create a precedent for cleaning up in post-conflict situations. They first made this clear in the Gulf war. [The Gulf war cleanup] cost $700m, but luckily the Kuwaitis could pay," Col Flanagan says. Kosovo, by contrast, is poor and much more heavily populated than the Kuwaiti desert.

"My personal opinion is that if they're going to use these kinds of weapons, they have to recognise there is a postwar environmental effect," he adds.

Traditional landmines are mainly used to defend fixed sites, and armies usually keep records of where they are laid so that they can be lifted later. Cluster bombs are attack weapons and inaccurate.

Since June, 54 people have already been killed by mines or cluster bombs in Kosovo; another 250 have been maimed. In the worst cluster-bomb accident, four children died near Gnjilane and one was seriously hurt when they threw a stone at the yellow canister lying in a field. Only 30% of Kosovo's arable land was used last year because most refugees came back too late to plough. This year, however, mine casualties are expected to rise in spite of efforts to make people aware of the dangers lurking in their fields.

K-For, the Nato-led international peace force, says it will lift mines and unexploded cluster bombs only if they obstruct its mission to provide security; in practice, this means those found on main roads or near K-For bases and buildings.

The non-governmental organisations' (NGO) disposal teams have destroyed 2,743 bombs so far, but that still leaves over 25,000. The US government and other Nato partners are paying for some of the NGO work, but every contract requires time-consuming lobbying and pleading for funds. It would be easier to use the Pentagon's trained weapons disposal teams, but cowardice among politicians and the consequences of casualties even in a volunteer army appear to preclude it.

Tomorrow: Jonathan Steele on the bureaucratic nightmare in Kosovo

fields.headline: Spick and span.com
fields.standfirst: But people push vacuum cleaners
fields.trailText: But people push vacuum cleaners
fields.body:
For many of its business-to-consumer applications, the internet gets us only so far. Buy a book or disc and it needs to be delivered. Order groceries and ditto. You can set up coiff.com but cannot style hair online. At the end of the chain, hi-tech turns out to rely on low or at least unmodified tech - man with van, humper of parcels, woman with manual skills. Unilever's proposed move into domestic service suggests we are going to see much more of this odd coupling of technological sophistication and labour-intensive personal service work. Clicking on cleaning dot.com will not activate some R2D2 to do the carpets in the living room. At best the internet will be that bit quicker in securing a real live person - very probably female - who her employers will be anxious to pay no more than the minimum wage.

Here is an object lesson in uneven development. Some technologies change rapidly, prompting hyperbole about speed and impermanence. Others, de spite the best efforts of Mr Dyson, are still basically the same as they were in the 1890s. No one (again, the reason may be because it is generally woman's work) has yet invented a non-laborious way of negotiating the S-bend. Stripping sheets off a bed and getting them into the washing machine was, is and will remain back-bending hard work.

Yet the internet could help professionalise domestic work, even improve productivity on this last frontier of the paid economy. Provided householders are willing to pay properly, cleaning could become a neutral function, like waitering, with none of the traditional opprobrium of "service".

Still, Unilever may find customers resist the idea of having different people coming in each day. Even stretched eight-to-eight workers enjoy a special relationship with the person who does their dirty laundry and knows the content of their litter bins. Confidentiality agreements, anyone?

webTitle: 'Everyone knows there is going to be a civil war in Serbia now. We can smell it'

fields.headline: 'Everyone knows there is going to be a civil war in Serbia now. We can smell it'
fields.standfirst: Dead city: Everyone is scared of Milosevic. They have lost everything - except hope
fields.trailText: His mobile phone plays the Serbian national anthem when it rings; he presses the receiver with a hand the size of a T-bone steak. A Serb paramilitary, one of the feared "Tigers" who killed in Kosovo, he smothers the bay-blue handset with massive fingers.
fields.body:
His mobile phone plays the Serbian national anthem when it rings; he presses the receiver with a hand the size of a T-bone steak. A Serb paramilitary, one of the feared "Tigers" who killed in Kosovo, he smothers the bay-blue handset with massive fingers.

"I'd like to find a nice girl and get married, but we have to wait until this is over and [Yugoslav President Slobodan] Milosevic has gone," he says.

There is a sense in Belgrade that civil war may come to Serbia - Mr Milosevic and his praetorian guard of police and military against the people. Everyone is scared.

In this city, where random political assassinations are the norm, police consolidate their grip on power by breaking up protests, smashing TV transmitters and silencing the dissenters with fear.

"The crackdown started three weeks ago after he addressed the party congress. The message was clear: Don't start or else," says Natasha Kandic, a lawyer and director of the humanitarian law centre in Belgrade. She one of the few people prepared to speak out. "They have started arresting people. A young lawyer from my office was taken for an 'information talk' for two days, now he has resigned. I don't blame him - he has a young family."

A former police chief who claims to have been the head of internal security and a confidant of Mr Milosevic's wife, Mira Markovic, confirms that the crackdown has started. "But it's going to get much worse. The elections may be coming, maybe not. He is cornered and he will fight to the end - his end or ours."

Even those hardened by years on the frontlines of the war under the Tigers' assassinated paramilitary leader, Zeljko "Arkan" Raznatovic, are wary of the country's changing political climate. "When Arkan was alive, I felt some safety," says the former paramilitary soldier. "I didn't cry when my mother died, but when Arkan was shot, I felt it deep in my soul."

He joined Arkan when he was 19 after the army kicked him out for breaking his commanding officer's chin. In the pizza parlour in Republica Square, he dips into the waistband of his tracksuit and pulls out his gun; the handle is engraved with the Serbian crest. "Arkan didn't think it could happen to him. In Serbia, anybody could be killed. Some body could come and kill me right now."

Arkan, Mr Milosevic's protege who carried out the president's dirty work in Croatia and Bosnia, is just one of a number who died when the regime began to implode.

"Arkan had about 400 people working for him. He was making his money mostly from stealing cars in Germany and then selling them to the Middle East," the former police chief said. "Cars and cigarette smuggling, but he was killed because of the protection business and because the regime was nervous of him. He couldn't be controlled by them any more. He wanted too much protection money from too many. Four, or was it five, of them got together. It got sanctioned at the top and that was it."

He adds: "You in the west don't understand how it works. After 10 years [of war], crime, business and politics are webbed together in Serbia. They are intermingled in the grey zone. A hit like that doesn't happen unless it is approved from the top."

Belgrade is a place where even the Tigers are tired and scared. Last week, five armed men broke into the opposition's TV station and beat up a technician and a guard; the gang took the station's transmitters. It was the fifth station to be closed in Serbia recently, as the government attempts to stifle any voice of opposition.

The mention of the president's name draws fury everywhere. "Milosevic stole 10 years of my life with wars and all this shit," a taxi driver says.

Zoran, who also fought for Arkan in the Croatian and Bosnia wars, sits in the Stupida bar, near Belgrade's national theatre. "I will not fight again until I am fighting this regime," he says. "I can't live in my own country, everything is controlled by 200 people."

Milena Joksimovic, a 21-year-old student and activist echoes similar sentiments: "Everybody thinks it's going to end soon and we are all afraid of what is coming. But we are determined to fight. Now the only thing that is left in Pandora's box is hope."

Ms Joksimovic and her mother marched in protest against Mr Milosevic for 170 days in the southern town of Nis. "Everyone knows there is going to be a civil war now," she says. "We can smell it."

But in Belgrade people seem too worn out by poverty and sanctions to fight. "Milosevic's secret weapons have been sanctions from the west," says the police chief. "People are so tired out just trying to make a living that they can't think about organising against him."

On the third floor of a tiny street behind Republica Square, a weary gold merchant opens the door of his shop to another day of business. "Business is terrible," he says. "After nine years of sanctions, the people have nothing left to sell. I get women taking off their wedding rings and handing them to me. I tell them to think about it, but if they insist."

He takes out tiny black scales. "Your wedding ring, let me see - 18 carats, 2.3 grams - I'd give you DM24 [£12] for it. But it was your grandmother's? He smiles a practised smile. "There's a lot of sad stories out there, but I'm a businessman," he says.

On a Saturday night in Belgrade, a city of 2m people, having fun takes energy and money - two commodities that are in short supply.

Sasha Jortjevic spent £1m on his XL nightclub in Sarevejska Street, where he created a disco the size of a barn. A former captain of the Yugoslav basketball team, he made the money playing for three years in Barcelona. Last Saturday it closed down; the area that surrounds it is now dead.

"We are dead people in a dead city," said Alex Stenovic, 28. He knows that elections should be held this spring, but he, like almost everyone, does not expect them to happen. The opposition parties are so discredited that the mention of their leaders brings a snort.

"The opposition is slow," he says. "They have meetings on humanitarian aid and elections with representatives of the European countries, but people expect more."

Serbia's most famous journalist, Aleksander Tijanic, a government minister sacked by Mr Milosevic, wrote recently: "Serbia is now a great morgue in which the barely alive bewail the recent dead. Damned and despairing we stand in line and behind all success, wealth and power, the henchman is there. His judgment awaits."

"It could take another year," the ex-police chief says. "Milosevic still has the money he got from China and Panama and can keep things going for a while and pay off his police force. Then, there will be blood for 10 or 20 days and it will be over."

webTitle: Nato strives for role after cold war

fields.headline: Nato strives for role after cold war
fields.standfirst:
Defence: The allies are split over plans for a European army

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Defence: The allies are split over plans for a European army
fields.body:
Victory over the Serbs a year ago appeared to be Nato's finest hour. Today it is struggling to find a new role in the post-cold war, post-Kosovo world. Added to this sense of uncertainty, a rift is developing between European members and the US over the European Union's plans to have its own force.

In an interview, the Nato secretary general, Lord Robertson, dismissed such a pessimistic assessment. He saw a new role for Nato in protecting Europe against a vast array of security threats that had not been imagined by the organisation's founders.

He cited as a reason for optimism the suggestion from the Russian leader, Vladimir Putin, last month that Moscow might apply for membership one day, a proposal once unthinkable. "A year ago this would have been regarded as stark, raving bonkers. Eighteen months ago it would have been seen as heretical," Lord Robertson said. He admitted that the suggestion "was way down the line", but that it was feasible.

Although engaged in a humanitarian mission to prevent ethnic cleansing in Kosovo, doubts were expressed at the time. There are even more now, with little prospect of withdrawal from Kosovo for years and an increasing danger of a re-run of Northern Ireland, where soldiers initially welcomed as protectors quickly turned into targets.

Lord Robertson said that the Bosnian crisis, and the inability of United Nations forces to cope, had provided a "wake-up call" for the west: "Nato was all there was," he said. It had demonstrated that again last year in Kosovo, which he portrayed as the Bosnian conflict on a bigger scale.

Nato would have plenty of work ahead in the coming years, but a different kind of work. "Most of the security issues that we will face in the next 20 years are ethnic warfare, collapse of states, [nuclear] proliferation, the whole discussion of arms control, international crime, migration rendering borders meaningless," he said. "These are serious challenges. They threaten the future of generations in the Euro-Atlantic area."

That was why, he argued, Mr Putin's suggestion that Russia might apply for membership was not as ridiculous as it might first appear, because these problems would also be faced by Moscow.

Relations between Nato and Russia were strained by the Kosovan conflict, with Russia instinctively siding with its fellow Serbs in Belgrade. Moscow remains concerned that Nato acted without securing the approval of the United Nations.

Mr Robertson saw Mr Putin in Moscow last month and began the healing process, securing a promise from Mr Putin of the re-establishment of a joint Nato-Russia body to discuss defence issues.

Relations between Russia and the US will come under renewed pressure if President Bill Clinton approves an anti-ballistic missile system that would protect the US, allegedly from "rogue" states such as North Korea or Iraq. The Russians would view it as an a sign of aggression, a re-engagement of the arms race.

webTitle: Pressure on Clinton over IMF job

fields.headline: Pressure on Clinton over IMF job
fields.standfirst: The European Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Germany's new candidate to run the International Monetary Fund won the unanimous backing of EU governments yesterday, pressurising the United States to resist turning the selection process into a farce by refusing to support him.
fields.body:
Germany's new candidate to run the International Monetary Fund won the unanimous backing of EU governments yesterday, pressurising the United States to resist turning the selection process into a farce by refusing to support him.

Horst Köhler, head of the London-based European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, was endorsed by all 15 member states at a meeting of finance ministers in Brussels.

In a statement, he hailed the move as decisive in his candidacy to succeed Michel Camdessus as the IMF's managing director. "It is a crucial step towards establishing the necessary support of the broad majority of IMF shareholders," Köhler said.

The US blocked Europe's first choice for the job, Caio Koch-Weser, and has refused to discuss the merits of Köhler until EU governments adopted a common position on his candidacy.

Now that they have rallied behind him, Hans Eichel, Germany's finance minister, said he would be speaking to President Clinton about the EBRD chief last night.

Having humiliated the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, by rejecting Koch- Weser, Germany's deputy finance minister, few observers expect the president to risk a major diplomatic row by vetoing his second choice.

But Larry Summers, US treasury secretary, is understood to be taking a hard line against Köhler. Like Koch-Weser, Köhler, 57, is seen as an extremely able bureaucrat but lacks the political profile some consider necessary to run the world's most powerful financial institution.

In his time at the German finance ministry in the early 1990s, Köhler was instrumental in German unification and the decision to merge the two currencies at a one-for-one rate.

He was also closely involved in supporting Russia in the aftermath of the break-up of the Soviet Union and played a key role in negotiating the Maastricht Treaty on European economic and monetary union before taking over the helm of the EBRD 18 months ago.

Italian Treasury Minister Giuliano Amato, who is touted as a potential compromise candidate if Köhler is rejected, said he did not think Clinton will block Köhler. "I don't think it will happen," Amato said.

Schröder, who has staked his personal reputation on a German running the IMF, vowed to press Köhler's candidacy hard.

"We, and above all the [European Union] presidency, as it has assured us, will work intensively to achieve [a consensus with the US]," he told a news conference in Berlin.

Portuguese prime minister, Antonio Guterres, in Berlin for talks with Schröder, said: "I always said the success of this candidacy is an enormous test of responsibility in the transatlantic relationship. I think it is a very important element for that. And we will all work together for that purpose."

French finance minister Christian Sautter said Köhler's experience in dealing with eastern Europe could prove invaluable to the IMF in the period following the Russian presidential elections which take place a week on Sunday.

German government sources said the IMF executive committee may hold a first vote on Köhler's candidacy later this week.

fields.headline: Marble mission
fields.standfirst:
MEPs head for London to back Greek case

The European Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is to face unexpected pressure from the European Parliament to re-open the vexed question of returning the Elgin Marbles to Greece.    The European Parliament has voted to send a high level delegation to Britain to give evidence to next month's Commons inquiry by the Commons culture, media and sport committee - following culture secretary Chris Smith    saying Britain will not change its policy of keeping the 2,500 year old marbles in the British Museum.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is to face unexpected pressure from the European Parliament to re-open the vexed question of returning the Elgin Marbles to Greece. The European Parliament has voted to send a high level delegation to Britain to give evidence to next month's Commons inquiry by the Commons culture, media and sport committee - following culture secretary Chris Smith saying Britain will not change its policy of keeping the 2,500 year old marbles in the British Museum.

The delegation will be led by Willy De Clerq, the former deputy Prime Minister of Belgium and European Commis sioner for external affairs. He will be supported by Ana Palacio Vallelersundi (correct), a Spanish MEP who backs the ruling Christian Democrat group in the Parliament and Giogio Ruffulo, an Italian socialist MEP and former environment minister.

The MEPs are expected to give strong evidence that the British Museum should no longer keep the marbles after a new museum is built near the Parthenon to house the artifacts in 2004. Their appearance will fuel the controversy over their future after the museum faced strong criticism from British historians - notably William St Clair - over covering up damage done to them 60 years ago during cleaning.

Gerald Kaufman, the Labour chairman of the committee, is planning to look at the future of the marbles as part of a wider inquiry looking at the restitution of artifacts and whether stolen treasures in museums should be returned to their original owners. He is already under pressure to take evidence from the Greek embassy, the British Committee for the Restitution of the Parthenon Marbles, the British Museum and the ministry of culture and he plans to take his committee to Athens to look at the Parthenon at the end of the month. The result is that the issue of the marbles are expected to dominate the hearings.

webTitle: PCC check on payment to Aitken

fields.headline: PCC check on payment to Aitken
fields.standfirst: The Aitken affair: special report
fields.trailText: The Press Complaints Commission confirmed yesterday that it would investigate the Sunday Times over the reported six-figure sum it paid for the memoirs of Jonathan Aitken, the disgraced former Tory minister.
fields.body:
The Press Complaints Commission confirmed yesterday that it would investigate the Sunday Times over the reported six-figure sum it paid for the memoirs of Jonathan Aitken, the disgraced former Tory minister.

Lord Wakeham, PCC chairman, said the deal would be investigated after Peter Bradley, Labour MP for The Wrekin, complained that it was a breach of guidelines on payments to convicted criminals. Aitken was convicted of perjury after his failed libel action against the Guardian.

The Sunday Times editor, John Witherow, a member of the PCC's editors council, denied the sum paid was as high as six figures and said the money would go to Aitken's creditors. "We have a legal agreement that the money must go to the trustee for bankruptcy who is responsible to pay it to the creditors."

Aitken is now bankrupt and owes substantial sums to creditors, including the Guardian and Granada Television. He was released from prison in January after serving nearly seven months of an 18-month sentence.

Lord Wakeham said: "I can confirm that we will be investigating the complaint from Peter Bradley MP about the serialisation of Jonathan Aitken's book, Pride and Perjury, in the Sunday Times."

He added: "Some reports this morning have suggested that the PCC 'cleared' the serialisation in advance of publication. This is quite wrong, not least because the PCC has no such powers." Janine Gibson

fields.headline: Side lines
fields.trailText: Gypsy chic or cheek? | IT boys
fields.body:
Did anyone notice a woman dressed up as a Romany gypsy carrying a doll around London's West End recently? Were you one of those generous British citizens who gave her your hard-earned cash? If so, you were done over by a reporter from the Mail on Sunday. She dressed up in a chiffon scarf and "a long, dour skirt from Oxfam" to learn the "tricks of the trade" practised by the gypsies she sees "plaguing London's streets and Underground". Funny, then, that the next day the paper's daily sister ran a fashion story entitled "Could you wear the gypsy look?" inspired by "the feminine look of the traditional gypsy" featuring clothes that cost... ooh, the value of several weeks' worth of food vouchers. Sidelines presumes this is a Romany beggar's day-off wear.

 The latest jubilation about yetties (young internet technocrats) has had a nasty side-effect. The nerd has acquired sex appeal. So not only are they everywhere we look, we're now supposed to fancy them, too. Thus the muscled window cleaner who brought the office to a standstill in the Diet Coke advert has been replaced with a fully-clothed computer geek. IT boys don't do it for us.

 Music and politics can be enjoyed this Saturday at London's Scala when Meera Syal, Sanjeev Bhaskar, Asian Dub Foundation Soundsystem and Sister India, among others, take part in a club night. The night is in support of Zoora Shah, a Muslim woman from Bradford who was jailed for 20 years for killing a man she claimed abused her for more than a decade. She is currently awaiting a decision from Jack Straw on the reduction of her tariff. Tickets cost £7 before 11pm and £10 after; doors open at 9pm. For more information, tel 0181 571 9595.

fields.headline: Spit and polish
fields.standfirst: Enjoy housework? You're kidding! Er, apparently not.  Angela Neustatter on why women are reclaiming cleaning
fields.trailText: Enjoy housework? You're kidding! Er, apparently not.  Angela Neustatter on why women are reclaiming cleaning
fields.body:
Television ads these days may show us chaps in aprons marvelling at a white wash and women spiralling along mountain roads in snazzy cars, but not many of us are fooled. If you peer into any stripped wood and stainless steel kitchen, you are more likely to see a woman shoving the washing up into the sink or dirty clothes into a machine than catch her partner at it.

This week, Unilever has proposed an online venture to provide domestic help via the net. Whatever the take-up, it remains no surprise that the latest study into who does what, published last week, shows working mothers spending almost eight hours per day on household chores, which would earn them £21,000 if they were paid, while fathers get away with doing half as much. It's the latest update on an enduring story, but if it was tough in the past, when Betty Friedan wrote in The Feminine Mystique about women who had all day to do their chores popping valium to get through the tedium of dolling up the doll's house, it is no less tough today. The only surprise is that we don't regularly hear women giving vent to the sentiments voiced by Rebecca West 90 years ago when she declared: "Hatred of domestic work is a natural and admirable result of civilisation."

The interesting thing is that some women - those, it needs saying, with a choice - are actually starting to say they enjoy housework. They are talking of brisk stair-cleaning, stripping beds and cooking a meal with the music up as a fun de-stresser after the constraints of office life.

Then we have Madonna declaring she loves suburban life and knitting, that long-despised means by which women were kept quietly in their place doing something useful, emerging as a compulsive new therapy in Tinseltown. Stars such as Demi Moore, Cameron Diaz and Roseanne are now gathering for "stitch 'n' bitch" sessions. And why are they doing it? Not because they have no independent income to enable them to buy the garment in a store, but presumably because there is real pleasure in these ancient crafts.

So what is going on? Are we heading into the regressive times yearned for by America's newly emergent Surrendered Wives, who think women striving to be equal with men is responsible for marriage breakdown and unhappiness, and who are giving up on control and striving to be the submissive other half to husbands they can look up to? Can this be what post-feminism means, amnesia over The Sociology of Housework, Anne Oakley's seminal analysis of how it was the oppression and exploitation of women? I don't think so.

Obviously choice is the point. If we can buy help with our earnings, it strips housework of its political meaning - though there is still a need for sexual politics to kick up the backside those men who are happy for their wives to bring in 50% of the household money but still avoid doing their share of the chores.

That said, it seems to me a cheering sign of advanced feminism that some women can stand up and say doing housework - if it's on our terms - can be as much fun as going to the gym or walking the dog. It is not progress to feel the onus is on us to prove we are dynamic, cutting-edge women by zipping around outside the home. Today's sisters can afford to be seen polishing a door knob.

webTitle: Dead banker's daughters win paternity fight

fields.headline: Dead banker's daughters win paternity fight
fields.trailText: Nearly 15 years after a Japanese banker was killed in one of the world's worst airline disasters, two teenage sisters were legally recognised yesterday as his daughters.
fields.body:
Nearly 15 years after a Japanese banker was killed in one of the world's worst airline disasters, two teenage sisters were legally recognised yesterday as his daughters.

Cassie Bayly, 18, and Diana Bayly, 14, both musicians, have been battling to prove that they were the children of Akihisa Yukawa, a millionaire executive of Sumitomo Bank.

He died on August 12 1985, when the Japan Airlines Boeing 747 on which he was travelling crashed into a mountain north-west of Tokyo, killing 520 of the 524 people on board.

He was married to a Japanese woman but had been involved with the girls' mother, Susanne Bayly, 43, for almost 10 years when he was killed.

Ms Bayly had kept their romance secret to spare his family public disgrace but broke her silence last year for the sake of her daughters' education. Cassie, a pianist studying at the Royal College of Music, and Diana, who wants to be a concert violinist, lack funds to pay for their tuition.

Mr Yukawa's son and heir has refused to acknowledge his half-sisters and cut off all payments to Ms Bayly. But yesterday's declaration of their parentage by Mr Justice Singer at the high court in London means they can apply for a share of the father's estate. The girls' mother can also claim compensation for their upbringing from JAL, which had maintained that because the couple were not married it could do nothing until the paternity issue was decided.

"This was not just about money," Cassie Bayly said after the hearing. "I am filled with joy and happiness and feel so proud now that it has been acknowledged who I am."

"Japanese society found it very difficult to accept who I was. I felt it was important to go through the courts for my father. I still have memories of him. My sister was not born when he died, but now everyone knows who we are.

"Yes, we are illegitimate. But I remember the great love between our parents - the perfect love between them."

Miss Bayly and Mr Yukawa, more than 20 years her senior, met in London in 1979 when he was head of the bank's European operation and she was a ballet dancer. They fell in love, and two years later she gave up her career and moved to Tokyo, where she lived secretly in an apartment until his death, when she was about to give birth to Diana.

In the turmoil that followed, Ms Bayly signed away her and her daughters' rights to a share in Mr Yukawa's estate and any reparations from JAL in exchange for £340,000. The mother and daughters were ostracised by Mr Yukawa's family - with the exception of his mother, Takako, who secretly funded the girls' education until she died last year.

Before she died Takako told Ms Bayly that she had placed with a solicitor a written promise to carry on sending money to her family, but the letter has never been found.

In the light of the ruling by Mr Justice Singer, who was provided with DNA evidence of the girls' parentage, the family court in Tokyo will hold a mediation hearing on the case on Thursday.

"Now I have been officially recognised as [Mr Yukawa's] daughter, I just want the same inheritance as my two half-brothers," Cassie Bayly said yesterday. "It has never been in any doubt that Diana and I are his daughters; it has just been a way for them [her Japanese family] to increase the costs."

The case has had widespread coverage in Japan, especially after the family made a visit to the crash site last August, where Diana played the violin at a ceremony to mark the anniversary of the disaster.

Cassie said yesterday: "This was a huge experience for me. It was then I realised that it was very important that I had this document which shows who I am."

"Now I have been officially recognised as [Mr Yukawa's] daughter, I just want the same inheritance as my two half-brothers," Cassie Bayly said yesterday. "It has never been in any doubt that Diana and I are his daughters; it has just been a way for them [her Japanese family] to increase the costs." The case has had widespread coverage in Japan, especially after the family made a visit to the crash site last August, where Diana played the violin at a ceremony to mark the anniversary of the disaster. Cassie said yesterday: "This was a huge experience for me. It was then I realised that it was very important that I had this document which shows who I am."

webTitle: RAF reservist wins chance to regain bank job

fields.headline: RAF reservist wins chance to regain bank job
fields.trailText: An RAF reserve officer sacked by an international bank after serving during the Kosovo crisis yesterday won the first step in a legal battle which could safeguard the jobs of thousands of military service volunteers.
fields.body:
An RAF reserve officer sacked by an international bank after serving during the Kosovo crisis yesterday won the first step in a legal battle which could safeguard the jobs of thousands of military service volunteers.

Sebastian Nokes, a 34-year-old Old Etonian, successfully overturned claims by his former employers, Credit Suisse First Boston, that he was ineligible to apply for reinstatement or compensation under arcane and "relatively uncharted" legislation at an industrial tribunal in Stratford, east London.

But he must now wait until June to seek redress. In a separate action, he will also claim he was unfairly dismissed and suffered racial discrimination.

Yesterday the reinstatement committee panel at the tribunal heard that Mr Nokes, from Barbican, east London, joined CSFB in February 1998 and worked as vice-president of its strategic planning department, earning £70,000 plus bonuses each year.

But his career with the bank ended after the flight lieutenant with the Royal Auxiliary Air Force was called up on permanent service in April 1999.

Within three months he was informed he would be made redundant, and after finishing his military service in August he was sacked.

Yesterday Jeremy Johnson, for Mr Nokes, told the tribunal the bank had shown a "cynical disregard" for the reserve forces (safeguard of employment) act - the law to protect the jobs of reservists under which Mr Nokes is claiming reinstatement.

He added that there was "plainly a public interest" in ensuring such a law was upheld. "Membership these days is entirely voluntary and there's plainly a public interest in seeking volunteers to the reserve forces in ensuring the protection of their employment is effective," he said.

But Martin Palmer, for CSFB, told the hearing Mr Nokes's redundancy had nothing to do with his call-up service.

The bank will claim he was warned of the risk of being sacked before embarking on active service.

After the hearing Mr Nokes's solicitor, Julian Fidler, said he and his client were "encouraged" the panel committee's chairman, who had described the rarely-used act as "relatively uncharted waters", had ruled it was applicable.

"It's been found today the 1985 act does apply and the application was also made in time. The next stage will be to find out what liability there is and the quantum of damages," he said.

He said that Mr Nokes would pursue a claim of racial discrimination on the grounds that Swiss employees - who have to serve conscription in the national army - would not have been treated in this way.

The case was adjourned until June.

fields.headline: Student saved from arranged marriage
fields.trailText: A British-born Indian woman rescued by diplomats from an arranged marriage in India to a man she had never met was an "extreme example" of a practice common across much of Asia, foreign office officials said yesterday.
fields.body:
A British-born Indian woman rescued by diplomats from an arranged marriage in India to a man she had never met was an "extreme example" of a practice common across much of Asia, foreign office officials said yesterday.

The 21-year-old student was tricked by her parents into flying to the Punjab just before Christmas on the pretext of visiting her dying grandmother. She was imprisoned by her aunt's family while they sought a suitable groom for her.

Her British-born boyfriend, who was born in Gujarat, and of whom her parents disapproved, reported her missing when she failed to turn up to college. While her relatives in India confiscated her passport and moved her from village to village, a team from the British high commission in Delhi, together with the Indian police, mounted a search.

At the first village they came to they drew a blank. But three days later local detectives discovered her near the north Indian city of Chandigarh, trapped in a third floor room with only one exit. She was being watched over by several relatives, including her aunt, her aunt's husband, their son and his wife.

"When I found the girl at first she was weeping," Inspector Parmjit Singh of the Punjab police said yesterday. "She said she would not talk to anyone. Then Angela Slater [the first consul at the high commission] and the British party reassured her that they were genuine.

"We took her to the sub-divisional magistrate where she gave a statement saying she wanted to go with Mrs Slater and she did not want any criminal charges against her relatives or parents."

The woman, who has not been named, is now in the care of a women's group in Britain. A spokeswoman for the high commission in Delhi yesterday said that she was one of "a handful" of extreme cases every year, in which British-born women were forced into arranged marriages in India.

"This is not a daily occurrence. They often do not get to this stage. This poor girl was practically being held prisoner," she added. "It isn't just India. This is happening in lots of other south Asian countries. But it is relatively unusual for us to rescue someone like this."

Foreign office officials estimate that there are two cases of forced marriages a week across India, Pakistan and Bangladesh. Last week the foreign office minister Lady Scotland of Asthal announced she was setting up a team to work with Asian communities in Britain to try and halt the practice. Most cases in India take place in the states of Gujurat and Punjab, which have the strongest UK links.

Madhu Kishwar, who edits a Delhi-based women's rights journal, Manushi, yesterday said that young "expatriate" Indian women often under went more "subtle forms of pressure" than imprisonment to agree to an arranged marriage. "This level of coercion isn't very usual. The majority of mothers would emotionally pressure their daughters to marry within the community. It comes from a desire for communities to remain cohesive. Once inter-marriage starts then bonds loosen."

Following her release on February 3 the student, who had been taken to India by her father, told police she had not expected anyone to help her. She had grown resigned to the fact she was about to marry a young man she should have met later that day, "and that would be her life".

Inspector Singh said: "She was wearing a salwar kameez, and although there were no signs that she had been hurt, she said her passport had been taken away and she had been kept under close watch. The wedding was probably to have taken place in a month or so. She said: "I love my parents, but I can't believe they would do such a thing."

The high commission in Delhi yesterday said it was only able to act in the cases of British passport holders when there was clear information as to where women had been taken. When dual nationals are involved, foreign office staff are often powerless to intervene because countries like Bangladesh and Pakistan do not recognise the individuals as British, even if that is how they see themselves.

fields.headline: Hero award for joyrider campaigner
fields.trailText: "I'm not Arnold Schwarzenegger", said Janet McAlister, 62, of Coventry, "but I've always believed in fighting for what is yours."
fields.body:
"I'm not Arnold Schwarzenegger", said Janet McAlister, 62, of Coventry, "but I've always believed in fighting for what is yours."

She was one of seven people presented with gold hero awards for gallantry and endurance at the fifth yearly awards of the Association of Retired and Persons over 50 at a London hotel yesterday.

Ms McAlister, a widow and mother of seven, was honoured for confronting vandals and joyriders. When she began her campaign, police had been called to Mulliner Street, Coventry, 260 times in six months. Every night she left a water bucket under her letter box in case of a revenge fire bomb attack.

The other awards went to:

 Joe Smith, 65, of Deal, Kent, who last September became the oldest Briton to swim the Channel;

 John Harmer, 69, from Cheltenham, who dived into the flooded river Chelt and saved Sue Colling whose car was being swept along;

 Paul Stableforth, 65, from Gower, Glamorgan, a retired surgeon and non-swimmer, who helped save an injured fellow yacht race competitor;

 Barry Sessions, 52, an oyster fisherman from Lustleigh, Devon, who rescued Turkish earthquake survivors;

 Shirley McKiernon, 63, a tour manager, of Bledlow Ridge, Buckinghamshire, who helped holidaymakers on a sinking cruise ship;

 Brian Jones, 52, of Erlestoke, Wiltshire, who with Bertrand Piccard became the first to navigate the globe in a balloon in March last year. John Ezard
