webTitle: Hall rescue a culture shock for Cornwall

fields.headline: Hall rescue a culture shock for Cornwall
fields.standfirst: Arts council's £200,000 aid for flagship venue in impoverished county inflames passions as co-founder and general manager are forced out
fields.trailText: It was supposed to be the answer to the cultural barrenness of Cornwall: a venue that, for the first time, would lure national orchestras and dance and theatre companies to one of Britain's poorest counties, and encourage local arts to flourish.
fields.body:
It was supposed to be the answer to the cultural barrenness of Cornwall: a venue that, for the first time, would lure national orchestras and dance and theatre companies to one of Britain's poorest counties, and encourage local arts to flourish.

But barely two years after its opening, the Hall for Cornwall, a £6m venture which boasts the Prince of Wales as its patron, risks abandoning its ideals and selling-out in a final attempt to avoid bankruptcy.

This week the arts council announced a £200,000 rescue package for the county's cultural flagship, but only on condition its artistic director - one of the men behind its conception - and general manager get the boot in a cost-cutting exercise.

The redundancies have inflamed passions among Cornwall's vibrant artistic community, with the dismissal of Chris Warner, who co-founded the trust behind the scheme 13 years ago, and Tim German, a former Welsh National Opera singer widely credited with expanding its education programme, being seen as scapegoating by a London-based quango ignorant of the problems of a fiercely independent but impoverished county.

Mr Warner has been gagged from speaking to the press by the threat of losing his redundancy payment, but describes feeling "shock, outrage and now anger". "He feels as if he's been run over," added his partner, Beverly Skiltern.

Mr German, the general manager, who is considering seeking legal advice, is still bemused by a sacking which, the trust's chairman Dennis Arbon has publicly insisted, bore no relation to their capabilities. "We've been told we've done nothing wrong," he added. "We haven't been given a reason for why this has happened beyond that the arts council has demanded it. We've just been made scapegoats."

The arts council, which as part of its rescue package negotiated with local author-ities and the regional arts board, south west arts, is demanding a single director combining both roles be appointed.

The hall, which has been haemorrhaging up to £300,000 a year since its November 1997 opening, is in no position to be sentimental about the sackings, it insists.

"Obviously we regret anyone needs to be made redundant in this process, but this goes beyond personalities," said its spokeswoman Caroline Leech. "It's about the survival of a good venue in the national jigsaw and we have to look at the best way in which this can happen."

The suggestion is that, while both men had the artistic vision demanded to ensure an eclectic range of nationally-acclaimed performers - from the violinist Tamsin Little and English National Opera to the Royal Ballet, Van Morrison and Lenny Henry - attended the converted grade two-listed Victorian building in Truro, they lacked the business acumen to see it flourish.

"Like so many businesses, you have different phases and different requirements," said Mr Arbon, himself a retired businessman. "Chris Warner and Tim German have superb artistic capabilities but the arts council required the skills and abilities of someone very different."

The hall's immense financial difficulties - a £250,000 contingency fund was eradicated once conversion costs spiralled by £750,000 over budget - cannot be laid at the men's door.

The hall had tried to do something no other non-commercial arts venue in Britain had achieved: break even without looking to the local authorities or arts council for revenue funding.

"We realised that's impossible," admitted Mr German, who said similar-sized venues were subsidised to the tune of £500,000 a year.

In addition, it was crippled by problems posed by Cornwall: with one in four unemployed out of season and the average salary 25% below the national average, ticket prices could never be high; with less than 500,000 people in the whole county runs have been short, leading to increased costs for constructing and breaking down sets; and with a poor transport infrastructure, the venue could not recoup much from the bar.

The concern of Chris Warner and Tim German and their supporters is that the hall's seemingly-insurmountable financial difficulties will mean it has to compromise. Gone will be the support for community projects such as the amateur Duchy Opera, and in its place will be an insistence on drawing in more mainstream names. "Our fear is that people will take over who've never understood what it was about and it will become just another commercial venture," said Beverly Skilton.

The sentiment may appear a little precious, but with one in seven of Cornwall's inhabitants visiting it, and 1.5m tickets being sold each year, it seems the demand to fill its 980-seat auditorium is strong.

"It must not become the same as any high street theatre in London, Manchester, Bath or Brighton," said Mr Warner. "London must realise that Cornwall has different needs from the big cities across Britain. I'm concerned that this is a decision made with little appreciation of the needs of such an individual part of Britain."

webTitle: BBC newsroom protester to be held under mental health act

fields.headline: BBC newsroom protester to be held under mental health act
fields.trailText: A media studies student who rampaged through BBC TV's west London newsroom in an apparent protest over television licence charges was yesterday ordered to be detained indefinitely in a mental hospital.
fields.body:
A media studies student who rampaged through BBC TV's west London newsroom in an apparent protest over television licence charges was yesterday ordered to be detained indefinitely in a mental hospital.

At one point Nigel Flack got within feet of newsreader Anna Ford as he threatened to take the station off the air and kill anyone who tried to stop him.

Flack, 21, who later admitted planning to "have it out" with new BBC director general Greg Dyke, was finally overpowered by staff.

But before he was subdued he caused damage running into thousands of pounds at the Television Centre at Shepherds Bush, west London, Middlesex Guildhall crown court was told.

A security officer and a cameraman who tried to overpower him were slightly injured.

Flack, of Camberley, Surrey, admitted one count of affray and two of common assault last September.

Judge Simon Smith told the Middlesex university student that he was clearly mentally ill and needed treatment.

After "careful consideration" he and the two magistrates sitting with him had decided that an order needed to be made under the mental health act allowing him to be detained "without limit of time".

Flack not only had little insight into his condition but there was a real risk he would not continue with his medication if left unsupervised.

The court heard that despite tighter security imposed at the Television Centre after the murder of presenter Jill Dando outside her home in Fulham, west London, Flack was able to force his way through electronically controlled turnstiles and run up to the second floor.

There he picked up a coffee table and hurled it through a floor-to-ceiling plate glass window leading to the "secure" news centre. He climbed through and went on the rampage, shouting and threatening staff," said Richard Burrington, prosecuting.

"Flack then picked up two TV monitors and threw them to the floor, breaking them, before picking up a chair and trying to throw it through another window leading to the newsroom's nerve centre control," Mr Burrington added.

fields.headline: Custody for boy, 14, with 73 offences
fields.trailText: A boy aged 14 who twice broke an anti-social behaviour order was ordered yesterday to serve six months in a secure unit.
fields.body:
A boy aged 14 who twice broke an anti-social behaviour order was ordered yesterday to serve six months in a secure unit.

Magistrates at Nottingham youth court had made an order allowing Decland Madigan to be identified in media reports, saying it was in the public interest to name him in an "exceptional case".

Madigan was given a 12 month secure training order, six months of which will be spent under supervision at home, after he pleaded guilty to 14 offences. He was banned from driving for two years.

He now has a record of 73 offences, most vehicle-related. Yesterday, as part of the 12 month order, he was given three months for stealing £850 in cash and vouchers from a Nottingham store.

The court heard that in January he breached the anti-social order when he stole a Ford Escort XR3. During a chase he crashed into a police patrol car and fled.

Officers found that Madigan, 4ft 11in tall, had used a "booster" seat to help him to see over the steering wheel.

He will spend only three months at the secure unit near Rugby, Warwickshire, having already spent three months in custody.

His solicitor, Andy Siddall, asked the court to impose a supervision order rather than lock his client up, saying he was a "troubled young man" who had seen the error of his ways. His father, Tony Madigan, told magistrates: "His family didn't make him like this." He said his son had first been suspended from school when he was eight, but blamed the authorities for letting him down.

After the hearing, Graham Chapman, Nottingham city council leader, said: "I am pleased he is being put away, but the custody of three months isn't enough to turn him around."

webTitle: Wealth of Asians:  High earners make their mark

fields.headline: Wealth of Asians:  High earners make their mark
fields.trailText: Britain's richest 200 Asians increased their combined wealth by 40% over the last year, with expansions in the internet, food, oil and steel.
fields.body:
Britain's richest 200 Asians increased their combined wealth by 40% over the last year, with expansions in the internet, food, oil and steel.

Compiled by the newspaper Eastern Eye, and to be published on Friday, the list shows that the combined wealth of the 200 is £10.6bn, of which the top 10 control £6.2bn.

The wealthiest is Lakshmi Mittal, whose company Ispat International is the sixth largest steel manufacturer in the world. He returns to number one after losing it to the Hinduja brothers last year; 1999 saw an upturn in profits taking Mr Mittal's combined earnings to £2.2bn.

Sri and Gopi Hinduja, whose company has interests in finance, oil, industry and telecoms, are second this year, valued at £1.95bn.

This year's highest climber is Dinesh Dhamija, owner of Flightbookers travel agency, who added £195m to his net worth, having increased his wealth exponentially by setting up e-bookers in 1998.

There are 47 new entries, together worth £785.5m. Six are internet entrepreneurs with a combined wealth of £50m. They include Serena Doshi of Liv4Now, Mark Kotecha of Net Interlink, and Amir Ahmed of Ocean Home Shopping.

The youngest entry is Kashif Ahmed Ahmed, who at 25 runs the Laundry clothing label and is part of the Joe Bloggs label.

Fashion was one of the highest earning sectors at £840m with high street names such as New Look, Bay Trading and Ciro Citterio. Food brought in more at £945.8m with companies such as Tilda Rice, Noon Products and Pataks Spices.

Some 154 of the 200 live in the south-east or London, 24 in the north-west, 14 in the West Midlands, and 11 in Scotland. The four oldest are each aged 71, and there are six under 30.

Sarwar Ahmed, publisher of the list, said yesterday: "We started this four years ago and it's fascinating to see the growth of Asian wealth in the UK .

"It's also interesting to note that there is a definite broadening of the industries that Asians are investing in, although the stronghold remains in food, fashion and retailing. However, we are seeing the community diversify into finance, media, pharmaceuticals and IT."

fields.headline: Stalking horse may challenge Trimble
fields.standfirst:
Arch critic ready to stand for party leadership

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: David Trimble is increasingly likely to face a challenge to his leadership of the Ulster Unionist party this month from one of his most vociferous critics.
fields.body:
David Trimble is increasingly likely to face a challenge to his leadership of the Ulster Unionist party this month from one of his most vociferous critics.

Jonathan Bell, a councillor in Craigavon, in Mr Trimble's Upper Bann constituency, confirmed yesterday that he was considering standing as a stalking horse challenger. He is opposed to the Good Friday agreement and the proposed reforms of the RUC.

The 860-strong Ulster Unionist council holds its annual general meeting on March 25. It must re-elect the party leader every year.

Mr Bell, a social worker, was one of the organisers of last year's "long march" across Northern Ireland in support of the victims of the troubles. It was seen as a hardline unionist event.

Willie Thompson, MP for West Tyrone, supported a challenge. He believed it would keep Mr Trimble on his toes.

Mr Bell, who suggested he could win 30% of the vote, said: "Trimble promised he would secure the future of the police force and disarm the terrorists.

"His leadership has led us to a place where the terrorists are re-armed and the police force is disbanded."

Several one-time Trimble supporters want him ousted. But Trimble loyalists believe any leadership challenge now would be pointless.

They point out there is no obvious successor, and say he kept his promises in securing the suspension of devolution last month because there had been no start to IRA decommissioning.

They regard Mr Bell as an opportunist who loves the limelight. He resigned the party whip on Craigavon borough council because his colleagues refused to put him forward for mayor last June.

He threatened to quit the party last November if the power-sharing executive was set up before the IRA began to decommission arms. But he changed his mind after devolution.

Mark Neale, another Ulster Unionist councillor in Craigavon, said: "Why try and wing the leader now? He has done everything he said he would. There is no sensible alternative leader or strategy. It seems madness."

Any challenge appears doomed to failure. There seem to be few parallels with the last stalking horse challenge, which evenutally paved the way for Mr Trimble to succeed Jim, now Lord, Molyneaux.

Lee Reynolds, a 21-year-old Queen's university student from Coleraine, Co Londonderry, secured 15% of the vote in 1995.

Mr Molyneaux resigned five months later, on his 75th birthday. But he had been leader for more than 15 years and there were several Westminster colleagues vying to take over.

There is now no obvious successor to Mr Trimble, the youngest of the party's 10 MPs, apart from Jeffrey Donaldson, Lord Molyneaux's successor as MP for Lagan Valley. He is firmly ruling out any challenge.

webTitle: Teenager stabbed to death lover who beat her

fields.headline: Teenager stabbed to death lover who beat her
fields.trailText: A teenage woman yesterday admitted the manslaughter of her boyfriend, whose body parts were found strewn across East Sussex.
fields.body:
A teenage woman yesterday admitted the manslaughter of her boyfriend, whose body parts were found strewn across East Sussex.

Julia Adamson, 18, pleaded guilty at Lewes crown court to stabbing Robert Kavanagh, 31, through the heart with a seven inch carving knife in June last year.

After the killing Mr Kavanagh's body was stored in a freezer before being cut up in a desperate attempt to conceal the crime. It took three weeks before his head, his arms and his legs were found near Bexhill, East Sussex, after a dog was seen by its owner chewing on the hand.

It took another five months for his torso to be recovered. Adamson pleaded guilty to manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility after the court heard that Mr Kavanagh had repeatedly beaten her.

One attack was so severe that she had to use crutches. Adamson had won a restraining order against her older lover but had then allowed him to stay with her again. The two had started their relationship when Adamson was 16. Three psychiatrists who examined her concluded that she was suffering from anxiety and depression when she stabbed Mr Kavanagh.

In the weeks leading to his death, Adamson told friends how she poured bleach in his eyes and attempted to suffocate him with a pillow in an attempt to get rid of him.

Christopher Kinch, prosecuting, told the court that Adamson, then aged 17, killed Mr Kavanagh while he slept and then told friends: "I've finally done it. I've stabbed him."

He added: "Matters built to a tragic climax in which she stabbed him through the chest and heart."

After the killing Mr Kavanagh's body was dragged from the bedroom into a cupboard, where it stayed for two days. Two men were seen carrying a bloodstained mattress and bed from the house.

Two men have been arrested and charged with attempting to pervert the course of justice. They cannot be identified for legal reasons. Adamson then tried to get friends to help her dispose of the body.

One tipped off the police who found her trying to clean up the flat to destroy evidence of the crime, but officers could not find the body.

Within a month a terrier dog unearthed the first part of Mr Kavanagh's remains near Bexhill after being taken for a walk by its owner.

On December 23 a council worker operating a digger near Hailsham, East Sussex, unearthed Mr Kavanagh's torso. A postmortem showed that he had died from a stab wound to his heart.

The postmortem also showed that his body must have been stored in a freezer before being dumped. Police said a mechanical saw had been used with "some skill" to dismember the corpse.

After yesterday's hearing, Detective Superintendent David Gaylor of Sussex police announced a £2,000 reward for information leading to the prosecution of those responsible for cutting up and disposing of Mr Kavanagh's body.

Mr Gaylor said both Adamson and Mr Kavanagh had used amphetamines and cannabis and added: "She was mentally ill and it affected the balance of her mind. She was mentally ill because of the drugs and abuse she suffered at his hands.

"It's not an excuse, its a factor to be taken into account. The killing was pre-meditated and she had other options."

Adamson will be sentenced next month.

fields.headline: Scientists 'must talk to public'
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Scientists need to open a dialogue with the public that is "direct, open and timely", according to a report from the Lords select committee on sci ence and technology yesterday. Public trust, shaken by BSE and GM foods, could only be restored by a substantial change in science and in scientific policy-making.
fields.body:
Scientists need to open a dialogue with the public that is "direct, open and timely", according to a report from the Lords select committee on sci ence and technology yesterday. Public trust, shaken by BSE and GM foods, could only be restored by a substantial change in science and in scientific policy-making.

Lord Jenkin of Roding, the committee's chairman, said it was a paradox that this crisis of trust should come at a time when the public was finding science, engineering and technology more interesting and exciting than ever.

"But the evidence of mistrust is undeniable, and must be of deep concern. "

There remained a culture of governmental and institutional secrecy that invited suspicion; the public tended to question all authority, including scientific authority; and some issues treated by decision makers as scientific involved many other factors which provoked negative attitudes to science, the committee argued.

It urged the government to back the Royal Society's committee for the public understanding of science (and perhaps think of a less patronising name for it), train scientists in communicating' encourage scientists to share their work with the public, and fund initiatives to improve women's understanding of science.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Cancer patients' 10-month wait
fields.body:
Cancer patients' 10-month wait

Cancer patients in Britain, which has some of the worst cancer survival rates in Europe, can wait from three to 10 months for surgery, researchers said yesterday. A survey of 13,454 cancer patients in 223 hospitals in October 1997 by a Birmingham university team showed waiting times depended on type of cancer and urgency of treatment.

Porpoise heads for Commons

London aquarium staff were called to the Thames by tourists yesterday to identify a sea creature jumping out of the water. It turned out to be a porpoise - the first recorded as far upstream as Westminster Bridge and the House of Commons.

Cherie Blair drops action

Cherie Blair has dropped her legal action against Jonathan Harris, the literary agent involved in the row over the publication of a nanny's account of life in Downing Street. Last week she dropped her claim for damages against her family's former nanny, Ros Mark, whose account appeared in a Sunday paper.

Book returned 60 years late

A library book borrowed by a schoolboy was returned more than 60 years late. The HG Wells title, The Bulpington Of Blup, was taken out by Ivor Hockman from Clapton library in September 1939, days before he was evacuated from London. He found it among some old possessions and returned it with a cheque for £13.25 - one old penny for each week overdue.

Trouser woman agrees payout

The woman who won her claim for sexual discrimination against the Professional Golfers' Association after being sent home to change her trousers for a skirt has agreed compensation in an out of court settlement , it was announced yesterday. Judy Owen, 39, from Solihull, West Midlands, had been expected to win tens of thousands of pounds after her victory at a Birmingham employment tribunal earlier this year.

fields.headline: Witnesses in bloodless kidney swap
fields.trailText: A Jehovah's Witness couple forbidden by their religion to receive blood transfusions were recovering in hospital yesterday after undergoing   "bloodless" kidney transplant procedures.
fields.body:
A Jehovah's Witness couple forbidden by their religion to receive blood transfusions were recovering in hospital yesterday after undergoing "bloodless" kidney transplant procedures.

Marie Hoyle, of Bradford, West Yorkshire, donated a kidney to her husband, Alf, 51, after he had waited nine years for a donor organ. The operation was the first of its kind in Britain to involve Jehovah's Witnesses.

The procedures, performed at St James's hospital, Leeds, on Friday, were said to be a success, with both patients expected to leave hospital within a week.

The "bloodless" technique relies on a salt solution which increases blood volume during surgery to allow for small losses. Precision instruments are used to lessen the chance of severed arteries, and any blood spilled is cleaned and recycled. Bloodless surgery is a recognised alternative for Jehovah's Witnesses, who cite at least 400 biblical references prohibiting them from receiving blood.

The couple, who have been married for 30 years and have two children, decided to undergo the surgery after Mr Hoyle had been on dialysis three times a week for nine years. He said: "I can't express what a loving thing, what a tremendous thing my wife has done in giving me a kidney."

webTitle: HIV manager sacked after food store feared sales would suffer

fields.headline: HIV manager sacked after food store feared sales would suffer
fields.trailText: A supermarket manager diagnosed with HIV lost his £34,000 a year job because the company claimed his illness might put off customers.
fields.body:
A supermarket manager diagnosed with HIV lost his £34,000 a year job because the company claimed his illness might put off customers.

Mark Hedley, 34, is to sue the German-owned Aldi chain after he was barred from returning to the Seaham store in County Durham.

The manager, who had previously been praised as a good manager by his superiors, was told to stay away when he tried to go back after treatment.

Mr Hedley, from Gateshead, Tyne and Wear, has launched a legal battle with the backing of disability campaigners.

Evidence lodged by Aldi ahead of an employment tribunal due to start on April 10 showed it feared he would have a negative impact on business. Defending the ban, Aldi cited "genuine and understandable concerns that if the applicant remained in situ sales at the store would suffer".

The company also claims some staff would be "uncomfortable" working with him when it put him on paid "gardening leave" last June.

Mr Hedley is claiming direct discrimination against him because of his disability and, following last year's landmark European victory by gay service personnel booted out of the armed forces, sex discrimination.

Mr Hedley, who worked for Aldi's for four years, disputes Aldi's claim that staff were unhappy about working with him. "Aldi's used my shop as an example of how to run a store, how it looked and that," said Mr Hedley. "The staff knew I was gay and I've spoken to most of them and they have no problem with me being HIV."

Mr Hedley's solicitor, Stefan Cross, said: "I'm shocked this conduct still exists in the 21st century. The employer is trying to justify what it is doing."

Aldi, which has opened 250 stores in Britain since 1990, failed to comment yesterday.

webTitle: Man with rare tropical fever critically ill in isolation hospital

fields.headline: Man with rare tropical fever critically ill in isolation hospital
fields.trailText: A British man was fighting for his life yesterday in a sealed tent in the high security unit of a London hospital after contracting the highly infectious tropical disease Lassa fever.
fields.body:
A British man was fighting for his life yesterday in a sealed tent in the high security unit of a London hospital after contracting the highly infectious tropical disease Lassa fever.

The virus is extremely rare in Britain, with only 12 cases imported into Europe and North America since 1970. Extreme precautions have to be taken because the disease is so infectious, and kills 20% of sufferers.

The patient, who has not been named, is an aid worker in his early 50s from Kent. He fell ill in Sierra Leone, West Africa, where he has been working on a contract for Britain's department for international development, helping former soldiers to disarm, learn new skills and reintegrate into civilian life after the civil war.

He was flown to the capital, Freetown, from the rural area where he had been working when he became unwell. On Monday, when his condition had not improved, he was evacuated by air ambulance and taken to the Tropical Diseases hospital in north-west London.

Doctors at first suspected malaria or typhoid but tests confirmed Lassa fever. The patient was put in the high security isolation facilities of Coppetts Wood hospital in Muswell Hill, north London.

After his transfer it was thought his condition was improving, but his lungs began failing on Sunday. Last night he was unconscious and being ventilated in the transparent tent. Air is pumped in and taken out through filters. Doctors and nurses have to don special suits before treating him.

William Weir, the consultant in infectious and tropical disease who is treating the man, said: "He is critically ill. I spoke to his wife yesterday, and she is understandably upset.

"In situations like this we have to be completely truthful with relatives and tell them exactly what the patient's future contains."

About 5,000 people in West Africa die from Lassa fever every year. Victims suffer a high fever, headaches, diarrhoea, brain inflammation, nausea and internal bleeding. Anti-viral drugs can reduce the symptoms, but there is little doctors can do if the patient's body cannot fight off the disease.

Dr Weir said: "The effectiveness of the drugs began to declare themselves on Saturday, when it became apparent that the patient's haemorrhagic tendencies have improved.

"Clinically he did seem to be better, but unfortunately on Sunday he developed complications in relation to his breathing."

Infection control specialists are monitoring the 90 or so hospital staff who have come into contact with the patient since he arrived in Britain.

It was emphasised that the public was not at risk because the virus was spread only through contact with bodily fluids. There have been no reported incidents of human-to-human transmission in Europe.

The man is employed by Crown Agents for Overseas Governments and Administration, a private company working on the government contract. He had been in Sierra Leone since last October. He returned home for Christmas and went back at the end of January.

He fell ill in Sierra Leone, West Africa, where he has been working on a contract for Britain's department for international development, helping former soldiers to disarm, learn new skills and reintegrate into civilian life after the civil war. He was flown to the capital, Freetown, from the rural area where he had been working when he became unwell. On Monday, when his condition had not improved, he was evacuated by air ambulance and taken to the Tropical Diseases hospital in north-west London. Doctors at first suspected malaria or typhoid but tests confirmed Lassa fever. The patient was put in the high security isolation facilities of Coppetts Wood hospital in Muswell Hill, north London. After his transfer it was thought his condition was improving, but his lungs began failing on Sunday. Last night he was unconscious and being ventilated in the transparent tent. Air is pumped in and taken out through filters. Doctors and nurses have to don special suits before treating him. William Weir, the consultant in infectious and tropical disease who is treating the man, said: "He is critically ill. I spoke to his wife yesterday, and she is understandably upset. "In situations like this we have to be completely truthful with relatives and tell them exactly what the patient's future contains." About 5,000 people in West Africa die from Lassa fever every year. Victims suffer a high fever, headaches, diarrhoea, brain inflammation, nausea and internal bleeding. Anti-viral drugs can reduce the symptoms, but there is little doctors can do if the patient's body cannot fight off the disease. Dr Weir said: "The effectiveness of the drugs began to declare themselves on Saturday, when it became apparent that the patient's haemorrhagic tendencies have improved. "Clinically he did seem to be better, but unfortunately on Sunday he developed complications in relation to his breathing." Infection control specialists are monitoring the 90 or so hospital staff who have come into contact with the patient since he arrived in Britain. It was emphasised that the public was not at risk because the virus was spread only through contact with bodily fluids. There have been no reported incidents of human-to-human transmission in Europe. The man is employed by Crown Agents for Overseas Governments and Administration, a private company working on the government contract. He had been in Sierra Leone since last October. He returned home for Christmas and went back at the end of January.

webTitle: Musician dies in fall from college window

fields.headline: Musician dies in fall from college window
fields.trailText: A 20-year-old musician who had been visiting an old school friend at an Oxford college died after plunging 40ft from a window.
fields.body:
A 20-year-old musician who had been visiting an old school friend at an Oxford college died after plunging 40ft from a window.

James Ferrada sustained serious head injuries in the fall at Balliol college at about 10pm on Sunday night. He died at the city's John Radcliffe hospital.

Mr Ferrada had been visiting a school friend, Archie Campbell, 20, an experimental psychology student at Balliol. The two men had been drinking in the college bar and "larking about" that evening, according to people at the college.

They had been friends since they were 14-year-old pupils at the City of London Freeman's school in Ashtead, Surrey.

Mr Ferrada had hoped to become a composer. After studying at Coventry university and then at Bretton Hall, in Wakefield, West Yorkshire, for a term, he dropped out early last year to write music.

He had lived in a flat in Brighton for a time but had recently moved back to the family home in Oxshott.

Mr Ferrada's former headteacher, David Haywood, said he was "a popular all-rounder, brilliant at games, academically bright and a very good musician. He was an extremely popular boy."

His father, Salvador Ferrada, said last night that he did not believe his son was the victim of foul play. "We still don't really know what happened to our son.

"My wife and I are totally devastated by this. We have had a very hard day and it will take us a very long time to get over it. James was a lovely boy and he has gone to a much better place."

"James was one of those young men who wanted to find his own direction and if he found various courses were not to his liking then he moved on to something else," Mr Ferrada said.

Detectives yesterday interviewed staff at Balliol college and other students. A 20-year-old man was arrested and interviewed at St Aldate's police station but later released without charge.

Though inquiries were continuing, police sources said they were unlikely to charge anyone in connection with Mr Ferrada's death.

In February, 21-year-old metallurgy and materials science student, Kai Dawson, fell to his death from a tower crane in east Oxford.

webTitle: Arthur Daley of politics takes £100,000 stake in the used car business

fields.headline: Arthur Daley of politics takes £100,000 stake in the used car business
fields.trailText: Would you buy a used car from Jeffrey Archer? The Arthur Daley of politics has branched out into second-hand motors.
fields.body:
Would you buy a used car from Jeffrey Archer? The Arthur Daley of politics has branched out into second-hand motors.

The disgraced Lord Archer, kicked out of the Tories for lying, is backing a firm that tracks down models for drivers on the internet. The peer has invested £100,000 in Bournemouth-based One Stop Car Shop which hopes to open 25 stores over the next three years.

The managing director, Hugo Mackenzie Smith, attempted to play down the novelist's involvement as he admitted they were grateful for his money. "He's a totally passive shareholder," he said. "He has the midas touch, everyone agrees that, and we're very honoured that someone with his business acumen has chosen to invest in One Stop Car Shop."

The company started trading last year after raising £2m.

Details of Archer's investment emerged as the writer, under police investigation after persuading a friend to lie in a libel trial, is attempting a public comeback. He has written a court play in which he will star with the audience judging him at the end of every performance, and has resumed charity auctioneering.

The £100,000 car investment is one-fifth of the £500,000 the Daily Star is seeking to recover after it lost a libel case over the allegation that Archer slept with prostitute Monica Coghlan.

Mr Mackenzie Smith said his company would avoid the "usual motor industry stuff", including dodgy salesmen who call every old banger a good runner with one careful owner.

Lord Archer's involvement sparked a series of Arthur Daley-type jibes last night at his expense.

Sir Ken Jackson, head of the AEEU engineering union that represents car workers, said: "Archer might be called the Arthur Daley of politics but I bet Arthur Daley would never want to be branded the Jeffrey Archer of car sales."

webTitle: Proof that knowledge is good for the brain

fields.headline: Proof that knowledge is good for the brain
fields.trailText: They have The Knowledge by name, and the knowledge by nature. London taxi drivers - that rare breed who can scoot down an obscure sideroad, perform a three-point turn on a postage stamp and recite the complete works of Richard Littlejohn all at the same time -are today revealed by scientists to have bigger brains.
fields.body:
They have The Knowledge by name, and the knowledge by nature. London taxi drivers - that rare breed who can scoot down an obscure sideroad, perform a three-point turn on a postage stamp and recite the complete works of Richard Littlejohn all at the same time -are today revealed by scientists to have bigger brains.

London researchers report today in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, a prestigious US journal, that they scanned the brains of 16 right-handed London cabbies and found that in all cases, the size of a region of the brain called the hippocampus was millimetres larger than in a comparable group of 50 ordinary right-handed men who did not drive taxis.

The hippocampus is closely associated with spatial memory - where the brain keeps its maps. London taxi drivers, famous for knowing routes between thousands of places in the city, spend two years assembling a detailed map which they file away in the memory.

"The hippocampus is where we store the things we consciously remember," said Eleanor Maguire, of the institute of neurology at University College, London.

"As part of that, we would include navigation. We know in animals that navigation and the hippocampus are intimately linked. So, it would seem now, is the human hippocampus."

Tests with rats, squirrels and birds had shown that if the hippocampus is damaged, the creature can no longer find its way around.

Ordinary mortals, too, have shown that they use the hippocampus to find their way around. But the brains of London taxi drivers grew to ac commodate the gazetteer of a whole city. The better they knew their way around, the bigger the hippocampus.

"They are an excellent group of people to study," Dr Maguire said. "They have already acquired a vast amount of spatial information. It's the kind of study you can only do in this city, because taxi drivers elsewhere aren't licensed in the same way."

The researchers had previously placed volunteer drivers in scanners, quizzed them on the best routes around London, and watched the brain fire up. This time, they simply invited them to lie back - silently - and have their grey matter measured by two different techniques.

"What we did was look at the amount of time spent as a taxi driver and then looked at a brain scan," said Dr Maguire.

"We found a significant correlation, in that the posterior of the back part of the hippocampus increased in size. The longer you were a taxi driver the bigger it got."

fields.headline: Blair's spokesman drops anonymity
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The Downing St press secretary, Alastair Campbell, finally agreed yesterday to media demands that he should be identifiable by name when speaking on behalf of the prime minister.
fields.body:
The Downing St press secretary, Alastair Campbell, finally agreed yesterday to media demands that he should be identifiable by name when speaking on behalf of the prime minister.

Faced with complaints from press, radio and TV reporters about his unilateral decision to cooperate with Michael Cockerell for a BBC TV documentary, Mr Campbell reluctantly conceded the anonymity which routinely presents him as "the prime minister's official spokesman."

"I don't think it adds up to a row of beans. I speak as the prime minister's spokesman. We are a parliamentary democracy and the government is accountable to parliament," he told reporters at his daily 11am briefing in the basement of No 10.

Tension has been growing again between ministers and the media over what Tony Blair last week criticised in Scotland as a negative media culture. "Scepticism is healthy, cynicism is corrosive," Mr Campbell said yesterday - speaking on message.

But his decision to let Mr Cockerell, a distinguished maker of political profiles who recently made two programmes about Mr Blair's first 1,000 days, offended fellow TV journalists. They have wanted to film briefings for many years to enhance the use of pictures for TV news reports and sound feed for radio.

Print journalists have been more wary, fearing that essentially informal sessions will turn into a three-ringed circus as both sides grandstand for the benefit of cameras - in the manner of a White House press conference. But spokesmen in other EU capitals are seen on TV. Mr Campbell, former political editor of the Daily Mirror, placed his twice-daily briefings on the record when he became Downing St spokesman in 1997, but - on advice from Whitehall officials - said he did not wish to be identified by name.

He already enjoyed a high profile as a prominent Blair aide. Anonymity has not diminished it since 1997 and Mr Campbell is the object of criticism, sometimes tinged with jealousy, as an over-mighty official who is not elected. MPs and even ministers complain about his access to Mr Blair, at his side for much of the day.

This week reporters felt they had been bounced by a unilateral decision to admit Mr Cockerell, thought to be part of Downing St's efforts to tame an unruly - in their terms "irresponsible" - media.

The end of a long-running battle between the traditional "non-attributable" secrecy which surrounded relations between Downing St and parliamentary lobby journalists at Westminster thus came yesterday, not with a bang but a whimper.

In the 1980s several newspapers - including the Guardian - which felt that Lady Thatcher's spokesman, now Sir Bernard Ingham, had over-stepped his civil servant's role, boycotted the lobby briefing system for five years.

John Major's spokesman, Gus O'Donnell, conceded that briefings could be attributed to Downing St or the prime minister's office.

The boycott ended on those terms, which Mr Campbell has since enlarged. Newspapers, including the Guardian had increasingly begun to identify him in such controveries where he has played a crucial role - for instance the writ against the Blair nanny's book.

webTitle: Hague insists on tax guarantee in Portillo rebuff

fields.headline: Hague insists on tax guarantee in Portillo rebuff
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague will today assert his authority over Michael Portillo when he reaffirms his commitment to the Tories' contentious "tax guarantee" which was recently challenged by the ambitious shadow chancellor.
fields.body:
William Hague will today assert his authority over Michael Portillo when he reaffirms his commitment to the Tories' contentious "tax guarantee" which was recently challenged by the ambitious shadow chancellor.

In an unashamedly Thatcherite speech, the Tory leader will argue that lower taxes create a more compassionate society by encouraging people to donate more money to charity.

"We will commit ourselves to a guaranteed reduction in the tax burden," Mr Hague will tell the right-wing think tank Politeia. "We must show that it is our Conservative low tax agenda that is not just the basis of a dynamic economy but also the foundation of a moral, compassionate, free and just society."

Tory sources said last night that Mr Hague's speech was designed to show that he was standing by his "tax guarantee" to reduce the overall tax burden as a share of Britain's GDP. The sources said that Mr Portillo fully endorsed Mr Hague's speech.

However, Mr Hague's decision to develop the arguments in favour of low taxes will be seen as a rebuff to Mr Portillo who failed to endorse the "tax guarantee" in a radio interview last month. Just days after abandoning the Tories' oppoosition to Bank of England independence and the minimum wage, Mr Portillo would only say that he was "happy to discuss" that when asked about the guarantee.

Mr Hague believes that he is on strong ground in the light of mounting evidence that the tax burden has increased under Labour, despite the government's denials. In a report over the weekend, PricewaterhouseCoopers said that the chancellor has increased the total tax burden as a proportion of GDP by 2.4% , which works out at around £23bn.

In his speech today, Mr Hague will dismiss the government's claims that his "tax guarantee" would lead to cuts in frontline public services. He will confirm that spending on health and education under a Tory government would be ring-fenced and he will point out that the Tories have already identified savings of £4bn a year in welfare and government costs.

Mr Hague will say: "Conservatives can go on the defensive about a low tax society, instead of being defensive against those who equate high taxes with a decent society."

fields.headline: Murder most complicated
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: The curry house proprietor was a man of taste and discrimination. He barred the customer's way and said "I know you! You're from the TV! You can't come in here!" A ringing and magnificent defiance.
fields.body:
The curry house proprietor was a man of taste and discrimination. He barred the customer's way and said "I know you! You're from the TV! You can't come in here!" A ringing and magnificent defiance.

The TV celebrity came in anyway. They have hides like rhinos.

This was the bit I liked best in The Blind Date (ITV), an over-complicated thriller. If, when it finishes next week, you have the slightest recollection what happened this week, you'll have to remind me.

There were two exceptionally nasty murders, a very vicious mugging and a suicide. I suppose it clears the deck of suspects.

The theme seems to be loneliness and lovelessness. Angela and Patty, being journalists, are obviously desperate cases and join a dating agency, Select Friends ("Sometimes fate needs a helping hand.") Their friend Lucy (Zara Turner), a disgraced detective, however, has an embarrassment of unsuitable suitors. Men pop up like, well, pop-up men. There is a fatherly senior officer in the CID. A forensic photographer ("He takes pictures of dead bodies for the Old Bill.") Her murdered sister's widower, who, being an estate agent, is clearly a suspicious character.

And the murder suspect himself, whom Lucy seduced to secure a confession only to have the case dismissed for entrapment. She is a willow wand of a woman with the sort of enviable physique which makes you think there may be something in the single-rib theory of creation. Why she lives in a mouldering belfry with bats and bells and a brass band rehearsing Onward Christian Soldiers at all hours is something you will have to explain to me. It probably suits her mood.

There seems to be a sub-plot about lost jewels. They're in the chandelier! The jewels are always in the chandelier. You'd think a detective would know that.

Meanwhile Coronation Street (ITV) has its own little mystery going when a recently dead body is dug up round the corner in Victoria Street. As Deirdre very truly says, it could be anybody ("People disappear all the time.") They certainly do in soaps, particularly if they get up the producer's nose. The archetype was Benny in Crossroads, who climbed up to fix a star on the motel Christmas tree. And was never seen again.

A word in the ear of the Weatherfield constabulary. Check closely to see if the body has a wooden leg. If so, it could be Don, the mad taxi-driver, who tried to set fire to Mike's knicker factory and then hopped it . If it has four legs, it might be Monica, Tyrone's greyhound, who has been lying doggo lately.

The Secret Life Of The Crash Test Dummy (Equinox, C4) was a horror-comedy of singular force. Fasten your seat belts. It's going to be a bumpy read.

The earliest crash testers were human volunteers. The next were anaesthetised pigs. Pigs had this advantage over people, the researchers ate the evidence. Then they used human corpses or "post- mortem human surrogates" as Americans predictably called them. Prof Walter Pilkey said "We'd call the families as soon as we heard about the body becoming available and get their specific approval for injury research. Basically, I learned to hand them a Kleenex and hope that improved the situation a little bit."

By now you were screaming silently as in a nightmare.

To keep more and more motorists alive, scientists needed more and more corpses. Amputated legs simulated ankle injuries. Decapitated heads recorded brain damage. The nightmare is nearly over. In 10 years all test crashes will be on computer.

I will arise now and go to Peckskill. It sounds my kind of place. Savage Planet (ITV) began "It had been a quiet evening in Peckskill." You feel that most evenings in Peckskill were like that. Then a meteorite, having streamed across the States, hit Peckskill. It burned a hole through Michelle Christiana's car and quite upset her cat. The Peckskill police said it must be a prank and used the meteorite as a doorstop. (A meteorite is worth about $1000 per lb.) Michelle, a shrewder cookie, sold her old jalopy for ten times its real value as a cosmic curiosity. I just like everything I hear about Peckskill.

"Oh sod!" said Delia (BBC 2). It was one of the cookery cock-ups with which she always ends a series. Seeing the joke before Denis Norden does.

Basically, I learned to hand them a Kleenex and hope that improved the situation a little bit." By now you were screaming silently as in a nightmare. To keep more and more motorists alive, scientists needed more and more corpses. Amputated legs simulated ankle injuries. Decapitated heads recorded brain damage. The nightmare is nearly over. In 10 years all test crashes will be on computer. I will arise now and go to Peckskill. It sounds my kind of place. Savage Planet (ITV) began "It had been a quiet evening in Peckskill." You feel that most evenings in Peckskill were like that. Then a meteorite, having streamed across the States, hit Peckskill. It burned a hole through Michelle Christiana's car and quite upset her cat. The Peckskill police said it must be a prank and used the meteorite as a doorstop. (A meteorite is worth about $1000 per lb.) Michelle, a shrewder cookie, sold her old jalopy for ten times its real value as a cosmic curiosity. I just like everything I hear about Peckskill. "Oh sod!" said Delia (BBC 2). It was one of the cookery cock-ups with which she always ends a series. Seeing the joke before Denis Norden does.

fields.headline: Keeping the beat
fields.standfirst: Police shows come and go - except, that is, for The Bill. But recent no-holds-barred shockfests like The Cops have radically altered the way we see the police on TV.  Matthew Baylis explains how the boys at Sun Hill stay on top
fields.trailText: Last week newly married PC Quinnan confronted his demons, becoming a youth worker on the estate where he was once stabbed, and then vanishing. The story marked a turning-point in delving so deeply into the private life and past of its characters.
fields.body:
Last week newly married PC Quinnan confronted his demons, becoming a youth worker on the estate where he was once stabbed, and then vanishing. The story marked a turning-point in delving so deeply into the private life and past of its characters.

The Bill has always been a showcase for innovation - particularly in terms of the writing. This makes it the most curious beast in the drama jungle - continually evolving, yet still keeping its high rung on the ratings ladder.

The show has undergone numerous structural changes. In autumn 1998, it moved to its current format of two, 60-minute episodes per week. In fact, this was a return to earlier roots. The show was born in 1983 as Woodentop, which despite sounding like a precursor to Teletubbies was a gritty cop drama, so popular it spawned another three series. The Bill only assumed the 30-minute format in 1988.

Enjoying popularity throughout these changes, it has had a cast turn-over that would impress Cecil B DeMille. Seventy-seven coppers have served at Sun Hill, not to mention the hordes of slags and scallywags who have shone - and sometimes shot to stardom - after a bit-part. Lily Savage, Rik Mayall, Denise van Outen. An actor saying they've been in The Bill is akin to students saying they've been to Goa - so commonplace it barely registers on the CV.

For those raised on a traditional soap diet, the idea that a show with such a fast-changing cast could inspire viewer loyalty is hard to understand. But The Bill has a huge fan club. When one of its cast misbehaves, tabloid outrage is twice that for the average coke-snorting soap star. It's almost as if we believe its characters are police officers, and consequently expect more of them.

This is fitting, because The Bill is not soap. The correct term is "precinct drama", and under that heading, the Sun Hill mob rub shoulders with Casualty and Peak Practice. Action is centred around a public place, with a small core cast, but a high turnover of characters drifting through and thereby generating stories. The stories are begun and ended within the duration of one episode, more rarely two or three. As a result, the writers' skill lies in creating and resolving drama, rather than developing character.

So The Bill can get away with storylines for which soaps end up in the dock. Take the killer virus in Brookside. It arrived from "outside", not because of an appropriate action by an established character. (Emily Shadwick's descent into crime is a good example of appropriate action - she's a recent orphan and very angry.) When the crisis was over, none of the characters were changed by their experiences. Mick and Ron never mention it, partly because it was an embarrassment to the show's creators.

Yet The Bill successfully depicts an outside event - like that perennial favourite, a riot on the Jasmine Allen estate - every week. To an extent this is due to subject matter - we expect the police to be involved in events of high drama. But it's also due to the way The Bill uses characters.

Casual viewers say the coppers in The Bill only exist in terms of their jobs. True, up to a point. There are many "short-hand" characters - a few hastily portrayed details, slotted in sporadically to remind us what, rather than who, they are. PC Hollis - offi cious nerd. Sgt Cryer - tough but fair. DI Burnside - rule-breaker. But why did Hollis become a copper instead of, say, a maths teacher? What private grief made Burnside so irredeemably bad? We don't know, don't need to. Look at it from the writer's perspective. When you've got to show "big stuff" happening - a bank job or domestic slaying - and you've got to wrap it up in 30 minutes, you don't have time to tell the viewers where DC Glaze goes to get his Afro retouched.

But devotees know this is half the story. In fact, some of The Bill's most popular episodes have delved deep into its characters' after-hours existences. What about the 1986 clash between Sgts Cryer and Penny? The impeccable Cryer was loitering with intent around Penny's wife. Or the episode in 1987, when WPC Ackland got pickled on duty following the death of her father.

Such scarce moments are multiplying now the show has returned to the one-hour format. Recently we've seen PC Garfield lose his heart to an Irish nurse, and then turn his back, not just on Irish nurses, but on the Force itself when she plumped for PC Quinnan. We then saw Quinnan court and marry her; we even know what sort of duvet they've got. And our thoughts were very much with his wife when he vanished last week. For the first time we sympathised with an "ordinary" character. Our interest has been taken beyond the precinct, and into people's hearts.

These developments are a deliberate measure. An hour is a weird time in telly terms - too short for a movie, too long for a soap. To keep momentum, without overloading on action, you need to lay bait for the viewers, spice it with human detail. DI Burnside informing some scrote that he's "goin' daahn" won't wash; you need to see how Quinnan's job affects his marriage. The result may be more uncharted territory for The Bill, but it's also intelligent drama that will keep millions handcuffed to the screen.

fields.headline: Big spenders
fields.trailText: It's an alluring story, a story that's got everything: ups, downs, fantasy, despair. It's got a bit of sex, a bit of violence, a bit of "I wish it was me", a bit of "there but for the grace of God".
fields.body:
It's an alluring story, a story that's got everything: ups, downs, fantasy, despair. It's got a bit of sex, a bit of violence, a bit of "I wish it was me", a bit of "there but for the grace of God".

The story of Viv Nicholson (below), the "spend, spend, spend" woman, is tailor-made for a dramatic screenplay - but what it turned into was a West End musical and, as producer Andre Ptaszynski has found out, that's a different game altogether.

Viv was unlucky. It was 1961 - three or fours years too early. A little later and she'd have caught up in that whole Beatles/Swinging Sixties thing, but 1961 was still a conservative place, and a lippy northern working-class woman - it was asking for trouble. Putting on a West End musical is also asking for trouble. The streets are littered with the corpses of good ideas in an age when Disney reigns.

Tonight's Trouble At The Top, (9.50pm, BBC2) a show that specialises in these up-against-the-wall stories, is not so much about the Viv phenomenon as the stage show. What's the allure of Viv? Why is the story still vibrant? This is 40 years ago now.

"She was the first person who was famous for being famous", says the programme's producer, Kim Shillinglaw. "She went up and she went down. But she came out of the other side. It was that spirit of survival that I think appeals to people. Apparently Camelot uses her as a model of what not to do, which I think is hilarious. If she was American, Warhol would have painted her. As it was, she was English and Morrissey put her on an album cover." There's a moral there somewhere.

Without giving the game away, the story with the musical is this. Despite "terrific reviews - which didn't make the slightest bit of difference", the show nearly sank. That it would have cost £600,000 to close kept it alive. And now? "They've just won an Olivier award for Barbara Dickson and that should help, but they're not out of the woods yet", says Shillinglaw. "Losses are still in the hundreds of thousands and it will be a couple of months before anyone knows, but they've got a chance. They're through the first stage."

webTitle: Rightwingers and locals preferred for safe Tory seats

fields.headline: Rightwingers and locals preferred for safe Tory seats
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The Conservatives are picking known Eurosceptics, Portillo-ites and candidates with strong local connections to fight their safe and winnable seats at the general election - at the expense of ex-MPs and pro-Europeans, Tory insiders said last night.
fields.body:
The Conservatives are picking known Eurosceptics, Portillo-ites and candidates with strong local connections to fight their safe and winnable seats at the general election - at the expense of ex-MPs and pro-Europeans, Tory insiders said last night.

Though some high-profile supporters of William Hague look set to enter parliament, the pro-Michael Portillo Conservative Way Forward (CWF) group has been exercising a powerful, if discreet, influence in some selection battles, it is also claimed.

"They're the ones who delivered Kensington and Chelsea to Michael [in the byelection]. They always have someone on the selection panel to sift potential rivals out of the shortlist. They can deliver 50 votes in the ballot and have 'planted snipers' to ask tricky questions," explained one MP.

With John Major's announcement that he is retiring from the Commons when the election comes (probably early summer or autumn next year), the struggle for influence is about to focus on his landslide-proof seat at Huntington with its 18,140 majority.

Though some dark horse contenders have yet to show their hand, Tory MPs tip their smooth ex-colleague, Andrew Mitchell, to make his strongest effort yet to get back to Westminster, against a local contender who has been quietly nursing the seat.

Mr Mitchell was unexpectedly defeated in Faversham last week by Hugh Robinson, a local candidate. Described as a late convert to Euroscepticism, he is certain to provoke a backlash in Huntingdon. Local associations famously guard their independence and are in no mood to be dictated to by Central Office in London after the divisions and disasters of 1992-97.

"The [associations] feel MPs were much more out of touch than the grassroots activists, and wouldn't listen," one former party official admitted. Local knowledge, especially of farming in the wake of BSE and the agricultural prices crisis, is at such a premium that in one rural seat, Stroud in Gloucestershire, an ardently pro-European Union farmer, Neil Carmichael, has won the nomination.

All the same, Mr Hague has managed to install Brooks Newmark, a wealthy venture capitalist and close chum since Oxford, as candidate in Braintree in Essex, won by Labour with a majority of 1,451 in 1997. Last week Charles Hendry, another ally and an ex-MP, took the nomination in Wealden in Sussex, majority 14,204, against the strong challenge of David Cameron, a much-fancied ex-treasury adviser.

Mr Hendry's trump card was that he had lived in the constituency until he was 18. He is also married to a wealthy Littlewoods heiress. "Cameron should have slaughtered him," insiders said.

But the symbolic "five-star" seat, the Cities of London and Westminster, being vacated by Peter Brooke, went to Mark Field, 35, a Kensington solicitor regarded as a high flyer who was given the backing of the pro-Portillo CWF. Mark McGregor, a prominent CWF activist, has won the nomination in Thanet South.

The unforgiving mood of activists is hard on ex-MPs who are trying to find another seat, though 17 "retreads" have been adopted again - mostly in the seats they lost in 1997.

The combative rightwinger, David Shaw, who lost Dover to Labour, is one of few to get a better prospect - Lib-Dem-held Kingston and Surbiton.

Women are again poorly represented in the better of the 150 seats that have picked candidates, and there is also concern about the showing of ethnic minorities. Shailesh Vara, a solicitor in his 30s, has won the nomination for Northampton South with a Labour majority of only 744, but insiders argue he should have been found an even safer bet.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: In The Long View (9.0am, Radio 4) Jonathan Freedland launches a plea for justice for the Scottish body-snatchers Burke and Hare. Apparently they have been woefully traduced these past 180 years, never having robbed a grave in their lives. Edinburgh's anatomists were looking for fresh bodies, uncorrupted and free of the graveyard's unpleasantly sticky clay. So the lads carefully smothered their candidates at home and presented them to the surgeons as fresh as a daisy.

Starting in showbiz as the Eichelbaum Family never had a convincing ring, which is why Michael Freedland opens his new series about The Men Who Made Hollywood (9.0pm, Radio 2) with the Warner Brothers. That's what the Polish cobbler's four little boys (including Jack, pictured) named themselves when they moved to Hollywood in 1917 to start a film company. Three years later, with times turning hard, they staked everything on an untried process called Vitaphone. It synchronised sound with moving pictures and made their fortune.

fields.headline: Getting personal with Gina Yashere
fields.trailText: Full Name: Gina Iyashere, but I dropped the I because people kept calling me Eye-ashere and it got on my nerves
fields.body:
Full Name: Gina Iyashere, but I dropped the I because people kept calling me Eye-ashere and it got on my nerves

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why? Yes, to claim Housing Benefit.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why? No, I really am thirteen.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad? Desperate, not choosy Nigerian seeks a human with both legs.

What was the last illegal thing you did? Drove at 120 in a 40mph zone

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did?

I picked up an old lady who had run away from an old peoples home and drove round with her for four hours trying to find an imaginary address. Eventually, I found the name of the home in her slippers.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?

Angela Ferreira, because she pays me.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with?

DO

Has a critic ever made you cry?

No

What would you advertise without a fee?

My own show.

What would you never advertise?

Skin bleaching cream.

What wakes you up screaming at 4 in the morning?

A spider falling on my face.

What takes you to a "happy place" ?

Food and money.

Gina Yashere stars in Blouse And Skirt, tonight, 11.20pm, BBC2

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Victor/Victoria
fields.body:
Victor/Victoria

(Blake Edwards, 1982)

9pm, TCM

There's much to admire in Edwards's musical comedy: his wife, Julie Andrews, for starters, marvellous as a cabaret singer masquerading as a female impersonator in 30s Paris. James Garner, as a would-be lover not knowing which way to turn, and Robert Preston, as Vic's gay pal, are excellent.

Lock, Stock And Two Smoking Barrels

(Guy Ritchie, 1998)

10pm, Sky Premier

This tale of four East End lads losing out to local villain 'Atchet 'Arry (PH Moriarty) in a fixed card game, and their attempts to drum up the half-million they owe him, has prompted umpteen Brit gangster movies aiming to cash in on its extraordinary success. There are big plusses - Vinnie Jones's well tasty enforcer (pictured), Lenny McClean's gruesome Barry the Baptist and a stonking soundtrack. But for a lesson in how it should be done, see the re-released The Long Good Friday.

The Holy Mountain

(Alejandro Jodorowsky, 1975)

12midnight, FilmFour

The Chilean master of oddness had looser purse strings than usual this time (with a little help from friends like John Lennon), allowing his freakishly fertile imagination to spill across the screen with even less restraint than usual. Jodorowsky himself is the mute protagonist, this time a Christ-like figure wandering through a series of characteristically surreal tableaux (the conquest of Latin America re-enacted with frogs?) before falling in with an interplanetary group planning a hostile quest for immortality.

Simon Of The Desert

(Luis Buñuel, 1965)

12.20am, FilmFour

Bible-bashing Buñuel has Simon Stylites (Claudio Brook) perched on a pillar in the desert, exposed to all manner of temptations by devilish Silvia Piñal. Meanwhile the villagers, at first so proud of their saint, grow irritated... an iconoclastic master class in a mere 50 minutes.

Steve Rose & Paul Howlett

Jodorowsky himself is the mute protagonist, this time a Christ-like figure wandering through a series of characteristically surreal tableaux (the conquest of Latin America re-enacted with frogs?) before falling in with an interplanetary group planning a hostile quest for immortality. fields.headline: Stars in his eyes
fields.standfirst:
Michael Foale is the British-born astronaut who saved the Mir space station. He tells Julian Borger how he became an ambassador for Nasa - and why Britain will never be taken seriously in the space race
Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Foale is the British-born astronaut who saved the Mir space station. He tells Julian Borger how he became an ambassador for Nasa - and why Britain will never be taken seriously in the space race
fields.body:
Michael Foale was the first punk in space. The British-American astronaut, and the closest thing we have to the kind of guy who starred in the Right Stuff, was a Sex Pistols and Ramones fan. He met his wife, Rhonda, when she was playing in a punk band called the Kitty Projectiles.

All that is behind him now. He listens to Depeche Mode these days. He is a 43-year-old father of two and one of Nasa's most senior and revered astronauts - a seemingly squeaky-clean hero in an orange space suit.

Yet something remains of the rebellious days of his youth - an open dislike for the unimaginative ways of the British establishment and the Thatcherism which he believes still pervades Whitehall's corridors of power. Foale blames that culture and its refusal to contemplate a British astronaut programme for driving him across the Atlantic to the US and Nasa.

The rest is space history. Foale was on the Mir space station in 1997 when the Russians accidentally sent an extra-terrestrial rubbish truck hurtling into its hull. Not long after that, he was sent tumbling helplessly through space when a Russian cosmonaut unplugged the wrong cable.

Yet Foale kept his cool through the string of near disasters, for which he earned universal respect. He speaks excellent Russian, has kept in close touch with his cosmonaut chums, and is one of the few Nasa officials the Russian space people trust.

"The perfect diplomat" is how Foale is described by his fellow astronaut, Jerry Linenger. It is not meant entirely as a compliment. Linenger, Foale's predecessor on Mir, has just brought out a tell-all book portraying himself as a gruff and fearless maverick, unafraid to speak out against the sloppiness of the Russian space programme and convinced that Nasa's $400m-a-year financial contribution was an extortionate rip-off. Foale comes out of the book, Off the Planet, looking like a conformist goody-goody.

"That is the big difference between me and Jerry," Foale says. "Jerry saw himself as an ambassador of the US way of life, and of US supremacy in space. He decided his role was to tell the Russians how it should be done."

Even Foale, the very embodiment of cultural sensitivity, acknowledges that safety precautions on board Mir were not all they could have been, and has likened his stay on board the orbiting Russian station to "a very dirty and grimy camping trip in an old car". But he says the experience was much more enjoyable and educational than it would have been had everything gone well.

Foale is Nasa's leading astronaut-diplomat, responsible for negotiations with Russia and the west Europeans over the much delayed International Space Station now under construction outside Earth's atmosphere. It is a hugely ambitious vehicle which he hopes one day to command.

In the course of a wide-ranging and meandering conversation on a Houston spring afternoon, he loses his sure footing only once, when the sticky subject of sex in space creeps up. "I would never be unfaithful to my wife," he says, somewhat defensively. Heaven forbid, but what about cosmic sex in general? A French astronomer called Pierre Kohler has just stirred up some fuss and free publicity for his new book by claiming that US and Russian astronauts have already had extra-terrestrial sex, and that Nasa had even designed a contraption to prevent astronauts floating away from each other at the vital moment. He says Kohler is misinformed on his tales of steamy zero-gravity coupling. "It hasn't happened. These organisations [Nasa and the Russian space programme] are so old-fashioned - this is taboo. It's not talked about," says Foale.

Although Foale left Britain almost two decades ago (in 1983) and now carries a US passport, he is still British enough to feel embarrassed about his native country's lack of interest in sending people into space. For the past few years he has been unsuccessfully lobbying Whitehall for the money to put up a real British astronaut. He was involved in recent talks on the subject between Nasa and Downing Street and when he met Tony Blair, the prime minister seemed to be genuinely interested. But the idea was quashed as soon as it reached Blair's scientific advisers.

"In the civil service the feeling is that human space flight is for entertainment only. It is extraordinarily dismissive and incorrect, to put it bluntly," Foale says.

Among the world's main industrialised countries, Britain is now almost alone in refusing to get involved in any astronaut programme. Only one truly British astronaut has been in space - Helen Sharman, in 1991 - but she was Soviet-funded, a shortlived product of glasnost.

"I think Britain has stopped thinking adventurously, officially," he says. "When the civil service gets together and says: 'What are Britain's interests?', they narrow their horizon at the start of the conversation, by saying: 'We will not do anything that does not have a return within three or five years.' They don't have a 20-year plan. They have a three-year plan or a five-year plan."

Foale's argument is that by thinking small, we are missing the point - that through the ages, exploration inspires and drags society along behind it. "Going into space with human beings captivates and motivates children's imagination to such an extent that they go out and strive to achieve greater things."

Rather than pay for it, Britain has counted on the vicarious thrills provided by other countries' astro nauts and cosmonauts, and there is clearly something to be said for that approach. It doesn't cost a penny, and it clearly worked for the young Foale, who made up his mind to be an astronaut after seeing John Glenn's Friendship 7 capsule at a space exhibition. His father was an RAF pilot, and so it seemed natural to follow in his footsteps. But some officious optician diagnosed an eyesight problem (wrongly, Foale says) and cut short that route to the stars. So Foale took the academic path, embarking on degrees in astrophysics and astronomy, and hoping he would pass muster with the European Space Agency (ESA).

He reckoned without Margaret Thatcher, who made it clear that her government would not finance ventures with such an unquantifiable rate of return as manned space flight. As a result, would-be British astronauts did not have much of a chance of passing muster with the ESA selection committee. So Foale decided to "activate" his American half: his mother is an American citizen and had the foresight to register the infant Michael with the US embassy.

There was another, tragic, reason for Foale's departure from Britain. In 1980, he was on holiday with his brother and his girlfriend, driving across what was then Yugoslavia on the way to Greece. Foale was at the wheel when a truck swerved across the road, killing both passengers. He survived but he was lost, amputated from his former life. Alongside his course-work, it was the company of a pair of Cambridge boozing buddies which helped to distract him - a couple of Falstaffian aesthetes making their way up the university comedy arts scene, Stephen Fry and Hugh Laurie, who larked around in a drinking club called the Cherubs.

"I was the oldest of the Cherubs," he recalls. "I was trying to be busy, active to regain my own interests in life. They helped me a lot through my own emotional hard times and my recovery and they were very sensitive to me, and I'm grateful."

There is a certain unmistakeable Englishness about the hero of Mir. He attributes his ability to stay cool in the isolation of space only half-jokingly to his years at public school. "There were no girls there [at King's School, Canterbury] and no girls on the Mir. The food on the Mir was better, the freedoms on the Mir were less, the sports activity about the same. And the education about the same."

On June 25 1997, Foale was the Nasa guest astronaut on board Mir with cosmonauts Vasily Tsibliev and Sasha Lazutkin. Energia, the Russian corporation running Mir, announced that the crew would have to attempt a docking with a supply ship call Progress which had been orbiting earth filled with junk removed earlier from Mir.

There was no real reason for the docking, but Energia did not want to continue paying the Ukrainians for an automatic coupling system, and insisted the Mir crew practise a manual method. It had been tested just once before, with near-disastrous results. Yet the ground controllers insisted it be tried again.

This time, with Tsibliev at the controls, it hit a solar panel and then crashed into the Spektr module, Foale's sleeping quarters. At the time he was in the far end of the space station. He said he recalled a "bad thud", and hung weightless, waiting for the air to be sucked out of his lungs. That did not happen, but he could feel the pressure drop. "It was just like when you're in a lift going up in a building and that was the sure sign that we definitely had a problem that the air was leaking out," he says.

Mir was saved only because Lazutkin ignored the emergency drill and refused to abandon ship. Instead, he and Foale managed to close the hatch on the Spektr module and isolate the leak.

Days later, it was Foale's turn to save the ship. When one of the cosmonauts mistakenly uncoupled Mir's main computer, the station began cartwheeling, throwing its solar panels out of alignment with the sun, threatening to trigger a catastrophic loss of power.

An attempt to escape might have been lethal, as the Soyuz pod most likely would have collided with Mir's spinning arms. Instead, Foale took the controls of the Soyuz and improvised, using the escape pod's thrusters to nudge the whole station back into its proper orbit.

By surviving, Foale has doubtless used up a good portion of his luck quota, but he is already planning his next trip for when the International Space Station is ready to receive astronauts later this year. "I'm still willing to take risks," he explains. "In fact, the more things I seem to dodge, the more I think: OK, act carefully, but keep living."
