webTitle: Labour heartlands row as south gets hi-tech

fields.headline: Labour heartlands row as south gets hi-tech
fields.standfirst: North-west MPs call on Blair to reverse 'stark' divide in science funding after Cheshire site loses £500m synchrotron project
fields.trailText: North-west MPs call on Blair to reverse 'stark' divide in science funding after Cheshire site loses £500m synchrotron project
fields.body:
Tony Blair was facing a new revolt in Labour's heartlands last night after the government decided to base a £500m hi-tech science project in Oxfordshire, rather than at a leading laboratory in the north-west.

Mike Hall, a government whip and Derek Twigg, a ministerial aide in the department of trade and industry which made yesterday's announcement, called on Downing Street to reverse the "stark" north-south divide in science funding.

Mr Hall, whose Weaver Vale constituency lost out, and Mr Twigg, his neighbouring MP at Halton, tried unsuccessfully to persuade the prime minister to change his mind yesterday morning. They said: "The decision will be devastating news for the staff at Daresbury laboratory [which lost out]. The government urgently needs to address the stark imbalance between science funding in the north-west and science funding in the Oxford and Cambridge area."

Such a strongly worded intervention by two loyal members highlighted the anger among north-west MPs at the decision to base the synchrotron project at the Rutherford Appleton laboratory near Didcot in Oxfordshire instead of at the government-financed Daresbury laboratory in Cheshire, which is home to Britain's existing synchrotron.

The prime minister's official spokesman said that the project's other two partners - the French government and the Wellcome Trust - had argued for Didcot. "There was a risk of losing the project had we not gone along with this."

The government attempted to sweeten the blow by announcing a package of measures to encourage science in the north-west. The science minister, Lord Sainsbury, pledged £25m to boost the scientific base and a further £25m to develop biotechnology industries.

Workers and scientists at Daresbury accused the Well come Trust of bullying the government into backing south against north, and they suggested that the French, also reportedly in favour of an Oxfordshire site, might yet pull out of the deal.

Bob Cernik, director of physical sciences at Daresbury, said: "We felt that we won the scientific argument, we won the logistical argument and clearly the political arguments were in favour of the north-west, and we feel that the government has just taken the size of Wellcome Trust's wallet, balanced all the scientific common sense against the size of that wallet and taken the money.

"In the beginning of science week it is interesting to note that Tony Blair has decided that the only science that can take place in this country will take place in the south-east."

The synchrotron is a huge accelerator which discharges high precision radiation beams of enormous energy - to explore the structure of a protein, or what happens to molecules of cement as they harden into concrete. Lord Sainsbury announced that the Daresbury machine would operate for another seven years as the new machine will take five years to build.

The battle of Daresbury has been bitter. The new synchrotron source - codenamed Diamond - is a tool for engineering, drug development and materials manufacture at scales of billionths of a metre.

Staff at Daresbury first heard last summer of a bid to build the instrument at Rutherford Appleton (RAL), and mounted a furious campaign, calling in big business, local politicians and Nobel prizewinners on their side.

They pointed out that if Daresbury shut down, there would be only 270 government-funded research and development jobs left in the north-west, against an estimated 8,665 in the south-east. The trade secretary, Stephen Byers, said several times he wanted to see the instrument at Daresbury. It became clear that other partners - the Wellcome Trust is providing more than £100m - thought otherwise.

"They had made up their mind that Oxford - the Rutherford Appleton - was the place, and they would not shift," said Dr Cernik. Now, he said, the French government and Michael Dexter, the chief executive of the Wellcome Trust, seemed to be dictating science policy to government. Mr Byers had said in print, and on at least three occasions to Daresbury staff, that he wanted the instrument in the north-west.

"His arm has been twisted, it seems by Tony Blair, who values the private-public partnership between the government and the Wellcome Trust more highly than he values the quality of the scientific staff at Daresbury," said Dr Cernik.

Dr Dexter said it was "nonsense" to suggest that the Wellcome Trust had exerted pressure. "Obviously we do support the decision by the government to support the new synchrotron at RAL.

"I do think it does create tremendous opportunities for UK science, working in partnership with the French government and the academic community of this country to get a machine that is going to be a major benefit to the biomedical, and the physical sciences. I see a fantastic opportuinity to establish a truly international venture at RAL."

fields.headline: Peers face tougher cash rules
fields.standfirst: Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: Members of the House of Lords seem certain to be forced to register their business interests after an inquiry into the conduct of peers was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Members of the House of Lords seem certain to be forced to register their business interests after an inquiry into the conduct of peers was announced yesterday.

Lord Neill, chairman of the committee on standards in public life, is to examine whether the present voluntary system of declarations by peers should be scrapped and replaced with a compulsory register with penalties for those breaking the rules.

The inquiry follows last year's removal of 600 hereditary peers from the House of Lords, leaving 92 hereditary peers, 548 life peers and 26 bishops and archbishops.

The House of Lords escaped thorough reform after the 1994 "cash for questions " scandal which led to Lord Neill's predecessor, Lord Nolan, proposing strict rules and penalties for MPs who failed to declare their interests. The Lords at the time set up a mainly voluntary register, only requiring declarations where peers represented lobbying firms or were ministers in the government.

The Neill committee will look at peers' registration and declaration of interests, the need for a code of conduct in the Lords, parliamentary consultancies and lobbying, disciplinary procedures and penalties.

They will also decide whether the Lords should have its own parliamentary commissioner for standards.

Lord Neill said yesterday: "The committee has had a long-standing commitment to considering these issues in relation to the House of Lords. At a time when the house has undergone such a radical change in its composition, it is now particularly appropriate that we should fulfil that commitment."

The House of Lords is increasingly dominated by appointed life peers, who have become much more active in overturning controversial government legislation, forcing Jack Straw, the home secretary, to abandon his first attempt to abolish trial by jury for many offences. This more active approach by peers is leading to demands for greater scrutiny of their outside interests.

The proposed inquiry will report in the autumn after taking evidence over the summer. It was welcomed by all parties yesterday.

The leader of the Lords, Lady Jay said: "Labour ministers in the Lords already declare their interests to the same standard as is required in the Commons. Many Labour peers have followed suit. Any resistance to such an inquiry in the past has come from parties in opposition and not from the Labour party."

The opposition peers' leader, Lord Strathclyde, confirmed that the opposition "will cooperate fully with any requests from the inquiry".

The Liberal Democrat party treasurer, Lord Razzall. said the inquiry was long overdue. "In the light of the reform of the House of Lords, the same standards must apply to peers as are in place in the House of Commons."

Leading members of the House of Lords with extensive interests:

Lord Alli, 35-year-old millionaire Blairite Labour life peer. Already declares 22 directorships in the media industry. These are:

24 Hour Productions Limited; Animation Distribution Company; Charles Parsons Productions; Crystal FM; Deep Silver Television; Doomsday ll; Entertainment Reports); Fleetwillow (property); G1049FM; Impossible Television ; International Classical Music Awards; More 1054FM; Planet 24 Ltd; Planet 24 Productions (this company has produced party po litical broadcasts for the Labour party); Planet 24 Radio; Planet 24 Service; Planet Hat Trick; Planet Wild Productions; Planet World; Regional Radio Scotland; Yemeyah (public relations); Z Music Publishing; Interest in Atomic International BV (media).

If the rules are changed he may have to declare his income from these directorships.

Lord Archer, aged 59, former Tory mayoral candidate for London and former vice-chairman of Tory party. Currently declares earnings from media appearances connected with books. Will have to declare much more if the rules are changed, including revenue from his new acting career.

fields.bodyText: Members of the House of Lords seem certain to be forced to register their business interests after an inquiry into the conduct of peers was announced yesterday. Lord Neill, chairman of the committee on standards in public life, is to examine whether the present voluntary system of declarations by peers should be scrapped and replaced with a compulsory register with penalties for those breaking the rules. The inquiry follows last year's removal of 600 hereditary peers from the House of Lords, leaving 92 hereditary peers, 548 life peers and 26 bishops and archbishops. The House of Lords escaped thorough reform after the 1994 "cash for questions " scandal which led to Lord Neill's predecessor, Lord Nolan, proposing strict rules and penalties for MPs who failed to declare their interests. The Lords at the time set up a mainly voluntary register, only requiring declarations where peers represented lobbying firms or were ministers in the government. The Neill committee will look at peers' registration and declaration of interests, the need for a code of conduct in the Lords, parliamentary consultancies and lobbying, disciplinary procedures and penalties. They will also decide whether the Lords should have its own parliamentary commissioner for standards. Lord Neill said yesterday: "The committee has had a long-standing commitment to considering these issues in relation to the House of Lords. At a time when the house has undergone such a radical change in its composition, it is now particularly appropriate that we should fulfil that commitment." The House of Lords is increasingly dominated by appointed life peers, who have become much more active in overturning controversial government legislation, forcing Jack Straw, the home secretary, to abandon his first attempt to abolish trial by jury for many offences. This more active approach by peers is leading to demands for greater scrutiny of their outside interests. The proposed inquiry will report in the autumn after taking evidence over the summer. It was welcomed by all parties yesterday. The leader of the Lords, Lady Jay said: "Labour ministers in the Lords already declare their interests to the same standard as is required in the Commons. Many Labour peers have followed suit. Any resistance to such an inquiry in the past has come from parties in opposition and not from the Labour party." The opposition peers' leader, Lord Strathclyde, confirmed that the opposition "will cooperate fully with any requests from the inquiry". The Liberal Democrat party treasurer, Lord Razzall. said the inquiry was long overdue. "In the light of the reform of the House of Lords, the same standards must apply to peers as are in place in the House of Commons." webTitle: Boateng backs down on probation service name

fields.headline: Boateng backs down on probation service name
fields.trailText: Paul Boateng, the home office minister, was last night forced to abandon his plan to rebrand the probation service as the "community punishment and rehabilitation service".
fields.body:
Paul Boateng, the home office minister, was last night forced to abandon his plan to rebrand the probation service as the "community punishment and rehabilitation service".

Mr Boateng had claimed that the name change was essential and nicely balanced "tough" with the constructive tone of rehabilitation but it ran into a storm of criticism that it was "a silly plan".

Last night the minister said in a Commons written reply: "The government has listened to representations from MPs and others, and we intend that the new unified service will be called the national probation service of England and Wales. We have listened to views from across the criminal justice system."

He admitted the name "probation" enjoyed wide international recognition but said ministers intended to use the opportunity to stress the role of the service as a "law enforcement agency". A criminal justice and court services bill to be published on Thursday will reduce the 54 area probation services to 42 and put them under a national director.

Last night Geoff Dobson, chairman of the Association of Chief Officers of Probation, said: "It is a good decision. Our fear was that a new name would reduce, rather than increase, public awareness of the service and confuse people. We can now concentrate on the very important changes to the way the service is run."

fields.headline: Eleanor Goddard
fields.trailText: Eleanor Goddard, who has died aged 73, was one of the few people who could recall the early life of Norma Jean Baker, in the years before fame transformed her into Marilyn Monroe. The pair met when, after living in a series of foster homes, they spent several years together in Van Nuys, then a quiet Los Angeles suburb, at the home of Goddard's father. He had recently married a close friend of Norma Jean's mother, Gladys Baker, then in a mental institution.
fields.body:
Eleanor Goddard, who has died aged 73, was one of the few people who could recall the early life of Norma Jean Baker, in the years before fame transformed her into Marilyn Monroe. The pair met when, after living in a series of foster homes, they spent several years together in Van Nuys, then a quiet Los Angeles suburb, at the home of Goddard's father. He had recently married a close friend of Norma Jean's mother, Gladys Baker, then in a mental institution.

Known as "Bebe", and six months younger than her now foster sister, Eleanor remained friendly with Monroe up until her suicide in 1962. She spoke at observances for the 20th, 25th, 30th and 35th anniversaries of the star's death, held at her crypt in the Westwood Village memorial park, a fashionable part of LA's west side.

Monroe used to tell anecdotes about the hardships of growing up in a series of foster homes, where she suffered beatings, hunger, and loneliness. But, according to Goddard in her final years, these were actually "borrowings" from stories Goddard had told Monroe about her own early life.

In Van Nuys, even during the early 40s, Eleanor and Norma Jean appeared to be typical southern California teenagers, going to the same high school, visiting cinemas, dreaming of Hollywood, and giggling over male matinee idols. They would, it seems, swap clothes and cosmetics, indulge in make-up sessions, and talk for hours about what they would do with wealth and fame.

But early on it became ob vious that Norma Jean had looks that differentiated her. In 1991, when Goddard visited their old school, Van Nuys High, for the presentation of a portrait of the woman who made The Seven-Year Itch, Bus Stop, and Some Like It Hot, she described the teenage Monroe as "just a really average girl, except she was so much more beautiful than average".

In 1953, the two shared Monroe's birthday celebration. She was making Gentlemen Prefer Blondes and was well on her way to becoming a major star. Goddard and her parents visited Monroe's flat for dinner and a birthday cake, but ate "not-well-cooked liver and kind-of-tough baked potatoes," Goddard recalled. Monroe's lack of domestic skills is well documented, but Americans today would be shocked to hear she even touched liver, a dish now almost taboo.

Goddard would reflect on how Monroe had been badly treated by her studio and Hollywood figures "who really didn't know her well." "To me," she wrote, "it's a glorious experience that the interest in Norma Jean keeps increasing, and I hope she's up [in heaven] thumbing her nose at them all."

Little is known of Goddard's later life, although in her last years she became an active campaigner for smoker's rights and fought California's strictures on the habit. A lifelong chain-smoker, she blamed her emphysema on air pollution around her Burbank home.

 Eleanor 'Bebe' Goddard, born December 17 1926; died February 11 2000

fields.headline: Laurence James
fields.standfirst: Gifted novelist of many names
fields.trailText: Gifted novelist of many names
fields.body:
In 1970, the writer Laurence James, who has died of cancer aged 56, became an editor at the paperback publishing house, New English Library. It was the beginning of a career that saw him become what he described as the country's "least known bestseller", writing, under pen-names, 12 to 14 novels every year, 160 in total, which sold more than 12m copies.

The NEL he joined handled a list ranging from Harold Robbins, Irving Stone, Frank Yerby and Dorothy L Sayers to a line of original novels that exploited the tabloid headlines of the day. In 1970, the company published the bestseller Skinhead, by Richard Allan (James Moffatt), but the real boom began a year later, when William Terry's novelisation of the spaghetti western, A Town Called Bastard, inspired a series starring Edge, the Loner, written by Terry Harknett (as George G Gilman). That year too, Peter Cave's hell's angel novel, Chopper, appeared.

Only recently discovered by academics, but longtime cult favourites for collectors, these million-sellers inspired a rash of imitations. Since NEL was, as James admitted, "the bottom end of the market, we were either creative or we went under".

James left NEL in 1973 to freelance for the market he had helped create. He wrote hell's angel novels as Mick Norman; Viking and Roman historical novels as Arthur Frazier, Andrew Quiller and Neil Langholm; science fiction under his own name; humorous confessions as Jonathan May and Christopher Nolan; and romances as Mary Fraser. He produced dozens of westerns, beginning in 1974 with the Apache series (as William M James), a violent revenge story which ran over two dozen novels, as did the Herne The Hunter series for Corgi (written as John J McLaglen). Many of James's pseudonyms were shared between a small, alternating group of writers; for example, William M James was split between James, Harknett and John Harvey.

The paperback boom lasted only five years, after which James turned to horror novels, writing as James Darke and Richard Haigh, juvenile books (some in collaboration with his son, Matthew) about American football and baseball, and a children's fantasy series. In 1986, as James Axler, came his most successful series, the Darklands books. Set a generation after nuclear war has devastated America, they were grim adventures, imaginatively written. In any of the three dozen titles that James wrote, Vikings or General Custer were as likely to show up as mutants or survivalists.

After grammar school, Harris trained as a teacher at Goldsmith's College, south London, found work as a scaffolder, and later sold books at Foyles and Harrods, before entering publishing with Leslie Frewin in 1968. In the mid-1990s, he was diagnosed as having cancer, which he endured with honesty and humour. He is survived by his wife, the writer Elizabeth James, two sons and one daughter.

fields.headline: Grenville Jones
fields.standfirst: Pioneering political consultant to the world's underdogs
fields.trailText: Pioneering political consultant to the world's underdogs
fields.body:
The political consultant Grenville Jones, who has died aged 77, was an elegant, four-square pioneer on the fringe of Westminster and the old colonial office. He was light years away from the brown-envelope, moonlight-flit spin-and-spiv "consultancies" of the last decade.

Through his company, External Development Services, which he founded in 1960, Jones's net was wide. The imprisoned Nelson Mandela was a client - EDR's offices were burgled three times by the apartheid South African secret service, and there was also a bungled arson attack. Repatriation of the Canadian Indians was another cause, so was the Banaban islanders' claim on the British government over phosphates. EDR also represented the Biafran government during the Nigerian civil war. Jones specialised, almost as consul in Britain, for a number of Gulf states.

He would have made a terrific MP. An all-rounder, his charm and saucy wit would have wowed the tin-rattling constituency fetes and jumble sales, just as they would the backbenches at Westminster, where he would have been admired as a convivial, free-thinking good egg in the tearooms.

His Welsh-borders' birth- right and allegiance was to liberalism with a capital L. It was during a time of depressing fortunes for the party that he stood unsuccesfully in three general elections - for the Isle of Ely in 1950, when he was still at St Catherine's College, Cambridge; for North Hereford in 1959 and for Tavistock in 1964. By the time he joined the Labour party in the mid-1960s, he was past the age and bother of seeking constituency selection, and EDS - of which Jeremy Thorpe was briefly a director - was already beginning to claim his full attention.

Earlier, after war service as an RAF wireless-operator/ air-gunner, Jones went to Cambridge as a mature student, and revelled in life there. He was a star debater and Liberal Club chairman, and left to work on the Crossbencher column of the Sunday Express, then an unmissable weekly read of political leaks, gossip and, sometimes, scurrility.

So imagine the wide-eyed dazzle of it, when Jones, a staffer from Fleet Street's famed column, a spruce and genially dapper Celt, burst into the one-room, one-man Leominster branch office of the Hereford Times in 1958 and announced his immediate advancement to this writer, then a quivering 20-year old cub-reporter. Said Grenville: "Keating, boyo, I'm North Hereford's new Liberal candidate: I'm going to make you - and you're going to make me."

A nd so, mutually, we each contrived to do so. There was no official Lib organisation; the Tories were landslidingly first, the rest nowhere. Grenville's first target was to do better than the Libs in South Hereford, considered winnable, where Robin Day was Liberal candidate. We were to do better, and comfortably; the supercillious townee Day was out of his element on the rustic hustings, whilst alongside him at joint meetings, off-the-cuff Grenville would have the smocks rocking and rolling in agreement and mirth in the cattle-aisles and among the pig-pens.

This star-struck young reporter played his part. Gren- ville would telephone from London with his variety of opinions - anything from the National Farmers Union's local fatstock prices to the end-of-the-monarchy or Kenya's Mau-Mau - and, shamelessly, I would patch-in these matters of policy into reports of non-existent meetings around the constituency, invariably "packed-out and enthralled".

At head office in Hereford, only the beady-eyed, anti- establishment chief sub- editor, Ray Goulding, sort of twigged. "Your Jones fellow is putting himself about a bit, isn't he, laddie?" was all he would say with a thin smile as he spread Grenville's latest thoughts across two frontpage columns. The Tory won. But local boy Jones was a terrific, trend-breaking radical second.

Five years later, when Grenville took on Tavistock, another Tory stronghold, I was working in outside broadcasts for ITV in London. I could now officially be called "campaign manager." The Olympic Games were in the offing in Japan, and I had mates in the graphics department doctor huge posters showing star athletes lunging to breast the tape - with Jones's face superimposed and the legend announcing "A Gold For Grenville". In one weekend, we must have pasted up more than a thousand. The Tories were rattled - but, of course, hung on to win. Grenville, gloriously, took the silver again.

In the end, he had the best of both his worlds. From EDS's chandeliered offices on the Pall Mall edge of Trafalgar Square, he could alternate his lunchtime constitutional (he never learned to drive) either at Fleet Street's El Vino or Westminster's Annie's Bar. For many years, you could tell the time by his longer walk, in his distinctive rust-red overcoat, every other weekend over Richmond Bridge, from his lovely home to Old Deer Park, Twickenham, to watch London Welsh at rugby.

In 1966, Jones married the journalist Jill Pound-Corner. Their daughter Sian is a television producer.

fields.headline: Helen Flint
fields.trailText: I first met the novelist and poet Helen Flint, who has died aged 47, in 1988, when I was a commissioning editor for Heinemann Young Books. I had read her first novel, Return Journey, for which she won the Betty Trask Award, and, stung by the humour and bitter honesty of her prose, felt she was a natural writer for young adults. Not Just Dancing was the result; her third novel for teenagers was Not Just Babysitting.

I first met the novelist and poet Helen Flint, who has died aged 47, in 1988, when I was a commissioning editor for Heinemann Young Books. I had read her first novel, Return Journey, for which she won the Betty Trask Award, and, stung by the humour and bitter honesty of her prose, felt she was a natural writer for young adults. Not Just Dancing was the result; her third novel for teenagers was Not Just Babysitting.

With Heinemann, she also published two adult novels, In Full Possession and Making The Angels Weep, as well as a book on creative writing for the Women's Press. Writing for teenagers, she had the ability to address serious issues with candour, humour and frank observation.

Helen was born in Cam bridge, but had a peripatetic childhood as the family followed her father, a professor of history, on his overseas postings. She read English at Oxford university, then did a postgraduate certificate in education. Full of enthusiasm for the child-centred approach of the time, she found her first experience in the classroom an eye-opener.

Far from responding to the permissive atmosphere of the school, the children were running riot, and the staff, in her view, on the edge of nervous collapse. It was Helen's first collision with political correctness. She always refused to bow dutifully to its tenets, and took the risk of voicing her opinions, aware that such honesty could make her unpopular. Her sense of justice and her ability to place herself under equal scrutiny won her respect, even from those who disagreed with her.

Helen was passionate, outspoken, intensely loyal to her family and friends and extremely sensitive, a quality she attempted to conceal with her sharp sense of humour. By the time we worked together, she was already ill with a neurological disease. She said that being disabled made her think longer and more deeply about things, and she refused to allow anything to get in the way of her priorities - her family and her writing.

With characteristic purpose and against all the odds, she continued to write, completing her last children's novel, Not Just Rescuing, shortly before she died. It will be published together with re-issues of the previous two Not Just . . . books.

She leaves her husband, John Lawlor, a daughter and a son.

 Helen Sarah Lawlor (née Flint), writer and poet, born June 7 1952; died January 14 2000

fields.headline: Ian Auld
fields.standfirst: Innovative potter and teacher entranced by Middle Eastern architecture and African culture
fields.trailText: Innovative potter and teacher entranced by Middle Eastern architecture and African culture
fields.body:
Ian Auld, who has died aged 74, was a member of the postwar generation of innovative potters who came to prominence in the 1960s. He also created one of the most successful and happiest ceramics departments in London and was a major collector of African material culture.

Born in Hove, Sussex, to a businessman father and a part-American mother, Auld spent the early years of the second world war in Devon. As a schoolboy he was drawn to country life, and for a while wanted to be a farmer. A period painting theatrical scenery and cinema hoardings was followed by wartime service as a naval radar operator. After the war, rather against his father's wishes, he decided to become an artist, spending a fruitful year at Brighton school of art. From 1948-51, he was at the Slade in London, where he felt lonely but won a prize for his lino and woodblock prints.

Everything changed when, as an insurance policy, he took a teacher's certificate at the institute of education. There he encountered the potter William Newland: "For the first time, I found a teacher who was friendly and wanted to help."

In 1952, Auld worked at John Bew's Odney pottery, at Cookham, Berkshire, "wheeling barrows of coke and packing things in straw", subsequently becoming the technician in the stimulating atmosphere of the Central school's ceramics department. He spent 1954-57 in Baghdad, starting up a pottery department at the city's art school and travelling to India, Turkey and Iran to study early and traditional work in clay, metal and glass.

On his return to England, he settled with his first wife, the weaver Ruth Harris, at Wimbish, near Saffron Waldron, where he built an oil-fired kiln. He taught both at the Central school and at Camberwell school of art, where he worked alongside Hans Coper. At this time he made some of his most impressive work, mostly powerful slab-built pots inspired by middle eastern architecture. Most were ash-glazed in subdued colours, and some were impressed with plaster of Paris seals incised with a private language of abstract signs. Others were remarkable for their rough surfaces, influenced by painters such as Antoni Tapies.

By 1966, Auld was living in Chippenham, Wiltshire, sharing a studio with fellow ceramicist Gillian Lowndes, who was to become his life's partner. He also taught at Bath academy of art and Bristol polytechnic.

In 1969, a year after the birth of his son Ben, he opened a small shop in Camden Passage, Islington. In 1970, he showed some East African pots there, and that year took leave of absence from Bristol to become a research fellow in the department of African studies at Ife University, Nigeria. This, too, was to prove a transformative experience, and Auld, Gillian and Ben travelled round Nigeria in a camper van, immersing themselves in the visual culture and, in particular, studying Yoruba carving and shrine paintings.

Auld became head of ceramics at Camberwell in 1974, swiftly broadening the interests of a department best known for its concentration on clay bodies. Inspired by the ethos at Bath academy, he invited (and retained) the best practising ceramicists to teach at Camberwell on a part-time basis. The quality of students who graduated during this period - including Henry Pim, Sara Radstone, Sarah Scampton, Julian Stair and the late Angus Suttie - testify to this golden age.

But running a department took its toll, though he made some of his most tender work on his return from West Africa - inspired by sources as varied as Ashanti weights and the cowrie jackets worn by Yoruba Ibeji figures.

Auld had always been a keen and discerning purchaser of objects, buying English slipware, William and Mary plates and 16th and 17th century furniture. His tastes were broad and, informed by the standards both of early modernism and of the authentic vernacular, included fine early Cypriot, Chinese and pre-Columbian ceramics, Samoan bark cloths and Roman glass.

But the glory of his collec tion was its African art, in which he brought together the finest group of Yoruba carvings and metalwork to be found anywhere in the world. Auld bought with the discerning eye of a modern artist and his taste was remarkable for its focus and formal sensitivity.

His manner was direct and candid. He hated pretension and was modest about his remarkable knowledge. After retirement from Camberwell in 1985, he was to be found holding court in his shop in Islington (a meeting place for all serious collectors of African art), or planting vegetables and tending his bees in a windy garden full of chickens, handsome cockerels and speckled guinea fowl.

Gillian and Ben survive him. &#`149; Ian Hamilton Auld, potter, educationalist and collector, born January 5 1926; died February 10 2000

fields.headline: Bombs raise tension in Tehran
fields.standfirst: Violent attempt to destabilise reform regime as explosions follow shooting
fields.trailText: Mortar bombs exploded in a Tehran residential district yesterday, one day after the attempted assassination of a leading political strategist and adviser to President Mohammed Khatami.
fields.body:
Mortar bombs exploded in a Tehran residential district yesterday, one day after the attempted assassination of a leading political strategist and adviser to President Mohammed Khatami.

The two incidents, which appeared unrelated, heightened political tensions between the factions vying for power in Iran. Reformers blamed conservatives for the Sunday shooting of Saeed Hajjarian, and accused them of trying to destabilise the country.

Half a dozen mortar bombs exploded at about 1:30pm in north Tehran, next to a base of the revolutionary guards, the highest security force in charge of protecting the capital. Several cars bore the brunt of the explosion, and shrapnel tore into an apartment building, witnesses said. The building is home to five MPs, one of whom was home at the time but was unhurt.

Four people were injured, including a gardener at the guards' complex, whose legs were blown off, and a young woman, Mehrnaz Foroughi-Shad, who was hit in the face with shrapnel. The Mojahedin e-Khalq, an opposition group which appears on the US state department's terrorist list, claimed it was behind yesterday's explosions. It had also claimed responsibility for explosions near the presidential palace and government buildings last month.

But other elements are suspected of trying to kill Mr Hajjarian - the mastermind behind the reformers' victory in Iran's parliamentary election of February 18 - who was in a critical condition at a Tehran hospital with a bullet lodged in his neck, doctors said.

He was shot in the face at close range on Sunday morning by one gunman and an accomplice. Witnesses and police said the attackers fled on a 1000cc motorcycle; motor bikes of this power are banned for general use but licensed to security personnel in the intelligence ministry and the police force.

Reformers saw the motorbike as evidence that the attackers were hardliners in law enforcement who wanted to kill Mr Hajjarian in revenge for the conservatives' defeat in the polls. Reformers won 29 of 30 seats in Tehran and an esti mated 100 seats elsewhere, of 290 up for election. Some 65 seats are at stake in a second round of voting.

Friends of Mr Hajjarian said he had received written death threats in connection with material published by the progressive newspaper he edits. It has accused rightwing extremists of murdering several intellectuals in 1998.

"The terrorist attack on Mr Hajjarian is a declaration of war on the nation," said Ayatollah Yousef Sanei, a reformist cleric in the religious centre of Qom. "Why don't you hardliners try to accommodate the people, why don't you accept their vote?"

President Khatami's chief of staff said the assault on Mr Hajjarian was politically motivated. "The calamity of the assassination attempt on our in tellectual brother Hajjarian was one of the prices that the reformist current must pay," newspapers quoted Mohammed Ali Abtahi as saying.

"If the government cannot stop such terrorist acts and barbaric attacks by pressure groups, it is only contributing to its own decline and demise," said Ayatollah Hossein Ali Montazeri, a leading dissident who is under house arrest.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Plea for political calm in Austria
Amid fears of an increase in racism and xenophobia in Austria, President Thomas Klestil urged politicians yesterday to tone down their rhetoric.
fields.body:
Plea for political calm in Austria
Amid fears of an increase in racism and xenophobia in Austria, President Thomas Klestil urged politicians yesterday to tone down their rhetoric.

But Mr Klestil - whose country has been shunned by western countries since the far-right Freedom party joined the government last month - also urged European Union officials to "give the new government a chance". AP, Vienna

Israeli air force attacks rebels
Israeli war planes repeatedly struck positions of Palestinian groups near the Syrian border yesterday, according to Lebanese security sources.

Also targeted were suspected Hizbullah guerrilla bases closer to Israel's south Lebanon occupation zone. The raids came two days after the Arab League warned Israel to stop attacks on Lebanon and resume peace talks. Reuters, Wadi al-Aswad, Lebanon

Christian sect members held
Police in central China are holding 16 members of a Christian sect banned in a government crackdown on cults, a human rights group said yesterday.

Officers were said to have arrested followers of the China Evangelistic Fellowship in Xinyang. Campaigners fear that those arrested will be sent to a labour camp. AP, Beijing

Suicidal father kills twin girls
A man with a shotgun killed his twin four-year-old daughters before committing suicide, Spanish police said yesterday.

The killer, from Platja D'Aro in Catalonia, was said to have been distraught following the breakup of his marriage. AP, Platja D'Aro

webTitle: UN moves to close net on Angolan rebel leader

fields.headline: UN moves to close net on Angolan rebel leader
fields.trailText: Jonas Savimbi, the leader of Angola's Unita rebel movement, could be indicted for murder in the United States - the country that for nearly two decades of the cold war was his unconditional backer.
fields.body:
Jonas Savimbi, the leader of Angola's Unita rebel movement, could be indicted for murder in the United States - the country that for nearly two decades of the cold war was his unconditional backer.

The proposal by the United Nations sanctions committee is to be discussed by the security council tomorrow. Another recommendation is for an arrest warrant for his right-hand man and chief diamonds-for-arms trafficker, Moses Dachala, to be enforced by Interpol.

The UN report contains 39 proposals which would effectively take Mr Savimbi out of the Angolan picture that he has dominated for so long.

It names two African presidents - of Togo and Burkina Faso - as personally benefiting from presents of illegal diamonds from Unita, and is a major step forward by the UN in its attempt to extend international responsibility for ending the war.

Both presidents deny breaking UN sanctions. The UN imposed arms and fuel sanctions on Unita in 1993 when the rebels returned to war after losing the general election. In 1998 sanctions were extended to include diamond trading, which was Unita's only source of funding for its war.

The conflict worsened and the UN itself became a target, with its workers killed, its trucks ambushed and its planes shot down. The UN sanctions committee's lawyers have suggested that the indictment of Mr Savimbi in the US for murder could be based on evidence from senior Unita defectors, who have said UN planes were shot down on the orders of Mr Savimbi. One of the UN staff killed in these crashes was an American.

The UN report brings the European Union and Nato into the equation by proposing that they require would-be members to comply with the arms embargo on Unita. Bulgaria, which wants to join the EU, has been the conduit for east European armaments sold to the rebels in exchange for diamonds.

Other measures include a blacklist in the diamond industry in Belgium for those known to be trading in Unita diamonds, DNA testing on any captured Unita fuel to show where it originated, and loss of some diplomatic privileges for countries which allow Unita to use their passports.

A three-year arms embargo is being proposed on the west African state of Togo, which has allowed Unita to use its end-user certificates for arms buying, while a recommendation that no meetings or conferences should be held in countries involved in sanctions breaking will rule out Togo from taking over the chair of the Organisation of African Unity in July.

Mr Savimbi's children have been hosted in Togo by President Gnassingbe Eyadema for several years, after the Unita leader lost his key support bases in Africa with the deaths of presidents Felix Houphouet-Boigny of Ivory Coast and Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire. The relationship is purely a business one, according to former Unita officials who testified to the UN committee.

"Savimbi used to say that Eyadema was only interested in money - worse than Mobutu," said one official.

President Blaise Compaore of Burkina Faso, a relative by marriage of Houphouet-Boigny, is revealed in the report as Mr Savimbi's closest remaining friend. Mr Savimbi has for years funded Mr Compaore's political campaigns at home and abroad, in Liberia in particular.

Last year, when Unita had a fuel crisis, Mr Compaore sent three planeloads of fuel to the rebels. "It was an absolutely clear breach of UN sanctions," said one UN official.

Mr Dachala has frequently visited Burkina Faso with diamonds and often met diamond and arms dealers there, according to the UN. "This is a man who Savimbi trusts with $100m of diamonds in a briefcase," said one UN official. "The threat of Interpol removing him from the scene would be serious for Savimbi."

An early version of the sanctions committee's report leaked at the weekend named President Omar Bongo of Gabon and Vice-President Paul Kagame of Rwanda as implicated in illegal traffic with Unita, but the two names have been withdrawn from the final report. "The first-hand evidence wasn't there," said a source in the committee. A statement from Kigali, the Rwandan capital, "categorically denied" the allegations.

Individuals from South Africa, Zambia, Congo-Brazzaville, Democratic Republic of Congo and Namibia are linked to arms procurement or diamond smuggling by Unita. In one case a high official is involved, but has not been named. South Africa has promised to take a tough line with any of its citizens who are named in the report.

A panel of experts has worked for six months to produce the sanctions committee's report, which is extremely detailed.

After six years, during which the committee did very little and the sanctions were ineffective enough for the rebel movement to rearm and resupply heavily for a major offensive, the committee's work was given fresh impetus by the appointment of the Canadian ambassador, Robert Fowler, as its chairman last year.

After the report has been debated in the security council this week, there will be a full UN debate on it next month, and a resolution on the action to be taken by member states.

webTitle: I don't feel defeated: I still seek justice

fields.headline: I don't feel defeated: I still seek justice
fields.standfirst: 'If they try to close the file and say, this is over, these four policemen might go out and do it again'  Kadiatou Diallo speaks for the first time of the acquittal of police who killed her son.
fields.trailText: The first time Kadiatou Diallo visited New York it was for a carefree week with friends, driving around the city and exploring restaurants. The next occasion was to collect the body of her son, Amadou, an innocent and unarmed black man who had been shot dead by four white policemen.
fields.body:
The first time Kadiatou Diallo visited New York it was for a carefree week with friends, driving around the city and exploring restaurants. The next occasion was to collect the body of her son, Amadou, an innocent and unarmed black man who had been shot dead by four white policemen.

"I just think, why did God choose me, why my son?" says Ms Diallo. She has not been assisted in her quest for an answer by the trial of the officers, which cleared them of all charges, from murdering the 22-year-old street trader down to reckless endangerment.

Since he was killed 13 months ago his name has become a byword for police brutality. His death is perhaps the most startling representation of what can happen when crime figures are driven down by official policies which funnel white fear and suspicion into the targeting of minorities.

In fact, the city is more than 60% non-white, though you would never know it if you spent most of your time below 96th street, in what Tom Wolfe described as the boutique of Manhattan.

Ms Diallo is talking in the 34th-floor offices of her lawyers, a block away from Wall Street, emblem of the economy that drives the unofficially segregated city.

A 40-year-old businesswoman from Africa, in a pistachio-coloured suit and black high-heels, her hair tied back in a bow, she is not an urban warrior. The details of, and motivation behind, the death of Amadou in the entrance to his apartment building have been disputed endlessly, but no one denies the dignity with which his mother has borne herself throughout the affair.

"It's not easy, I do it with prayers and by having faith," says Ms Diallo, a Muslim. "And my other children [two sons and a daughter, aged between 17 and 21] have given me a lot of moral support.

"In public maybe once or twice I have shown anger. But I am carrying the legacy of my son. Sometimes when I feel so sad I think of him in paradise. But people are looking through me at the image of my son. It's the first time we've had that kind of situation in my family.

"We have lots of support, all races and religions have come forward. Our purpose is to let the whole world know who he was and what kind of family he came from."

The police were looking for a rapist in the Bronx, one of the five boroughs of New York city, when they shot down Amadou. They thought he was reaching for a gun, when it was actually his wallet. They fired at him 41 times, 19 of the bullets hitting him.

Ms Diallo's hands move from a face that smiles more often than it might, and she sighs when asked about the trial verdicts. The case was moved 150 miles north to predominantly white Albany because it was decided that the officers would not get a fair hearing in the Bronx.

"I was shocked," she says. "I am a kind of person who does not try to seek something out of anger. But they had the opportunity of doing something better. This [the killing] could have happened to anyone. We expected to have something stronger than that from the case."

She is highly critical of the conduct of the prosecution. They kept saying the jury should put themselves in the shoes of the police. Amadou didn't come out in the trial. His side is also supposed to come out. But I don't feel defeated: we still seek justice," she says.

The justice department is considering a federal case against the policemen, a procedure used against the officers in the notorious beating of Rodney King in Los Angeles. Ms Diallo hopes that this will benefit both her family and the New York police department.

"That would be a way to help both sides. If they try to close the file and say this is over, these four men might go out and do it again," she says.

Ms Diallo has not allowed her grief to interfere with her purpose of securing justice for her son. Nor will she hear a word against Rev Al Sharpton, who marshalled the anger of the city after the death into a movement that put the case on the political map. "He's a very good man," she says. "Maybe he'll have a problem because he doesn't think twice when he sees something wrong, he just jumps in and helps."

Ms Diallo is aware of the accusation that the man hailed by some as a civil rights hero and by others as a charlatan has used her son's death to further his career. "If Rev Sharpton is mobilising people for the cause, people might criticise, but what I would say to them is: where were you when people came and helped our family?" she says firmly.

She has been away for close to a year from her job as a gold and bauxite mine manager, and believes that soon she might be dismissed. She has a very American attitude towards that possibility. "I'm not afraid of starting anew. I know I can make it, that's not a difficulty for me. What I have here is the most important thing. This is my son - that's more than anything for me. With an atrocity like that, you can't just turn the pages."

webTitle: US offers Vietnam defence ties but no regret

fields.headline: US offers Vietnam defence ties but no regret
fields.trailText: The US defence secretary, William Cohen, began a historic three-day trip to Vietnam yesterday, meeting government officials and visiting a paddy field site where a US jet fighter crashed during the Vietnam war.
fields.body:
The US defence secretary, William Cohen, began a historic three-day trip to Vietnam yesterday, meeting government officials and visiting a paddy field site where a US jet fighter crashed during the Vietnam war.

Mr Cohen said he had held "cordial and warm talks" with the Vietnamese defence minister, General Pham Van Tra, on developing modest military ties.

He stressed that both countries wanted to move carefully, and that joint efforts to account for the 2,000 US service personnel still listed as missing in action from the war would remain central.

As he spoke, scores of Vietnamese women shifted mud from the paddy field crash site as they searched for plane fragments and other remains.

Asked if he had encountered problems in his talks because of the war, in which South Vietnam, backed by the US, fell to the communist north in 1975, Mr Cohen said: "I did not detect any psychological baggage."

He added: "That we don't overestimate what can be established in a short period of time, that we take it step by step and engage in mutual confidence building measures - that will be the best way to achieve a much broader relationship with Vietnam."

Mr Cohen is the first US defence secretary to visit Vietnam since the end of the conflict, which killed about 58,000 US soldiers and an estimated 3m Vietnamese troops and civilians.

He repeatedly praised Hanoi for its increasing cooperation in helping resolve the issue of US troops missing in action.

Mr Cohen said that he and Mr Tra had discussed military medicine, de-mining and chemical dioxins that the US sprayed during the conflict.

Vietnam's vice-president, Nguyen Thi Binh, has said about 1m Vietnamese were victims of the dioxin Agent Orange, out of a population of 79m.

But Mr Cohen said at the weekend that the US would not make any apologies for the Vietnam war. Reuters

webTitle: Cook presses Croatia on war crimes

fields.headline: Cook presses Croatia on war crimes
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, yesterday urged the new Croatian government to hand over evidence of war crimes to the international tribunal at the Hague.
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, yesterday urged the new Croatian government to hand over evidence of war crimes to the international tribunal at the Hague.

Croatia's lack of cooperation with the tribunal poisoned the country's relations with western Europe during the regime of president Franjo Tudjman, who died last December. The tribunal has long insisted that Zagreb hand over documents relating to operations Flash and Storm, in which Serbs were driven out of the Krajina region of Croatia in 1995.

"They have started a process of handing over documents. I am very pleased that I've been able to witness what is, in all senses, a Zagreb spring," Mr Cook said yesterday before talks in Zagreb with President Stipe Mesic, Mr Tudjman's successor.

The tribunal believes that the documents may contain information which could lead to indictments for war crimes. British officials in Zagreb said there was a long way to go before all the requested papers were handed over.

Croatia has been angered by the recent 45-year sentence passed on a Bosnian Croat general, Tihomir Blaskic, for his part in the ethnic cleansing of Muslims during the 1992-95 Bosnian war. Blaskic's sentence was the heaviest handed down by the tribunal so far and has retarded moves to extradite one indicted suspect, the Bosnian Croat warlord Mladen "Tuta" Naletilic.

Mr Cook said last night that the trial of the former Bosnian Serb general Radislav Krstic, which opened at the Hague yesterday, showed that "ethnic identity was not a factor in the tribunal's pursuit of justice".

The foreign secretary also praised Croatia's new centre-left coalition government for promising to negotiate the return of Serb refugees expelled during the Bosnian war.

webTitle: Federal agents hunt for gunman in woods

fields.headline: Federal agents hunt for gunman in woods
fields.trailText: A 31-year-old electrician with a history of mental illness, who is wanted for shooting dead four people a week ago, was still at large in woods last night, eluding more than 100 police and FBI agents.
fields.body:
A 31-year-old electrician with a history of mental illness, who is wanted for shooting dead four people a week ago, was still at large in woods last night, eluding more than 100 police and FBI agents.

"Almost everybody is staying indoors," said Tony Tusing, a toys entrepreneur from Essex, outside Baltimore. "We've had businesses closing down early. Some of the main highways have been closed off. I can't believe one man is fooling the cops like he is."

Joseph Palczynski, who is thought to be wearing camouflage gear, carrying a handgun and to have a battery-powered television somewhere in the 95 square acres of woodland near his former home, has experience of living in the wild. Police called more than 1,700 homes in the area to warn people of the fugitive.

"It's a mess over here," said Kenneth Kincer, a local truck driver. "Everybody is in their house. I had sirens and helicopters screaming by my house just five minutes ago."

Mr Palczynski's mother, Patsy Long, said: "Please Joseph, I know you are tired, I know you are weary and I know you are sorry for what you have done. I don't want you hurting more people, because when you hurt people you hurt me."

Mr Palczynski fled from the area, about two miles from the site of three of the killings, last Tuesday and headed out of Maryland into Virginia. The shootings occurred after he tried to kidnap his former girlfriend from her boss's home.

Tracy Whithead, 22, had gone to stay with George and Gloria Shenk after their relationship collapsed. The electrician burst into their home and shot Mr and Mrs Shenk dead in front of children before turning his gun on a neighbour who tried to intervene.

Mr Palczynski got away with his former girldfriend but she later escaped. The next day he allegedly shot dead another woman and wounded two others during an attempted carjacking. Police believe he reached Virginia by hiding on a freight train.

fields.headline: Game over
fields.standfirst:
Meet Decland. He's 14, has 67
convictions and yesterday
became the first person to be
jailed for breaking an antisocial
behaviour order. Esther Addley
on the making of a one-person
crimewave
fields.trailText:
Meet Decland. He's 14, has 67
convictions and yesterday
became the first person to be
jailed for breaking an antisocial
behaviour order. Esther Addley
on the making of a one-person
crimewave
fields.body:
Mention the name Decland Madigan in Bulwell, and the reaction is extraordinary. "He wants putting down," says the man on the flower stall. "If he came in here on his own, I'd kill him." His partner interrupts with a story of how he cost her her business, stealing so much that she couldn't afford the insurance.

The man in the newsagent says he has caught him with a screwdriver trying to nick his car. He has seen him on the roof of the next-door shop, he says, and even heard of him trying to demolish, brick by brick, a wall that obstructs his joy-riding route. While he is talking a radio receiver crackles at his waist. Two of the boy's friends are coming down the high street. "Fifteen of us have radio links," he says. "If I see him or his cronies coming down I'll put a radio call out to the next two shops, and they will radio on down the road. It let's you know who's about, how many, a description. It's a good system, it works."

There is scarcely a soul in this Nottingham suburb, it seems, who does not have something to tell you about the boy the local papers long ago dubbed "a one-person crime wave". Madigan's claim to this moniker is alarmingly persuasive: at just 14 he has 67 convictions for car theft, robbery, assault and racially aggravated assault, driving while disqualified and without insurance, handling stolen goods, interfering with motor vehicles, public order offences and intimidating witnesses. He has spent three months in custody, since a high-speed car chase ended with him ramming into a police vehicle. When police stopped the car they found that Madigan, who is less than five feet tall, was sitting on a child's booster seat to see over the dashboard.

In January, he became the youngest person to be convicted of breaking an antisocial behaviour order (ASBO), a "contract" of prohibited behaviour aimed at reining in the behaviour of persistent trouble-makers. Yesterday, to the delight of many of his Bulwell neighbours, he became the first person to be jailed for breaching such an order. A Nottingham magistrate imposed a 12-month secure training order, taking the unusual step of ruling that Madigan should also be named publicly for the first time.

Madigan's story is one of a childhood derailed - and of the increasingly desperate attempts of officialdom to contain him. It will have echoes for police, social services and courts struggling to cope with persistent young offenders in many of Britain's poor suburbs.

A pretty market town with a weed-fringed stream and hilltop church, Bulwell would be full of tea rooms and Japanese tourists if it were in the Cotswolds. Instead it has been engulfed by housing estates and swallowed into Nottingham's northern suburbs. Forbidding pubs, arcades and a sad, greying Woolworth's spill out on to a pedestrianised market square. Groups of cheaply fashionable teenagers slouch around in their single-sex groups, flirting aggressively from opposite sides of the road.

Madigan's life was troubled almost from the start. His mother was killed in a car crash when he was just six weeks old. His father - an alcoholic, according to the council - suddenly left in sole charge of four children, was unable to cope. "It is suggested," the profile compiled by the council reads simply, "that he felt lost without his wife."

Things went downhill from there, it seems. By the age of eight Decland was no longer going to school. The council says he stopped attending, and that he defied several attempts to get him back into education. But Andrew Siddall, the boy's solicitor, says his father withdrew the boy briefly from school because he was being teased about his Irish name, and was unable to find another school willing to take him.

"He was quite keen to go to a local comprehensive," he says, "but he was only allowed to attend in the mornings. He was sent home before lunch, and so he wasn't able to mix with the other kids and make friends."

For a while, Madigan went to a special school, his reading and writing having fallen well behind. But he was frustrated by being taught alongside children with special needs, and stopped attending as soon as his friends found out he was going there. An experiment with a home tutor proved successful for a while, but the relationship soon broke down. "No matter what slant the education authority put on it, he was not taken back into school, and he was not provided with adequate educational facilities," says Siddall.

Madigan's "antisocial behaviour" began almost as soon as he left school. First it was riding his push bike on the pavements and forcing pedestrians out of the way. Then he progressed to motorbikes, which he had to steal. Then cars.

As he became increasingly well known in the area, says Jeff Whitmore, an inspector with the local police, he would attract groups of youths eager to be seen with him. Even the older kids, the 17- and 18-year olds, do what he says.

"There is something about Decland," says Whitmore, a genial, square-jawed man, with a direct gaze and a brow that crinkles when he talk about Madigan. "He has a very, very strong character. It's incredible, really, that this 14-year-old youth can have this effect."

The extent of the Madigan effect is clear from the boy's neighbours on the Crabtree Farm estate above the town. It's a bleak and strangely empty place, despite the thousands who live there.

One man's eyes cloud with genuine anxiety when Madigan's name is mentioned. "We are just so afraid of reprisals," he mutters, anxious that the playing children nearby won't hear. Specifying carefully what exactly can and cannot be said to identify him, he tells of vicious retribution "within an hour of him giving the order" on one occasion when he spoke out against the boy. Some of the stories he tells of the problems shopkeepers and neighbours have stretch one's credulity. But like Whitmore, there is a trace of almost pastoral warmth in his voice, too. "Police heavyhandedness in throwing him into prison will be no good for this boy. He doesn't need to put in prison, he needs a minder - he's never had that."

Siddall claims Madigan has become a whipping boy for youth crime in Nottingham. "Possibly he was an easy target, because he was relatively young. Because the system didn't allow for him to be locked up, he became a persistent offender. He became an easy target for politicians to say, 'Look, this lad has committed x numbers of offences in the last few weeks, and yet he is still walking free.'"

He points to the fact that the council leader, Graham Chapman, the council's anti-social behaviour team and inspector Whitmore all attended at court yesterday, waiting several hours for the hearing. As soon as the sentence was announced, Chapman convened a press conference in the waiting area of the youth court. "This is a 14-year-old lad who is no worse than many who have appeared in the youth courts," says Siddall. "I don't think for a minute he could understand why all these people had taken an interest in him, why people wanted to put him on television, why people wanted to report about his case."

It's a bleak and strangely empty place, despite the thousands who live there. One man's eyes cloud with genuine anxiety when Madigan's name is mentioned. "We are just so afraid of reprisals," he mutters, anxious that the playing children nearby won't hear. Specifying carefully what exactly can and cannot be said to identify him, he tells of vicious retribution "within an hour of him giving the order" on one occasion when he spoke out against the boy. Some of the stories he tells of the problems shopkeepers and neighbours have stretch one's credulity. But like Whitmore, there is a trace of almost pastoral warmth in his voice, too. "Police heavyhandedness in throwing him into prison will be no good for this boy. He doesn't need to put in prison, he needs a minder - he's never had that." Siddall claims Madigan has become a whipping boy for youth crime in Nottingham. "Possibly he was an easy target, because he was relatively young. Because the system didn't allow for him to be locked up, he became a persistent offender. He became an easy target for politicians to say, 'Look, this lad has committed x numbers of offences in the last few weeks, and yet he is still walking free.'" He points to the fact that the council leader, Graham Chapman, the council's anti-social behaviour team and inspector Whitmore all attended at court yesterday, waiting several hours for the hearing. As soon as the sentence was announced, Chapman convened a press conference in the waiting area of the youth court. "This is a 14-year-old lad who is no worse than many who have appeared in the youth courts," says Siddall. "I don't think for a minute he could understand why all these people had taken an interest in him, why people wanted to put him on television, why people wanted to report about his case."

fields.headline: Sex on the edge
fields.standfirst: How can a man with Aids defend the practice of having unprotected sex with his gay partners? That's just what Nigel Wrench, the presenter of BBC's PM programme, has done in an article in the Pink Paper. He explains the growing phenomenon of 'barebacki

How can a man with Aids defend the practice of
having unprotected sex with his gay partners? That's
just what Nigel Wrench, the presenter of BBC's
PM programme, has done in an article in the Pink

'barebacking' to Matt Wells
fields.body:
Nigel Wrench is used to taking risks. Before an awards ceremony where his radio show was up for a gong, he decided to use the acceptance speech to reveal he was HIV-positive. Given that the programme was up against two rivals, there was only a one-in-three chance that his BBC bosses would find out. They did.

Wrench, now the presenter of Radio 4's teatime news programme PM, has just made another confession: this time in the gay press. Taking a chance that no one outside the Pink Paper's readership circle would notice, he wrote: "Since I've been HIV-positive, I've had 'unsafe' sex more times than I can remember, often with men whose names I could not tell you now."

Even to many gay men, it is a startling admission. For the safe sex message, like the early anti-drugs campaigns, has been unequivocal. Use condoms or you'll get Aids and die horribly. Even more important, if you have Aids, use a condom always - even if you know your partner is positive too.

But, as the "just say no" brigade discovered, telling people not to do something usually has the opposite effect. As with drug use, unprotected sex among gay men, particularly among those who are HIV-positive, is on the increase almost to the point of normality. It's so normal that personal advertisers and internet chatroom users have come up with a name for it. It's called barebacking.

Until now, it's a practice that has been confined to the anonymous locations of internet chatrooms, personal ads, cruising areas and London's underground sex-club scene. But Wrench's admission, although he is at pains to stress that he only has unprotected sex with other men who are also HIV positive, will shock even the most tolerant of Hampstead liberals. And it is a confession which is dangerous for the journalist himself, given his high-profile role as one of the presenters of Radio 4's prime-time afternoon news show, PM.

The article in the Pink Paper - where Wrench, 39, is a regular columnist on HIV and Aids issues - was framed in candid terms. "The first guy I ever fucked without a condom gave me HIV," he opened. "What's more, that night on Hampstead Heath, he wanted me to fuck him without a condom." He went on: "I am not part of some Aids army out to recruit everyone who comes anywhere near. I simply seek to point out that there is a rational debate to be had." And he concluded: "Barebacking can be warm, exciting and involving. We need to debate it. But don't let's start by writing it off as irresponsible and stupid. That, frankly, is both absurd and dangerous."

Wrench became HIV-positive in 1993 and now has full-blown Aids which is under control thanks to a combination of drugs. Clearly, he is determined to be heard. His message is simple: knee-jerk condemnation of men who have unprotected anal sex by choice is pointless.

Among sexual health professionals, it is a view which has gained currency. For a year or two now, groups involved in health promotion have been steering away from the stark "always use a condom" message towards encouraging men to make an informed choice. An authoritative survey of 10,000 gay men by the Terrence Higgins Trust showed that one in three had unprotected anal sex at least once in the previous year.

When the Guardian published an article in 1991 describing the prevalence of unprotected sex among gay men in London clubs, protesters picketed the newspaper's offices. Now, such is the change in climate that it is hard to find many informed commentators who will disagree very much with what Wrench says.

Still, among many ordinary gay men, the reaction is one of horror, as a glance at the letters pages of the gay press will testify. Before Wrench wrote his piece, the editor of the gay listings magazine Boyz, David Hudson, penned an editorial in response to the internet barebacking phenomenon, where at the extreme you can find personal ads for men who want to become HIV positive, and dates for "sero-conversion parties". This is dancing right at the precipice of sexual edge-play - and is a practice which Wrench does not seek to defend or support - but it is certainly going on. To what extent, no one really knows.

While those who defend the practice claim it is the "ultimate expression of intimacy", Hudson brands its practitioners simply selfish. "I thought if you cared about someone, you'd want to do your best to protect them, not put their lives at risk - or your own. I hate to be the reminder of depressing news, but although there have been great advances in drug treatments, there is still no cure for Aids and there is no drug that can totally eliminate HIV from the body."

Whether deliberately or not, men are having unprotected sex with men, every night of the week. Many of these encounters are between men who know they are HIV-positive. Some, inevitably, are not. As the opportunities for wild, anonymous sex increase, the risk of more men becoming infected with HIV is increasing too.

Few outside the gay circle probably know it, but there are now around a dozen clubs in London where sex on the premises is actively encouraged, as well as numerous "saunas" and "steam rooms". The London Apprentice has closed since the Guardian made it the focus of the piece in 1991, but scan the pages of the gay listings weeklies and the phenomenon is there for the initiated to see. The description "cruisy atmosphere" is usually the giveaway. That means that there is an area of the club, maybe a separate room, where you can have sex with anyone who takes your fancy. It's steamy, sweaty, and the clubs can't pack them in tighter. If nothing else, sex in a "backroom" is a far more inviting prospect than a shivery fumble on Hampstead Heath.

The practice is probably illegal, but the law doesn't get involved. The crimes committed are classed as "victimless", and the police have taken the decision that there are better ways for them to be spending their money. So the ball is firmly in the court of the "gay community", whatever that is.

Almost a decade after those protests at the Guardian's offices, Wrench says that it is time to acknowledge reality. "Lots of people are barebacking. We do need to talk about it and we do need to say these are the choices we're making in having unprotected sex, and we are aware of these choices, so as to make those choices more informed."

Hence the provocative language of his Pink Paper article. "I think that having unprotected sex is something that people just don't talk about, even in the gay community where you can talk about everything. It is the unspoken. It is something that other people do. Because everybody knows people who are dying, it is unacceptable. That makes it very hard for people to speak about it, I think precisely because of the Aids crisis, because everybody knows somebody who's died, everybody knows somebody with HIV."

While he insists that he has never had unprotected sex with a partner who was not aware of his HIV status, Wrench says it is not good enough to confer on to HIV-positive men total responsibility for disclosing their status to their partner. His argument is that to do so is actually a highly dan gerous strategy, since it assumes that, in that dark room, every HIV-positive man is going to wipe the sweat from his brow and smoke from his eyes, and shout above the thumping dance beat: "I've got Aids." It's just not a realistic proposition.

"I think it is the responsibility of both people," Wrench says. "To say otherwise is dangerous to both sides. It says that men who are negative are going to assume that men who are positive are going to tell them. That is assuming the opposite of what the safe sex message is all about. It assumes that all men with Aids are going to declare their status."

It is a powerful argument, and it is a message which the health promotion groups are now actively pursuing in their campaigns.

Matthew Hodson, a project worker for Gay Men Fighting Aids, an organisation that works in London, seeks to persuade gay men that the choices they make have to be informed. "If you are both positive, it is fairly easy to establish, but if you are both negative, that is where you are only as safe as your last test result."

He stresses that protected sex is still the safest, but acknowledges that this is not the right message for all gay men. "The best advice I can offer someone who does not want to become HIV positive is that they shouldn't have unprotected anal intercourse. But if they really want to have unprotected anal intercourse then the pay-off is talking about testing and testing again, three months later."

It is a "harm reduction" strategy. Two men in a monogamous relationship, for instance, might want to dispense with the prophylactic. His advice would be to talk about it, ensure that the relationship is founded on trust - so that if one partner does have risky sex, it can be discussed. It is a much more complicated message, and as such, far more difficult to get across. "I can't pretend that is an easy strategy," says Hodson. "The simplest advice is that if you have sex, use a condom."

Colin Dixon, the assistant director of the Terrence Higgins Trust, a nationwide organisation which does not just work with gay men, says that the "harm reduction" debate is one which organisations such as his went through a couple of years ago. But he suggests that men who have HIV must think carefully about their status. Choosing his words carefully, he says: "Men with HIV do have a key role."

This is just about as far as anyone in the field is prepared to go. For to do otherwise would be to stigmatise HIV positive men: and to alienate this group is simply to exclude them from the process. As Wrench wrote in his Pink Paper article: "It's absurd to attempt to corral into a corner those who choose to have unprotected sex, and label them as pariahs."

It is time, argues Wrench, that the views of men living with HIV and Aids were heard. "I think that what you want to do is to make sure people are making an informed decision. We are not somehow 'other', we are people with sex lives, we are having sex and it is important for our views to be heard. We are not people who want to be preached at, but we are people who are responsible, who are making responsible decisions about our sex lives."
