webTitle: The used to be rich list

fields.headline: The used to be rich list
fields.standfirst: They used to be loaded. Some of them were even in those tedious rich lists the Sunday newspapers produce each year. Now they've lost it - or most of it.  Emma Brockes charts 10 people who ended the last century on a low
fields.trailText: They used to be loaded. Some of them were even in those tedious rich lists the Sunday newspapers produce each year. Now they've lost it - or most of it.  Emma Brockes charts 10 people who ended the last century on a low
fields.body:
Sultan of Brunei: Loss: £20bn
Five years ago, he was worth more than £40bn and by far the world's richest man. Last year, however, Forbes magazine valued him at about half that and only number three in the world (the Microsoft founder, Bill Gates, was at number one), a result of his younger brother Prince Jefri's reckless spending. Prince Jefri is said to have 2,000 cars and 17 aircraft, reducing the sultan's coffers to what one recent report put at under £10bn. The sultan decided to sue his brother last month.

Warren Buffet:Loss: £20bn
Buffet, the so-called Sage of Omaha whose investment company is the phenomenally successful Berkshire Hathaway, makes a surprise entry on this year's list after his failure to invest in the dot.com boom and continuing his strategy of relying on blue-chip certainties such as Coca-Cola. For the first time since 1990, Buffet's company recorded an annual decline, when the share price dropped by half.

St Michael: Loss: £6bn
By September of last year, M&S clothing sales were down by 10% since the previous year, and the 1997 sales recorded a 10% drop as well. Annual profit estimates were trimmed by somewhere between £30m and £60m, to be brought as low as £600m. Over the past three years, the market value of M&S has almost halved from £14bn to £6.6bn. With the sturdy old ompany looking to a new line of lingerie to dig it out of the hole, things couldn't be grimmer.

Lord Sainsbury: Loss: £200m
The supermarket magnate was one of the biggest losers in the 1999 Sunday Times Rich list, with his wealth dropping from the 1998 figure of £3,300m to £3,100m, a change attributed to a fall in the value of the company's shares.

Jacques, Duke of Orleans: Debt: £30m
If the French Revolution had never happened, Jacques, Duke of Orleans's father would have been King Henri VI of France. Unfortunately, he could only claim succession to the much lesser title of Count of Paris, which was none the less thought to be worth some £400m when it became his in 1940. By 1999, that figure was nearer £36.8m, a sum his son Jacques, the oldest of 11 children, might sensibly have imagined to be heading his way when his father died last June. On inspecting the accounts and his father's estate, however, young Jacques found some £30m missing, mainly in priceless trinkets and jewellery that once belonged to Marie Antoinette. What remained, the count left to the St Louis Foundation, having maintained a profound dislike for his offspring all his life. Jacques did not come away empty-handed, however, inheriting six handkerchiefs and a pair of slippers.

Joe and Katherine Jackson: Loss: up to £30m
Michael and Janet Jackson's parents filed for bankruptcy in March last year, claiming debts of up to £30m and joining the pop stars' brothers Tito, Jermaine and Randy, who went bust years earlier after failing to pull off solo careers when the Jackson Five collapsed. Several members of the family were ordered to pay £1.1m in a lawsuit, for backing out of a deal to buy a guitar company in 1994. Mr and Mrs Jackson have already sold off one of their Rolls-Royces and are thought to be preparing to auction the piano on which Michael composed Thriller.

Jonathan Aitken: Debt: estimated £13m
He may have paid his debt to society after a spell as prisoner CB9298 in Belmarsh prison, but the former first secretary to the treasury still owes creditors an estimated £13m after his failed libel action against the Guardian and Granada Television. Aitken faces a £2.4m bill for costs after lying about his 1993 trip to the Paris Ritz, but legal sources estimate this to be just 15% of his total liabilities. Last May, he applied for bankruptcy and while managing to hang on to his £1.8m home in Lord North Street, had to sell off a nice Rolex Oyster watch and a pair of Asprey's cufflinks.

Stephen Humphries: Loss: £750,000
Humphries holds the title for Most Lost in a Single Day. At 19 years old, after a brief career as a footballer for Reading FC, Humphries became a freelance, or "local" trader on the Liffe exchange, specialising in government gilts. For three years he traded successfully, earning up to £100,000 a month and living with wife and two children in Surrey. On July 5 last year, he joined John Sussex Futures and on Friday, August 6, he met his destiny. At 8.30am, he was £1,000 up. At 11am, he was £400 down. That figure rapidly rose to £12,000, then £20,000 when, in a state of mounting panic, he accidentally hit the "buy" instead of "sell" button. In a desperate bid to save himself by controlling the market, Humphries kept on buying. By 4.30pm when he left the trading floor, he had run up a debt of £743,7000, not in Nick Leeson's £850m league, but not bad for a day's work.

Neil Hamilton: Debt: £500,000
Hamilton, the disgraced former Conservative MP for Tatton, has had a temporary stay of execution on the £500,000 he owes towards the £2m legal bill for his failed libel action against Mohamed Al Fayed, but his £750,000 Georgian house and all its contents aren't safe until a final judgement is made. Hamilton was plunged into the red in February when the high court ordered him to pay £500,000 towards Al Fayed's legal costs after he had unsuccessfully sued him over the "cash for questions" allegations. Hamilton, a strong contender in the moral bankruptcy Top 10, described his state as "penniless" and admitted just before Christmas, "yes, I do feel broken".

Eddie Grundy: Loss: everything
The demise of Ambridge's favourite farmer has gripped fans of the agricultural radio soap right up to its devastating climax: Eddie and Clarrie Grundy's notice to quit Grange Farm and their declaration of bankruptcy, a chillingly accurate portrait of farming in the new millennium that left Eddie and Clarrie destitute and Joe wandering about an art gallery in Ambridge, muttering to himself.

That figure rapidly rose to £12,000, then £20,000 when, in a state of mounting panic, he accidentally hit the "buy" instead of "sell" button. In a desperate bid to save himself by controlling the market, Humphries kept on buying. By 4.30pm when he left the trading floor, he had run up a debt of £743,7000, not in Nick Leeson's £850m league, but not bad for a day's work. Neil Hamilton: Debt: £500,000 Hamilton, the disgraced former Conservative MP for Tatton, has had a temporary stay of execution on the £500,000 he owes towards the £2m legal bill for his failed libel action against Mohamed Al Fayed, but his £750,000 Georgian house and all its contents aren't safe until a final judgement is made. Hamilton was plunged into the red in February when the high court ordered him to pay £500,000 towards Al Fayed's legal costs after he had unsuccessfully sued him over the "cash for questions" allegations. Hamilton, a strong contender in the moral bankruptcy Top 10, described his state as "penniless" and admitted just before Christmas, "yes, I do feel broken". Eddie Grundy: Loss: everything The demise of Ambridge's favourite farmer has gripped fans of the agricultural radio soap right up to its devastating climax: Eddie and Clarrie Grundy's notice to quit Grange Farm and their declaration of bankruptcy, a chillingly accurate portrait of farming in the new millennium that left Eddie and Clarrie destitute and Joe wandering about an art gallery in Ambridge, muttering to himself.

fields.headline: No: 1593 Clive James
fields.trailText: Name: Clive Vivian Leopold James.
fields.body:
Name: Clive Vivian Leopold James.

Age: 60.

Appearance: "Lightbulb features, squat, toad-like shoulders and a bull neck," according to one vitriolic critic (he has many). A curious mix of egghead and couch potato.

Description: Wit, intellectual, poet, lyricist, novelist, memoirist, critic, TV presenter, linguist, essayist... I could go on, but I've got some low-quality Japanese game shows to mock.

Ah, yes - Saturday Night Clive. Never did square with the thoughtful polymath image, did it? Detractors have long suggested that chuckling patronisingly at cockroach-eating southeast Asian quiz contestants might be a little too... well, easy.

Clive disagrees, doubtless. Well, he's always claimed to suffer from "a personality failing which can only be solved by exposing myself to millions of people at a time" - but now it seems he might have changed his mind.

He's off? It looks that way. James has announced that he's turning down a new ITV contract rumoured to be worth £500,000, quitting the "tyranny" of television to spend more time writing.

What's his problem? He was one of ITV's highest-paid presenters, but says TV lacks intellectual stimulation.

Well, pardon me for asking. Just don't accuse of him of being a prima donna. Or as Clive puts it: "I don't do star things, I don't have the star trappings, I have no star behaviour, no star houses, no star existence."

Famous lady-friends, though. You mean Diana, with whom the happily married James had a deep platonic relationship. Hell, he even smuggled her into the studio to watch him record his show.

Friends say: "He knows a great deal about most subjects" (George Melly).

Enemies say: " He pretends to be an irreverent figure, but in fact is a cringing man on the make" (Auberon Waugh).

Programme pitches most likely to lure James from retirement: Cl!veTV (acerbic relaunch for the unwatched cable channel); Clive and Kicking (Saturday morning kids' show - but with a razor-sharp edge of acid humour).

webTitle: Burmah Castrol may go to BP for £5bn

fields.headline: Burmah Castrol may go to BP for £5bn
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
BP Amoco
fields.trailText: BP Amoco yesterday confirmed it was back on the takeover trail with talks over the possible acquisition of Burmah Castrol in a potential £5bn deal.
fields.body:
BP Amoco yesterday confirmed it was back on the takeover trail with talks over the possible acquisition of Burmah Castrol in a potential £5bn deal.

Shares in Burmah Castrol raced ahead 33% at one stage yesterday to £12.85 and ended at £12.45, while BP finished the day down 3p at 549p.

BP Amoco's shares have been in the doldrums since a £16bn planned purchase of Atlantic Richfield in the United States became embroiled in a legal wrangle with the federal trade commission.

But chairman Sir John Browne made clear at a recent meeting that he remained aggressively expansionist. He had refused to comment on speculation that talks with Burmah Castrol were back on the agenda after early talks broke down last year.

However, a spokesman yesterday confirmed the negotiations but declined to give further details. This followed a formal statement from Burmah Castrol after a precipitous rise in the firm's shares. It said: "Burmah Castrol confirms that it is in discussions with BP Amoco which may or may not lead to an offer for the company."

At the £12.85 price Burmah Castrol would be worth £2.3bn, but City analysts said BP would have to pay at least double that to win control of a company which is in sound shape after a £150m restructuring. Burmah Castol recently announced a record pre-tax profit of £259m, up 5% and ahead of City foreasts.

BP Amoco has been interested in a deal ever since regulators required the unravelling of a BP Amoco joint venture with Mobil following that company's merger with Exxon.

"Put the BP Amoco muscle behind Burmah and they could displace Mobil," said Philip Morrish analyst with AE Sharp Securities.

Burham Castol would benefit from its range of lubricants being sold at BP Amoco's 8,900 service stations across Europe.

webTitle: Fiat steers out of skid with GM tie-up

fields.headline: Fiat steers out of skid with GM tie-up
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
General Motors
Fiat
fields.trailText: Massive competition and serious overcapacity in domestic markets, growing research and development costs, plus mounting pressure from the green lobby: it is no wonder carmakers are steering towards defensive alliances such as the one announced yesterday by General Motors and Fiat.
fields.body:
Massive competition and serious overcapacity in domestic markets, growing research and development costs, plus mounting pressure from the green lobby: it is no wonder carmakers are steering towards defensive alliances such as the one announced yesterday by General Motors and Fiat.

After all, these are the giants of the "old" economy. While the new telecoms and technology companies tend to have few staff, limited physical assets but tons of hope and potential, automobile makers have thousands of staff, dozens of plants and storm clouds obscuring the view through the front windscreen.

Consolidation and globalisation are the pre-occupations of the motor industry, as it has been in bastions of the old world such as the oil business. But while the BPs and Exxons have been swallowing their rivals, car groups often have been forced to consider more limited equity swaps and alliances. This has partly been done to appease local politi cians who still see a car industry as a symbol of national pride as well as a source of jobs.

Ironically the all-important American market, home of the two biggest car companies GM and Ford, has been in good shape recently on the back of a fast-growing economy. By contrast Europe has been suffering badly.

But US companies worry about what happens when home demand begins to sag and believe a restructured continental market still offers future opportunities.

GM last year reported after-tax profits from continuing operations of $5.69bn as it took advantage of a strong domestic performance, although its German subidiary Opel is heavily in the red, its UK arm Vauxhall has tiny profit margins and its Swedish interest Saab is recovering from a string of losses.

GM believes a tie-up with Fiat offers another major step into western Europe, where Fiat holds an 11% market share, plus the opportunity to cut costs and pool resources. Rival Ford last year tied up its own deal with the acquisition of Volvo Cars but has also chopped 1,500 jobs at its Dagenham plant in England amid speculation that one or more of its European plants could be shut down.

Both Ford and GM have also been looking at expanding into Asia where growing personal wealth and less competition gives them opportunities denied at home.

The Asian currency crisis demolished home markets but they have been picking up fast again at a time when indigenous manufacturers are burdened by debt.

GM already holds interests in Japanese carmakers. It has a 49% stake in Isuzu and 10% in Suzuki while Germany's Daim lerChrysler is in advanced talks with Mitsubishi for a 34% stake. Renault of France last year spent $5.4bn purchasing a 37% stake in Nissan while both GM and Fiat have been considering bids for troubled Daewoo Motors in Korea.

For the Europeans a tie-up with North America has obvious attractions. Fiat, which accumulated $500m of losses over the past 15 months but expects to make profits this year, has no serious presence in the US.

Gianni Agnelli, honorary chairman of Fiat which also produces Alfa Romeo, Maserati and Ferrari cars, has watched Fiat's share of the Italian market shrink from 60% to less than 40% in recent years.

The Agnelli family, which holds a 30% stake in Fiat, has spent the last six months denying a tie-up was on the cards but investors have ignored them and dealing in the company's shares has been feverish.

The only question in most peoples minds was whether it would be GM or DaimlerChrysler who tied the knot. GM was the preferred partner but DaimlerChrysler is not completely out of the running and might still make a last attempt to break up the party.

Speculation abounds on the next likely target of globalisation and consolidation. BMW and Peugeot Citroen are the two most likely in Europe. Like Fiat they are largely controlled by family interests - the Quandts and Peugeots respectively - but shareholders have had their patience stretched by difficulties such as those suffered by BMW's UK subsidiary Rover.

Full takeovers offer the greatest chance of cost-cutting but the more limited alliances and cross-shareholdings allow participants the chance to share R&D in a world where new models can cost between $1bn and $2bn to develop and there is increasing pressure to produce environmentally-friendly cars and engines. Partnerships also allow big savings to be made in the joint procurement of components and help in the move to provide common plat forms or chassis for a range of different models.

But perhaps most importantly they are a politically acceptable way for closer cooperation and make it easier should one partner decide to pursue a full takeover later on.

In the past car companies could rely on governments worldwide bailing them out if things got really tough. But £151m of public money given by Whitehall to encourage BMW to build a new generation of car at Longbridge near Birmingham is being challenged by Brussels and Professor Kumar Bhattacharrya , an industry expert at Warwick University, says grants are going to be harder to come by in future.

webTitle: Intel sizes up mothballed LG plant

fields.headline: Intel sizes up mothballed LG plant
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report Intel
fields.trailText: Intel, the world's largest manufacturer of computer chips, could set up its first British fabrication operation by acquiring the mothballed LG Semicon plant in south Wales.
fields.body:
Intel, the world's largest manufacturer of computer chips, could set up its first British fabrication operation by acquiring the mothballed LG Semicon plant in south Wales.

The company has been holding talks with the Welsh Development Agency about the state-of-the-art Newport facility as part of a worldwide search for opportunities to increase its fabrication capacity.

Intel employs around 3,000 people at two plants near Dublin but has no other European manufacturing operations.

It recently announced plans to acquire a plant in Colorado Springs to increase production of flash memory chips for use in mobile phones. A spokesman said yesterday that nothing had been agreed but confirmed that talks about the Newport site were continuing.

News of Intel's continuing interest raises hopes that the south Wales economy may yet reap the full benefit of the hi-tech jobs promised when LG announced what was Europe's biggest inward investment in July 1996.

More than 2,000 jobs have already been created at a computer monitor plant operated by the Korean group's electronics arm. But hopes that a further 1,700 would be created by the end of this year at the adjacent wafer fabrication plant alongside the M4 were dashed in the face of the far eastern economic crisis and a slump in computer chip prices.

The LG Semicon operations were subsequently merged with those of Hyundai as part of a rationalisation of Korea's leading conglomerates. While work on the external structure of the Newport plant is complete, fitting out of the fabrication facility has been on hold since the merger of the two group's semiconductor operations was first mooted.

The Welsh Development Agency, which took a lead role in securing the LG investment four years ago, said yesterday it had been working closely with Hyundai to achieve a satisfactory outcome to the Newport situation.

A WDA spokesman said: "No decision has been reached at this stage about the future use of the plant.

"But given the quality of the facility and its strategic location we are confident that this development will ultimately prove to be a major source of high skilled jobs and an important economic asset to Wales."

webTitle: Oppression in the name of the state

fields.headline: Oppression in the name of the state
fields.standfirst: The new terrorism bill embraces everyone from armed extremist to GM activist
fields.trailText: The new terrorism bill embraces everyone from armed extremist to GM activist
fields.body:
Not long ago, when Labour was in opposition, Lord Williams of Mostyn warned his fellow peers: "If we condemn our citizens to the possibility of 10 years imprisonment on the basis of reasonable suspicion... we are in serious danger of giving terrorism a victory that it would not otherwise achieve". The legislation, he said, was "far too harsh and draconian". He warned it would "bring us into serious conflict with the European convention on human rights".

He was referring to new clauses in the prevention of terrorism act introduced by the previous Conservative administration. They have been described by Lord Bingham, the lord chief justice, as undermining "in a blatant and obvious way" the basic right of a defendant to be presumed innocent until proved guilty.

Lord Williams is now attorney general. Surprise, surprise, the clauses which as an opposition home affairs spokesman he so roundly condemned now reappear as a central feature of Labour's new terrorism bill.

Under the bill, to be debated by MPs tomorrow before going to the Lords, it will be a criminal offence to possess any "article" or "information", including photographs, in circumstances which give rise to a " reasonable suspicion" they would be used for "terrorist" purposes - a clause which has serious implications, not least for journalists. It will also be a criminal offence to withhold from the police any knowledge of "terrorist" activities.

All these clauses reverse the burden of proof - it will be up to the accused to prove their innocence, in other words,to prove a negative, a task which Bingham, and other judges (agreeing with Lord Williams before he entered government) have said is incompatible with article 6 of the European convention.

That is not all. The definition of terrorism in the bill includes "the use or threat , for the purpose of advancing a political, religious, or ideological cause , of action which involves serious violence against any person or property " (italics added). This could embrace not only armed extremists but also environmental activists attacking GM crops.

For the first time, the term "terrorism" will apply to domestic groups which can be proscribed by the home secretary. It will be an offence to "provide money or other property" which may be used "for the purposes of terrorism" and not tell the police when you suspect others of doing so.

It will be a criminal offence to speak at the same meeting as someone from a proscribed organisation. As Deborah Clark, parliamentary officer of the civil rights group Liberty, has pointed out, this will have the peculiar result of making it a criminal offence to oppose such an organisation. The meeting could be of no more than three people, private or public. It could be a an informal gathering or a discussion in a pub.

The bill also introduces a criminal offence of "incitement" - an offence which could catch, for example, anyone calling for the overthrow of undemocratic regimes abroad. It would have caught Nelson Mandela and other ANC leaders who supported armed struggle against the apartheid regime in South Africa and those who opposed the illegal Indonesian occupation of east Timor.

The bill gives the police an array of sweeping new powers and in effect sets up a parallel criminal justice system wide open to abuse and far beyond the provisions of the police and criminal evidence act. It gives them stop and search powers on the basis of "expediency" and of "suspicion", not of committing any offence, but of being connected, or potentially connected, to the bill's vague description of "terrorism".

The bill is strongly opposed by the Northern Ireland human rights commission, a statutory body set up by the Good Friday agreement. Brice Dickson, its chief commissioner, yesterday described the bill's definition of terrorism as "seriously flawed". By concentrating on motivation, it included activity which the vast majority of the public would not regard as terrorism, while excluding gangs of racketeers or drug-runners, for example, engaged in serious criminal activities.

Yet as it sailed through its Commons committee stage MPs scarcely raised an eyebrow. Charles Clarke, the home office minister, claimed the bill was aimed at those who seek to "undermine democratic processes by the use of violence". Yet as Dickson points out, "there is no wording in the bill which remotely reflects this intention".

It was left to Simon Hughes, the Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, to oppose what he described as a measure "threatening the liberties of all our constituents and giving powers to the state that throw the relationship between the state and the individual out of balance". British juries, he added, would have to make political assessments about what constituted "terrorism" abroad. British citizens potentially caught by the bill - anyone who on "ideological" grounds attacked an animal-testing laboratory, for example - could be dealt with by existing criminal law.

Clarke, who has likened the bill to "motherhood and apple pie", swept all such concerns aside. The bill had been drafted, he said, so it could deal with all sorts of "suspicious circumstances" such as someone "having coffee grinders in every cupboard or car boots full of fertiliser in the middle of London".

Remarkably, he dismissed Hughes' objections that the bill could catch dissident groups fighting dictatorships or oppression by asserting: "It is vital to understand that the world has changed ... endangering the lives of innocent people are crimes, whatever the ... motivation or however corrupt the regime they are fighting against". Beware then, those who incite attacks against Saddam Hussein, or the Taliban regime in Afghanistan.

Despite - when he was in opposition - the attorney general's savage criti cism of clauses included in the new terrorism bill, Jack Straw now insists they are compatible with the European convention on human rights. The home office refuses to disclose its legal advice.

The Belfast-based human rights commission has little doubt the bill contravenes the convention, not least in a section applying to Northern Ireland which states that a mere assertion by an RUC officer that someone is a member of a proscribed organisation is admissible evidence.

Clarke appears to recognise that the terrorism bill is indeed open to abuse. But don't worry, he seems to be saying, defendants can rely on the police; and if not them, the courts; and, if absolutely necessary, a jury, being "reasonable" in their interpretation of it. That is cold comfort.

The legislation, he said, was "far too harsh and draconian". He warned it would "bring us into serious conflict with the European convention on human rights". He was referring to new clauses in the prevention of terrorism act introduced by the previous Conservative administration. They have been described by Lord Bingham, the lord chief justice, as undermining "in a blatant and obvious way" the basic right of a defendant to be presumed innocent until proved guilty. Lord Williams is now attorney general. Surprise, surprise, the clauses which as an opposition home affairs spokesman he so roundly condemned now reappear as a central feature of Labour's new terrorism bill. Under the bill, to be debated by MPs tomorrow before going to the Lords, it will be a criminal offence to possess any "article" or "information", including photographs, in circumstances which give rise to a " reasonable suspicion" they would be used for "terrorist" purposes - a clause which has serious implications, not least for journalists. It will also be a criminal offence to withhold from the police any knowledge of "terrorist" activities. All these clauses reverse the burden of proof - it will be up to the accused to prove their innocence, in other words,to prove a negative, a task which Bingham, and other judges (agreeing with Lord Williams before he entered government) have said is incompatible with article 6 of the European convention. That is not all. The definition of terrorism in the bill includes "the use or threat , for the purpose of advancing a political, religious, or ideological cause , of action which involves serious violence against any person or property " (italics added). This could embrace not only armed extremists but also environmental activists attacking GM crops. For the first time, the term "terrorism" will apply to domestic groups which can be proscribed by the home secretary. It will be an offence to "provide money or other property" which may be used "for the purposes of terrorism" and not tell the police when you suspect others of doing so. It will be a criminal offence to speak at the same meeting as someone from a proscribed organisation. As Deborah Clark, parliamentary officer of the civil rights group Liberty, has pointed out, this will have the peculiar result of making it a criminal offence to oppose such an organisation. The meeting could be of no more than three people, private or public. It could be a an informal gathering or a discussion in a pub. The bill also introduces a criminal offence of "incitement" - an offence which could catch, for example, anyone calling for the overthrow of undemocratic regimes abroad. It would have caught Nelson Mandela and other ANC leaders who supported armed struggle against the apartheid regime in South Africa and those who opposed the illegal Indonesian occupation of east Timor. The bill gives the police an array of sweeping new powers and in effect sets up a parallel criminal justice system wide open to abuse and far beyond the provisions of the police and criminal evidence act. It gives them stop and search powers on the basis of "expediency" and of "suspicion", not of committing any offence, but of being connected, or potentially connected, to the bill's vague description of "terrorism". The bill is strongly opposed by the Northern Ireland human rights commission, a statutory body set up by the Good Friday agreement. Brice Dickson, its chief commissioner, yesterday described the bill's definition of terrorism as "seriously flawed". By concentrating on motivation, it included activity which the vast majority of the public would not regard as terrorism, while excluding gangs of racketeers or drug-runners, for example, engaged in serious criminal activities. Yet as it sailed through its Commons committee stage MPs scarcely raised an eyebrow. Charles Clarke, the home office minister, claimed the bill was aimed at those who seek to "undermine democratic processes by the use of violence". Yet as Dickson points out, "there is no wording in the bill which remotely reflects this intention". It was left to Simon Hughes, the Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, to oppose what he described as a measure "threatening the liberties of all our constituents and giving powers to the state that throw the relationship between the state and the individual out of balance". British juries, he added, would have to make political assessments about what constituted "terrorism" abroad. British citizens potentially caught by the bill - anyone who on "ideological" grounds attacked an animal-testing laboratory, for example - could be dealt with by existing criminal law. Clarke, who has likened the bill to "motherhood and apple pie", swept all such concerns aside. The bill had been drafted, he said, so it could deal with all sorts of "suspicious circumstances" such as someone "having coffee grinders in every cupboard or car boots full of fertiliser in the middle of London". Remarkably, he dismissed Hughes' objections that the bill could catch dissident groups fighting dictatorships or oppression by asserting: "It is vital to understand that the world has changed ... endangering the lives of innocent people are crimes, whatever the ... motivation or however corrupt the regime they are fighting against". Beware then, those who incite attacks against Saddam Hussein, or the Taliban regime in Afghanistan. Despite - when he was in opposition - the attorney general's savage criti cism of clauses included in the new terrorism bill, Jack Straw now insists they are compatible with the European convention on human rights. The home office refuses to disclose its legal advice. The Belfast-based human rights commission has little doubt the bill contravenes the convention, not least in a section applying to Northern Ireland which states that a mere assertion by an RUC officer that someone is a member of a proscribed organisation is admissible evidence. Clarke appears to recognise that the terrorism bill is indeed open to abuse. But don't worry, he seems to be saying, defendants can rely on the police; and if not them, the courts; and, if absolutely necessary, a jury, being "reasonable" in their interpretation of it. That is cold comfort.

webTitle: More die of Aids than war in Africa says Kofi Annan

fields.headline: More die of Aids than war in Africa says Kofi Annan
fields.trailText: More people have died of Aids in the past year in Africa than in all the wars on the continent, the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, said yesterday in London.
fields.body:
More people have died of Aids in the past year in Africa than in all the wars on the continent, the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, said yesterday in London.

This extraordinary statistic includes wars in Angola, Sierra Leone, Congo, Congo-Brazzaville, Somalia, Sudan, Ethiopia and Eritrea.

"Aids is a major crisis for the continent, governments have got to do something. We must end the conspiracy of silence, the shame over this issue," Mr Annan said, revealing that he has ordered a major UN study on Aids in Africa, which will be completed by May.

In answer to a question, he said the study would "probably" be published, but he is likely to encounter resistance from regional leaders.

Mr Annan is in London to deliver the annual Commonwealth lecture tonight and is also scheduled to meet Tony Blair and Robin Cook.

Some African leaders have begun to speak about Aids, Mr Annan said, but most are still reluctant to confront it.

"If I say that we must get people to use condoms, I find I'm said to be encouraging people to be promiscuous - this won't do," Mr Annan said.

The only African leader who regularly raises the issue and calls for a change in sexual habits is President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda, where dire rates of infection have improved as a result.

Of the world's 36m Aids sufferers, 23m live in sub-Saharan Africa.

"None of us has yet begun to grasp the full impact of this horror - on the quality of life in Africa, its economic potential and its social and political stability," Mr Annan said.

He cited Ivory Coast, where a teacher dies of Aids every schoolday, and of Botswana, where a child born today has a life expectancy of 41 years whereas, without Aids, they would have been expected to live to 70.

In Zimbabwe government projections show that by 2005 HIV and Aids will consume 60% of the health budget, and even that will fall far short. Aids permeates the military and police to such an extent that neither group can be used as blood donors. But, as in Malawi and Zambia where infection rates are extremely high, the subject is taboo.

In South Africa Nelson Mandela and his wife Graca Machel have broken the silence on the disease, but Aids sufferers are still shunned.

fields.headline: Japan's slip sliding away
fields.standfirst:
Analysts ignore gloomy results and predict internet boom

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Japan has slipped back into recession but, far from generating anxiety about the world's second largest economy, yesterday's news had ministers and analysts insisting that cyclical recovery and a home-grown internet boom were just around the corner.
fields.body:
Japan has slipped back into recession but, far from generating anxiety about the world's second largest economy, yesterday's news had ministers and analysts insisting that cyclical recovery and a home-grown internet boom were just around the corner.

According to the economic planning agency, Japan's gross domestic product declined 5.5% on an annualised basis in the final three months of 1999, a significantly worse slump than analysts had expected.

This slide - the country's third steepest since 1945 - followed negative growth during the previous quarter.

Underlining the fragility of the Japanese economy, this gloomy data was recorded at a time when other Asian nations were recovering from the regional financial crisis of 1998 and other developed nations were racking up impressive growth thanks to the dot.com revolution.

The main reason for the decline is the continuing reluctance of Japanese shoppers to open up their wallets. Consumer spending, which accounts for 60% of GDP, fell by 1.6%. Government outlays on public works projects which have been used to fill the gaps in the economy also dried up. Housing investment fell 5.8% and exports declined relative to imports.

But government ministers said a sharp 4.6% increase in corporate investment - the first rise in nine months - showed that confidence had returned in the private sector.

"I don't think we should worry too much", finance minister Kiichi Miyazawa told reporters. "On the contrary, I'm pleased that capital investment showed some improvement."

Although a general election is looming, analysts said that this rosy outlook is not just political spin.

"There have been strong signs this year of a private sector-led recovery," said Kiichi Murashima of the Nomura Research Institute. "But the foundation for recovery remains shaky."

As well as a pick-up since January in industrial production, job offers, overtime hours and machinery orders, a new government spending package worth ¥6.5 trillion (£37bn) will kick in from April.

Many large companies have also increased their profitability through restructuring, while other weaker firms have merged with stronger partners. In the latest shift in the financial sector, Sanwa Bank, Tokai Bank and Asahi Bank confirmed they are in talks to form the world's third largest banking alliance which would have combined assets of more than ¥100 trillion (£571bn).

To achieve sustained growth, however, the government is looking to hitch on to the internet bandwagon by making the most of the country's lead in mobile communications technology.

"Although GDP was negative for two consecutive quarters, I do not consider this a recession," said Taichi Sakaiya, economic planning minister. "New areas of growth, such as in information technology, will pull the economy forward."

Yesterday, however, new technology companies dragged the Nikkei index of the Tokyo Stock Exchange back by 560 points as investors expressed increasing doubt about the valuations of internet-related equities.

In little more than a month, the share prices of Japan's two biggest e-companies - Softbank and Hikari Tsushin - have lost more than 45% of their value.

webTitle: NTL aims to score with stake in Boro

fields.headline: NTL aims to score with stake in Boro
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report

Cable firm extends holdings ahead of Premier League bidding
fields.trailText: NTL, Britain's biggest cable company, is aiming to extend its influence in football by taking a 9.9% stake in Premier League club Middlesbrough.
fields.body:
NTL, Britain's biggest cable company, is aiming to extend its influence in football by taking a 9.9% stake in Premier League club Middlesbrough.

The acquisition of a stake in the Teesside club would add to NTL's existing holdings in Aston Villa and Newcastle and is the tenth in the past 12 months or so to have attracted investment from a media company.

The rate of investments has accelerated as the media sector manoeuvres into position ahead of the issue of a crucial tender document for the next set of Premier League broadcasting rights, which could fetch between £1bn-£2bn. BSkyB secured the last set for £670m over five years and will be fighting against growing competition to retain its hold over the rights.

The talks with Middlesbrough emerged as NTL, which is listed on the Nasdaq exchange in New York, reported revenues of $1.6bn (£1bn) for 1999. The company is in the process of acquiring the residential business of Cable & Wireless Communications to underline its market leadership and will have more than 3m customers in TV and telephony when the deal goes through.

Around four in 10 homes passed by NTL cables take at least one service from the company it said. As at December 31, it had 2.4m customers spending an average £35 a month.

NTL is also reported to be circling Arsenal. Carlton Communications held talks with the north London club in 1998 but the two failed to agree a price.

Middlesbrough chairman Steve Gibson took complete control of his home club when he bought back ICI's 20% shareholding in the business earlier this year. NTL already owns the club's cable channel Boro TV.

The biggest aggregator of stakes in football clubs has been BSkyB which two weeks ago paid £40m for a 9.9% share in Chelsea. It has also taken stakes in Manchester United, Manchester City, Leeds and Sunderland.

fields.headline: Infineon off to flying start
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: In pace with chief executive Ulrich Schumacher's arrival for work in a racing car, shares in German computer chip maker Infineon Technologies set a scorching pace on flotation yesterday, more than doubling in value. The flotation was hailed as the largest such technology stock offer in history.
fields.body:
In pace with chief executive Ulrich Schumacher's arrival for work in a racing car, shares in German computer chip maker Infineon Technologies set a scorching pace on flotation yesterday, more than doubling in value. The flotation was hailed as the largest such technology stock offer in history.

Amid expectations that after its flotation it will soon become a member of Germany's main Dax 30 index, Infineon's shares closed at €70.26 (£42.70), compared with their €35 issue price, after touching a peak of €84.99 euros, which valued the company at more than €53bn.

However, the closing price was well below the grey market range of €90-120 as the Dax lost 3.5% of its value and technology stock suffered from heavy profit-taking.

However, Mr Schumacher said the float "surpassed our and the banks' expectations".

He added: "I expect that at some point we will be in the Dax ... from microchip to blue chip."

The issue was 33 times oversubscribed after frenzied ordering by investors including millions of small private buyers chasing the much-publicised technology issue.

About 29% of the former loss-making semiconductor subsidiary of the industrial group Siemens was floated.

fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Glaxo WellcomeICI

fields.trailText: Cadbury Schweppes, the chocolate and soft drinks company whose origins lie in the abstemious Quaker tradition, yesterday appointed the boss of one of Britain's biggest cigarette manufacturers as its chairman.
fields.body:
Cadbury Schweppes, the chocolate and soft drinks company whose origins lie in the abstemious Quaker tradition, yesterday appointed the boss of one of Britain's biggest cigarette manufacturers as its chairman.

Derek Bonham, head of Imperial Tobacco, former Hanson director and a non-executive director of drugs group Glaxo Wellcome, will take over from Sir Dominic Cadbury whose retirement on May 12 will end his family's unbroken presence in the boardroom.

A Cadbury official denied any incompatibility between the appointment of a cigarette boss and the Quaker heritage of a company. She said the company had not been Quaker since its merger with Schweppes in the late 1960s.

Cadbury accounts for some 29% of the British confectionery market. It is estimated that the average Briton last year spent more than £91 on confectionery but while adults bought 94% of confectionery they ate only 62% of it. Children make up just over 20% of the population but comprise nearly four in every 10 sweet eaters.

Mr Bonham - who also has non-executive directorships at Fieldens and TXU Corporation - will be only a part-time chairman for Cadbury unlike Sir Dominic who served full time. The company official said Mr Bonham was regarded as having valuable international expertise from roles such as chief executive of Hanson, non-executive director of US Industries and chairman of The Energy Group.

Cadbury is understood to have its eyes on the consumer arm of Warner Lambert, which might come on to the market after that company's acquisition by Pfizer, and retains a carbonated drinks business in the US. The group, whose shares were down 8p yesterday, has made no secret of its ability and willingness to spend heavily on an acquisition that will push it up the world confectionery rankings.

webTitle: Byers attempts to ward off curse of the DTI

fields.headline: Byers attempts to ward off curse of the DTI
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The Department of Trade and Industry has long been the graveyard of ambitious politicians. Apart from Michael Heseltine and, peculiarly, given his short stint, Peter Mandelson (still grieved over in Victoria Street), its incumbents have had rapid, inauspicious stopovers on the way, normally, to political nadir.
fields.body:
The Department of Trade and Industry has long been the graveyard of ambitious politicians. Apart from Michael Heseltine and, peculiarly, given his short stint, Peter Mandelson (still grieved over in Victoria Street), its incumbents have had rapid, inauspicious stopovers on the way, normally, to political nadir.

Is Stephen Byers about to suffer the DTI curse? On the face of things, there is no such danger. Here is an extremely affable, clever, though strangely passionless New Labour apparatchik, with seemingly all the attributes for turning the DTI into the department for the new economy.

A lawyer in a cabinet of advocates, Byers is close to Tony Blair and, therefore, able to open the conduit to the presidential suites in Downing Street, seemingly closed by Mandy's unfortunate exit. But, as an ex-treasury and education minister, he is also someone with an inside track on Gordon Brown's empire and the chancellor's executive control on spending initiatives.

That's the theory. The reality may be that Mr Byers is beginning to flounder and, who knows, may even sink. One or two steel-capped boots are looking to keep him under. And here are just a few of their recent justifications:

 Taking over the mantle for the knowledge-driven economy, he has failed to put together a coherent package for supporting its growth - and seen Mr Brown wrest initiative after initiative from the DTI - the internet being the obvious example. (Not true, say Mr Byers' friends: It's his and our agenda and it will gain lift-off when the new DTI director-general for innovation starts work in April.

Oh, and you may think that Pat Hewitt launched the money-spinning auction for third generation mobile phones, with a licence reserved for a newcomer, but it was Mr Byers' brilliant idea - and one he imposed on a recalcitrant DTI wedded to rewarding just the four incumbents).

 Worse still, in the eyes of his Labour critics, he stood on the sidelines of debates, such as raising the national minimum wage, and did not even attend the key meeting where Blair and Brown agreed upon a very modest increase - when the DTI is the lead department. (Not true, say his friends: We got the raise by skilful, sensible lobbying and without forcing Brown to dig his heels in via a frontal attack).

 Even worse, Byers has suffered the humilation of simply dropping huge chunks of his flagship utilities bill designed to raise common standards for regulating the former state monopolies and empower consumers. Even now the legislation lacks clarity and cogency.

Mr Byers, it is said, proved hapless when, first, the telecoms industry led by Vodafone and BT complained to Blair they were at the cutting edge of the new economy and scarcely a horny-handed old utility. Much better to be freshly regulated within a broadcasting bill given that telecoms and media are converging technologies. Mr Blair agreed.

His haplessness was complete, his foes add, when John Prescott waded in and, against DTI resistance, forced the removal of the water industry from the bill - leaving a shell covering just energy.

(Even more untrue, say My Byers's friends. The legislative programme, hijacked by the - reformed - Lords, is jammed and several bills will have to be equally shrunk). Telecoms was out of it once the white paper on converging industries was published, implying an Ofcom to replace Oftel/ITC and the like. And the DTI never controlled water, which had piggybacked into the utilties bill - and will now get its own bill in the next session.

T he list goes on: Interference in decisions over mergers and acquisitions, notably the marriage between cable operators, when he promised to exit such matters - unless when national security is involved. Leaving the ice-cream industry in the dark about when rival products can be stored in freezers. Leaving serious doubts over BMW's commitment to Rover and Brussels' approval of a £152m aid package for the Longbridge car plant is just another example.

Last, but not least, is last week's claim of political meddling in the departure of John Taylor as BNFL chief executive.

Mr Byers' associates are trying to laugh all this off, arguing that it is natural for a big hitter on issues such as the euro to become prone to counter-spin. But in some quarters of the City it is being seen as evidence of a lack of experience in an understanding of business itself. The Square Mile does notice when a minister fails to assert himself. Falling foul of serial Whitehall in-fighting just does not look good.

New Labour swept to power on a coalition of the old and new economies, seeking to represent and marry the interests of unions and business, industry and consumers.

That's some circle to try and square. Mr Byers is clearly struggling, but then those calling for his head might also ponder on whether the whole DTI machinery needs a rethink.

Oh, and you may think that Pat Hewitt launched the money-spinning auction for third generation mobile phones, with a licence reserved for a newcomer, but it was Mr Byers' brilliant idea - and one he imposed on a recalcitrant DTI wedded to rewarding just the four incumbents).  Worse still, in the eyes of his Labour critics, he stood on the sidelines of debates, such as raising the national minimum wage, and did not even attend the key meeting where Blair and Brown agreed upon a very modest increase - when the DTI is the lead department. (Not true, say his friends: We got the raise by skilful, sensible lobbying and without forcing Brown to dig his heels in via a frontal attack).  Even worse, Byers has suffered the humilation of simply dropping huge chunks of his flagship utilities bill designed to raise common standards for regulating the former state monopolies and empower consumers. Even now the legislation lacks clarity and cogency. Mr Byers, it is said, proved hapless when, first, the telecoms industry led by Vodafone and BT complained to Blair they were at the cutting edge of the new economy and scarcely a horny-handed old utility. Much better to be freshly regulated within a broadcasting bill given that telecoms and media are converging technologies. Mr Blair agreed. His haplessness was complete, his foes add, when John Prescott waded in and, against DTI resistance, forced the removal of the water industry from the bill - leaving a shell covering just energy. (Even more untrue, say My Byers's friends. The legislative programme, hijacked by the - reformed - Lords, is jammed and several bills will have to be equally shrunk). Telecoms was out of it once the white paper on converging industries was published, implying an Ofcom to replace Oftel/ITC and the like. And the DTI never controlled water, which had piggybacked into the utilties bill - and will now get its own bill in the next session. T he list goes on: Interference in decisions over mergers and acquisitions, notably the marriage between cable operators, when he promised to exit such matters - unless when national security is involved. Leaving the ice-cream industry in the dark about when rival products can be stored in freezers. Leaving serious doubts over BMW's commitment to Rover and Brussels' approval of a £152m aid package for the Longbridge car plant is just another example. Last, but not least, is last week's claim of political meddling in the departure of John Taylor as BNFL chief executive. Mr Byers' associates are trying to laugh all this off, arguing that it is natural for a big hitter on issues such as the euro to become prone to counter-spin. But in some quarters of the City it is being seen as evidence of a lack of experience in an understanding of business itself. The Square Mile does notice when a minister fails to assert himself. Falling foul of serial Whitehall in-fighting just does not look good. New Labour swept to power on a coalition of the old and new economies, seeking to represent and marry the interests of unions and business, industry and consumers. That's some circle to try and square. Mr Byers is clearly struggling, but then those calling for his head might also ponder on whether the whole DTI machinery needs a rethink.

fields.headline: Low fat returns
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Scotia Holdings, one of Britain's oldest biotechnology companies, desperately wants to be regarded as a serious pioneer in medical research. Unfortunately, its lead product is a weight-loss yoghurt, which rather reduces its gravitas in the City.
fields.body:
Scotia Holdings, one of Britain's oldest biotechnology companies, desperately wants to be regarded as a serious pioneer in medical research. Unfortunately, its lead product is a weight-loss yoghurt, which rather reduces its gravitas in the City.

Yesterday, Scotia announced it had signed a deal with US group Bestfoods, which wants to put Olibra, the yoghurt's crucial ingredient, in its Knorr range. Knorr sales amount to hundreds of millions of dollars each year, and Scotia is likely to get a royalty of around 5%. It adds to a deal with another US food maker General Mills, which wants to put Olibra into cereals.

However, the shares slipped 2p to 227p. Drugs investors are more interested in hi-tech gene bashers at the other end of the pharmaceuticals sector.

This attitude is a little unfair. Later this year, Scotia is likely to join a select band of biotech companies with a drug on sale. US regulators are set to approve Foscan, a treatment for head and neck cancer.

Foscan is injected into tumours and becomes active when patients sit under a certain type of light. In some clinical studies, patients' tumours have entirely disappeared.

Analysts at Charterhouse Securities reckon the market for head and neck cancer in the US and Europe is worth about £66m and trials begin soon to extend the product towards other cancers.

Scotia has had more than its share of disappointments in the past. Founded in the late 1970s, it initially failed to make an impact. Founder Robert Horrobin was replaced two years ago by former Roche executive, Robert Dow, who drastically slimmed down the development pipeline.

Stability has returned and although Scotia's shares have doubled in the recent biotech boom, they are nowhere near their 1996 peak of 810p.

Scotia is still at the high-risk end of drug development, with only two advanced products. But the current market capitalisation of £200m will look very modest if both Olibra and Foscan are successful.

webTitle: What the Americans are sending us now

fields.headline: What the Americans are sending us now
fields.trailText: What is a fund supermarket?
fields.body:
What is a fund supermarket?

Originally an American idea, it allows private investors to buy and sell a range of funds through one channel with a bit of help along the way.

Are they successful?

Fidelity is the largest player in the US, and thus the world, and has taken $177bn (£110bn) through its supermarket.

How does it work?

The customer sets up an online account and then buys and sells funds within that account. Each site is equipped with a facility to help the investor tailor the choice of funds to individual circumstances. On Fidelity's American site - it plans to launch a UK version in the summer - there are 4,100 funds to choose from including 900 "no load" ones (funds with no initial charge). The shelves of egg's supermarket will initially be relatively bare with only 169 unit trusts and open-ended investment companies out of more than 1,500 on the market. Because the supermarkets are not authorised to offer ad vice, recommendations are made only on a loose basis.

Are they cheap?

Cheaper than advisers because they discount commission but more expensive than discount brokers.

Will there be others to choose from?

US players Fidelity and Charles Schwab are UK-bound.

webTitle: Rainy day might come in May

fields.headline: Rainy day might come in May
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: One of the market's favourite old wives' tales - sell in May and go away - has new legs, thanks to the inland revenue.
fields.body:
One of the market's favourite old wives' tales - sell in May and go away - has new legs, thanks to the inland revenue.

Around £4bn of new money is expected to flood into UK equities over a few weeks as small investors take advantage of the once-only chance to put £7,000 into a tax-free Isa ahead of the April end-of-year deadline. In the following month, if the history of Peps is anything to go by, sales will collapse by 75%.

A wave of cash hitting the stock market means one thing; rising share prices, according to research this week from Salomon Smith Barney. When the wave recedes in May, prices head south again.

Figures for monthly returns on the FTSE All Share index since 1965 show that April is the second-best month of the year, giving investors an average return of 3.6%, only slightly lower than the best month, January. May is the only month in the past 35 years when average returns have been negative.

So amateur punter who pile into shares in late March and early April are paying dear. But prices do not pick up much after May until the end of summer. Salomon's advice is to sell in April and stay away until October.

Each year the effect is becoming more pronounced as the level of retail flows reaches new peaks. It is not just a UK story: net sales of mutual funds in Europe have tripled since the middle of last year, led by bumper sales in Italy.

This year's twist is technology. Sales of tech-invested unit trusts made up just 1% of the total UK funds market as recently as June last year but are expected to grab 50% of all sales over the next few weeks. A glance at any of the personal finance sections of the national newspapers, crammed with adverts for the latest tech funds, confirms this is the only story investors are buying.

The beneficiaries will be the TMT (technology, media, telecoms) stocks. Telewest, CMG, Kingston Communications and Energis are tipped as winners from a liquidity-driven push upwards.

But those pundits who have been predicting an imminent end to the TMT boom may have a point.

The big sellers in 1999's final Pep season were corporate bond funds. Six months later the average punter was sitting on a loss of 15%.

fields.headline: Boost for AstraZeneca
fields.standfirst:
Sweden gives green light to ulcer treatment.

E-finance: special report
AstraZeneca
fields.trailText: AstraZeneca, Britain's second largest drugs company, yesterday got the green light from Swedish regulators to sell its ulcer treatment Nexium, giving the company's shares a needed boost.
fields.body:
AstraZeneca, Britain's second largest drugs company, yesterday got the green light from Swedish regulators to sell its ulcer treatment Nexium, giving the company's shares a needed boost.

Nexium is the follow-up product to Losec - AstraZeneca's popular gastric treatment which is due to lose its patent protection next year.

Sweden is the first country to approve the drug and other European Union members are likely to follow under a mutual recognition procedure.

AstraZeneca's shares rose 87p to £25.73, recovering some of the ground lost after the group's annual results disappointed the market last month.

Chief executive Tom McKil lop described the news as "a major milestone for the company". He said Nexium was the first major advance in acid-related disease treatment in more than a decade.

Analysts were encouraged by the wide range of uses approved for inclusion on the drug's label - the prescribing advice issued to doctors.

Paul Diggle of SG Securities said: "The crucial question was whether the label would be superior to Losec's. It sounds to me as though they've got the label they hoped they'd get."

The Swedish authorities agreed that in certain cases, Nexium could be used to treat intermittent stomach upsets - where Losec was only suitable for chronic disorders.

The exact range of applications for the drug is consid ered crucial in persuading doctors to choose Nexium, rather than cheaper generic versions of Losec - which are rapidly appearing on the market.

With sales last year of $5.9bn (£3.7bn), Losec contributed more than a third of AstraZeneca's turnover.

The company has come under intense pressure to explain how it will plug the gap when the drug goes off patent.

Analysts believe annual sales of Nexium could peak at between $2bn and $3bn. They also have high hopes for ZD4522 - a cholesterol-lowering drug which is still in clinical trials.

AstraZeneca shares have also been squeezed recently by fears that the company will struggle to compete following the merger of Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Mutuals claim loans victory

Building societies have outstripped the mortgage banks in the amount of home loans made and savings attracted over the past two years, according to the Buildings Societies Association.
fields.body:
Mutuals claim loans victory
Building societies have outstripped the mortgage banks in the amount of home loans made and savings attracted over the past two years, according to the Buildings Societies Association.

Last year building societies, led by the Nationwide and Bradford & Bingley, lent £10.6bn net compared with the banks' £9.1bn. Building societies attracted a net £11.1bn of savings in 1999, while the mortgage banks showed a net outflow of £1.7bn. The BSA claimed the difference could be accounted for by the better savings and loans rates offered by mutual societies.

Bovis attacks new restriction
Bovis, a house building firm, yesterday threw its weight behind criticism of the government's new planning restrictions to limit the number of homes the company can put up in one of its major areas of operation, the south-east.

Reporting a 23% rise in profits for last year to £55.4m, Bovis said the government's latest hurdle to the development of greenfield sites would delay the planning process and result in house prices rising faster than inflation.

The average selling price of Bovis houses rose to £114,100 last year from £104,200, while the price the company had to pay for plots increased from £22,100 to £22,900.

Malcolm Harris, the chief executive, said: "We see the industry being a provider of the solution and not actually a cause [of the problem]."

Asda price cuts fuel debate
Asda, the supermarket chain, yesterday announced £14m worth of price cuts on fresh meats and said it would still be making a profit.

The price reductions, which will fuel the debate on whether supermarkets have been cashing in on the farming crisis, follows a recent £6m package by Tesco.

Asda said that the reductions would not lead to farmers having to accept lower prices for their livestock, and was made possible by increased sales.

Liffe sees futures in US
The London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange (Liffe) yesterday said its FTSE 100 index futures contract can now be offered and sold to US investors.

The development follows the receipt by Liffe on March 10 of a 'no action' letter from the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

Liffe's FTSE 100 index futures contract is traded on Liffe Connect - its electronic trading system.

fields.headline: GM grabs stake in Fiat
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Fiat
General Motors
fields.trailText: Fiat, a proud symbol of Italian car engineering, yesterday bowed to the relentless pressures of global competition by agreeing to sell a 20% stake to General Motors of the United States.
fields.body:
Fiat, a proud symbol of Italian car engineering, yesterday bowed to the relentless pressures of global competition by agreeing to sell a 20% stake to General Motors of the United States.

The Turin-based motor group, which controls legendary marques such as Alfa Romeo, sold the 20% stake for $2.4bn (£1.5bn) but has gained a 5.1% stake in GM making it one of that company's biggest shareholders.

As part of the deal, GM has won the right of first offer if Fiat Auto, which has been controlled for over a century by the Agnelli family, decides to put the remaining 80% holding up for sale.

Shares in Fiat were suspended ahead of the news but other European motor groups such as Citroën Peugeot and Renault raced ahead in early trading as investors saw the French companies as the likely next targets of restructuring. Car shares were boosted by GM being seen to have paid a full price for the Italian group.

The defensive alliance between GM and Fiat will generate savings of $1.2bn annually by year three and $2bn by year five through joint ventures in purchasing, engines and financing, according to the two companies.

The partners will exploit synergies wherever possible but will remain operationally independent from one another and will continue to compete in markets around the world, they say. The Agnelli family will keep its 30% holding in Fiat.

Paulo Fresco the Fiat chairman said the partnership would unlock value for shareholders while protecting the interests of staff, suppliers and the "Italian system at large" by maintaining control of its destiny.

Jack Smith, chairman and chief executive of GM, said: "GM is aggressively moving ahead on our strategy to grow our global automotive business. the opportunity to create an alliance with a large and technologically strong company like Fiat in a capital efficient manner helps us to strengthen our position in Europe and South America - a key strategic objective for GM."

The alliance does not involve Fiat's sports car marques, Ferrari or Maserati. It has been cautiously endorsed by trade unions."If this is an agreement on integrating production to enlarge the market so that both GM and Fiat grow, fine. If its the start of a gradual sale [by Fiat] it would be awful," said Pietro Larizza , leader of the UIL union federation.

webTitle: Clinton bows to pressure over top IMF job

fields.headline: Clinton bows to pressure over top IMF job
fields.trailText: President Bill Clinton will support Europe's new candidate, Horst Köhler, to head the International Monetary Fund, effectively ending a four-month wrangle over choosing the head of the global lender. White House spokesman Joe Lockhart said yesterday that Mr Clinton had spoken to German chancellor Gerhard Schröder in the afternoon and "the president told chancellor Schröeder that the United States was prepared to support Mr Köhler as the new head of the IMF".
fields.body:
President Bill Clinton will support Europe's new candidate, Horst Köhler, to head the International Monetary Fund, effectively ending a four-month wrangle over choosing the head of the global lender. White House spokesman Joe Lockhart said yesterday that Mr Clinton had spoken to German chancellor Gerhard Schröder in the afternoon and "the president told chancellor Schröeder that the United States was prepared to support Mr Köhler as the new head of the IMF".

"The president and Schröder agreed that Mr Köhler should come to Washington to meet with the IMF board, particularly with the developing countries," Mr Lockhart said. "The president and Schröder also agreed that Köhler should retain the talented management team at the IMF." The post of IMF managing director traditionally goes to a European, while the job of World Bank president traditionally goes to an American, and Washington has made clear it does not want to break with that tradition.

The race to find a candidate to succeed France's Michel Camdessus had dragged on for more than four months, first because of bickering in Europe about who the European candidate should be and then because of a transatlantic argument between Europe and the US about whether Europe's first pick was up to the job.

Köhler earlier won the unanimous backing of EU government. Now head of the London-based European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, he was endorsed by all 15 member states at a meeting of finance ministers in Brussels. In a statement, he hailed the move as decisive in his candidacy to succeed Michel Camdessus as the IMF's managing director. "It is a crucial step towards establishing the necessary support of the broad majority of IMF shareholders," Mr Köhler said. The US blocked Europe's first choice for the job, Caio Koch-Weser, and had refused to discuss the merits of Mr Köhler until EU governments adopted a common position on his candidacy.

Larry Summers, the US treasury secretary, was understood to be taking a hard line against Mr Köhler. Like Mr Koch-Weser, Mr Köhler, 57, is seen as an extremely able bureaucrat but lacks the political profile some consider necessary to run the world's most powerful financial institution.

In his time at the German finance ministry in the early 1990s, Mr Köhler was instrumental in German unification and the decision to merge the two currencies at a one-for-one rate. He was also closely involved in supporting Russia in the aftermath of the break-up of the Soviet Union and played a key role in negotiating the Maastricht Treaty on European economic and monetary union before taking over the helm of the EBRD 18 months ago. Italian treasury minister Giuliano Amato, who was touted as a potential compromise candidate if Mr Köhler was rejected, had said he did not think Mr Clinton would block Mr Köhler's candicacy.

Mr Schröder, who has staked his personal reputation on a German running the IMF, had also vowed to press Mr Köhler's candidacy hard. "We, and above all the [EU] presidency, as it has assured us, will work intensively to achieve [a consensus with the US]," he told a news conference in Berlin.
