In his time at the German finance ministry in the early 1990s, Mr Köhler was instrumental in German unification and the decision to merge the two currencies at a one-for-one rate. He was also closely involved in supporting Russia in the aftermath of the break-up of the Soviet Union and played a key role in negotiating the Maastricht Treaty on European economic and monetary union before taking over the helm of the EBRD 18 months ago. Italian treasury minister Giuliano Amato, who was touted as a potential compromise candidate if Mr Köhler was rejected, had said he did not think Mr Clinton would block Mr Köhler's candicacy. Mr Schröder, who has staked his personal reputation on a German running the IMF, had also vowed to press Mr Köhler's candidacy hard. "We, and above all the [EU] presidency, as it has assured us, will work intensively to achieve [a consensus with the US]," he told a news conference in Berlin.

fields.headline: A crazy, mixed-up Victorian
fields.standfirst: The Tate's huge new exhibition of John Ruskin and his times is really an analysis of the critic's troubled inner life, writes  Adrian Searle
fields.trailText: The Tate's huge new exhibition of John Ruskin and his times is really an analysis of the critic's troubled inner life, writes Adrian Searle
fields.body:
John Ruskin stands beside a foaming stream, somewhere in Scotland. With his high collar and city shoes, which are not quite planted on the rugged stone beneath his feet, he has the appearance of a man pasted on to the landscape. Which indeed he is: the painter, Sir John Everett Millais, accompanied the critic and his wife, Effie Gray, to Scotland in 1853, and spent months painting the rocks and the gushing water. He painted the lichen, the texture of the rocks, the bubbles drifting on the water; but he only roughed-in the space in the painting reserved for his full-length portrait of the great man. He had Ruskin pose for him in London the following year. Betweentimes, Millais and Ruskin's wife fell in love. Ruskin's marriage was annulled in July of 1854, on the grounds that it had never been consummated.

It is hard not to see the painting as emblematic of Ruskin's own displacement, the awkwardness of the painting an echo of the awkwardness of the relationship between painter and subject. It is also, inadvertently, a painting of the critic somehow a little less real than the rocks themselves. It is a portrait, then, of a man who is not quite there.

Millais's painting is the first exhibit in the huge exhibition Ruskin, Turner and the Pre-Raphaelites at the Tate Gallery. It is a kind of keynote, opening show for the relaunch of the gallery as Tate Britain this month. The show's curator, Robert Hewison, has been doing the rounds promoting Ruskin and making claims for the Pre-Raphaelite painters as the avant-garde Young British Artists of their day.

But this re-reading of Ruskin and his circle feels somehow facile, even if the Pre-Raphaelite painters - Millais, Holman Hunt, Burne-Jones, Rossetti and the rest - were indeed the hot young artists of their day, thanks to Ruskin. Hewison, one of Ruskin's successors as Slade professor of fine art at Oxford, knows how to turn a trick, and the exhibition itself has been designed to blow our socks off, if not quite blow away a conception of Ruskin as a stuffy, mixed-up Victorian.

Patriarchal and patronising as much as he was perceptive and passionate, Ruskin sticks in my craw, no matter the difficulties in his life that lend him sympathy as an essentially tragic figure who aspired to do good. Reeling out at the end of the show, my own feet were a little off the ground. I felt, too, a little ashamed of my profession - if what the critic does, like Ruskin, is to champion a coterie, to be blind to half the world of art, to hector and rant and dictate to artists as well as to the world. Learning, in John Batchelor's biography of the critic, that Ruskin's lec tures at Oxford degenerated into farce, with the great critic reduced to flapping his gown as he squawked around the stage imitating a bird, leaves me fearful of the critic's fate.

The Tate's rooms change from charcoal-black rooms to oxblood walls, from purple to a kind of ecclesiastic maroon, as we move through Ruskin's life, following his activities as a collector and champion of artists and as an artist. Dramatic lighting, rooms filled with light and rooms lowering in blackness dramatise the works they contain and create an atmospheric backdrop to what is really an analysis of the critic's inner life.

Here is Ruskin as a blond tot, painted by James Northcote in a Joshua Reynolds landscape. Here are the lad's parents, the sherry importer and the evangelical, strict mother, who groomed the boy for the pulpit. Here's the hellish nightmare of Turner's Slavers Throwing Overboard the Dead and Dying, with its lurid sky, the wild sea and chained bodies drowning in the waves. Turner could never paint people, or sea monsters, yet Ruskin felt for many years that this painting - which his father bought for him - represented the epitome of Turner's genius.

How is it that Ruskin could idolise Turner so much, yet go on to claim that Holman Hunt's Light of the World was one of the "noblest works of sacred art ever produced"? How could he be revolted by Mantegna's dead Christ, yet swoon over Burne-Jones's The Golden Stairs, with its daft parade of Grecian girls in nighties? The undercurrents of Ruskin's life, his inner turbulence, his repression and his late madness are inevitably as much a theme as the paradoxes of his taste and his enthusiasms, the indigestability of all that regurgitated learning. Ruskin himself listed all the topics on which he had had to become familiar in order to write his magnum opus, Modern Painters: "On German Metaphysics, on Poetry, Political Economy, Cookery, Music, Geology, Dress, Agriculture, Horticulture and Navigation... all of which I have had to 'read-up'." This list represents but a small corner of Ruskin's learning, the endless work that blighted him as much as it buffered him from his troubles.

The American critic Rosalind Krauss asked, "Is it possible, I imagine someone asking, to think of Ruskin - who could never produce a thought about art that was not at the same time a sermon - in the same universe as modernism?" It is easy to laugh at him, she wrote. What Krauss rescued in her 1993 book The Optical Unconscious is Ruskin on a beach, mesmerised by the sea, child Ruskin fascinated by the pattern on a carpet, the whorls of wood-grain, Ruskin the "infant fetishist of patchwork". Little wonder that he had an abiding fascination for complex pattern and plenitude, for the strata of rocks, the sheen of bird's wings, for mountainscapes and cloud formations, for pebbles and for leaves. The natural world reared up at him, and in it, he saw the hand of God. And in man's works too - in Italian Gothic architecture, in the paintings of Tintoretto, in Verrocchio, in Turner and in the Pre-Raphaelites. He also came to the conclusion, late on, that the painter needs to be a little bit wicked, and worldly, to achieve anything.

A good part of the project to rehabilitate Ruskin is to reclaim him through the understanding of his complexity, through sympathy for his upbringing, and through the breadth of his influence. It involves embracing, too, Ruskin the sexual failure, the evangelical moralist and anti-catholic, the man who hero- worshipped Turner and hated Whistler. But must we embrace mad old Ruskin with his infantilist baby-talk and obsession for little girls?

What an unsympathetic creature he was, what a great subject for biography he is, what a movie he would make. He shaped his time as much as he was shaped by it. How much his moral certainties and their unravelling contributed to his madness, and how much madness there always was in him is unclear. His recent biographers - Batchelor and Tim Hilton (the concluding, second volume of whose monumental Life of Ruskin is newly published, 15 years after the first) - have to cope with the escalation of Ruskin's insanity, and with the fact that, as much as Ruskin idolised art and artists as both critic and collector, his greatest idolisation was reserved for himself.

There is as much that is laughable, pompous, ridiculous and awful about these works as there is that is astonishing. The show includes the paintings by Whistler that led to the ridiculous 1878 libel trial - in which Whistler won a farthing's damages from Ruskin - and a couple of the remaining erotic sketches by Turner that escaped Ruskin's censorship and destruction. We also have here a large selection of Ruskin's own drawings and watercolours, which as much as they chart his looming decline, show that at least he had a practical sense of how art is made and what it might achieve.

With each room painted a different colour, and with quotes (shortened into snappy epigrams, as though Ruskin was a High Victorian master of spin and soundbite) emblazoned high on the walls, the exhibition turns Ruskin's century, and Ruskin himself, into a kind of postmodern spectacle. It is not a pretty sight.

fields.headline: So what  is  classical music?
fields.standfirst: Last week, William Orbit's Pieces in a Modern Style was banned from the classical music charts.  Andrew Clements  asks why
fields.trailText: Last week, William Orbit's Pieces in a Modern Style was banned from the classical music charts. Andrew Clements asks why
fields.body:
The news that Pieces in a Modern Style, the album by rock producer and "ambient composer" William Orbit has been banned from competing in the classical album charts, is the kind of nonsense that can only give "classical music" a bad name. Orbit's disc, which takes works by Samuel Barber, Arvo Part and Gorecki among others - no prizes for guessing which pieces - and rearranges them for synthesisers, has been dismissed by the Classical Advisory Panel (whatever that is) because, it decreed, the results "were not suitable for live performance in a concert setting" and that "the tonal colours of the original works were totally altered".

In the end, though, who cares? Who outside the record companies cares about the classical music charts, of which there seem to be so many competing versions that every one you see contains a totally different list of discs from the next, and who among those who actually buy the albums cares about which pigeonhole some Classical Advisory Panel puts them into? Classical music (if we have to use that outmoded and inaccurate term) has enough problems with its image already, without the industry making itself look stupid as well.

Whether these Pieces in a Modern Style are any good or not is beside the point. Each month there are too many new releases that comfortably meet the criteria for the classical charts yet aren't worth the plastic they are pressed on. I wouldn't try to defend Orbit's work on artistic grounds, or even use the dubious argument, often trotted out on behalf of this kind of album, that its accessibility may bring a new audience to the music who may then be tempted to explore further. But at the same time no one should say that Orbit should not be able to do what he likes, assuming the original composers or their representatives on earth agree. No doubt the publishers of Barber and all the rest are getting a nice little royalty on the sky-high sales - just as Steve Reich and his record company could only be grateful to the DJs who sampled his works as dance tracks, enabling him to put out a whole disc of the best of them; one was even used in a TV ad for Rover.

What is more intriguing, though, are those two criteria that were used to kick the Orbit album out of the chart - the notion of its unsuitability for live performance (though I gather that Orbit has performed some of these numbers in public), and the altering of the "tonal colours" of the originals. But surely the idea that in some way recordings are a faithful replica of live performances went out with black vinyl; producers and engineers "cheat" all the time, not just in the obvious way of editing different takes together, but often by abandoning all pretence that a particular recording was made in a studio on one specific occasion. Placido Domingo recently recorded the tenor role in Mahler's Das Lied von Erde, but his songs were recorded months apart from the baritone numbers which are interleaved with them on the disc. And when Mahler's eighth symphony, conducted by Riccardo Chailly, was recorded recently in Amsterdam, not all the singers were available; apparently their contributions are going to be dubbed on to the digital master later. Where does all that leave the notion of a recording being a performable version of a piece of music?

As for that business of the tonal colours - there are many orchestral versions of Mussorgsky's Pictures at an Exhibition (a piano work as he conceived it) in the record catalogue, the best known of them by Ravel. Who can explain to me the difference between what Ravel did to Mussorgsky and what Orbit is now doing to Gorecki et al? There is a whiff of cultural snobbery about all this. Surely the classical world has enough accusations of elitism heaped upon it, without bringing more down upon itself.

fields.headline: Kiwis can end Australian run
fields.trailText: New Zealand were 130 runs away from an improbable win and Australia five wickets from likely victory yesterday after the third day of a fluctuating first Test in Auckland.
fields.body:
New Zealand were 130 runs away from an improbable win and Australia five wickets from likely victory yesterday after the third day of a fluctuating first Test in Auckland.

The Kiwis, set 281 runs to deny Australia their eighth consecutive Test victory, were making a good fist of it. At the close they were 151 for five with Craig McMillan unbeaten on 57.

Shane Warne, the greatest leg-spinner of his time, equalled Dennis Lillee's Australian-record 355 Test wickets when he bowled Nathan Astle around his pads. And Daniel Vettori finished with career-best figures of seven for 87 in Australia's second innings for a match analysis of 12 for 149, the best by a New Zealander in a Test at Eden Park.

But the off-spinner Colin Miller did the early damage for Australia. He removed Matthew Horne (11), Mathew Sinclair (6) and then Stephen Fleming (8) with what looked like an unplayable ball.

fields.headline: Anwar steps down
fields.trailText: Second day Pakistan's off-the-field problems increased today as Saeed Anwar stepped down as captain after just five Tests in charge.
fields.body:
Pakistan's off-the-field problems increased today as Saeed Anwar stepped down as captain after just five Tests in charge.

"Anwar came to us and told us that due to health problems and pressure he wants to step down from captaincy and would like to concentrate on his batting," said Yawar Saeed, director of operations at the Pakistan Cricket Board - who announced just last week that Anwar would lead the side until July.

Moin Khan - who reportedly declined the captaincy ahead of the Sri Lankan's tour - will lead Pakistan in the Sharjah tri-series which starts on March 22 until Pakistan's return trip to Sri Lanka in June. Inzamam-ul-Haq will be his deputy.

On the field, the third and final Test between Pakistan and Sri Lanka was evenly poised after the second's day's play at Karachi.

Pakistan reached 88 for three at stumps in their second innings - 117 runs ahead of the tourists, who made 227 in their first innings with Russel Arnold making the top-score of 48.

Shahid Afridi and Ashraf Naveed shared in an opening partnership of 70, but the hosts then three quick wickets as Sri Lanka hit back.

Muttiah Muralitharan trapped Naveed lbw for 27 and then Ravindra Pushpakumara bowled Afridi (34).

Muralitharan had new batsman Ijaz Ahmed caught by Tillekerktne Dilshan for just three to leaveH the match finally balanced. Inzamam-ul-Haq (12) and nightwatchman Shoaib Akhtar (0) are currently not out.

The tourists lead the three-match series 2-0.

fields.headline: Every club needs an Anelka
fields.standfirst: Anelka out for 45 days
fields.trailText: Nicolas Anelka is the latest in a long line of players adept at creating well-timed off-pitch diversions to divert attention from a club crisis.
fields.body:
To borrow a phrase from Atletico Madrid's president Jesus Gil, Nicolas Anelka is currently about as welcome in Spanish football as a piranha in a bidet. The Real Madrid striker is refusing to turn up for training despite being fined almost £20,000 a day for doing so. "The boy is sick in the head" was the verdict of Real's president Lorenzo Sanz.

I suspect this is exactly what the club, if not Anelka, wants. He has adapted to the ways of the press. In the past decade the pace of football has increased off the pitch as well as on it. Space is at a premium not just during the game but before and after it. How, for example, would Tommy Lawton and Nat Lofthouse have coped against the bigger, stronger and more mobile media of today?

Higher-quality players such as the Frenchman now make important decoy runs even when they are not playing. On the pitch a well-timed diversion can make a scoring opportunity for a team-mate; off the pitch it can take the public's eye momentarily off a crisis and create room in which those around or behind him can operate.

Anelka is a master of the art. Since the former Arsenal man arrived in Madrid the Spanish press has lost its shape quicker than a cheap jumper. His immediate criticism of his new colleagues distracted attention from Real's poor start to the campaign. As the press followed the striker's wonderfully executed dummy down a blind alley, the new coach Vicente del Bosque was able to ghost into the resulting gap and engineer a revival.

Now the Frenchman is off again, his selfless running dragging opponents with him and away from Real's financial turmoil. Fans of the Bernabeu giants can only pray that the bit of leeway Anelka has squeezed for Sanz and co will be enough for them to work some magic in.

To some great players such vision comes naturally. Perhaps the first footballer fully to appreciate the importance of off-the-field movement was that force of nature George Best. During the early 70s the Ulsterman's weaving dribbles away from Manchester would frequently lure as many as 70 journalists and photographers from the steps of Old Trafford and on to the patio of a Costa del Sol love-nest, leaving United's directors free to create gilt-edged chances for managers such as Frank O'Farrell.

Sadly no British player has followed in Best's unevenly spaced footprints. It has been left to foreign imports to demonstrate the efficacy of the technique.

Last term there was Pierre van Hooijdonk with Nottingham Forest. But the world champions France lead the way. In the 80s and 90s the French introduced a widely respected youth coaching system. Evidence suggests that among the lessons taught was how to manufacture a smoke-screen by playing on the latent xenophobia of the media.

Frank Leboeuf is a supreme exponent. Last week, with Chelsea having suffered a setback in the Champions League, pressure was mounting on the manager Gianluca Vialli. Then up popped the shaven head grumbling about the noise of the jets flying over Chelsea's training ground. This dart from the deep took him straight on to the back pages, leaving Vialli time to plot a win over Marseille.

Anyone who worries that English football lags behind its European counterparts can only hope that our youngsters are watching and learning from Leboeuf, Van Hooijdonk and the perpetually busy Emmanuel Petit. If they are, then the international tournament cannot be long away at which an England player draws attention from the team's lack of a left-sided midfielder by moaning about the food in several different languages .

fields.headline: Anelka out for 45 days
fields.trailText: Real Madrid announced late last night that Nicolas Anelka has been suspended for 45 days without pay.
fields.body:
Real Madrid announced late last night that Nicolas Anelka has been suspended for 45 days without pay.

After missing three days of training, the former Arsenal striker ended his boycott yesterday but trained on his own.

"This is the maximum penalty that the team's internal regulations permit and the decision has been communicated to the player," said Jaime Ussia, one of the club's directors.

According to press estimates the French international thus stands to lose about 75m pesetas (£275,000) for his latest stand-off with the club, who have already announced that he is up for sale.

fields.headline: Niger river delta blues
fields.standfirst: Ali Farka Toure, Barbican, London ***
fields.trailText: Ali Farka Toure, Barbican, London ***
fields.body:
It has become increasingly difficult to prise Malian guitarist Ali Farka Toure away from the rural life in his home village of Niafunke. "Music is very important to me, but my profession is agriculture," says Ali, who spends most of his time irrigating chunks of the Sahara desert. He doesn't see music as mere entertainment, more as something that grows organically out of the land, which is why putting him and his band in a formal concert hall is always going to feel somewhat stilted. In his Malian French, he explained that he didn't plan to come back to London, and would be handing on the baton to his long-time music pupil and guitar player Afel Boucoum, who played the evening's opening set.

Still, having dragged himself onstage and plugged in his guitar, Ali at least seemed to be enjoying himself. He'd frequently let out a bark of laughter as he unleashed some particularly fiendish foray up the fretboard, while the call and response interplay between Ali and his backing vocalists swayed back and forth like a cobra coiling itself for action.

Ali has developed his musical style almost entirely untainted by outside influences - although he did win a Grammy for his collaboration with Ry Cooder on Talking Timbuktu - so its similarities to Mississippi blues is uncanny. His songs were often slow, mournful and infinitely weary, with only some modal scales and keening vocal lines to suggest this music was looking east before it went west. Elsewhere, he applied his ringing, metallic guitar tone to springier tempos, peeling off jangling melodic lines bizarrely reminiscent of Merseybeat and The Byrds viewed through the freeform prism of John Coltrane. Although I don't suppose that's how he hears it.

Boucoum's set shed a different light on the sounds of the Niger river. Where Toure's band (featuring several of the same musicians) appeared in simple shirts and trousers, Boucoum's team appeared in a dramatic assortment of hats, cloaks and capes. Their best pieces were constructed around relaxed but faintly menacing tempos, stretched over loping basslines and measured out in clattering cross-rhythms. Boucoum's guitar playing is stringy and nagging where Toure's bubbles effervescently, but it makes a perfect fit with the long, slow currents of his songs. I reckon Toure's right, though - this music wasn't designed for the Barbican Hall.

fields.headline: Egg's supermarket opens doors
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Egg
Prudential
fields.trailText: Egg, the internet bank owned by Prudential, opened the virtual doors to its online funds supermarket yesterday, aiming to entice novice investors.
fields.body:
Egg, the internet bank owned by Prudential, opened the virtual doors to its online funds supermarket yesterday, aiming to entice novice investors.

The service is a discount broker with a difference, based on a successful American model. Until April the service is available only to egg's existing 1m customers who will be able to buy and sell 169 investment funds from 12 managers, and set up individual savings accounts (Isas) on a paperless basis.

Once the new tax year has started on April 6, access to the funds will be broadened to include anyone who opens an egg savings account.

Like any modern supermarket, there are a few special offers on the shelves to tempt the first few customers in and, according to Mike Harris, the bank's chief executive, "to attract some attention".

Until April 27, egg will discount the initial commission on some of the funds so that it does not exceed 1.5% - instead of a typical charge of between 3.5% and 5% if the investor buys direct or through an adviser.

All other funds will be available with no initial charge and all investors who open funds through Isas will receive 1% of their cash back.

On funds where there is no initial charge this deal will result in a 1% profit for the investor. After April 27, a spokeswoman for egg said, the bank hopes to keep initial commissions below 3%. There will be no cost for investors who wish to switch to another fund in the egg range.

The launch of the service had been planned for last summer but was held up by technical problems with egg's online credit card. Launch of the supermarket was delayed to allow time to resolve these difficulties and avoid a repeat performance.

Egg positions its service between discount brokers - who offer no advice and a far broader range of funds - and independent financial advisers who offer full advisory services across all funds in return for commission.

The investment supermarket provides an "investor profiler". This is a question-and-answer facility to establish the needs of the investor and highlight a handful of funds from a sector that seems to suit the individual.

Products available on the site were selected by the 12 fund managers working with egg on the project, on the basis that they will be the most popular among mainstream investors.

The fund managers themselves were selected on similarly populist criteria - retail brand presence and funds under management, for example - because to use past performance records would be tantamount to offering advice under personal investment authority regulations.

Torquil Clark, a Wolverhampton-based discount broker, also launched a fund supermarket yesterday, offering access to 600 Isa funds.

Fidelity and Charles Schwab, numbers one and two respectively in this sector of the US market, plan to launch similar services in Britain later this year.

What the Americans are sending us now

What is a fund supermarket?
Originally an American idea, it allows private investors to buy and sell a range of funds through one channel with a bit of help along the way.

Are they successful?
Fidelity is the largest player in the US, and thus the world, and has taken $177bn (£110bn) through its supermarket.

How does it work?
The customer sets up an online account and then buys and sells funds within that account. Each site is equipped with a facility to help the investor tailor the choice of funds to individual circumstances. On Fidelity's American site - it plans to launch a UK version in the summer - there are 4,100 funds to choose from including 900 "no load" ones (funds with no initial charge). The shelves of egg's supermarket will initially be relatively bare with only 169 unit trusts and open-ended investment companies out of more than 1,500 on the market. Because the supermarkets are not authorised to offer ad vice, recommendations are made only on a loose basis.

Are they cheap?
Cheaper than advisers because they discount commission but more expensive than discount brokers.

Will there be others to choose from?
US players Fidelity and Charles Schwab are UK-bound.

webTitle: Competition cuts mobile phone prices by 17%

fields.headline: Competition cuts mobile phone prices by 17%
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Fierce competition in the mobile phone market sent prices tumbling by 17% last year with even deeper cuts in the burgeoning pre-pay market, the regulator Oftel said yesterday.
fields.body:
Fierce competition in the mobile phone market sent prices tumbling by 17% last year with even deeper cuts in the burgeoning pre-pay market, the regulator Oftel said yesterday.

The watchdog used the figures to argue there was no need for intervention to force further reductions. Pre-pay, which has accounted for much of the market's growth in the past year and where the scramble for customers is most intense, saw prices fall by 23% on average.

"Prices of mobiles continue to fall," said Oftel director general David Edmonds.

"Our review shows that increasing competition means consumers are getting cheaper calls from their mobile phones which supports our view that competition really is the best way to deliver lower prices."

Oftel would continue to monitor prices, with a further review of the market due to be carried out later this year.

During 1999 the price of calling mobiles from a fixed line also fell by around 25% as a result of action by the regulator. It is now aiming to improve pricing transparency between the four networks.

The market has undergone explosive growth in the past 12 months: one in four Britons now owns a mobile phone. During the last three months of 1999, 4.4m mobile phones were sold, taking the UK total to 24m - more than one per household.

About 80% of sales during the quarter were pre-pay, allowing consumers to keep a tighter control on bills by paying in advance with credit vouchers. Pre-pay phones are retailing for as little as £69.99.

A spokesman for One2One said of the falling prices: "It's a competitive industry and that is borne out by the figures. It is good news for the consumer."

 The money on the table in the auction of the next generation of mobile phone licences reached £1.3bn yesterday.

Bidding for the licences, which will bring multimedia applications to the mobile phone market, reached around 21 of the multi-phase contest and so far none of the 13 companies to have entered has pulled out.

NTL Mobile bid the highest for licence A with £295.1m while Vodafone is leading the race for licence B with a £541.4m bid. Epsilon, the Nomura subsidiary has put the highest offer for C at £152.1m, Telefonica for D at £154m and US telecoms group WorldCom for E at £158.9m. The auction continues today.

webTitle: Banks told to stop shielding fraudsters

fields.headline: Banks told to stop shielding fraudsters
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
SFO chief attacks police and employers' attitudes
fields.trailText: British banks must abandon their long-held practice of hushing up fraud committed by staff and outsiders, the head of the serious fraud office will say today.
fields.body:
British banks must abandon their long-held practice of hushing up fraud committed by staff and outsiders, the head of the serious fraud office will say today.

"[Principally] fraud does not get reported because it is not felt to be in the interests of a bank to [say] it has been the dupe of a clever criminal or con-man," Rosalind Wright will tell the British Bankers Association.

The days of giving crooked staff, at worst, a neutral reference must end. "Fraudsters who stay unidentified and unprosecuted live to defraud another day - and another victim.

"How would you feel if a fellow bank discharged a fraudulent employee, getting him to pay back as much as he could of what he had stolen from them (and)... gave him a clean bill of health?"

Mrs Wright's message will aim to bring down the curtain not only on big banks hushing up conventional fraud against them -for fear of damaging confidence - but also the paying of "security consultancy fees" to computer hackers who penetrate their systems.

Mrs Wright will put her comments within a broader context, suggesting that fraud of all types against banks, including money laundering, represents a threat to the national economy.

She believes the SFO's caseload of £2bn represents only the tip of the iceberg; the true toll may be six times greater.

Mrs Wright will also take the opportunity to hit out at the attitude of the county and regional police forces in the fight against white collar crime. "You may not be aware that commercial and financial crime does not merit a mention in national police priorities... The number of police officers assigned to fraud squads throughout the country has seriously declined over recent years.

"This is in stark contrast with the exponential rise in the figures for fraud reported by leading firms of accountants and our own experience."

Mrs Wright will add, in repeating her earlier calls for a national fraud squad,: "Fraud squads are increasingly used as a reserve so that if there is a sudden demand for police for... a murder or a riot, the chief police officer can raid the fraud squad for the necessary manpower. In some cases, fraud squads have been disbanded altogether."

The net effect of big financial institutions' weakness and the winding down of local fraud squads is that fraud had become "a low risk, high profit activity... increasingly attractive to organised crime".

London's banking system is a "magnet" for money launderers and "fraud is not a victimless crime... Life-savings are lost... businesses fail... despair and suicides do result."

Mrs Wright will appeal to the banks to be more active.

"I can urge you to help the authorities to crack the fraud and catch the fraudsters... "[Principally] fraud does not get reported because it is not felt to be in the interests of a bank to [say] it has been the dupe of a clever criminal or con-man," Rosalind Wright will tell the British Bankers Association. The days of giving crooked staff, at worst, a neutral reference must end. "Fraudsters who stay unidentified and unprosecuted live to defraud another day - and another victim. "How would you feel if a fellow bank discharged a fraudulent employee, getting him to pay back as much as he could of what he had stolen from them (and)... gave him a clean bill of health?" Mrs Wright's message will aim to bring down the curtain not only on big banks hushing up conventional fraud against them -for fear of damaging confidence - but also the paying of "security consultancy fees" to computer hackers who penetrate their systems. Mrs Wright will put her comments within a broader context, suggesting that fraud of all types against banks, including money laundering, represents a threat to the national economy. She believes the SFO's caseload of £2bn represents only the tip of the iceberg; the true toll may be six times greater. Mrs Wright will also take the opportunity to hit out at the attitude of the county and regional police forces in the fight against white collar crime. "You may not be aware that commercial and financial crime does not merit a mention in national police priorities... "This is in stark contrast with the exponential rise in the figures for fraud reported by leading firms of accountants and our own experience." Mrs Wright will add, in repeating her earlier calls for a national fraud squad,: "Fraud squads are increasingly used as a reserve so that if there is a sudden demand for police for... a murder or a riot, the chief police officer can raid the fraud squad for the necessary manpower. fields.headline: Composer decides
fields.standfirst: Endymion Ensemble/ George Benjamin, Purcell Room, London ****
fields.trailText: Endymion Ensemble/ George Benjamin, Purcell Room, London ****
fields.body:
It is always fascinating to dis cover what composers chose when they are given carte blanche to concoct a concert programme. George Benjamin has done more of that than many of his contemporaries, but who would have thought that for the last in the current Endymion Ensemble series of composers' choices, he would come up with Copland and Scarlatti, as well as Scriabin, alongside the more predictable Elliott Carter, Ravel and two of his own pieces?

Benjamin admitted he was putting in a plug for Copland in his centenary year, but still showered praise on the "perfect" construction of the Sextet, a boiling down of his Short Symphony, which appeared in 1936, and perhaps the clarity of line and the lucid formalism are ideals that chime with some of Benjamin's own preoccupations as a composer.

Certainly the unstable harmonies of two late Scriabin piano Preludes would appeal to someone with his acute harmonic sense, while the intricate expressiveness of Carter's song cycle, A Mirror on Which to Dwell, and the lyric simplicity of Ravel's Chansons Madécasses, both sung remarkably well by Eileen Hulse, have the jewel-like concentration that much of his own music prizes.

Benjamin's At First Light, which ended the concert, remains one of his most remarkable achievements, completed in 1982 when he was just 22, and as convincing a demonstration of those qualities - the compelling ear for instrumental colour, the totally personal harmonic world, the sureness of touch in dealing with form - as he has ever written. But his Viola, Viola is a tour de force of another kind, which takes the most unpromising combination of instruments - two violas - and creates a totally gripping world. The lines cross with bewildering complexity, creating an extraordinary trompe l'oreille ; it's as if a whole orchestra of strings is there, each with its own sharply defined musical line. It's cruelly difficult to play, too - the Endymion's two violists, Catherine Manson and Ralph Ehlers, worked miracles.

fields.headline: Weighing up the costs
fields.trailText: I am 19 and working for a dot.com start up. This is a job many graduates would kill for - so should I go to university?
fields.body:
The problem

I am 19 and working for a dot.com start up. Theoretically I am on a year out before university having just failed to achieve my necessary grades.

This is a job many graduates would kill for. I am about to get share options and a pay rise to £17,000 from my current £14,500. Going to university is beginning to seem like an expensive luxury: in such a fast moving market I would be back where I started and I have calculated that going to college would cost me approximately £80,000 in debts and lost earnings.

The solution

My view may be somewhat controversial, but I am inclined to agree that University for you may not be necessary - or even a good idea. The idea of higher education for all has, in my view, resulted in a devaluing of the degree so that it is almost becoming unworthy of the paper it is written on. Yes, many employers want graduates, but they want so much more than that. They want communication skills, work experience, business acumen, evidence of responsibility...all the things that most graduates lack, but which you have in abundance.

Many, many people make it without going to University. And indeed, many who do get that degree, don't make it. They emerge three years later, considerably poorer, but with few of the key transferable skills that today's employer is looking for. Yes, they may have a great social life, get drunk a lot, join societies, meet people...but who says you can't do all these without an NUS Card?

I think that you have pretty much made up your mind about University and are looking for reassurance that you are not throwing a great opportunity away. But, University will still be there, so why not take another year _out_ and see how you feel next year? There's nothing to stop you going back to University in three or five years time if you feel the need or inclination. Indeed, in my experience, mature students work harder, are more dedicated and thus get better grades anyway. They also have much more to offer the employer than their younger and less workwise contemporaries.

As for your mates - don't worry. You'll have the last laugh when the money rolls in whilst they are scrounging a few quid off you for a pint.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House, £9.99) and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't (Element, £9.99)

webTitle: Hackers reveal how to forge a bank card

fields.headline: Hackers reveal how to forge a bank card
fields.trailText: A controlled panic spread through the French banking system yesterday after computer hackers sent emails to banks detailing a formula for creating and using plastic cards which can fool electronic safeguards.
fields.body:
A controlled panic spread through the French banking system yesterday after computer hackers sent emails to banks detailing a formula for creating and using plastic cards which can fool electronic safeguards.

The Bank of France ordered the rapid introduction of new security measures after bank card operators admitted that their system, which uses microchip integrated plastic, was "vulnerable".

A month ago the Groupement des Cartes Bancaires, which administers Mastercard, Visa and other widely used charge cards, said it was not possible to crack the existing system of electronic protection. However, it has since emerged that that system has not been reviewed since 1985.

The reassurances were given before the trial of Serge Humpich, a programmer who received a 10-month suspended jail term when he was found guilty of using a homemade card which he claimed could deceive all electronic safeguards.

Humpich was charged with fraud after demanding £20m to disclose the secret formula and offering help in setting up a fail-safe system.

Humpich said his invention was smart enough to unravel a 96-number code and to persuade electronic bank guards to allow him access to the vaults. He proved his case by buying Métro tickets from a distributor, but was arrested while negotiating with bank officials.

Humpich's sentence appears to have angered hackers, including two who go by the names of Anie Nomat and Mail. They sent the formula for homemade bank cards from cyber cafes at the Odéon and the Boulevard Saint-Michel, in the student quarter in central Paris.

Bank detectives have drawn a blank in establishing their true identities.

After a complaint to the police, the formula vanished from the internet but not before banks and many private subscribers had been emailed information on how to make cards using equipment worth about £250 that can be bought on the internet.

The information included deciphered codes to validate forgeries when microchip-carrying cards were fed into cash dispensers or mobile phone-style terminals used by most shops and banks.

These are linked to central accounting, which carries out immediate debits as soon as the terminal reads the card number and the user enters his or her PIN number, without a signature being required.

Cryptographers who helped to dismantle the bank code said it had been a simple task because France was not yet protected by the same international security safeguards that protect Eurocard, Visa and Mastercard.

"It's possible to make cards carrying any PIN number you like," Humpich said. "They can be totally invented or real. Any hacker can pick up the first numbers from discarded cash dispenser receipts and then debit existing accounts."

During Humpich's trial, banks claimed his method posed no threat. But they have since admitted that his cards could be used to buy petrol or rail tickets, and to withdraw money from supermarket cash dispensers and rural banks. These terminals are not directly connected to central accounting.

Hervé de Lacotte, a spokesman for the Groupement des Cartes Bancaires, admitted that some of the banks' equipment was "vul nerable", but said there was no risk of loss to customers, only to the banks. But a security overhaul was not expected to be completed before 2004.

Jacques Stern, a cryptography professor, said specialists had warned banks of potential loopholes in security when France introduced microchip integrated plastic in 1985.

"But nothing was done about it," Prof Stern added. "Microchip cards are a remarkable invention but security updating has been forgotten for 15 years."

fields.headline: Cunningly contrived
fields.standfirst: Jeremy James & Company, The Place Theatre, London ***
fields.trailText: Jeremy James & Company, The Place Theatre, London ***
fields.body:
Dancers like Jeremy James, who turn choreographer mid-career, sometimes never get further than duplicating their personal style on a large scale, the steps they make for others creating clones of themselves. James, though, is a dance maker with a passion for structure. His point of view is not his own body but the stage picture as a whole. So the pleasure of his latest programme, Floppy Affordable, is more than watching its five strikingly individual performers; it is scrutinising the internal mechanisms that activate the choreography, the cogs and wheels of motion which lock the dancers together in such cunningly contrived ways.

The first two works, The Day I Stopped and Parts, are set to music by Matteo Fargion whose style perfectly mirrors James's own: short energetic modules of invention which either terminate abruptly, or link in increasingly complex forms. James's choreography is a mix of nervy gesture and bold linear action, so that a phrase may originate with a sharp toss of the head; gather momentum as an arm or leg swings into space and then complicate into a sculptural torque of the body.

James also builds an impressive scale through cross currents of movement, giving a phrase to one dancer, then to two, and finally splintering it apart as different bodies elaborate variations on its theme. At moments of climax the stage hums like an elegant pinball machine with sparks and currents of energy zigzagging between the five bodies.

This is most beautifully achieved in Parts, which shares the stage with an extraordinary piece of film and video art by Steve Jackman and Hugo Glendenning. Projected onto the back of the stage are close-up images of paint - stripes, whorls and clumps of colour which flicker like an aura around the moving dancers. Towards the end these images become digitalised and hugely magnified so that we seem to see atoms of pure pigment pulsating and dissolving on the screen: the intricate world of the choreography mirrored in what looks like the secret life of paint.

The final work, Cheese, is set to a much hazier piece of music, trancelike and techno, and the dance itself has a looser, more whimsical feel. There are moments of eccentric humour and sensuous release, but the theatrical effect is far less exhilarating - verging more towards club than stage.

 Jeremy James & Company are at Castle Arts, Wellingborough (01933-270007) tonight and touring through March; also Linbury Studio, Royal Opera House, April 8 and 9.

fields.headline: UK output passes France
fields.trailText: Britain has overtaken France as the world's fourth biggest economy as the strength of sterling and the weakness of the euro have combined to boost the value of the UK's annual output, the European Union said last night.
fields.body:
Britain has overtaken France as the world's fourth biggest economy as the strength of sterling and the weakness of the euro have combined to boost the value of the UK's annual output, the European Union said last night.

The government was studiously avoiding breaking out the champagne after Brussels said that only the US, Japan and Germany now have higher GDP than the UK.

Figures from Eurostat, the EU statistical arm, showed that Britain's lead over France was by the narrowest of margins with UK output last year to talling €1.348 trillion (£822.3bn) to France's €1.347 trillion (£821.7bn). It is the first time since Eurostat started publishing the figures 10 years ago that Britain has taken the number four slot.

Economists attributed the move up the rankings to the strong pound and weak euro last year and Britain's relatively strong recent economic performance compared to the bulk of the eurozone.

"It's a nice feel good statistic but it tells you more about the strength of the pound than the strength of the UK economy," said Alison Cottrell, European economist at PaineWebber.

Other analysts warned that the strength of sterling was double-edged sword, pointing out yesterday's figures for inflation in manufacturing showed that the surge in the pound was intensifying the squeeze on Britain's factories.

Fuel and raw material costs for industry are rising at the fastest rate for 20 years as a 170% increase in oil prices over the past twelve months feeds through into the economy, according to government figures.

Despite seeing the costs of basic materials rise by 14.5% since February 1999, firms have been unable to pass on the increases to their customers. Data from the office for national statistics indicated that the price of goods leaving factory gates was up by just 2.3 % over the past year. Oil prices stood at around $10 a barrel at the start of last year, but have since recovered as the Opec cartel has limited production. Last night in the New York futures market, crude for April delivery was being quoted at just over $32 a barrel.

The Clinton administration is putting heavy pressure on Saudi Arabia - the world's biggest producer and a key US ally in the middle east - to ensure production curbs are lifted when Opec meets in Vienna on March 27. Some analysts believe the threat that Mexico, a non-Opec producer, will fill any shortfall caused by Opec, will concentrate minds at the meeting.

In the City, analysts said that the scale of the increase in fuel and raw materials would sharpen the debate at the Bank of England over whether interest rates needed to rise further.

"This presents a dilemma for the monetary policy committee", said David Coleman, chief economist at CIBC World Markets. "On the one hand it will be concerned the rise in energy costs will ultimately spill over into other markets and products. Against this, manufacturers do not yet appear to be passing on these higher costs and, in any case, there are hopes that oil prices will fall later this year."

Oil prices rose by 11.3% on the month, while the 172% annual increase was unprecedented since records began in 1974.
